tso: hi dinga ku tirhisana ku teka magoza yo sirhelela rihanyo ku nga ri ntsena ra vatirhi va ka hina va vuthu ra le mahlweni kambe vuthu hinkwaro ra vatirhi.

eng: there has already been sterling work done by unions in educating members around infection control and prevention and hygiene.
tso: se ku vile na ntirho wa kahle swinene lowu endliweke hi tiyuniyoni eka ku dyondzisa swirho hi mayelana na vulawuri na nsivelo na nsive lamavabyi.

eng: they are also supporting the work of the department of employment and labour in conducting workplace inspections to ensure health and safety protocols are in place for returning workers.
tso: ti tlhela ti seketela ntirho wa ndzawulo ya mitirho na vatirhi eka ku endla vukamberi bya le ndhawini ya ntirho ku tiyisisa leswaku ku na milawu ya rihanyo na vuhlayiseki leyi simekiweke ya vatirhi lava vuyelaka entirhweni.

eng: many of our trade unions are also providing coronavirus information to their members and employers are running awareness campaigns.
tso: to tala ta tiyuniyoni ta vatirhi titlhela ti nyika swirho swa tona vuxokoxoko bya khoronavhayirasi naswona vathori va le ku endleni ka mapfhumba ya vulemukisi.

eng: one of the challenges that has emerged in our country is the stigmatisation of people who have proven positive with coronavirus.
tso: wun'wana wa mitlhontlho leyi yi tumbulukeke etikweni ra ka hina i ku hlekuriwa ka vanhu lava va kombeke vumbhoni bya ku va na khoronavhayirasi.

eng: as a society, we have a collective responsibility to stamp out the stig matisation of people infected with the coronavirus.
tso: tanihi rixaka, hi na vutihlamuleri bya nhlanganelo ku simula ku hlekuriwa ka vanhu lava khomiweke hi khoronavhayirasi.

eng: there have been disturbing reports of individuals being ostracised from their communities and of communities protesting against coronavirus patients being admitted to local hospitals and clinics.
tso: ku vile na swiviko swo vavisa swa vanhu lava va nga eku tsan'wiweni emigangeni ya ka vona na swa ku va miganga yi kombisa ku vilela ehenhla ka vavabyi va khoronavhayirasi lava va amukeriwakaeswibedhlele na le titliliniki ta le migangeni.

eng: this must stop.
tso: leswi swi boheka ku yima.

eng: just as we came together to promote acceptance of people living with hiv and stood firm against victimisation, we must show understanding, tolerance, kindness, empathy and compassion for those who are infected with this virus and for their families.
tso: tanihiloko hi hlanganile ku kondletela ku amukeriwa ka vanhu lava hanyaka na hiv na ku yima hi tiya ehenhla ka ku xanisiwa, hi boheka ku komba ntwisiso, nkondzelelo, tintswalo, ku twela na ntwelavusiwana eka lavaya va tluleri weke hi xitsongwatsongwana na mindyangu ya vona.

eng: it is said that this stigmatisation is driven by fear of con tracting the disease and lack of understanding.
tso: ku vuriwa leswaku ku hlekuri wa loku ku lawuriwa hi nchavo wa ku khomiwa vuvabyi nampfumaleko wa ntwisiso.

eng: the best way to overcome our instinctive fear of illness and contagion is to observe the hygiene protocols that are in place.
tso: ndlela ya kahle swinene ku hlula nchavo wa rintumbuluko wa vuvabyi na ntlulelo wa vuvabyi i ku landzelela milawu ya nsivelamavabyi leyi yi simekiweke.

eng: the fear of infection is wellfounded and real.
tso: nchavo wa ntluletavuvabyi wu kona hakunene naswona i ntiyiso.

eng: at the same time, we know what we have to do to protect ourselves and others.
tso: hi nkarhi wun'we, ha swi tiva leswi hi bohekaka ku swi endla ku tisirhelela hina na van'wana.

eng: we know what causes the virus and what we can do to protect ourselves from becoming infected.
tso: ha swi tiva leswi swi vangaka xitsongwatsongwana na leswi hi nga swi endlaka ku tisirhelela eka ku tluleriwa hi vuvabyi.

eng: we know we have to maintain social distancing, to selfisolate if we have come into contact with those infected and to present to a hospital if we have symptoms.
tso: ha swi tiva leswaku hi boheka ku siya mpfhukanyana exikarhi ka vanhu, ku tiveka wexe loko hi khumbanile na lava va tluleriweke hi vuvabyi na ku ya exibedhlele loko hi ri na swikombeto.

eng: we must continue to be guided by facts and not rumours.
tso: hi boheka ku ya emahlweni hi leteriwa hi mitiyiso naswona ku nga ri maveriveri.

eng: the time when anyone could say they do not know anyone who is infected or affected by coronavirus has long passed.
tso: nkarhi lowu munhu wihi kumbe wihi a nga vulaka leswaku a nga tivi munhu wihi kumbe wihi loyi a tluleriweke kumbe a khumbekeke hi khoronavhayirasi wu hundzile khale sweswi, kutlula leswi swi nga tshama swi va xiswona, vanghana va hina, mindyangu, vatirhikulobye na vaakelana va dinga ku tweriwa na nseketelo.

eng: now, more than ever, our friends, families, colleagues and neighbours need our empathy and support.
tso: emasikwini, emavhikini na le tin'hwetini leta ha taka, mikarhi yin'wana hi ta tikuma hi ri na mimoya ya le hansi na ku va hi chava tanihiloko hi ri karhi hi vona tinhlayo ta vanhu lava khomiweke hi vuvabyi na ku lova ti ri karhi ti ya emahlweni ti tlakuka.

eng: it may be that things have gotten worse, but we are certain that they will get better.
tso: ku nga ha va ku ri leswaku swilo swi nyanyile, kambe ha tiyisisa leswaku hi ta antswa.

eng: our scientists and medical advisers told us that the rate of infections will go up as we move towards our peak.
tso: van'watisayense va ka hina na vatsundzuxi va swa vutshunguri va hi byele leswaku mpimo wa mitluletavuvabyi wu ta tlakuka tanihiloko hi ri karhi hi ya emaninginingini.

eng: but it will certainly come down.
tso: kambe hakunene wu ta ya ehansi.

eng: we pay tribute to the healthcare workers who lost their lives caring for the sick.
tso: hi xixima vatirhi va swa rihanyo lava va lahlekeriweke hi vutomi bya vona va ri karhi va ongola vavabyi.

eng: in their memory, let us keep ourselves and our fellow citizens safe by playing our part.
tso: hi ku va tsundzuka, a hi tihlayiseni hina na vaakatikokulobye va hina hi ku tlanga xiphemu xa hina.

eng: young farmer receives covid19 support vukuzenzele unnamed nomagcinandile suduka (27) is growing her family’s legacy and wealth by investing in agriculture.
tso: n’wamapurasi lontsongo a kuma nseketelo wa covid19 silusapho nyanda n’wamapurasi loyi a ha taka wa le kapavuhumadyambu hi un’wana wa vavuyeriwa va nkwama wa mphalalo wa khoronavhayirasi wa mfumo.

eng: the o wner of 4 u and 4 me primary cooperative in mooiplaas village received support from the department of agriculture, land reform and rural development’s coronavirus (covid19) relief fund for her egg, livestock and vegetable farm.
tso: nomagcinandile suduka (27) u kurisa ndzhaka ya ndyangu wa ka vona na rifumo hi ku vekisa eka vurimi.

eng: the department has awarded r1.2 billion worth of vouchers to farmers in need.
tso: n’wini wa 4 u na 4 me primary cooperative emu gangeni wa mooiplaas u kumile nseketelo kusuka eka nkwama wa mphalalo wa khoronavhayirasi (covid19) wa ndzawulo ya vurimi, antswiso wa misava na nhluvukiso wa matikoxikaya wa purasi ra yena ra matandza, swifuwo na matsavu.

eng: suduka says her vouchers will help her grow the egg producing side of her business.
tso: suduka u vula leswaku tivhawuchara ta yena ti ta n’wi pfuna ku kurisa tlhelo ra ku endliwa ka matandza ra bindzu ra yena.

eng: "i received three vouchers totalling r19 000. a voucher for r12 000 to buy layer egg chickens, a voucher for r6 500 to buy feed and a r500 voucher to buy medicines.
tso: "ndzi kumile tivhawuchara tinh arhu leti endlaka r19 000. vhawuchara ya r12 000 yo xava 100 ra tihuku to tshikela matandza, vhawuchara ya r6 500 yo xava swakudya swa tihuku na vhawuchara ya r500 yo xava mirhi."

eng: "she started her egg production farm by feeding her family’s traditional chickens with layer grower feed, which enables them to produce eggs without mating.
tso: u sungurile purasi ra yena ra ku endla matandza hi ku phamela tihuku ta ka vona ta xintima hi swakudya swa tihuku to tshikela matandza, leswi swi endlaka leswaku tihuku ti tshikela matandza ti nga hlanganangi na tihuku ta xinuna.

eng: her chickens now produce 50 eggs a day, which she sells weekly.
tso: sweswi tihuku ta yena ta 50 ti humesa 50 wa matandza siku na siku, lama a ma xavisaka vhiki na vhiki.

eng: suduka, who also farms with 73 goats, 25 sheep and 25 cows, started farming in 2015 after obtaining a public management n6 certificate from ikhala training and vocational education and training college.
tso: suduka, loyi a tlhelaka a fuwa timbuti ta 73, 25 wa tinyimpfu na 25 wa tihomu, u sungurile vurimi hi 2015 endzhaku ka loko a kumile xitifikheti xa yena xa n6 xa public management kusuka eka ikhala training and vocational education and training college.

eng: after realising that there were not a lot of job opportunities out there, she decided to take over the family’s then subsistence farm and turn it into a profitable business.
tso: endzhaku ka ku lemuka leswaku a ku nga ri na swivandlanene swa mitirho swo tala le handle, u kunguhatile ku teka purasi ra ka vona ro tihanyisa a ri cinca ri va bindzu ro vuyerisa.

eng: suduka says: "we grew up practising farming, so after graduating i decided to farm rather than look for a job."
tso: suduka u vula leswaku: "hi kurile hi karhi hi titoloveta swa mapurasi, hikwalaho endzhaku ka loko ndzi thwasile ndzi kunguhatile ku endla vurimi handle ko lava ntirho."

eng: this proved to be an inspired decision, as she has grown the number of goats and cows.
tso: leswi swi tikombile kuri xiboho xa nhlohlotelo, tanihiloko a kurisile nhlayo ya timbuti na tihomu.

eng: suduka’s sixhectare vegetable farm produces maize, potatoes, peas and beans.
tso: purasi ra suduka ra tihekitara ta tsevu ra matsavu ri humesa mavele, mazambhala, swibalakatsa na tinyawa.

eng: the maize is planted on four hectares, the potatoes on one hectare and the peas and beans share the last hectare.
tso: mavele ma byariwa eka tihekitara ta mune, mazambhala eka hekitara yin’we, naswona swibalakatsa na tinyawa swi byariwa eka hekitara yin’we leyo hetelela.

eng: building a better life vukuzenzele unnamed from humble begin nings in kwanon goma village, kwa zulunatal, 23yearold silondiwe magwaza has conquered many obstacles to reach her dream of becoming a construction manager.
tso: ku aka vutomi byo antswa vukuzenzele unnamed kusuka eka masungulo ya xiyimo xa le hansi emugangeni wa kwanongoma, ekwazulunatal, silondiwe magwaza wa 23 wa malembe hi vukhale u hlurile swikanganyisi swo tala ku fikelela norho wa yena wo va mininjhere wa swa vumaki.

eng: growing up surrounded by poor infrastructure motivated magwaza to explore new ways to uplift her community.
tso: ku kula a rhendzeriwile hi miako ya xiyimo xa le hansi swi hlohlotele magwaza ku ringeta tindlela tintshwa ku tlakusa muganga wa ka vona.

eng: she is now the first member of her family to obtain a degree.
tso: sweswi hi yena munhu wo sungula endyangwini wa ka vona ku kuma digiri.

eng: magwaza qualified at the university of the witwatersrand in 2019, obtaining an undergraduate degree in construction studies.
tso: magwaza u thwase eyuni vhesiti ya witwatersrand hi 2019, a kuma digiri ya masungulo ya tidyondzo ta vumaki.

eng: "kwanongoma has very poor infrastructure.
tso: "kwanongoma yi na swi makiwakulu swa xiyimo xa le hansi naswona ku hluvuka swi tikomba swi nonoka swinene.

eng: looking at all the challenges faced by my hometown, i was encouraged to do something relating to construction so that i can be one of the people to change the current state," she says.
tso: hi ku languta mitlhontlho leyi langutaneke dorobatsongo ra ka hina, ni hlohlotelekile ku endla swin’wanama yelana na vumaki leswaku ndzi ta va un’wana wa vanhu lava nga ta cinca xiyimo xa sweswi," a vula.

eng: obtaining her qualification was no easy feat.
tso: ku kuma nthwaso wa yena a swi nga olovi.

eng: magwaza says she found it difficult to concentrate due to her constant worry about funding.
tso: magwaza u vula leswaku swi n’wi tikerile ku yingisa hikwalaho ka ku vilela hi tihakelo.

eng: then, the municipal infrastructure support agent (misa) stepped in to assist.
tso: kutani, municipal infrastructure support agent (misa) yi nghenelerile ku pfuna.

eng: "i used to stress a lot about funding as i come from a disadvantaged background.
tso: "a ndzi hamba ndzi vilela swinene hi tihakelo hikuva ndzi karhi ndzi huma evuswetini.

eng: that was until 2018, when i received a bursary from misa.
tso: sweswo swi ve kufika hi 2018, loko ndzi kuma basari kusuka eka misa.

eng: this helped me to complete my degree without any more stress.
tso: leswi swi ndzi pfunile ku va ndzi hetisa digiri ya mina ndzi ri hava mabibi.

eng: i had everything paid for, all i had to do was focus on my studies," she says.
tso: a ndzi hakeleriwile swilo hinkwaswo, leswi a ndzi fanele ku swi endla a kuri ku tinyiketela eka tidyondzo ta mina," a vula.

eng: magwaza is one of hundreds of students who pass through misa’s youth development programmes each year.
tso: magwaza hi un’wana wa madzana ya swichudeni leswi swi pasaka hikwalaho ka minongoloko yo hluvukisa vantshwa ya misa lembe na lembe.

eng: the programmes provide funding and support and help students find job placements once qualified.
tso: minongoloko leyi yi nyika tihakelo na nseketelo naswona yi pfuna swichudeni ku kuma mitirho loko se swi thwasile.

eng: "i was really looking forward to our graduation ceremony.
tso: "a ndzi languterile ntlangu wo tlangela ku ambala gaweni.

eng: it would have meant a lot considering that i was going to be the first graduate in my family.
tso: a swi ta vula swo tala tanihiloko a ndzi tava wo sungula ku ambala gaweni endyangwini waka hina.

eng: i am still hoping that we have our graduation ceremony, but this might not be possible given the coronavirus pandemic," she says.
tso: ndza tshemba leswaku hi ta va na nkhuvu wo tlangela ku amba la gaweni wa hina, kambe le swi swi nga ka swi nga koteki hikwalaho ka ntungukulu wa khoronavhayirasi," a vula.

eng: the construction industry mainly consists of men.
tso: indasitiri ya vumaki yi tele ngopfungopfu vavanuna.

eng: "at times, women are made to feel small because their ability to bring about change is doubted.
tso: "mikarhi yin’wana, vava sati va endliwa leswaku va titwa va ri lavatsongo hikuva vuswikoti bya vona byo tisa ku cinca bya soriwa.

eng: sometimes their voices are not heard.
tso: nkarhi wun’wana a va yingiseriwi.

eng: "i still chose construction management because i believe that i have the power to change the industry and improve it where there is a need.
tso: "ndzi ale ndzi hlawula vu fambisi bya swa vumaki hiku va ndza tshemba leswaku ndzi na matimba yo cinca indasitiri leyi na ku yi antswisa laha swi faneleke.

eng: i have seen women in this industry making it to top positions and having influence.
tso: ndzi vonile vavasati va ya eka swiyimo swa le henhla eka indasitiri leyi na ku va na nhlohlotelo.

eng: i believe that i too can make it," she says.
tso: ndza tshemba leswaku na mina ndzi ta fikelela," a vula.

eng: misa bursaries are advertised on www.
tso: tanihi munhu wo sungula ku kuma digiri endyangwini wa ka vona, silondiwe magwaza u khensa misa.

eng: south africa acts to address ventilator shortage silusapho nyanda a locally developed ventilator will help patients with mild covid19 symptoms to breathe easier.
tso: aforika borwa e tsaya dikgato go samagana le tlhaelo ya metšhini ya go thusa go hema silusapho nyanda motšhini wa go thusa go hema o o dirilweng ka fa nageng o tla thusa balwetse ba ba nang le matshwao a a seng bogale a covid19 go hema botoka.

eng: the fight against the coronavirus disease (covid19) in south africa has been boosted with the production of the first ventilator made in the country.
tso: ntwa kgatlhanong le bolwetse jwa mogare wa corona (covid19) ka fa nageng ya aforika borwa e tshegeditswe ka tlhagiso ya metšhini ya go thusa go hema e e dirilweng ka fa nageng.

eng: the continuous positive airway pressure (cpap) ventilator helps patients with mild symptoms of covid19 to breathe easier by providing a mild level of oxygenated air pressure to keep their airways open.
tso: motšhini wa go thusa go hema o o bidiwang continuous positive airway pressure (cpap) o thusa balwetse ba ba nang le matshwao a a seng bogale a covid19 go hema botoka ka go ba bodulolela mowa o o itekanetseng mo dikarolong tsa bona tsa go hema gore di se tswalege.

eng: the ventilator was designed by the council for scientific and industrial research (csir) in collaboration with a number of local partners and will be rolled out nationwide to patients showing respiratory distress in the early phase of covid19 infection.
tso: metšhini ya go thusa go hema eno e dirilwe ke lekgotla la dipatlisiso tsa saense le intaseteri (csir) mmogo le badirisani mmogo ba yona ba le bantsinyana ba ka fa nageng mme e tla phasaladiwa naga ka bophara go thusa balwetse ba ba nang le matshwao a go sokodisiwa ke go hema fa ba le mo tshimologong ya go tshwaediwa ke covid19.

eng: "the air a person normally breaths has a 23 percent concentration of oxygen.
tso: "mowa o gantsi batho ba o hemang o na le diphesente di le 23 tsa oksijene.

eng: the cpap ventilator can pump a higher amount of oxygen, helping a person breathe.
tso: metšhini ya go thusa go hema ya cpap e kgona go pompa palo e e kwa godimo ya oksijene, mme seno se kgona go thusa motho go hema.

eng: the cpap pumps continuous concentrated oxygen.
tso: cpapa e pompa oksijene e e sa feleng e e humileng.

eng: you can increase or decrease the amount of oxygen one is breathing in," says executive manager of csir future production: manufacturing martin sanne.
tso: o ka kgona go oketsa kgotsa go fokotsa oksijene e motho a e hemang," ga rialo molaodikhuduthamaga wa csir mo ditlhagisweng tsa mo isagong: tlhagisodikuno e bong martin sanne.

eng: patients using the ventilator are connected via a face mask.
tso: balwetse ba ba dirisang metšhini ya go thusa go hema ba e dirisa ka go apara maseke wa go thusa go hema.

eng: oxygen is drawn from an oxygen gas tank and is mixed with natural air in the ventilator, from where it is transmitted to the mask and breathed in by the patient.
tso: oksijene e tswa mo tankeng ya oksijene mme e tswakwa le mowa o o tlwaelegileng o o leng mo motšhining wa go thusa go hema mme go tsweng foo e fetela mo masekeng moo e tla hemiwang ke molwetse.

eng: sanne says that in addition to pumping oxygenated air, the cpap also helps patients exhale.
tso: sanne a re mo godimo ga go thusa go pompa mowa o o fetlhilweng ka oksijene, cpap e thusa gape balwetse gore ba kgone go hemela kwa ntle mowa o o tswang ka fa teng ga matshwafo a bona.

eng: the cpap device can be used in both hightech clinical environments and temporary settings, such as field hospitals and quarantine facilities.
tso: didirisiwa tseno tsa cpap di ka dirisiwa mo mafelong a bookelo a a dirisang thekenoloji ya maemo a a kwa godimo le mo maokelong a nakwana, a a jaaka dipetlele tse di leng kgakala le baagi mmogo le mafelo a go katosa bao ba nang le mogare.

eng: sanne says the csir will have produced 10 000 ventilators by the end of august.
tso: sanne a re csir e tla re kwa bokhutlong jwa kgwedi ya phatwe monongwaga ya bo e tlhagisitse metšhini ya go thusa go hema e le 10 000. ka tirisanommogo le siemens, simera, akacia, gabler, umoya le yunibesiti ya motse kapa, csir e kgonne go tlhagisa dicpap ka go ikamanya le metheo ya mokgatlho wa lefatshe wa merero ya boitekanelo (who).

eng: working with siemens, simera, akacia, gabler, umoya and the university of cape town, the csir produced the cpap according to world health organisation standards.
tso: metšhini ya go thusa go hema ya ntlha e tla neelwa dipetlele tsa puso tse di tobaneng le matsapa a go tlhoka didirisiwa tsa go samagana le covid19.

eng: the first batch of ventilators will be given to state hospitals experiencing pressure due to the unavailability of equipment to deal with covid19.
tso: csir e simolotse ka tiro ya go dira dicpap morago ga gore go nne le tlhaelo ya metšhini ya go thusa go hema mo lefatsheng ka bophara.

eng: help stop the spread of covid19 vukuzenzele unnamed our nation is con fronted by the gravest crisis in the history of our democracy.
tso: thusa go emisa go anama ga covid19 vukuzenzele unnamed setšhaba sa rona se tobane le matlhotlhapelo a se kana ka sepe fa e sale re nna le temokerasi ya rona.

eng: for more than 120 days, we have succeeded in delaying the spread of a virus that is causing devastation across the globe.
tso: sebaka sa matsatsi a feta a le 120, re atlegile mo go diegiseng go anama ga mogare ono o o dubang matlhotlhapelo lefatshe ka bophara.

eng: but now, the surge in infections that we had been advised by our medical experts would come, has arrived.
tso: fela ga jaanong, tlhatlogo ya ditshwaetso e re sa bolong go lemosiwa ka yona ke baitseanape ba rona ba tsa boitekanelo gore e mo tseleng, e re aparetse.

eng: more than a quarter of a million south africans have been infected with coronavirus, and we know that many more infections have gone undetected.
tso: palo ya maaforika borwa a feta kotara ya milione jaanong e tshwaeditswe ke mogare wa corona, e bile re a itse gore batho ba bangwe gape ba le bantsi go santse go sa itsiwe fa ba tshwaetsegile kgotsa jang.

eng: we are now recording over 12,000 new cases every day.
tso: jaanong re iphitlhela re bega dikgetse tse dintšhwa di feta di le 12 000 letsatsi le lengwe le le lengwe.

eng: since the start of the outbreak in march, at least 4,079 people have died from covid19.
tso: fa e sale mogare ono o supotsa tlhogo ka kgwedi ya mopitlwe monongwaga, batho ba feta ba le 4 079 ba setse ba tlhokafetse ka ntlha ya covid19.

eng: like the massive cold fronts that sweep into our country from the south atlantic at this time of year, there are few parts of the country that will remain untouched by the coronavirus.
tso: fela jaaka ditsuatsue tse di maatla tse di tsubutlang naga ya rona go tswa kwa karolong ya borwa jwa lewatle la atlelanta mo pakeng eno ya ngwaga, le ka mogare ono wa corona go tla nna le dikarolo tsa naga eno tse di ka se tsubutlweng ke mogare wa corona.

eng: the coronavirus storm is far fiercer and more destructive than any we have known before.
tso: setsuatsue sa mogare wa corona se bogale thata e bile se senya tota go gaisa ditsuatsue tse dingwe tse re kileng ra sutlha mo go tsona.

eng: it is stretching our resources and our resolve to their limits.
tso: se tlhotlhora metswedi le maitlhomo a rona tota.

eng: the surge of infections that our experts and scientists predicted over 3 months ago has now arrived.
tso: tlhatlogo ya ditshwaetso e re sa bolong go lemosiwa ka yona dikgwedi di le tharo tse di fetileng ke baitseanape ba rona ba tsa boitekanelo le ba tsa saense gore e mo tseleng, e re aparetse.

eng: it started in the western cape and is now underway in the eastern cape and gauteng.
tso: e simolotse kwa kapa bophirima mme jaanong e tsweletse go tsubotla kapa botlhaba le gauteng.

eng: yet, while infections rise exponentially, it is important to note that our case fatality rate of 1.5 percent is among the lowest in the world.
tso: le fa tota ditshwaetso di tsweletse go tlhatloga ka bontsi, go botlhokwa thata go nopola gore palo ya tlhatlogo ya dikgetse tsa dintsho ya phesente e le nngwe le halofo ke e nngwe ya dipalo tse di kwa tlase thata mo lefatsheng ka bophara.

eng: this is compared to a global average case fatality rate of 4.4 percent.
tso: eno ke fa re e bapisa le palo ya tlhatlogo ya dikgetse tsa dintsho e e tletseng mo lefatsheng ya diphesente di le 4.4. re tshwanetse go leboga batlhankedi ba rona ba boitekanelo ka maitemogelo le boineelo jwa bona mmogo le dikgato tse re di tsereng go ithulaganya sentle mo tsamaisong ya boitekanelo go bo re na le palo eno e e kwa tlase ya dintsho mo nageng ya rona.

eng: we owe the relatively low number of deaths in our country to the experience and dedication of our health professionals and the urgent measures we have taken to build the capacity of our health system.
tso: le fa tota go na le batho ba le bantsi ka fa nageng ba ba tsereng dikgato go thibela go anama ga mogare ono, go santse go na le ba bangwe ba le bantsi ba ba sa direng jalo.

eng: even as most of our people have taken action to prevent the spread of the virus, there are others who have not.
tso: go na le ba bangwe mo go rona ba ba itlhokomolosang melaokiletso eno e e neseditsweng pula gore e ka dirisiwa go lwantshana le bolwetse jono.

eng: in the midst of such a pandemic, getting into a taxi without a face mask, gathering to meet friends, attending parties or even visiting family, can too easily spread the virus and cost lives.
tso: mo nakong eo re aparetsweng ke leroborobo leno, go namela thekesi o sa apara maseke wa go hema, go kokoana go etela ditsala, go ya meketeng kgotsa go etela balelapa, go dira gore go nne bonolo gore mogare o aname mme seno se ka tlhola dintsho.

eng: this may be a disease that is caused by a virus, but it is spread by human conduct and behaviour.
tso: jono e ka tswa e le bolwetse jo bo tlhodiwang ke mogare, fela bo anama ka ntlha ya maitsholo a batho.

eng: through our own actions – as individuals, as families, as communities – we can and we must change the course of this pandemic in our country.
tso: ka maitsholo a rona – re le batho ka borona, re le masika, re le baagi – re ka fetola ka fao leroborobo leno le itirelang ka teng boithatelo e bile re tshwanetse go dira jalo.

eng: we need to wear a cloth mask that covers our nose and mouth whenever we leave home.
tso: re tshwanetse go apara maseke wa lesela o o thibang nko le molomo fa re tswa ka malapa a rona.

eng: we must continue to regularly wash our hands with soap and water or sanitiser.
tso: re tshwanetse go tswelela go tlhapa diatla tsa rona ka gale ka metsi a sesepa kgotsa ka go a tlotsa ka sebolayamegare.

eng: we must continue to clean and sanitise all surfaces in all public spaces.
tso: re tshwanetse go tswelela go phepafatsa mafelo otlhe a a dirisiwang ka gale ke batho.

eng: most importantly, we must keep a safe distance – of at least 2 metres – from other people.
tso: se se botlhokwa go fetisisa, re tshwanetse go katogana – go katoga motho yo mongwe sekgala sa dimitara di le pedi.

eng: there is now emerging evidence that the virus may also be carried in tiny particles in the air in places that are crowded, closed or have poor air circulation.
tso: jaanong go na le bopaki jo bo supologang jo bo reng mogare ono o ka tsamaya ka dikarolo tse dinnye thata tse di leng mo moweng mo mafelong a go nyeumang batho mo go ona, a a tswalegileng kgotsa ao a sa tsenelweng ke phefo.

eng: for this reason we must immediately improve the indoor environment of public places where the risk of infection is greatest.
tso: ka ntlha ya seno re tshwanetse gore ka gangwe fela re tokafatse mafelo a batho ba tsenang ka fa gare ga ona ao mo go ona kgonagalo ya go anama ga mogare ono e leng teng.

eng: our decision to declare a nationwide lockdown prevented a massive early surge of infections when our health services were less prepared, which would have resulted in a far greater loss of lives.
tso: tshwetso ya rona ya go tsena mo kgatong ya go sekega nakwana ditiro tsa ka fa nageng e re thusitse gore re se gosomelwe ke ditshwaetsego tse dintsi re santse re le mo tshimologong fao ka nako eo maokelo a rona a neng a santse a ise a ithulaganye, e leng seo se ka bong se bakile dintsho tse di seng kana ka sepe.

eng: in the time that we had, we have taken important measures to strengthen our health response.
tso: mo nakong eo re nnileng le yona, re tsere dikgato tse di botlhokwa thata go matlafatsa maokelo a rona gore a kgone go samagana le mogare ono.

eng: we have conducted more than two million coronavirus tests and community health workers have done more than 20 million screenings.
tso: re setse re dirile diteko tsa mogare wa corona di feta di le dimilione di le pedi mme ka fa letlhakoreng le lengwe batlhankedi ba boitekanelo ba ba tsenang ntlwana ka ntlwana bona ba setse ba dirile ditlhatlhobo tsa boitekanelo di feta di le dimilione di le 20re beetse thoko malao a ka nna 28 000 kwa dipetlele go thusa balwetse ba covid19 mmogo le go tlhoma dipetlele tsa nakwana tse di leng kgakala le baagi tse di dirang go ralala le naga.

eng: we have made available almost 28,000 hospital beds for covid19 patients and have constructed functional field hospitals across the country.
tso: ga jaana re na le malao a feta a le 37 000 kwa maokelong a puso le a poraefete go ralala le naga a a beetsweng balwetse ba ba nang le mogare ono mme ba tlhoka go katosiwa, a a letetseng fela go amogela balwetse bao ba batlang go ka katosiwa mo bathong ba bangwe mme ba se na ditlogo tsa go ka ikatosa ka bobona fa ba le kwa malapeng a bona.

eng: we now have over 37,000 quarantine beds in private and public facilities across the country, ready to isolate those who cannot do so at home.
tso: re rekile ra bo ra romela dimilionemilione tsa didirisiwa tsa ipabalesego kwa dipetlele, ditleliniki le kwa dikolong go ralala le naga e le go ka babalela batlhankedi ba rona ba ba kopanang le badirelwa.

eng: we have procured and delivered millions of items of personal protective equipment to hospitals, clinics and schools across the country to protect our frontline workers.
tso: re thapile e bile re tsweletse go thapa baoki, dingaka le batlhankedi ba tirelo ya tshoganyetso ya boitekanelo.

eng: we continue to make progress in our efforts to deal with covid 19, but our greatest challenge still lies ahead.
tso: re tsweletse go nna le kgatelopele mo matsapeng a rona a go samagana le covid19, le fa go le jalo, kgwetlho ya rona e e namagadi e santse e tla.

eng: across all provinces, we are working to further increase the number of general ward and critical beds available for covid19 patients.
tso: go ralala le diporofense tsotlhe, re samagane le go oketsa palo ya diphaposibookelo tse di amogelang balwetse ba malwetse a a farologaneng mmogo le malao a a tlhokegang go amogela balwetse ba covid19.

eng: ward capacity is being freed up in a number of hospitals by delaying nonurgent care, the conversion of some areas of hospitals into additional ward space and the erection or expansion of field hospitals.
tso: mo dipetleleng di le dintsinyana balwetse ba ba sa tlhokeng kalafo ya tshoganyetso ba fokodiwa mo diphaposing tsa bookelo go romelwa kwa malapeng a bona, dikarolo dingwe tsa dipetlele di fetolwa go nna diphaposi tsa balwetse e bile go tlhomiwa kgotsa go okediwa gape le dipetlele tsa nakwana tse di leng kgakala le baagi.

eng: we are working to increase supplies of oxygen, ventilators and other equipment for those who will need critical care, including by diverting the supply of oxygen from other purposes.
tso: re samagane le go oketsa tlamelo ya oksijene, metšhini ya go thusa go hema mmogo le didirisiwa tse dingwe gape tse di botlhokwa tse di tla tlhokagalang go thusa bao ba leng mo maemong a a tlhobaetsang, go tsenyeletsa go tlamela ka oksijene mabapi le ditirelo tse di rileng.

eng: we are deploying digital technologies to strengthen the identification, tracing and isolation of contacts, and to provide support to those who test positive.
tso: re dirisa thekenoloji ya dijithale go gagamatsa matsholo a go nopola, go gata motlhala le go beela kwa thoko batho bao ba kopaneng le bao ba tshwaetsegileng, mmogo le go tshegetsa bao diteko di fi tlhetseng ba na le mogare ono.

eng: as we now approach the peak of infections, we need to take extra precautions and tighten existing measures to slow down the rate of transmission.
tso: jaanong jaaka re tsena mo maemong ao ditshwaetso di tla bong di le kwa godimo, re tlhoka go tsaya dikgato tse di gagametseng tsa polokesego mmogo le go gagamatsa dikgato tse ga jaana di leng teng go ka fokotsa lebelo la ditshwaetsego.

eng: regulations on the wearing of masks will be strengthened.
tso: melawanataolo ya gore batho ba apare dimaseke e tla gagamadiwa.

eng: employers, shop owners and managers, public transport operators, and managers and owners of any other public building are now legally obliged to ensure that anyone entering their premises or vehicle must be wearing a mask.
tso: bathapi, beng ba mabentlele le balaodi, beng ba dipalangwa tse di dirisiwang ke baagi, mmogo le balaodi le beng ba meago yotlhe e e dirisiwang ke baagi jaanong ke molao gore motho mang le mang yo a tsenang mo mafelong a bona kgotsa yo a namelang dipalangwa tsa bona o tshwanetse go bo a apere maseke.

eng: taxis undertaking local trips will now be permitted to increase their capacity to 100 percent, while long distance taxis will not be allowed to exceed 70 percent occupancy, on condition that new risk mitigation protocols related to masks, vehicle sanitising and open windows are followed.
tso: dithekesi tse di tsayang maeto a fa gautshwana di tla letlelelwa gore di ka tlatsa banamedi, mme tseo di tsayang maeto a maleele tsona di tla tshwanelwa ke go pega fela 70% ya banamedi, mme seno se tla letlelelwa fa fela ba ikamanya le dikgato tsa tsamaisokgwebo tse di ikamanyang le tiriso ya dimaseke, go tshela sejanaga seo ka sebolayamegare mmogo le go bula a mangwe a matlhabaphefo a sejanaga seno.

eng: there is now clear evidence that the resumption of alcohol sales has resulted in substantial pressure being put on hospitals, including trauma and icu units, due to motor vehicle accidents, violence and related trauma.
tso: jaanong go bopaki jo bo totobetseng gore go letlelelwa gore notagi e ka simolola go rekisiwa go nnile le ditlamorago tse di seng kana ka sepe mo dipetleleng, go tsenyeletsa le mo ditirelong tsa dikgobalo tse di masisi le mo ditirelong tsa diyuniti tsa balwetse ba ba lwelang botshelo le badimo, mme seno ke ka ntlha ya dikotsi tsa dijanaga, tirisodikgoka mmogo le ditiragalo tsa mothale ono tse di tlholang dikgobalo tse di masisi.

eng: we have therefore decided that in order to conserve hospital capacity, the sale, dispensing and distribution of alcohol will be suspended with immediate effect.
tso: ka ntlha ya seno, re tsere tshwetso ya gore, gore re kgone go somarela bokgoni jwa dipetlele go ka samagana le matsapa a re tobaneng le ona, thekiso, kabelano le phasalatso ya notagi e tla tshwanelwa ke go kgaotswa go tloga mo motsing one o. go tsaya kgato e nngwe gape go ka fokotsa boima jo dipetlele di bo rweleng, re tla tsenya gape le dikiletso tsa go tsamaya masigo magareng ga ura ya bo robongwe mo maitsiboeng le ura ya bone mo matsheng.

eng: we are taking these measures fully aware that they impose unwelcome restrictions on people’s lives.
tso: re tsaya dikgatokiletso tseno re itse sentle gore ke tseo batho ba sa itumeleleng tsone mo matshelong a bona.

eng: they are, however, necessary to see us through the peak of the disease.
tso: fela di botlhokwa thata mo pakeng eno gore re kgone go kgabaganya paka eno eo bolwetse jono bo tlhatlogelang kwa godimo mo go yona.

eng: there is no way that we can avoid the coronavirus storm.
tso: ga go tsela e nngwe e re ka efogang setsuatsue seno sa mogare wa corona.

eng: but we can limit the damage that it can cause to our lives.
tso: fela re ka fokotsa bogale jwa tshenyo eo e ka bo dirang mo matshelong a rona.

eng: as a nation we have come together to support each other, to provide comfort to those who are ill and to promote acceptance of people living with the virus.
tso: re le naga kgetse eno ya tsie re e kgona ka go e tshwaraganela, ka go thoba matswalo a bao ba gateletsweng mmogo le go rotloetsana gore re amogele bao ba tshelang ka mogare ono.

eng: crew juliet firefighter shares her story dale hes young firefighter vuyiseka arendse (26) is part of crew juliet, south africa’s first allfemale wildland firefighting team.
tso: motimamelelo wa setlhopha sa crew juliet o abelana ka naane ya gagwe dale hes basadi ba tshwanetse go gotetsa molelo, ga rialo motimamelelo.

eng: her strength and determination to make a name for herself in the maledominated world of firefighting is a true inspiration to all women.
tso: maatla a gagwe le phisegelo ya gagwe ya gore e nne motho bathong mo lekaleng la botimamelelo leo le tletseng ka banna ke seo se tlhotlheletsang basadi e le ruri.

eng: arendse grew up in the small western cape town of beaufort west.
tso: arendse o goletse ko teropong e nnye ya kwa kapa bophirima ya beaufort west.

eng: after school, she tried studying at a college in oudtshoorn, but decided to move back home to support her family.
tso: fa a sena go konosetsa dithuto tsa gagwe o ne a iteka lesego kwa kholejeng kwa oudtshoorn, fela o ne a fetola mogopolo mme a boela gae go tlhokomela balelapa la gagwe.

eng: she worked at a supermarket for a while, but then firefighting caught her eye.
tso: o ne a dira sebakanyana se se khutshwane kwa lebentleleng la dijo le legolwane, fela tiro ya go tima melelo e ne ya mo ngokela.

eng: "i saw the firefighters in their uniforms and the big red trucks.
tso: "ke ne ka bona batimamelelo ba apere diaparo tsa bona le diteroko tsa bona tse dikgolo tse dikhibidu, ka gangwe ke ne ka nna le kgatlhego mme ka batla go itse go le gontsi ka tiro eno," ga rialo arendse.

eng: arendse was one of the graduates of the western cape government’s chrysalis academy youth development programme in 2016. after the programme, she worked at the fire station in beaufort west, earning only r1 900 per month.
tso: arendse ke yo mongwe wa dialogane tsa bajalefa ba lenaane la tlhabololo ya bašwa la ngwaga wa 2016 la puso ya kapa bophirima la chrysalis academy.

eng: but then she came across an opportunity offered by ncc environmental services last year.
tso: mme o ne a bona tšhono e e neng e rebotswe ke ba koporasi ya tshomarelo ya tlhago (ncc) ya ditirelo tsa tikologo mo ngwageng o o fetileng.

eng: "i was at chrysalis academy as a facilitator when ncc came to talk to the students about the opportunity to apply for training for the first allfemale wildland firefighting team.
tso: "ke ne ke santse ke le motlhatlheledi kwa sekolong sa chrysalis academy fa ba ncc ya ditirelo tsa tikologo ba ne ba tla kwa sekolong go buisana le baithuti ka tšhono ya go dira dikopo tsa katiso mo setlhopheng sa ntlha sa batimamelelo mo dikgweng sa basadi fela.

eng: even though i was not one of the students, i was very interested and applied for the training, and i was accepted," arendse says.
tso: le fa ke ne ke se moithuti mo nakong eo, ke ne ke na le kgatlhego e e seng kana ka sepe mme ke ne ka tsenya kopo ya katiso, mme ba ne ba nkamogela," ga rialo arendse.

eng: arendse went through the training, which combined theory and practical aspects of firefighting.
tso: arendse o ne a tsenela katiso eo, e mo go yona e neng e tsenyeletsa dithuto tsa go buisa le go dira tiro.

eng: "i learnt so much.
tso: "go gontsi go ke ithutileng gone.

eng: for one, i didn’t know that there were firefighters tasked with putting out wildfires.
tso: go naya motlhala, ke ne ke sa itse gore go na le batimamelelo bao tiro ya bona e leng fela go tima melelo mo dikgweng.

eng: i had previously thought they only worked in towns to put out fires in buildings," she says.
tso: ke ne ke tsaya fela gore batimamelelo ba tima fela melelo kwa diteropong mo meagong," a rialo.

eng: arendse adds that it was an amazing feeling to pass the training and become part of the first allfemale firefighting team of its kind.
tso: arendse o tlaleleditse ka gore o ikutlwa a le motlotlo go bo a falotse katiso le go nna yo mongwe wa ditokololo tsa setlhopha sa ntlha se se tshwanang se le nosi sa basadi fela ba batimamelelo.

eng: "i felt very excited, especially because when i had told people i wanted to be a firefighter, many of them said i could not do it because i am a woman and would not cope with the job.
tso: "ke ne ke le motlotlo e le ruri, bogolosegolo ka ntlha ya gore fa ke ne ke bolelela batho gore ke batla go nna motimamelelo, bontsi bo ne bo nkgalala bo re ga nkitla ke atlega ka ntlha ya gore ke mosadi e bile ga nkitla ke kgona go itshokela tiro eno.

eng: this pushed me to show them that i can actually do it, not only for myself but for the rest of the women in south africa.
tso: seno se ne sa dira gore ke ikgotlokotse ke ba bontshe gore ga go sepe se se ka nkgoreletsang gore ke dire tiro eno, e se fela ka ntlha ya fa ke batla go itirela seno ke le esi, mme ke ne ke batla gape le go bontsha basadi ba naga ya aforika borwa gore le bona ba ka kgona go fitlhelela seno."

eng: "arendse says that fighting her first major fire in noordhoek was a challenging but highly rewarding experience.
tso: arendse a re o simolotse go tima molelo lwa ntlha mo botshelong jwa gagwe ka molelo wa kwa noordhoek o o neng o le boima go o lwantsha fela go o timeng go dirile gore a nne le maitemogelo a a seng kana ka sepe.

eng: "it was my first full 24hour shift and the first time we were working with all the other male firefighters.
tso: "e ne e le letsatsi la me la ntlha ke dira bosigo le motshegare e bile e ne e le lantlha re dira mmogo le batimamelelo ba banna.

eng: it was tiring and very hot in our protective gear but we finished the job and the feeling afterwards was very rewarding.
tso: diaparo tsa rona tsa ipabalelo di ne di le boima e bile di le mogote mo go maswe fela re ne ra konosetsa tiro ya rona mme maitemogelo ano a ne a se kana ka sepe."

eng: "arendse encourages the women of south africa to never underestimate themselves.
tso: arendse o rotloetsa basadi ba naga ya aforika borwa gore ba se ke ba inyatsa.

eng: "don’t be defined by what people say you can and can’t do."
tso: "o seke wa ya ka batho fa ba re ke eng se o ka kgonang go se dira le se o ka se kgoneng go se dira."

eng: celebrating women through economic inclusion vukuzenzele unnamed in august south africa celebrates women’s month.
tso: ku tlangela vavasati hi nkatso ku tlangela vavasati hi nkatso eka swa ikhonomieka swa ikhonomi vukuzenzele unnamed hi mhawuri afrikadzonga ri tlangela nhweti ya vavasati.

eng: this occasion marks the anniversary of the day in 1956 when 20,000 women marched to the union buildings – a great sea of womankind speaking many languages, from different places and of all races.
tso: ntirho lowu wu komba siku leri fanaka ra 1956 loko 20,000 wa vavasati va macha ku ya eunion buildings – lwandle ra kahle ra vaxisati lava vulavulaka tindzimi to tala, ku suka eka tindhawu to hambana hambana na tinxaka hinkwato.

eng: they were united in their demand for an end to the dreaded pass laws and for their right to live in freedom.
tso: a va khomanile eka swikoxo swa vona swa ku herisa milawu ya pasi na timfanelo ta vona to hanya va ntshuxekile.

eng: the status and position of women in south africa today is vastly different to that faced by our mothers and grandmothers in 1956. we have come a long way in realising a south africa that is nonracial, nonsexist, democratic, prosperous and free.
tso: xiyimo xa vavas atieafrikadzonga namuntlha xi hambanile swinene na lexi a xi langutane na vamanana na vakokwana wa hina hi 1956. hi suka ekule eka ku kumisisa afrikadzonga leri nga yiki hi rixaka, rimbewu, ra xidimokirasi, ro hluvuka no ntshuxeka.

eng: there has been real progress in improving the lives of south african women in the economy, in the political sphere and in public life.
tso: ku vile na ku antswa eka ku antswisa vutomi bya vavasati va afrikadzonga eka ikhonomi, eka xiphemu xa tipolotiki na le ka vutomi bya mani na mani.

eng: at the same time, we know there is so much further we still have to go.
tso: hi nkarhi wun'we, ha swi tiva leswaku kahari na ndlela yo leha leyi hi faneleke ku yi famba.

eng: women still face discrimination, harassment and violence, and bear the greatest brunt of poverty.
tso: vavasati vaha langutane na xihlawuhlawu, nxaniso na madzolonga, na ku rhwala ndzhwalo lowukulu wa vusiwana.

eng: if we are to truly realise the promise of our constitution we have to tackle the economic and financial exclusion that makes women more vulnerable to abuse and violence.
tso: loko ho lava ku lemuka xitshembiso xa vumbiwa ra hina hi fanele ku languta nkatso wa xiikhonomi na wa ximali leswi swi endlaka leswaku vavasati vava va nga hlayisekanga eka nxaniso na madzolonga.

eng: we have joined a groundbreaking campaign that links us to global efforts to achieve gender equality by 2030. generation equality is an ambitious and transformative agenda to end discrimination and violence against women and for their equal participation in political, social and economic life.
tso: hi nghenerile khampheni leyi nga se tshamaku yi endliwa leyi yi hi hlanganisaka na kutinyiketela ka misava hinkwayo ku fikelela ku ringana ka rimbewu hi 2030. ndzingano warixaka i ajenda leyi naveriwaka no cinca ku herisa xihlawuhlawu na madzolonga eka vavasati na ku nghenelela loku ringanaka eka vutomi bya swa tipolotiki, xinakulobye naxiikhonomi.

eng: as part of this campaign, we have joined two ‘action coalitions’, one for economic justice and rights and another against genderbased violence.
tso: tanihi xiphemu xa khampheni leyi, hi nghenele ‘mihlanganelo ya swendlo’ yimbirhi, wun'we wa vululami bya ikhonomi na timfanelo na yin'wana ku lwisana na madzolonga ku ya hi rimbewu.

eng: both of these themes are critical to our own national agenda.
tso: tithimi leti havumbirhi ti na nkoka eka ajenda ya hina ya tiko.

eng: eleven months since the emergency response action plan to combat genderbased violence and femicide was implemented we have made progress in expanding support and care to survivors, and progress is being made in legal reforms to afford them greater protection.
tso: khumen'we wa tinhweti loko kungu ra ku hlamula ra xilamulelamhangu ku lwisana na madzolonga kuya hi rimbewu na kudlawa ka vavasati ri simekiwile hi endlile ku antswa eka ku andzisa nseketelo na nhlayiso wa lava poneke, naswona ku antswa swi endliwa hi ku aka hi vuntshwa nawu ku va nyika nsirhelelo wa kahle swinene.

eng: during the month of august, we begin the implementation of the national strategic plan to combat genderbased violence and femicide.
tso: hi n'hweti ya mhawuri, hi sungula ku simeka kungu ra tiko ro lwisana na madzolonga yoya hi rimbewu na ku dlawa ka vavasati.

eng: a key aspect of the plan is on ensuring greater women’s financial inclusion.
tso: xa nkoka eka kungu leri i ku tiyisisa ku katsiwa ka vavasati eka swa timali.

eng: this is because economic inequality and social inequality are interconnected.
tso: leswi i mhaka ya leswaku kandzingano wa xiikhonomi na kandzingano wa vanhu swa fambisana.

eng: the economic status of women in south africa makes them more vulnerable to abuse.
tso: xiyimo xa vavasati eka ikhonomi eafrikadzonga swi va endla leswaku vava va nga hlayisekanga eka nxaniso.

eng: we must therefore scale up support for women to enable them to become financially independent.
tso: hi fanele ku tlakusa nseketelo wa hina eka vavasati ku endla leswaku va kota ku ti yimela hi swa timali.

eng: we have made a number of commitments under generation equality that will be given effect to through the national strategic plan.
tso: hi tibohile eka ndzingano wa rixaka lowu nga ta nyikiwa matimba hi kungu ra tiko.

eng: firstly, we are going to drive women’s economic inclusion through public procurement.
tso: xosungula, hi ta fambisa nkatso wa vavasati eka swa ikhonomi hi ku swikuma ka mani na mani.

eng: we have set the target of ensuring that at least 40 percent of goods and services procured by public entities are sourced from womenowned businesses.
tso: hi vekile xikongomiwa xo tiyisia leswaku kwalomu ka 40 wa tiphesente wa nhundzu na vukorhokeri lebyi kumiwaka hi swiphemu swa mfumo swi huma eka mabindzu ya vavasati.

eng: secondly, we are going to scale up support for womenowned smmes and for women who work in the informal sector or are unemployed.
tso: xa vumbirhi, hi ta tlakusa nseketelo eka tismme ta vavasati na vavasati lava tirhaka eka xiphemu xo ka xi nga pasisiwanga kumbe lava nga tirheki.

eng: this will include engagement with the financial sector to make financial services accessible and affordable for women.
tso: leswi swi ta katsa mburisano na xiphemu xa timali ku endla leswaku vukorhokeri byi fikeleleka eka vavasati.

eng: thirdly, we want to ensure more women have access to productive assets such as land.
tso: xa vunharhu, hi lava ku tiyisisa leswaku vavasati votala va kota ku fikelela ndhaka yo vuyerisa kufana na miasava.

eng: it is essential that women are beneficiaries of the accelerate land reform programme.
tso: swi na nkoka leswaku vavasati va va vavuyeriwa eka phurogireme ya endla antswiso wa misava.

eng: it is significant that of the r75 million in covid19 relief earmarked for farming input vouchers 53 percent of the beneficiaries will be rural women.
tso: swi na nkoka leswaku eka r75 timiliyoni ta mphalalo wa covid19 ti yisiwa eka tivhochara ta vurimi, 53 wa tiphesente wa vavuyeriwa kutava vavasati va matikoxikaya.

eng: we must ensure that women subsistence and smallscale farmers continue to receive support beyond the pandemic.
tso: hi fanele ku tiyisisa leswaku ku pfuniwa ka vavasati na van'wamapurasi lamantsongo va ya emahlweni va kuma nseketelo na loko ntungunkulu wu hundzile.

eng: fourthly, we want to ensure that women are protected from genderbased violence in the workplace.
tso: xa vumue, hi lava ku tiyisisa leswaku vavasati va sirhelelekile eka madzolonga yo ya hi rimbewu endhawini ya ntirho.

eng: in this regard, we will be working at a national and regional level towards the ratification of the ilo convention on violence and harassment in the workplace.
tso: hi ndlela leyi, hitava hi tirha eka xiyimo xa tiko na xa rhijini eka ku lulamisa ntolovelo wa ilo wa madzolonga na nxaniso eka ndhawu ya ntirho.

eng: it is said that freedom is not given, but taken.
tso: ku vuriwa leswaku ntshuxeko a wu nyikiwi, wo tekiwa.

eng: the emancipation of women is only words on paper unless it is matched by commitment from all sectors of society.
tso: ku ntshuxa vavasati i marito ntsena eka phepha handle ka loko ma fambelanisiwa na kutinyiketela kusuka eka swiphemu hinkwaswo swa rixaka.

eng: as we prepare for the reconstruction of our economy in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic, we have said that we cannot simply return to where we were before the outbreak of the virus.
tso: tanihi loko haha lulamisela ku aka hi vuntshwa ikhonomi ya hina eka ku tumbuluka ka ntungunkulu wa khoronavhayirasi, hi vurile leswaku a hi nga tlheleli ntsena laha hi ri kona khale kungasi va na xitsongwatsongwana.

eng: we must build a fundamentally different economy which, among other things, substantially improves the material position of women.
tso: hi fanelel ku aka ikhonomi yo hambana leyi, exikarhi ka swin'wana, yi antswisaka swinene xiyimo xa vavasati eka switirhisiwa.

eng: this means that our investment in infrastructure must support not only the development of local industry, but also womenowned businesses.
tso: leswi swi vula leswaku vuvekisi ba hina eka vumaki byi fanele ku seketela kungari nhluvukiso ntsena wa indhasitiri ya le hansi, kambe na mabindzu ya vavasati.

eng: it must deliberately create employment opportunities for women in all stages of planning, financing, building and maintaining infrastructure.
tso: byi fanelel ku humelerisa tindlela ta mintirho ya vavasati eka switeji hinkwaswo swa ku lulamisela, ku hakela, ku aka na ku hlayisa miako.

eng: by the same measures, as we scale up our public employment programmes, we must ensure that young women in particular are identified as participants.
tso: hi tindlela leti fanaka, loko hi karhi hi tlakusa tiphurogireme ta mintirho, hi fanele ku tiyisisa leswaku vavasati lavantsongo hi ku kongoma va hlawuriwa tani hi vatekaxive.

eng: in addition to an income, these programmes will provide them with an opportunity to acquire some of the skills and experience necessary to enter the mainstream economy.
tso: ku tatisa eka muholo, tiphurogireme leti ti ta nyika tindlela to kuma vuswikoti na ntokoto lowu faneleke ku nghena eka ikhonomi.

eng: as much as it is government’s responsibility to provide economic opportunities for women and create an enabling framework for advancing gender equality, everyone in society needs to play their part.
tso: tanihi loko kuri vutihlamuleri bya mgumo ku nyika tindlela ta ikhonomi eka vavasati na ku endla rimba leri pfumelelaka ku antswisa ndzingano wa rimbewu, un'wana na un'wana eka rixaka u fanele ku tlanga xiphemu xa yena.

eng: businesses must support womenowned enterprises in the procurement of goods and services.
tso: mabindzu ma fanele ku seketela mabindzu ya vavasati ku kuma nhundzu na vukorhokeri.

eng: they should employ more women and appoint more women to management positions.
tso: va fanele ku thola vavasati votala naswona va thola vavasati eka swiyimo swa vurhangeri.

eng: this is all the more important considering that the private sector’s record on genderrepresentation at management level lags behind that of the public sector.
tso: leswi hinkwaswo swi na nkoka loko hi languta rhekhodo ya xiphemu xoka xi ngari xa mfumo eka kuyimela rimbewu eka nkarhi wa le ndhaku wa levhele ya vurhangeri eka mfumo.

eng: this is an issue that is repeatedly raised in engagements i have had with a number of women’s business organisations.
tso: leyi i mhaka leyi yi tshamaka yi kha yi vuriwa eka miburisano leyi ni ngava na yona na minhlangano ya mabindzu ya vavasati yo hlaya.

eng: by equal measure, we must eliminate gender disparities in pay for men and women, and give effect to the principle of equal pay for equal work contained in the employment equity act.
tso: hi mpimo wo ringana, hi fanele ku herisa kandzingano wa rimbewu eka hakelo ya vavanuna na vavasati, na ku teketela enhlokweni nawu wa hakelo yo ringana ya ntirho wo ringana leswi nga eka nawu wa ndzingano wa ntirho.

eng: women must also be protected from harassment and discrimination in the workplace.
tso: vavasati va fanele ku sirheleriwa eka nxaniso na xihlawuhlawu eka ndhawu ya ntirho.

eng: it is up to transport operators, university administrators, school governing bodies and religious organisations to create conditions for women and girls to travel, study and worship in safety.
tso: swi le ka vafambisi va swa vutleketli, valanguteri va tiyunivhesiti, vafambisi va swikolo na mihlangano ya vukhongeri ku endla swivandla swa leswaku vavasati na van'hwana va endza, va dyondza na ku khongela eka ndhawu yo hlayiseka.

eng: we must forge ahead with our efforts to eradicate chauvinism, sexism and patriarchy.
tso: hi fanele ku rhangela hi matimba ya hina ku herisa ntshikelelo, ku hlawula kuya hi rimbewu na ku siyerisana ka vavanuna.

eng: it is these attitudes that enable the oppression of women.
tso: i matikhomelo lama lama ma pfumelelaka ntshikelelo wa vavasati.

eng: it is up to us – both men and women – to affirm that a woman’s value, position and opinions are no less than that of a man.
tso: swi le ka hina – vavanuna na vavasati – ku tiyisisa leswaku nkoka wa wansati, xiyimo na mavonelo a swi hambananga na swa wanuna.

eng: it is up to us as parents and grandparents to treat and raise our sons and our daughters the same.
tso: swi le ka hina tanihi vatswari na vakokwana ku khoma no kurisa majaha na tintombhi ta hina ku fana.

eng: it is up to us as men to reject and speak out against genderbased violence wherever we see it, even if it is against our friends, fathers or brothers.
tso: swi le ka hina tanihi vavanuna ku ala na ku vulavula ku lwisana na madzolonga ku ya hi rimbewu kwihi na kwihi laha hi swi vonaka, hambi loko kuri ku lwisana na vanghana va hina, vatatana va hina kumbe vaboti wa hina.

eng: let us be the generation that ends the oppression of women in all its forms, in our lifetime.
tso: a hi veni rixaka leri herisaka ntshikelelo wa vavasati hi tinxaka ta tona hinkwato, enkarhini wa hina wa ku hanya.

eng: back to work after covid19 a full guide allison cooper when can you return to work if you have tested positive for the coronavirus (covid19)?
tso: ku tlhelela entirhweni endhaku ka ku hola eka covid19 allison cooper xana u nga tlhele la rini entirhweni loko u kamberiwile u kumeka u ri na khoronavhayirasi (covid19)?

eng: the national institute for communicable diseases has the answers you need.
tso: national insti tute for communicable diseases yi na tinhlamulo leti u ti dingaka.

eng: when i test positive for covid19, how long do i have to stay in isolation?
tso: loko ndzi kamberiwile ndzi loko ndzi kamberiwile ndzi kumeka ndziri na kumeka ndziri na covid19covid19 , xana , xana ndzi fanele ku tshama nkarhi wo ndzi fanele ku tshama nkarhi wo leha ku fika kwihi eka ndhawu yo leha ku fika kwihi eka ndhawu yo khetela etlhelo?

eng: people who test positive for covid19, but don’t have any symptoms, must remain in isolation at home or in a government isolation facility for 10 days, from the day they receive their positive test result.
tso: vanhu lava va kamberiwaka va kumeka va ri na covid19 , kambe vangari na swikombeto, va fanele ku tshama eka ndhawu yo khetela etlhelo ekaya kumbe eka ndhawu yo khetela etlhelo ya mfumo ku ringana 10 ra masiku, kusukela hi siku leri va kumaka mbuyelo wa vona wo komba leswaku va na vuvabyi.

eng: those who have mild symptoms must remain in isolation at home or in a government isolation facility for 10 days, from the day their symptoms start.
tso: lava va nga na swikombeto swoka swi nga tikanga va fanele ku tshama eka ndhawu yo khetela etlhelo ekaya kumbe eka ndhawu yo khetela etlhelo ya mfumo kuringana 10 ra masiku, kusukela hi siku leri swikombeto swi sungulaka ha rona.

eng: those who have severe disease, who have to go to hospital, must remain in isolation for 10 days, from when they are stable and don’t need oxygen anymore.
tso: lava va nga na vuvabyi byo tika, lava va faneleke ku yaexibedhlele, va fanele ku tshama eka ndhawu yo khetela etlhelo kuringana 10 ra masiku, ku fika loko va antswa naswona va nga ha lavi moyatenga.

eng: how can a covid19 positive people transfer the disease to others?
tso: xana munhu loyi a nga naxana munhu loyi a nga nacovid19covid19 a nga hundzisela a nga hundziselavuvabyi njhani eka van'wana?

eng: according to health minister zweli mkhize, most people who have a mild infection can spread the virus for between seven to 12 days.
tso: kuya hi holobye wa rihanyo zweli mkhize, vanhu votala lava va nga na ntluleto wo ka wu nga tikanga va nga hangalasa xitsongwatsongwana ku ringana exikarhi ka nkombo ku ya eka 12 wa masiku.

eng: however, people who become very sick could be infectious and be able to transmit the virus to others for a longer period of time.
tso: hambiswiritano, vanhu lava va vabyaka ngopfu va nga tluleta na ku kota ku hundzisela xitsongwatsongwana eka van'wna ku ringana nkarhi wo leha.

eng: do i have to have another covid19 test, proving that i am negative, before i return to work?
tso: xana ndzi fanele ku kamberiwa xana ndzi fanele ku kamberiwa covid19covid19 nakambe, ku komba nakambe, ku komba leswaku a ndzi na yona, ndzi ngasi leswaku a ndzi na yona, ndzi ngasi tlhelela entirhweni?

eng: no.
tso: ee.

eng: retesting people who have experienced mild illness and have recovered is not recommended.
tso: ku kambela nakambe vanhu lava va nga va na vuvabyi byoka byi nga tikanga naswona va horile a swi bumabumeriwi.

eng: a person is considered safe to return to work and come out of isolation if they are no longer infectious.
tso: munhu u voniwa a nga ri na khombo ku tlhelela entirhweni na ku huma eka ku khetela etlhelo loko va nga ha tluleti vuvabyi.

eng: this means they developed their first symptoms more than 10 days ago and have not had any symptoms for at least three days.
tso: leswi swi vula leswaku va vile na swikombeto swo sungula eka masiku mo hundza 10 lama ma nga hundza naswona a va se va na swikombeto swihi kumbe swihi kuringana masiku manharhu.

eng: in most cases, employees can return to work without testing again if: they have completed 10 days of mandatory quarantine or selfisolation.
tso: hi kanyingi, vatirhi va nga tlhelela entirhweni va nga kamberiwanga nakambe loko: va hetile 10 ra masiku yo boha ya nhlambulo kumbe ku tikhetela etlhelo.

eng: those who had moderate or severe symptoms undergo a medical evaluation.
tso: lava va nga va na swikombeto swale henhla kumbe swo tika va va eka nkambisiso wa vutshunguri.

eng: they continue to practice personal hygiene and social distancing.
tso: va ya emahlweni va endla vutibasisi na ku siya mpfhuka exikarhi ka vanhu.

eng: the employer monitors the worker to ensure they do not regress.
tso: muthori u landzelerisa mutirhi ku tiyisisa leswaku a nga tlheleli endhaku.

eng: they wear a mask, from the date of diagnosis for at least 21 days.
tso: va ambala xipfalaxikandza, ku sukela eka siku va nga kuma leswku va na vuvabyi ku ringana 21 wa masiku.

eng: i have tested negative but i still have symptoms.
tso: ndzi kamberiwile ndzi kumeka ndzi ngari na vuvabyi kambe ndza hari na swikombeto.

eng: what now?
tso: ku humelela yini sweswi?

eng: it is possible to get a false negative test result.
tso: swa humelela ku kuma mbuyelo woka wu ngari wona wo komba leswaku munhu u hava vuvabyi.

eng: this means that your first test could be negative, but you could test positive at a later stage.
tso: leswi swi vula leswaku nkambelo wa wena wo sungula wu nga komba ku pfumala vuvabyi, kambe u nga kamberiwa u kumeka u ri na vuvabyi endhaku ka nkarhi.

eng: if you continue to have covid19 symptoms contact your healthcare professional.
tso: loko u ya emahlweni u va na swikombeto swa covid19 tihlanganisi na muhlayisi wa rihanyo wa wena wa phurofexinali.

eng: what if i am still showing symptoms after 10 days?
tso: loko ndzo va ndza ha komba loko ndzo va ndza ha komba swikombeto endhaku ka 10 ra swikombeto endhaku ka 10 ra masiku ke?

eng: it is common for patients to continue to have symptoms for longer than 10 days.
tso: swi tolovelekile kuva vavabyi va ya emahlweni va va na swikombeto nkarhi wo leha ku hundza 10 ra masiku.

eng: full recovery may take several weeks.
tso: ku hola hi ku hetiseka swi nga teka mavhiki mo hlaya.

eng: if you still have symptoms, seek advice from your healthcare professional.
tso: loko wa ha ri na swikombeto, lava switsundzuxo kusuka eka muhlayisi wa wena wa rihanyo wa phurofexinali.

eng: for more information about covid19, visit the national institute for communicable diseases’ website at www.
tso: ku kuma vuxokoxoko byo tala hi covid19 , endzela webusayiti ya national institute for communicable diseases’ eka www.

eng: nicd.
tso: nicd.

eng: managing covid19: at home and at a dedicated facility allison cooper if you are not able to selfisolate, call the national coronavirus hotline at 0800 029 999 for more information about your closest isolation or quarantine facility.
tso: ku lawula covid19 : ekaya na le ka ndhawu leyi nyikiweke allison cooper maafrikadzonga votala lava kamberiwaka va kumeka va ri na khoronavhayirasi (covid19) a va koti ku ti khetela etlhelo hikuva makaya ya vona i matsongo kuva va nga hanya no etlela eka kamara leri ri nga tirhisiweki hi munhu un'wana.

eng: it’s extremely important to separate yourself from others, either at home or at a free isolation facility, if you have tested positive for covid19.
tso: mfumo wu tiyisisile leswaku tindhawu to khetela etlhelo ti kona ta vanhu lava va nga kamberiwa va kumeka va ri na vuvabyi, na tindhawu ta nhlambulo tikona ta vanhu lava va nga yimela mbuyelo wo kamberiwa.

eng: both services are free.
tso: vukorhokeri hivumbirhi i mahala.

eng: according to dr marlin mccay, a general practitioner based in florida on the west rand, the first thing you need to do when diagnosed with covid19 is to limit the spread of the infection.
tso: ku ya hi dkd marlin mccay, dokodela wo tshungula mavabyi mo ka ma nga tikanga loyi a kumekaka eflorida ewest rand , xo sungula lexi u faneleke ku xi endla loko u kamberiwile u kumeka u ri na covid19 i ku hunguta ku hangalaka ka ntluletavuvabyi.

eng: "you want to protect your family," he says.
tso: "u lava ku sirhelela ndyangu wa wena," a vula.

eng: to do this, you need to go into isolation – either at home or at an isolation facility.
tso: ku endla leswi, u fanele u tikhetela etlhelo – kungava ekaya kumbe eka ndhawu yo khetela etlhelo.

eng: "if you are selfisolating it means you have to find a part of the house where you are totally cut off from the rest of the family.
tso: "loko u tikhetela etlhelo swi vula leswaku u fanele u kuma xiphemu xa yindlu laha u nga hlanganiki na ndyangu hinkwawo.

eng: no one should come within three metres of you.
tso: kungavi na munhu loyi a tshunelaka eka timitara tinharhu eka wena.

eng: you must eat on your own; use your own cutlery and crockery; use your own bathroom, if possible; and make sure there’s no contact with anyone else in the family.
tso: u fanele u dya u ri wexe; tirhisa swibye swa wena; tirhisa xindlwana xa wena, loko swi koteka; naswona tiyisisa leswaku aku na ku hlangana na munhu un'wana endyangwini.

eng: "your doctor or primary care giver should help you with certain basic medications to ease most of the symptoms, especially things like body aches and pains, headache and fever.
tso: "dokodela wa wena kumbe muhlayisi wa wena u fanele ku ku pfuna hi yin'wana ya mirhi ku hunguta swikombeto swotala, ngopfu ngopfu swilo swo fana na switlhavi swa miri na swivavi, ku pandza ka nhloko na ku hisa miri.

eng: there are also some good vitamins one can use to stay healthy," he says.
tso: ku na tivhitamini ta kahle leti munhu a nga ti tirhisaka ku tshama a hanye kahle," a vula.

eng: it’s also important to get enough rest and drink enough water or clear fluids to make sure that your urine stays a pale clear colour.
tso: switlhela swi va na nkoka ku wisa swinene na ku nwa mati mo ringanela kumbe swihalaki swo vonikela ku endlela leswaku mitsakamiso ya wena yi tshama yi ri na muhlovo wo vonikela.

eng: most people with mild illness will start feeling better within a week of the first symptoms, but it’s important to monitor your symptoms carefully.
tso: vanhu vo tala lava va nga na mavabyi mo ka ma nga tikanga va ta sungula ku antswa eka vhiki ro sungula ra swikombeto swo sungula, kambe swi na nkoka ku langutisa swikombeto swa wena kahle.

eng: if you develop any emergency warning signs, such as trouble breathing, chest pain or pressure in your chest that does not go away, coughing up blood, becoming confused, severe sleepi ness or blue lips or face you must call an ambulance or go to hospital immediately.
tso: loko u va na tisayini ta xihatla, kufana na kutikeriwa ku hefemula, swivavi swa xifuva kumbe ntshikelelo exifuveni lowu wu nga heleku, ku khohlola ngati, ku hlanganana, ku twa vurhongo swinene kumbe milomo kumbe xikandza xa wasi u fanele ku vitana ambulense kumbe u ya exibedhlele hi xihatla.

eng: for those who are not able to keep themselves away from others living in the home, government has setup free quarantine facilities around the country to keep you and your loved ones safe.
tso: tindhawu ta hlambulolava va nga koteki ku va ekule na van'wana lava tshamaka ekaya, mfumo wu endlile tindhawu ta mahala ya nhlambulo etikweni hinkwaro ku hlayisa wena na varhandziwa va wena.

eng: the western cape government recently published some comments from patients about its isolation facilities.
tso: mfumo wa kapavuxa waha ku humesa tikhomente kusuka eka vavabyi hi mayelana na tindhawu leti to khetela etlhelo.

eng: marie jantjies from witzenberg decided to follow healthcare workers’ advice and go to the isolation facility because her 97yearold mother lives with her and her children and she wanted to protect them.
tso: marie jantjies wo huma ewitzenberg u kunguhatile ku landzelela xitsundzuxo xa vatirhi va swa rihanyo a ya eka ndhawu yo khetela etlhelo hikuva manana wa yena wa 97 wa malembe hi vukhale u tshama na yena na vana va yena naswona a lava ku va sirhelela.

eng: "i was treated very well.
tso: "a ni khomiwe kahle.

eng: the food was nice – even nicer than at home.
tso: swakudyaa swi ri kahle – naswona a swiri kahle kutlula swa le kaya.

eng: i realised i just had to stay positive.
tso: ndzi lemukile leswaku a ni fanele ku tshama niri na ntshembho.

eng: i was anxious, but i prayed and tried to relax," she said.
tso: a ni chuwhile, kambe ni khongerile ni ringeta ku wisa," a vula.

eng: "that place can save lives!
tso: "ndhawu liya yi nga hlayisa vutomi!

eng: it really is the best," said john arnoldus, who recovered from covid19 at an isolation facility in drakenstein.
tso: i ya kahle swinene," ku vula john arnoldus, loyi a nga hola eka covid19 eka ndhawu yo khetela ethlhelo edrakenstein.

eng: "one of my friends was in quarantine at home and he struggled to recover on his own.
tso: "un'wana wa vanghana va mina a ri eka nhlambulo ekaya naswona u hluphekile ku hola a ri yexe.

eng: i told him to contact the people who cared for me – that is the way to get better.
tso: ndzi n'wi byerile leswaku a tihlanganisa na vanhu lava va nga ndzi hlayisa – hi yona ndlela yo antswa.

eng: the support of the medical staff and the manager there – that pulls you through," he said.
tso: nseketelo wa vatirhi va swa rihanyo na mufambisi wa kwele – lowu wu ku humesaka," a vula.

eng: arnoldus was initially hesitant to go to the isolation facility because of the wrong perception that if you go to a facility like this you will get sicker and die.
tso: arnoldus a kanakana ekusunguleni ku ya eka ndhawu yo khetela etlhelo hikwalaho ka vonelo ro ka ri nga ri rona ra leswaku loko u ya eka ndhawu yo fana na leyi u ta vabya swinene u lova.

eng: "i expected the worst, but i was received so well.
tso: "a ndzi langutele swo chavisa, kambe ndzi amukeriwile kahle.

eng: hats off to the staff!
tso: ndzi hluvulela vatirhi xihuku!

eng: they explained to me that as i already have covid19, no one at the facility could make me sick," he said.
tso: va ndzi hlamuserile leswaku tanihiloko ndziri na covid19 , a ku na munhu loyi a nga ta ndzi endla leswaku ndzi vabya eka ndhawu leyi," a vula.

eng: what can you expect from a quarantine facility?
tso: xana u nga langutela yini eka ndhawu ya nhlambulo?

eng: according to the western cape government, all of your needs are taken of.
tso: kuya hi mfumo wa kapavuxa, swidingo swa wena hinkwaswo swa hlayisiwa.

eng: let’s keep each other safe vukuzenzele unnamed our country has moved to alert level 2 in our response to the coronavirus pandemic.
tso: a hi hlayisaneni vukuzenzele unnamed tiko ra hina ri sukile ri ya eka levhele ya vulemukisi ya 2 eka ku hlamula ka hina eka ntungukulu wa khoro navhayirasi.

eng: this has come as a relief to all south africans who have had to live under stringent restrictions for the last five months.
tso: leswi swi antswiserile maafrikadzonga hinkwavo lava a va boheka ku hanya ehansi ka ku aleriwa ko tika eka tin’hweti ta ntlhanu leti nga hundza.

eng: it is a sign of the progress we are making in reducing new infections and demand on our health facilities.
tso: i xikombiso xa ku antswa loku hi ku endlaka eka ku hunguta mitluletovuvabyi na nkayivelo eka tindhawu ta hina ta rihanyu.

eng: it is also a very important development as we strive to restart our economy.
tso: ku tlhela ku va antswiso wa nkoka swinene tanihi loko hi lava ku sungurisa ikhonomi ya hina.

eng: but it is too soon to celebrate.
tso: kambe nkarhi a wuse pfumela leswaku hi nga tlangela.

eng: we are still very much in the middle of a deadly pandemic that has taken over 11,000 lives in south africa alone.
tso: ha hari exikarhi ngopfu ka ntungukulu wo dlaya lowu wu nga teka vutomi byo tlula 11,000 eafrikadzonga ntsena.

eng: at more than half a million confirmed cases, we still have the fifth highest number of infections in the world.
tso: eka hafu ya miliyoni wa timhangu leti tiyisisi weke, ha hari na nhlayo ya vuntlhanu hi kuva henhla ya mitluletovuvabyi emisaveni hinkwayo.

eng: and there is always a chance of a resurgence of the disease.
tso: kambe ku tshama ku ri na chansi ya ku tlakuka nakambe ka vuvabyi.

eng: if we ever need a stark reminder of the need for vigilance, we should look to recent events thousands of kilometres away in new zealand.
tso: loko hi tshuka hi lava xitsundzuxo xo helela xa xilaveko xa hiteko, hi fanele ku languta eka timhaka ta seswi leti nga ekule hi ma gidi ya tikhilomitara enew zealand.

eng: three months since the country was declared coronavirusfree, new zealand is once again under lockdown.
tso: i tin’hweti tinharhu ku tivisiwile leswaku aka hari na khoronavhayirasi, new zealand yi tlhele yi va eka ku pfaleriwa nakambe.

eng: although the latest outbreak was of relatively few cases, the government swiftly reimposed lockdown restrictions.
tso: hambileswi ku pfuka a kuri ka timhangu tintsongo, mfumo wu vuyelerisile ku aleriwa eka ku pfaleriwa.

eng: similar restrictions have had to be reimposed in several parts of europe as they experience a ‘second wave’ of infections.
tso: ku aleriwa loku fanaka ku vuyiseriwile eka tindhawu to hlaya ta europe tanihi loko va langutane na ‘gandlati ra vumbhirhi’ ra mitluleto vuvabyi.

eng: these experiences show just how swiftly things can change when it comes to covid19.
tso: mitokoto leyi yihi komba kahle leswaku swilo swi nga cinca hi ku hatlisa loko swita eka covid19 .

eng: it is a wakeup call to any among us who may harbour illusions that we are even close to seeing the end of this grave public health emergency.
tso: i xilemukisi eka un’wana na un ‘wana exikarhi ka hina loyi a nga vaka na swivono swa leswaku hi ngava hiri kusuhi na ku vona makumu ya mhaka leyikulu ya mani na mani ya xilamulelamha ngu ya rihanyo.

eng: certainly, there are signs of hope.
tso: hi ntiyiso, ku na swikombi so swa ntshembho.

eng: the number of new confirmed cases in south africa continues to decline.
tso: nhlayo ya timhangu tintshwa leti tiyisisiweke eafrikadzonga yi ya emahlweni yi chika.

eng: at the peak of the disease just one month ago, we were recording around 12,000 new cases a day.
tso: emaninginingini ya vuva byi eka n’hweti leyi nga hu ndza, a hi tsarisa kwalomu ka 12,000 wa timhangu tintshwa hi siku.

eng: this has dropped to an average of around 5,000 a day over the past week.
tso: leswi swi hungutekile ku ya kwalomu ka 5,000 hi siku eka vhiki leri nga hundza.

eng: our recovery rate stands at 80 percent.
tso: mpimo wa hina wa ku hola wu le ka 80 wa tiphesente.

eng: as the country moves to alert level 2, many restrictions on social and economic activity have been lifted.
tso: tanihi loko tiko ri ya eka levhele ya vulemukisi ya 2, ku aleriwa kotala eka timha ka ta ntolovelo na ikhonomi swi tlakusiwile.

eng: with this comes increased risk of transmission.
tso: leswi swi ta na nxungeto lowukulu wa hundziselo.

eng: we now need to manage this risk and ensure the gains we have made thus far in containing the pandemic’s spread are not reversed.
tso: swesi hi fanele ku lawula nxungeto lowu na ku tiyisisa leswaku ku vuyeriwa loku hi nga ku endla ku fika sweswi eka ku lawula ku hangalaka ka ntungukulu a swi tlheri seriwi endzhaku.

eng: the greatest threat to the health of nation right now is complacency.
tso: nxungeto lowukulu eka rihanyu ra tiko sweswi i nkaenelo.

eng: it may be that we are now permitted to meet friends and family, to visit entertainment venues, to travel for leisure and to consume alcohol in restaurants, bars and taverns.
tso: kungava leswaku sweswi hi pfumeleriwile ku hlanga na na vanghana na ndyangu, ku endzela tindhawu to hungasela, ku endzela ku ya wisa na ku nwa byalwa ema vhengeleni ya swakudya, tibara na swipotso.

eng: but as the old adage goes, just because you can, doesn’t mean you should.
tso: kambe tanihi loko xivuriso xi vula, hikuva u nga endla, a swi vuli leswaku u fanele u endla.

eng: many people who have the coronavirus do not have symptoms and may not even know they are infected.
tso: vanhu vo tala lava va nga na khoronavhayirasi a va na swikombeto naswona va ngava va nga switivi na leswaku yi va tlulerile.

eng: this is a sobering reality because it means that any of us could be infected right now and could unwittingly infect others.
tso: lowu i ntiyiso wa nkoka hikuva swi vula leswaku un’wana na un’wana wa hina a nga tluleriwa sweswi naswona a nga tluleta van’wana a nga switivi.

eng: this is particular the case when visiting relatives, especially the elderly and those with preexisting medical conditions that render them vulnerable to infection.
tso: leyi i mhangu ya loko hi endzela maxaka, ngopfu ngopfu vadyuhari na lava va nga na swiyimo swa ma vabyi man’wana lama ma va endlaka leswaku vava va nga hlayisekanga eka ntluletovuvabyi.

eng: it is also true for attending religious services or cultural activities.
tso: swi tlhela swi va ntiyiso eka ku ya eka tihlengeletano ta vukhongeri na mitlangu ya ndhavuko.

eng: the ‘second wave’ of infections that several other countries have experienced is an everpresent possibility for us too.
tso: ‘gandlati ra vumbirhi’ ra mitluletovuvabyi leyi matiko yo hlaya ya nga hlangana na yona hi leswi swi nga hi humelelaka na hina.

eng: although many restrictions have been lifted, it does not mean they will not return should we experience a significant rise in infections.
tso: hambileswi ku aleriwa ko tala ku nga tlakusiwa, a swi vuli leswaku a swi nga vuyeli loko ho humeleriwa hi ku tlakuka swinene ka mitluletovuvabyi.

eng: this pandemic is a matter of life and death.
tso: ntungu kulu lowu i mhaka ya ku fa na ku hanya.

eng: we need to adapt and we need to be vigilant.
tso: hi fanele ku tekelela naswona hi fanele ku hiteka.

eng: in the days, weeks and months that lie ahead, we must urgently focus our efforts on recovery.
tso: eka masiku, mavhiki na tin’hweti leti taka, hi fanele ku hatlisa hi kongomisa mi gingiriko ya hina eka ku hola.

eng: our economy and our society has suffered a great deal.
tso: ikhonomi ya hina na vaaki va xanisekile swinene.

eng: as we return to economic activity across almost all industries – and work to repair the damage done – we have a responsibility to not let our guard down as individuals, employers, communities, families, professionals, workers and citizens.
tso: tanihi loko hi tlhelela eka migingiriko ya ikhonomi eka tiindhasitiri to tala – naswona hi tirha ku lunghisa laha ku nga onhaka – hi na vutihlamuleri bya kuva hi nga ti khomisi tingana tanihi vanhu, vathori, miganga, mindyangu, vatokoti, vatirhi na vaakatiko.

eng: none of us wants a return to the early days of extreme lockdown restrictions.
tso: kuhava na un’we wa hina a lavaka ku tlhelela eka masiku ya masungulo ya kualeriwa lokukulu eka ku pfaleriwa.

eng: we want to move on with our lives.
tso: hi lava kuya emahlweni na vutomi bya hina.

eng: we want our friends and loved ones to remain healthy and safe.
tso: hi lava leswaku va nghana na varhandziwa va hina va tshama va hanye kahle na ku hlayiseka.

eng: as a nation, let us continue to work together to ensure that we progress.
tso: tanihi rixaka, a hi yeni emahlweni hi tirha kun’we ku tiyisisa leswaku hi ya emahlweni.

eng: the move to alert level 2 of the lockdown is not a ‘free for all.’ the rules on social distancing, mask wearing, social gatherings and international travel remain.
tso: ku ya eka le vhele ya vulemukisi ya 2 ya ku pfaleriwa a hi swa ‘maha la eka hinkwaswo.’ milawu eka ku siya pfhuka exikarhi ka vanhu, ku ambala xipfa laxikadza, tihlengeletano ta vanhu na ku endzela matiko ma le handle a swi se pfume leriwa.

eng: our success rests on our ability to abide by these regulations and to ensure that we each behave carefully and responsibly.
tso: ku humelela ka hina ku le ka vuswikoti bya hina bya ku landzelela swinawana na ku tiyisisa leswaku hi tikhoma kahle na hi vutihlamuleri.

eng: every time we are considering any form of nonessen tial activity, we should ask: what is the risk of infection to ourselves and to others?
