tso: eka nkarhi lowu hinkwawo wa nkavanyeto lowukulu, hi ta va hi nga ti endleli swa kahle loko hi endla switshe mbiso swo ka swi nga hume leriseki leswi swi tlakusaka ku langutela, ntsena ku tlhela hi kayivela loko swi nga humeleli.

eng: this is why each of the jobs and livelihood support interventions is fully funded, with a clear implementation plan.
tso: leswi hi swona swi endlaka leswaku wun'wana na wun'wana wa mitirho leyi na miphalalo ya nseketelo wa vutihanyisi swi nyikiwa timali hi ku hetiseka, hi kungu ra nsimeko leri nga erivaleni.

eng: the employment stimulus is not about vague commitments for some time in the future, but about jobs being created right here and now.
tso: xihlohloteri lexa mitirho a xi hi mayelana na vutiboheleri byo ka byi nga twisiseki eka nkarhinyana lowu taka, kambe xi hi mayelana na ku tumbuluxiwa ka mitirho eka nkarhi wa sweswi.

eng: the stimulus is the result of extensive consultation with national departments, provinces and metros to rapidly design employment pro grammes that can be rolled out or expanded within six months.
tso: xihlohloteri lexi i mbuyelo wa ku burisana ko angarhela swinene na tindzawulo ta rixaka, ta swifundzakulu na ta madorobakulu ku tumbuluxa hi ku hatlisa minongonoko ya mitirho leyi yi nga simekiwaka kumbe ku ndlandlamuxiwa ku nga si hundza tin'hweti ta tsevu.

eng: the implementing departments and other stakeholders were rigorously assessed on their capacity to implement.
tso: tindzawulo to tirhisa na vakhomaxiave van'wana swi kambisisiwile hi vukheta eka vuswikoti bya swona bya ku tirhisa.

eng: in every one of the programmes that fall under the stimulus, opportunities will be widely advertised and recruitment will be fair, open and transparent.
tso: eka wun'wana na wun'wana wa minongonoko leyi yi welaka ehansi ka xihlohloteri lexi, swivandlanene swi ta navetisiwa naswona ku thola swi ta va leswinene, swo pfuleka na ku tlhela swi va erivaleni.

eng: the goals we have set ourselves are realistic, measura ble and achievable, and draw lessons from past experience and international best prac tice.
tso: swikongomelokulu leswi hi nga tivekela swona swi humeleriseka, swa pimeka na ku fikeleleka, naswona hi nga dyondza kusuka eka ntokoto wa nkarhi lowu nga hundza na maendlelo ya kahle ya matiko ya misava.

eng: our people are ready and willing to work.
tso: vanhu va ka hina va lulamerile naswona va tsakela ku tirha.

eng: this vast potential must be harnessed, and our collective skills and capabilities brought to bear in rebuilding our country in the wake of the coronavirus.
tso: vuswikoti lebyo hambanahambana byi boheka ku tirhisiwa, na swikili swa nhlanganelo na vuswikoti swi tirhisiwa eka ku aka hi vu ntshwa tiko ra ka hina eka ku tumbuluka ka khoronavhayirasi.

eng: the presidential employment stimulus provides a respite for families who have endured a long hard winter with greatly reduced income, and for individuals who have spent many years without work.
tso: xihlohloteri xa mitirho xa phuresidente xi nyika ku wisanyana eka mindyangu leyi yi nga tiyisela vuxika byo tika no leha hi malinghena leyi hungutiweke swinene, na le ka vanhu hi un’weun’we lava va nga tshama malembe yo tala va nga tirhi.

eng: real, decent work is the right of every human being.
tso: ntirho wa kahle, wa xiviri i mfanelo ya munhu un'wana na un'wana.

eng: avoid becoming a human trafficking victim silusapho nyanda as the number of human trafficking cases being reported increases, it is important that you take steps to ensure your safety.
tso: papalata ku va muxanisiwa wa ngungumeriso wa vanhu silusapho nyanda tanihi laha nhlayo ya milandzu ya ngungumeriso wa vanhu leyi mangariwaka yi tlakukaka, swi na nkoka leswaku u teka magoza ya ku tiyisisa vuhlayiseki bya wena.

eng: to avoid becoming a victim of trafficking, you should avoid travelling alone at night or on deserted streets.
tso: ku papalata ku va muxanisiwa wa ngungumeriso u fanele ku papalata ku fambafamba u ri wexe, navusiku, kumbe ku famba eka switarata leswi nga tirhisiweki.

eng: it is important that you are aware of your surroundings at all times.
tso: swi na nkoka leswaku u twisisa ndhawu leyi u nga eka yona mikarhi hinkwayo.

eng: being alert will help spot something that is out of place.
tso: ku va u lemuka swi ta ku pfuna ku vona leswi swi nga tshamisekangiki.

eng: if you notice a person or a car following you, find a crowded place and contact the police or someone you trust immediately.
tso: loko u vona munhu kumbe movha wu ku landzelela, kuma ndhawu leyi nga tala vanhu u foyinela maphorisa kumbe munhu loyi u n'wi tshembhaka hi xihatla.

eng: traffickers often use the promise of a job to kidnap their victims and will approach potential victims offering them a job or some kind of opportunity.
tso: vangungumerisi va tala ku tirhisa xitshembhiso xa ntirho ku tlhakisa vaxanisiwa va vona naswona va ta tshinelela vaxanisiwa va vona ku va nyika ntirho kumbe swin'wana.

eng: this form of trafficking can happen anywhere – even on social media, at school, in the mall and outside your house.
tso: ndlela leyi ya ku ngungumerisa yi nga humelela kun'wana na kun'wana na le ka vuhlanganisi bya vanhu, exikolweni, emolweni na le handle ka yindlu ya wena.

eng: make sure you conduct thorough research on potential employers before going to meet them in person for interviews.
tso: tiyisisa leswaku u endla vulavisisi hi vuenti hi vathori u ngasi ya hlangana na vona hi nyama ku endla nkambelovutivi.

eng: this can be done by verifying that the company really exists by checking with the companies and intellectual property commission.
tso: leswi swi nga endliwa hi ku kambisisa leswaku khamphani yi kona hi ku kamba eka khomixini ya tikhamphani na nhundzu yo ka yi nga khomeki hi mavoko.

eng: you should also tell some one you trust when you are going to an interview and arrange for them to call you after a certain amount of time.
tso: naswona u fanele ku byela un'wana loyi u n'wi tshembhaka loko u ya eka nkambelovutivi u tlhela u kombela leswaku a ku foyinela endhaku ka nkarhi wo karhi.

eng: if possible, have someone go with you.
tso: loko swi koteka, famba na un'wana.

eng: be careful when using social media, especially when a stranger offers to help, offers money, a place to stay or a job opportunity in response to something you posted.
tso: vana na vukheta loko u tirhisa vuhlanganisi bya vanhu, ngopfu ngopfu loko munhu loyi u nga n'wi tiviki a tinyiketela ku ku pfuna, ku pfuna hi mali, ndhawu yo tshama kumbe ntirho hi ku hlamula leswi u nga swi tsala.

eng: if you are going out to meet someone new, do so at a public place and let someone you trust know where you are.
tso: loko u ya hlangana na munhu wuntshwa, endla tano endhawini ya mani na mani naswona u byela un'wana loyi u n'wi tshembhaka leswaku a tiva laha u nga kona.

eng: when going out with children, keep them close and make sure you can see them at all times.
tso: loko u huma na vana, tshama kusuhi na vona naswona u tiyisisa leswaku u kota ku va vona minkarhi hinkwayo.

eng: you should never send a child on an errand without a trusted adult to watch over them.
tso: u nga tshuki u rhuma n'wana a nga ri na munhu lonkulu loyi a tshembhekaka ku n'wi languta.

eng: recovery on the horizon for sa vukuzenzele unnamed the jacaranda trees are in full bloom across the nation’s capital, heralding the start of summer.
tso: nhlakarhelo wa vonaka evugimamusi bya afrikadzonga vukuzenzele unnamed mijakaranda yi le ku balekeni swi luva hi vutalo entsindza wa tiko, yi komba masungulo ya ximumu.

eng: after a long and difficult winter, the beginning of a new season should fill us with optimism.
tso: endzhaku ka xixika lexo leha na ku tika, masungulo ya nguva yintshwa ya hi xarha hi ntshembo wa leswi nene.

eng: when the national state of disaster was declared in march, our immediate priority was to contain the spread of the virus and provide emergency relief to citizens, communities, workers and businesses.
tso: loko xiyimo xa rixaka xa mhangu xi tivisiwa hi nyenyankulu, xirhangana xa hina xa xihatla a ku ri ku kamanyeta ku hangalaka ka xitsongwatsongwana lexi na ku nyika mphalalo wa xilamulelamhangu eka vaaka tiko, miganga, vatirhi na ma bindzu.

eng: over the course of eight months and with the support of our social partners, we rolled out a comprehensive set of measures to limit the social and economic impact of the pandemic.
tso: eku fambeni ka nhungu wa tin'hweti na hi nseketelo wa vatirhisani lava nga na xi nakulobye, hi simeke xikatsa xo katsakanya xa magoza ku hunguta nkhumbo wa vanhu na ikhonomi wa ntungukulu lowu.

eng: we massively expanded social protection on a scale that has never been attempted before in this country.
tso: hi ndlandlamukise hi mpimo lowukulu nsirhelelo wa vanhu hi xikalu lexi xi nga si tshamaka xi ringetiwa etikweni leri.

eng: we are one of the few countries in the world where the right of access to social security is enshrined in the constitution, and we can be proud that during this grave crisis we gave practical expression to this right in many ways.
tso: hi rin'wana ra matiko mangarimangani emisaveni laha mfanelo ya mfikelelo wa nsirhelelo wa vaaki wu sirheleriweke eka vumbiwa, naswona hi nga tinyungubyisa leswaku hi nkarhi wa xirilo lexi hi hume lerise mfanelo leyi hi tindlela to tala.

eng: in addition to our existing social grants, which reach more than 17 million people every month, we toppedup the old age, disability and child support grants.
tso: hi ku engetela eka timali ta nhlayiso wa vaaki leti nga kona, hi fikelela kutlula 17 wa timiliyoni ta vanhu n'hweti yin'wana na yin'wana, hi enge tele midende ya vadyuhari, vatsoniwa na vana.

eng: we rolled out a special coronavirus disease (covid19) social relief of distress grant, which has reached some six million people to date.
tso: hi simeke timali ta nhlayiso ta mpha lalo wa vaaki wa ( covid19) wo hlawuleka ta ntshikelelo, leti ti fikeleleke ntsevu wa timiliyoni ta vanhu kutafika sweswi.

eng: this was done within weeks of the national state of disaster being declared.
tso: leswi swi endliwile ku nga si hela mavhiki manga rimangani ya xiyimo xa rixaka xa mhangu lexi tivi siweke.

eng: the scale of such an undertaking cannot be understated.
tso: xikalu xa vutiboheleri byole byo xi nga ka xi nga tekeriwi ehansi.

eng: to bring this system online there was extensive collaboration between the south african social security agency, south african revenue service, home affairs and many others.
tso: ku endla leswaku sisiteme leyi yi kumeka eka inthanete ku vile na ntirhisano exikarhi ka ejensi ya timali ta nhlayiso wa vaaki ya afrikadzonga, vukorhokeri bya xibalo bya afrikadzonga, ti mhaka ta xikaya na van'wana vo tala.

eng: we set up a fully automated application and disbursement process, and integrated multiple databases, including the national population register and the unemployment insurance fund (uif) database.
tso: hi simeke xitirhisiwa lexi tilawulaka hi vutalo na phu rosese yo hakela, na tidatabe sinyingi leti pfanganisiweke, ku katsa na rhijisitara ra vanhu ra rixaka na databesi ya nkwama wa ndzindza khombo wa lava nga tirhiki (uif).

eng: we set up new application channels like whatsapp and ussd, and created systems with the commercial banks to enable banking detail verification.
tso: hi simeke tichanele to endla swikombelo eka tona tintshwa to fana na whatsapp na ussd, naswona hi tumbu luxe tisisiteme na tibangi ta swa bindzu ku endlela le swaku ku va na ntiyisiso wa vuxokoxoko byo banga.

eng: this is a remarkable achievement in a very short space of time.
tso: lowu i mfikelelo wo tivikana hi xinkadyana lexitsongo.

eng: alongside the measures we took to protect and sustain livelihoods, we also supported ailing businesses.
tso: ku fambisana na magoza lama hi ma tekeke ku sirhe lela na ku yisa emahlweni vutihanyisi, hi tlhele hi se ketela mabindzu lama a ma tikeriwa.

eng: we provided relief to small businesses in the form of debt relief, finance, tax payment deferrals and other instruments.
tso: hi nyike mphalalo eka mabindzu lamatsongo hi xivumbeko xa mphalalo wa swikweleti, timali na ku tlhelerisiwa endhaku ka tiha kelo ta xibalo na mitwanano yin'wana.

eng: we implemented a covid19 loan guarantee scheme to enable businesses to meet their operational expenses during the lockdown, and are currently looking at how this scheme can reach more companies in need.
tso: hi simeke xikimi xa ntiyi siso wa tiloni xa covid19 ku kotisa mabindzu ku fikelela swihakeleriwa swa wona swo tirha hi nkarhi wa ku pfale riwa, naswona eka nkarhi wa sweswi hi languta hilaha xikimi lexi xi nga kotaka ku fikelela hakona tikhamphani leti nga eku dingeni.

eng: we provided income protection to workers and relief to business owners through the temporary employer relief scheme administered by the uif.
tso: hi nyike nsirhelelo wa ma linghena eka vatirhi na mpha lalo eka van'wamabindzu hi ku tirhisa xikimi xa mphalalo wa vathori xa nkarhinyana lexi lawuriwaka hi uif.

eng: these were all in direct response to an emergency and were by nature temporary.
tso: leswi a ku ri angulo wo ko ngoma eka xilamulelamhangu naswona hi ntumbuluko a swi ri swa nkarhinyana.

eng: some are now coming to an end, while others have been extended as the labour market recovers.
tso: sweswi swin'wana swi le ku fikeni emakumu, kasi swin'wana swi ndlandlamukisiwile tani hiloko makete wa vatirhi wu ri karhi wu hlakarhela.

eng: the measures we implemented went a long way towards protecting our society from the harsh winds of covid19.
tso: magoza lama hi ma sime keke ma pfune swinene eka ku sirhelela rixaka ra ka hina eka mimoya ya tihanyi ya covid19 .

eng: the additional grants helped to prevent millions of people from falling below the food poverty line.
tso: timali ta nhlayiso to engetela ti pfune ku sivela ti miliyoni ta vanhu eka ku wela ehansi ka ntila wa vusweti bya swakudya.

eng: had we not intervened to secure livelihoods and save businesses, the living conditions of our people and the circumstances of thousands of businesses would have been considerably worse.
tso: loko a hi nga phalalangi ku sirhelela vutihanyisi na ku po nisa mabindzu, swiyimo swa ku hanya swa vanhu va ka hina na swiyimo swa magidi ma mabindzu a swi ta va swi nyanyile hi ndlela yo tivikana.

eng: now we are in a transition from relief to recovery.
tso: sweswi hi le ku cinceni ku suka eka mphalalo kuya eka nhlakarhelo.

eng: the emergency measures we put in place have laid a firm foundation on which to rebuild our economy.
tso: magoza ya xilamulela mhangu lama hi ma tekeke ma vumbile masungulo yo tiya lama hi faneleke ku aka ikhonomi ya hina hi vuntshwa ehenhla ka wona.

eng: as our focus now shifts to the implementation of the economic reconstruction and recovery plan, our priority will be to stimulate growth and create jobs.
tso: tanihileswi nkongomo wa hina sweswi wu cincelaka eka nsimeko wa kungu ra ku akiwa hi vuntshwa na nhlakarhelo wa ikhonomi, xirhangana xa hina xi ta va ku hlohlotela ku kula na ku tumbuluxa mitirho.

eng: there has already been progress in a number of areas.
tso: se ku vile na ndzima leyi khatsiweke eka swiyenge swo hlayanyana.

eng: we are seeing new funding commitments for infrastructure development following an infrastructure project roundtable last week.
tso: hi le ku voneni ka vutibo heleri bya ku nyika timali byintshwa eka nhluvukiso wa swimakiwakulu endzhaku ka nkanerisano wa phurojeke wa swimakiwakulu vhiki leri nga hundza.

eng: a number of employment programmes under the presidential employment stimulus have started.
tso: minongonoko ya mitirho yo hlayanyana ehansi ka xihlohloteri xa mitirho xa le hofisini ya phuresidente yi sungurile.

eng: we are pushing ahead with economic reforms in areas such as energy and telecommunications.
tso: hi le ku yeni emahlweni na mipfuxeto ya ikhonomi eka swiyenge swo tanihi eneji na vuhlanganisi bya swa tiqingho.

eng: plans are being converted to action and commitments are being reflected in jobs and opportunities.
tso: makungu ma le ku hundzu riweni ya swiendlo naswona vutiboheleri byi le ku kombi siweni eka mitirho na swiva ndlanene.

eng: it is all the more critical at this time, more so with the festive season approaching, that we do not become the architects of our own undoing.
tso: i swa nkoka swonghasi hi nkarhi lowu, ngopfungopfu leswi nguva ya makhisimusi yi tshinelaka, leswaku hi nga vi vapfapfarhutapulani va ku wa ka hina.

eng: the greatest vigilance is required from us all to keep the virus at bay.
tso: vuxiyaxiya lebyikulukumba bya laveka eka hina hinkwe rhu ku endlela leswaku xitsongwatsongwana lexi xi fambela ekule.

eng: a resurgence at any scale will not just dramatically reverse our health gains.
tso: ku tlakuka hi xikalu xihi kumbe xihi a swi nga to tlhe risela ntsena endzhaku hi ndlela yo hlamarisa mivuyelo ya hina ya swa rihanyu.

eng: it will choke the green shoots of economic recovery that have emerged, and take us back from spring to winter.
tso: swi ta vunisa matluka ya rihlaza ya nhlakarhelo wa ikhonomi lama ya hlukeleke, naswona swi ta hi tlherisela endzhaku kusuka eka ximun'wana kuya eka xixika.

eng: to prevent a second wave of covid19 infections, we must observe the public health guidelines that remain in place.
tso: ku sivela gandlati ra vumbi rhi ra mitluletavuvabyi ya covid19 , hi boheka ku la ndzelela swiletelo swa riha nyu swa vaaki leswi nga sala swi ri eku tirheni.

eng: when we fail to wear a mask at a social gathering, when we attend crowded events, we are not only putting ourselves and others at risk.
tso: loko hi hluleka ku ambala xipfalaxikandza eka nhlenge letano ya vaaki, loko hi ya eka swiendleko leswi nga tala vanhu, a ho veka ntsena hina na van'wana enxungetweni.

eng: we are also putting our economic recovery in jeopardy.
tso: kambe hi tlhela hi veka nhla karhelo wa ikhonomi ya hina ekhombyeni.

eng: let us all continue to play our part.
tso: a hi yeni emahlweni hi tirha xiphemu xa hina.

eng: the positive actions of wearing a mask, of maintaining social distancing and of regular hand washing helped us overcome the worst effects of the pandemic.
tso: swiendlo leswinene swa ku ambala xipfalaxikandza, swa ku siya mpfhuka exikarhi ka vanhu na ku hlamba swandla nkarhi na nkarhi swi hi pfune ku hlula switandzhaku swo biha kutlula mpimo swa ntu ngukulu lowu.

eng: healthdrink water to avoid dehydration allison cooper severe heat and not drinking enough fluids can lead to dehydration and heatstroke, which can be fatal.
tso: nwana mati ku papalata ku heleriwa hi mati emirini allison cooper ku hisa swinene na ku ka u nga nwi swihalaki swo ringanela swi nga vanga ku heleriwa hi mati emirini na xitiroku xo vangiwa hi ku hisa ngopfu ka miri, lexi xi nga tekaka vutomi.

eng: according to the western cape department of health, the summer heat brings with it a high risk of dehydration, which is a harmful loss of water in the body.
tso: ku ya hi ndzawulo ya swa rihanyu ya kapa vupeladyambu, ku hisa ka ximumu ku ta na nxungeto wa le henhla wa ku heleriwa hi mati emirini, leswi ku nga ku heleriwa hi mati emirini ko vava.

eng: dehydration is usually caused by not drinking enough liquids to replenish the water lost by sweating.
tso: ku heleriwa hi mati emirini hi xitalo swi vangiwa hi ku ka u nga nwi swihalaki ku tatisa mati lama ma nga hela hi ku juluka.

eng: it can also be caused by an illness, that causes vomiting or diarrhoea; and by sweating from a fever.
tso: swi nga tlhela swi vangiwa hi vuvabyi, lebyi byi vangaka ku hlanta na/kumbe nchuluko; na hi ku juluka loku vangiwaka hi ku hisa miri.

eng: the loss of body fluids does not only occur during hard physical activities, but can also result from walking, gardening or riding a bike, especially in hot or humid conditions.
tso: ku hela ka swihalaki swa miri a swi humeleli ntsena hi nkarhi wa migingiriko ya miri yo tika, kambe swi nga tlhela swi va mbuyelo wa ku famba, ku tirha exirhapeni kumbe ku khandziya bayisikiri, ngopfungopfu eka maxelo yo hisa kumbe ya nkahelo.

eng: when you are dehydrated, your body cannot function as usual.
tso: loko u heleriwile hi mati emirini, miri wa wena a wu nga tirhi tanihi hi ntolovelo.

eng: children younger than five, the elderly and people working outdoors are especially vulnerable to dehydration and heatstroke (a condition caused when your body overheats).
tso: vana va le hansi ka malembe ya ntlhanu, vadyuhari na vanhu lava va tirhelaka ehandle a va sirhelelekanga eka ku heleriwa hi mati emirini na xitiroku xo vangiwa hi ku hisa ngopfu ka miri (xiyimo lexi vangiwaka hi loko miri wa wena wu hisa ku tlula mpimo).

eng: heatstroke is a medical emergency.
tso: xitiroku xo vangiwa hi ku hisa ngopfu ka miri i xa vutshunguri bya xihatla.

eng: seek medical help immediately for any of these symptoms: feeling confused or your speech starts to become slow and unclear.
tso: kombela ku pfuniwa hi vutshunguri hi xihatla eka swikombeto swihi kumbe swihi swa leswi: ku titwa u kanganyiseka kumbe mbulavulo wa wena wu sungula ku nonoka na ku va wu nga twisiseki.

eng: nausea and vomiting.
tso: ku hlamba hi timbilu na ku hlanta.

eng: rapid, shallow breathing.
tso: ku hefemula hi ku hatlisa ko koma.

eng: heart starts to race.
tso: mbilu yi sungula ku ba hi ku hatlisa.

eng: a throbbing headache.
tso: ku pandziwa hi nhloko swinene.

eng: dehydration warning signssome of the early warning signs of dehydration include: feeling thirsty and lightheaded.
tso: swikombiso swa xitsundzuxo swa ku heleriwa hi mati emiriniswin'wana swa swikombiso swa xitsundzuxo swa ku heleriwa hi mati emirini swi katsa: ku twa torha na nsululwana.

eng: tiredness.
tso: ku karhala.

eng: having dark coloured, strongsmelling urine.
tso: ku va na mitsakamiso ya muhlovo wo byihala, wo nuha swinene.

eng: passing urine less often than usual.
tso: ku tshama u karhi u tsakamisa ku tlula ntolovelo.

eng: to stay hydrated and avoid heatstroke you should: drink more water than you usually do on hot days.
tso: ku tshama u ri na mati emirini na ku papalata xitiroku xo vangiwa hi ku hisa ngopfu ka miri u fanele ku: nwa mati yo tala ku tlula leswi u nwisaka swona hi ntolovelo hi masiku lama ku hisaka.

eng: stay inside or in shaded areas.
tso: tshama endzeni kumbe etindhawini leti nga na ndzhuti.

eng: wear a wide rim hat or use an umbrella.
tso: ambala xigqoko xo anama kumbe u tirhisa xambhulela.

eng: always carry a bottle of water with you and drink regularly.
tso: tshama u rhwele bodhlela ra mati u tlhela u nwa nkarhi na nkarhi.

eng: take regular breaks from the sun if you work outside.
tso: teka nkarhi wo wisa nkarhi na nkarhi u suka emun'wini loko u tirhela ehandle.

eng: cool yourself down by using a spray bottle.
tso: tiwisise hi ku tirhisa bodhlela ro fafazela.

eng: babies and childrenparents and caregivers should pay extra attention to children and babies, to make sure they are hydrated.
tso: tincece na vanavatswari na vahlayisi va fanele ku langutisisa swinene vana na tincece ku tiyisisa leswaku va na mati emirini.

eng: breastfeeding moms should feed their babies more frequently when it is very hot.
tso: vamanana lava mamisaka va fanele ku mamisa vana va vona nkarhi na nkarhi loko ku hisa.

eng: keep children indoors or in the shade, dress them in light clothing and wipe them down with a damp cloth to help them stay cool.
tso: tshamisani vana etindlwini kumbe endzhutini, va ambariseni swiambalo swo vevuka na ku va sula hi lapi ro tsakama ku endlela leswaku va tshama va ti twa kahle.

eng: remember to apply sunscreen when they go outdoors.
tso: tsundzukani ku va tota mafurha yo sivela dyambu loko va ya ehandle.

eng: if children younger than five have watery stools, keep vomiting and are tired, seek medical help immediately.
tso: loko vana va le hansi ka malembe ya ntlhanu va chuluka, va tshama va karhi va hlanta na ku karhala, kombela ku pfuniwa hi vutshunguri hi ku hatlisa.

eng: also seek immediate medical care if your baby is unable to breastfeed or has sunken eyes and a sunken soft spot (fontanelle) on its head.
tso: tlhela u kombela nhlayiso wa vutshunguri hi xihatla loko ricece ra wena ri tsandzeka ku mama kumbe ri ri na matihlo yo wela endzeni na ngoma yo wela endzeni (ngoma) enhlokweni ya rona.

eng: in children, other dehydration warning signs include: a dry or sticky mouth.
tso: eka vana, swin'wana swa swikombiso swa xitsundzuxo swi katsa: nomo wo oma na ku damarhela.

eng: few or no tears when crying.
tso: mihloti yintsongo kumbe ku pfumala mihloti loko va rila.

eng: urinating less or fewer wet nappies than usual.
tso: ku tsakamisa swintsongo kumbe malerhi matsongo mo tsakama ku tlula ntolovelo.

eng: dry, cool skin.
tso: nhlonge yo oma, na ku titimela.

eng: irritability.
tso: ku hlohlonyiwa.

eng: sa overcoming hiv and aids vukuzenzele unnamed as we continue our efforts to manage the devastating coronavirus pandemic, we cannot ignore the other public health challenges that our country faces.
tso: afrikadzonga yi hlula hiv na aids vukuzenzele unnamed loko hi ya emahlweni na matshalatshala ya hina yo lawula ntungu wa xitsongwatsongwana xa khorona lowu onhaka swinene, a hi nge papalati mintlhontlho ya swa rihannyu ra vaaki yin’wana leyi tiko ra hina ri kongomanaka na yona.

eng: for more than three dec ades, our country has been engaged in an ongoing struggle against hiv and aids, which has cost many lives and caused great hardship and suffering.
tso: ku tlula makumenharhu wa malembe, tiko ra hina ri nghenelele eka nkayankayo lowu yaka emahlweni wo lwisana na hiv na aids leyi nga koxa vutomi bya vanhu votala, naswona yi tise ku tikeriwa lokukulu na nhlupheko.

eng: since the outbreak of cov id19 in the country, with the nationwide lockdown and the pressure on our health facilities, many hiv , aids and tuberculosis services have suffered.
tso: kusukela loko ku tumbuluke covid19 etikweni, na ku pfa riwa ka tiko hinkwaro na ntshikelelo eka switirhisiwankulu swa hina swa rihanyu, vukorhokeri byotala bya hiv , aids na rifuva byi salele endzhaku.

eng: this has posed a challenge for people testing and starting antiretroviral treatment.
tso: leswi swi tise ntlhontlho eka vanhu lava kamberiwaka na ku sungula vutshunguri bya antirhithirovhayirali.

eng: many people found it difficult to collect their medicines and fewer people accessed other services, such as voluntary male medical circumcision.
tso: vanhu votala a va tikeriwa ku ya teka mirhi ya vona, naswona vanhu va nga ri vangani a va ﬁ kelela vukorhokeri byin’wana byo fana na ku yimba ngoma ya vaxinuna ya le xibedhlele hi ku tinyiketela.

eng: at the same time, there are many lessons that have been learnt from our public health response to the coronavirus pandemic that can strengthen our fight against hiv and tb.
tso: eka nkarhi lowu fanaka, ku na tidyondzo totala leti nga dyondziwa kusuka eka kuangula ka swa rihanyu ra vaaki eka ntungu wa xitsongwatsongwana xa khorona leti nga tiyisisaka ku lwisana ka hina na hiv na tb.

eng: south africa continues to have the largest number of people living with hiv in the world.
tso: afrikadzonga yi ya emahlweni yi ri na nhlayo ya le henhla swinene ya vanhu lava hanyaka na hiv emisaveni.

eng: it is encouraging, however, that over the last decade we made progress in reducing the number of new hiv infections in the population by nearly 60%.
tso: hambiswiritano, swi tiyisa nhlana ku tiva leswaku eka malembe ya khume lawa ma nga hundza, hi humelerile eka ku hunguta nhlayo ya mitlulelo ya hiv leyintshwa eka vanhu va tiko hi kwalomu ka 60 wa tiphesente.

eng: it is also encouraging that hiv infections in adolescent girls and young women have significantly declined in the last decade.
tso: swi tlhela swi tiyisa nhlana leswaku mitlulelo ya hiv eka vanhwanyana va kondloandzidyi na vamanana lavantshwa yi hunguteke swinene eka malembe ya khume lawa ma nga hundza.

eng: this is a crucial group because they are much more likely to be at risk of getting hiv .
tso: lowu i ntlawa wa nkoka swinene hikuva va tala ku va eka nxungeto wa ku kuma hiv .

eng: our treatment programme has contributed to a reduction in the number of deaths due to aids by 60%.
tso: nongonoko wa hina wa vutshunguri wu hoxe xandla eka ku hunguta nhlayo ya mafu hikwalaho ka aids hi 60 wa tiphesente.

eng: there has been a greater reduction in hivrelated deaths among young people.
tso: ku ve na ku hunguteka lokukulu eka mafu lawa ma fambelanaka na hiv exikarhi ka vanhu lavantshwa.

eng: it was possible to reduce the number of deaths because we, together with our partners, have rolled out an extensive antiretroviral programme reaching millions of people living with the disease.
tso: swi olovile ku hunguta nhlayo ya mafu hikuva hina hi ri swin’we na vanakulorhii va hina hi tirhise nongonoko wa antirhithorivhayirali lowukulu lowu nga fikelela timiliyoni ta vanhu lava va hanyaka na mavabyi lawa.

eng: at the beginning of the decade, our programme to prevent mother to child transmission (pmtct) of hiv had very low coverage.
tso: ekusunguleni ka malembe ya khume, nongonoko wa hina wa ku sivela ku tlulela kusukela eka manana kuya eka n’wana (pmtct) wa hiv a wu va nga na mfikelelo wa tindhawu to tala.

eng: now we have one of the highest rates of coverage of pmtct in southern africa, which has substantially reduced rates of infection among children.
tso: sweswi hi na mpimo wa le henhla swinene wa mﬁ kelelo wa tindhwau to tala wa pmtct edzongeni wa afrika lowu nga hunguta mpimo wa mitlulelo swinene exikarhi ka vana.

eng: while we have reduced deaths and new infections, we still are far from reaching the goal we committed ourselves in 2016 of achieving a 75% reduction in hiv infections by 2020. if we succeed in doing so, we are likely to end aids as a public health threat by 2030. unfortunately, we are not there yet.
tso: hambileswi hi nga hunguta mafu na mitlulelo leyintshwa, ha ha ri kule na ku fikelela xikongomelo lexi hi nga tiboha eka xona hi 2016 xa ku ﬁ kelela ku hunguta mitlulelo ya hiv hi 75 wa tiphesente hi 2020. loko ho humelela eka ku endla tano, hi nga swi kota ku herisa aids tanihi nxungeto wa swa rihanyu ra vaaki hi 2030. hi ku pfumala nkateko, a hi se fika.

eng: we have to do far more to ensure that young people are empowered to prevent infections, including through changing behaviour, accessing condoms and testing regularly.
tso: hi fanele hi tirha swinene ku vona leswaku vanhu lavantshwa va nyikiwa matimba ya ku sivela mitlulelo, ku katsa ku cinca matikhomelo, ku ﬁ kelela tikhondhomu na ku kamberiwa nkarhi na nkarhi.

eng: we need to make sure that everyone who is infected has access to treatment and care.
tso: hi fanele hi vona leswaku munhu wun'wana na wun'wana loyi a tluleriweke hi mavabyi u na mﬁ kelelo wa swa vutshunguri na vuhlayiseki.

eng: we need to work harder on hiv prevention among key populations, including sex workers, men who have sex with men, and people who inject drugs.
tso: hi fanele hi tirha hi nkhinkhi hi mayelana na ku sivela hiv exikarhi ka vanhu va tiko va nkoka, ku katsa lava xavisaka miri, vavanuna lava va endlaka timhaka ta swa masangu na vavanuna van’wana na vanhu lava va titlhavaka hi swidzidziharisi.

eng: we must end the stigma and discrimination towards these populations.
tso: hi fanele hi herisa nhlekulo na xihlawuhlawu eka vanhu lava va tiko.

eng: we cannot hope to end hiv if we ignore the needs, concerns and rights of any part of our population.
tso: a hi nge vi na ntshembo wo herisa hiv loko hi papalata swilaveko, swivilelo na timfanelo ta xiphemu xihi kumbe xihi xa vanhu va tiko ra hina.

eng: south africa needs to increase efforts to medically circumcise young men to reduce their risk of acquiring hiv .
tso: afrikadzonga yi fanele yi tlakusa matshalatshala ya ku yimbisa vavanuna lavantshwa exibedhlele ku hunguta nxu ngeto wa vona wa ku kuma hiv .

eng: unsafe circumcision should not leave young men with lifelong health problems, and no one should die from circumcision.
tso: ku yimba ko kala ku nga hlayisekanga a ku fanelanga ku siya vavanuna lavantshwa na swiphiqo swa rihanyu swa vutomi hinkwabyo, naswona a ku na munhu loyi a faneleke a lova hikwalaho ka ku yimba ngoma.

eng: we must make sure that young men have safe circumcision.
tso: hi fanele hi vona leswa ku vavanuna lavantshwa va yimba ngoma hi vuhlayiseki.

eng: we are encouraged by findings of a recent study on preexposure prophylaxis (prep).
tso: hi tiyisiwa nhlana hi leswi kumiweke hi vulavisisi lebyi bya ha ku endliwaka hi mayelana na preexposure prophylaxis (prep).

eng: unlike antiretroviral treatment that is given to people who are hiv positive, prep involves the regular use of antiretroviral drugs by hiv negative people to prevention infection.
tso: handle ka vutshunguri bya antirhithorivhayirali lebyi nyikiwaka vanhu lava va nga na hiv , prep yi khumba matirhiselo ya nkarhi na nkarhi ya tiphilisi ta antirhithorivhayirali eka vanhu lava nga hava hiv ku sivela ku tluleriwa.

eng: the study, conducted by scientists from the hiv prevention trials network, found that longacting injections once every eight weeks was better than the daily tablet used for hiv prevention.
tso: vulavisisi lebyi endliweke hi vativi va sayense vo huma eka netiweke yo ringeta ku sivela hiv va kume leswaku mitlhavelo leyi tirhaka nkarhi wo leha kan’we eka mavhiki ya nhungu man’wana na man’wana ya atswa ku tlula philisi leyi nwiwaka siku na siku ku sivela hiv .

eng: these findings have the potential to significantly strengthen our response to the epidemic.
tso: leswi kumiweke leswi swi na vuswikoti bya ku tiyisisa ku angula ka hina eka ntungukulu.

eng: if we are to succeed in ending aids as a public health threat within the next decade, we need to combine these medical breakthroughs with fundamental changes in behaviour.
tso: loko hi ta humelela eka ku herisa aids tanihi nxungeto wa swa rihanyu ra vaaki eka malembe ya khume lawa ma landzelaka, hi fanele hi hlanganisa ku humelela loku ka swa vutshunguri na ku cinca ka nkoka ka matikhomelo.

eng: we also need to tackle the economic and social conditions that contrib ute to high rates of infection.
tso: swi lava hi tlhela hi lwisana na swiyimo swa ikhonomi na matshamelo ya vaaki leswi hoxaka xandla eka mpimo wa le henhla wa mitlulelo.

eng: one of our central tasks is to empower adolescent girls and young women, educationally, economically and socially.
tso: mitirho yin’wana ya hina ya nkoka i ku nyika vanhwanyana va kondloandzidyi na vamanana lavantshwa matimba ya swa dyondzo, swa ikhonomi na ku tihlanganisa na vanhu van’wana.

eng: they need to be able to make their own decisions about every aspect of their lives, including their sexuality and sexual behaviour.
tso: va fanele va kota ku titekela swiboho swa vona hi mayelana na xiyenge xihi kumbe xihi xa vutomi bya vona, ku katsa swa masangu na matikhomelo ya vona eka swa masangu.

eng: ultimately, we will achieve the end of aids through the empowerment of young people, women and other people at risk.
tso: emakumu, hi ta fikelela ku herisiwa ka aids hi ku nyika vanhu lavantshwa, vamanana na vanhu van’wana lava nga le ka nxungeto matimba.

eng: this includes empowerment through access to information, advice and support.
tso: leswi swi katsa ku nyika matimba hi ku tirhisa mﬁ kelelo eka mahungu, switsundzuxo na nseketelo.

eng: it includes access to education and economic opportunities, especially for young women.
tso: leswi swi katsa mﬁ kelelo eka swivandlanene swa dyondzo na swa ikhonomi, ngopfungopfu vamanana lavantshwa.

eng: another chance to get your matric cathy grosvenor it is never too late to get your matric or to achieve the results you want, is the message behind the department of basic edu cation’s (dbe) second chance matric support programme.
tso: nkarhi wun'wana wa ku kuma matiriki ya wena cathy grosvenor a swi nge tshuki swi hlwerile ku kuma matiriki ya wena kumbe ku fikelela mivuyelo lowu u wu lavaka, i hugura nongonoko wa nsekete lo wa nkarhi wa vumbirhi wa matiriki wa ndzawulo ya dyondzo ya masungulo (dbe).

eng: director of the programme, dr sandy malapile, says a matric qualification is an absolute necessity because without it, many doors of opportunity remain closed.
tso: mufambisi wa nongonoko, dkd sandy malapile, u vula leswaku nthwaso wa ka matiriki i xilaveko hakunene hikuva loko wu nga ri kona, tinyangwa to tala ti tshama ta ha pfalekile.

eng: "sector training and education authorities (setas), tasked with upskilling the nation through skills programmes and apprenticeships, also require that candidates have a matric," says dr malapile.
tso: "vulawuri bya sekitara ya dyondzo na ndzetelo (tiseta), byi nyikiwile ntirho wo dyondzisa rixaka swikili swo engetela hi ku tirhisa minongonoko ya swikili na mitirhodyondzo, na ku tlhela byi lava leswaku mukamberiwa a va na matiriki," ku vula dkd malapile.

eng: launched in january 2016, the second chance programme supports anyone – of any age – who wants to achieve or improve a matric qualification, subjectbysubject and on a parttime basis.
tso: nongonoko wa nkarhi wa vumbirhi lowu simekiweke hi sunguti 2016, wu seketela munhu un'wana na un'wana – wa vukhale byihi kumbe byihi – loyi a lavaka ku fikelela kumbe ku antswisa nthwaso wa ka matiriki, dyondzo hi dyondzo na le ka xiphemu xa nkarhi.

eng: there are no costs involved.
tso: a ku na tihakelo leti lavekaka.

eng: people who want to im prove their matric results, whether they wrote matric recently or even decades ago.
tso: vanhu lava va lavaka ku antswisa mivuyelo ya vona ya ka matiriki, hambi va nga va va tsarile matiriki ya vona kungari khale kumbe malembexikhume lama nga hundza.

eng: dr malapile explains that a person wanting to obtain an engineering qualification, for in stance, might need to im prove their mathematics mark to qualify for the course.
tso: dkd malapile u hlamusela leswaku munhu loyi a lavaka ku fikelela nthwaso wa vuinjhiniyara, tanihi xikombiso, u ta dinga ku antswisa maraka ya metse ku fikelela khoso leyi.

eng: people who failed matric and want a second chance at passing.
tso: vanhu lava va nga feyila matiriki naswona va lava nkarhi wa vumbirhi wa ku pasa.

eng: people who left school after passing grade 9 (then standard 7), are 21 or older, and wish to obtain their matric.
tso: vanhu lava va nga tshika xikolo endzhaku ka ku pasa giredi ya 9 (leyi khale a yi ri ntangha 7), va nga na 21 kumbe kutlula, naswona va navelaka ku kuma matiriki ya vona.

eng: how to get startedregister at one of the 75 dis trict education offices across the country or online at this website: www.
tso: masungulelotsarisa eka yin'we ya tihofi si ta dyondzo ta xifundzatsongo ta 75 etikweni hinkwaro kumbe eka inthanete eka webusayiti leyi: www.

eng: eservices.
tso: eservices.

eng: gov.
tso: gov.

eng: za.
tso: za.

eng: registration opened on 1 october and will close in february 2021. learners either study on their own or at one of the 133 second chance centres where facetoface learning takes place afterhours and on weekends.
tso: ntsariso wu sungurile hi siku ra 1 nhlangula naswona wu ta pfala hi nyenyenyani 2021. vadyondzi va nga ha dyondza va ri voxe kumbe eka yin'we ya 133 ya tisenthara ta nkarhi wa vumbirhi laha ku dyondzisiwaka ku langutaniwile endzhaku ka nkarhi wa ntirho wa ntolovelo na hi mahele ya vhiki.

eng: dr malapile says only the top performing teachers in each district are employed at these centres.
tso: dkd malapile u vula leswaku ko va ntsena vadyondzisi lava va tirhaka kahle swinene eka xifundzatsongo xin'wana na xin'wana va thoriwaka eka tisenthara leti.

eng: the centres are not available in every town and village, but are located in areas where the greatest number of people have registered, which means their location could change each year.
tso: tisenthara a ti kumeki eka doroba na muganga wun'wana na wun'wana, kambe ti le ka tindhawu leti ti nga na nhlayo ya le henhla ya vanhu lava tsariseke leswi swi vulaka leswaku ndhawu ya vona yi nga cinca lembe rin'wana na rin'wana.

eng: both facetoface learners and learners who study at home have access to a full range of study support services, from lessons broadcast on radio and television at specific times; to downloadable online material; and, for those without access to computers, printers and the inter net−printed study material is sent to them by the dbe.
tso: havambirhi va vadyondzi va ku dyondzisiwa ku langutaniwile na vadyondzi lava va dyondzelaka ekaya va na mfikelelo wa vukorhokeri byo hetiseka bya nseketelo wa dyondzo, kusuka eka tidyondzotsongo leti haxiwaka eka rhadiyo na thelevhixini hi mikarhi yo karhi; kufika eka matheriyali wa le ka inthanete lowu dawunilodekaka; naswona, eka lava va nga kotiki ku fikelela tikhomphyuta, tipirintara na inthanete, matheriyali wo dyondza lowu pirintiweke eka inthanete wu rhumeriwa eka vona hi dbe.

eng: people with a computer but no internet or data, may request a cd with all the study material, which will be mailed to them.
tso: vanhu lava va nga na tikhomphyuta kambe va nga ri na inthanete kumbe data, va nga kombela cd leyi nga na matheriyali wo dyondza hinkwawo, lowu va nga ta poseriwa wona.

eng: "many adult learners may not have lots of time to devote to their studies.
tso: "vadyondzi lavakulu vo tala va nga ha va va nga ri na nkarhi wo tala ku tinyiketela eka tidyondzo ta vona.

eng: luck ily, they may decide how many subjects they want to do a year because they do not have to complete their matric within a set time.
tso: nkateko wa kona, va nga ha hlawula leswaku i tidyondzo tingani leti va lavaka ku ti endla hi lembe hikuva a va boheki ku heta matiriki ya vona hi nkarhi lowu pimiweke.

eng: "once registered, the dbe will help each older learner choose the subjects they want to do and explain which ones are compulsory.
tso: "loko u tsarisile, dbe yi ta pfuna mudyondzi lonkulu un'wana na un'wana ku hlawula tidyondzo leti a lavaka ku ti endla na kuhlamusela leswaku hi tihi leti bohaka.

eng: on qualifying, people who left school after 2008 receive a national senior certificate and those who left school earlier, receive an amended senior certificate.
tso: eka ku fikelela, vanhu lava va nga tshika xikolo endzhaku ka 2008 va ta kuma xitifikheti xa le henhla xa rixaka naswona lava va nga tshika xikolo ku nga si fika nkarhi lowu, va ta kuma xitifikheti xa le henhla lexi cinciweke.

eng: however, dr malapile says both qualifications carry the same weight and, depending on the subjects taken and marks achieved, can be used to apply to universities and colleges.
tso: hambiswiritano, dkd malapile u vula leswaku havumbirhi bya mithwa so byi na ntikelo wo ringana naswona, kuya hi tidyondzo leti tekiweke na timaraka leti kumiweke, yi nga tirhisiwa ku endla xikombelo etiyunivhesiti na le tikholichi.

eng: giving second chancesthe dbe holds community roadshows to encourage people to enrol for the second chance programme.
tso: ku nyika nkarhi wa vumbirhidbe yi khoma mapfhumba yo dyondzisa miganga ku hlohlotela vanhu ku tsarisela nongonoko wa nkarhi wa vumbirhi.

eng: tertiary education institutions and setas are invited to provide as much information as possible to interested people.
tso: mihlangano ya dyondzo ya le henhla na tiseta va rhambiwa ku ya nyika vuxokoxoko byo tala hilaha va kotaka hakona eka vanhu lava nga na ku tsakela.

eng: at many of these roadshows, minister angie mot shekga was asked by youth to introduce programmes that could assist young people to be more employable, says dr malapile.
tso: eka yo tala ya mapfhumba lamo dyondzisa miganga, holobye angie motshekga u komberiwile hi vantshwa ku sungula minongonoko leyi nga pfunaka vantshwa ku va va tholeka swinene, ku vula dkd malapile.

eng: in response, the dbe is launching a skills development programme this year that will target about 3.4 million young people who are not in employment, education or training.
tso: hi ku angula, dbe yi le ku simekeni ka nongonoko wo hluvukisa swikili lembe leri lowu wu nga ta kongoma 3.4 wa timiliyoni ta vantshwa lava va nga tirhiki, va nga riki ku dyondzeni kumbe va nga riki eka ndzetelo.

eng: courses will range from life skills – covering topics such as how to write a cv and what to do at a job interview; to basic skills courses, such as shoe repair, basic itc and literacy.
tso: tikhoso ti ta nava kusuka eka swikili hi swa vutomi – ti angarhela tinhlokomhaka to fana na matsalelo ya cv na leswi u faneleke ku swi endla eka nkambelovutivi wa ntirho; kufika eka tikhoso ta swikili swa masungulo, to fana na ku lunghisa tintangu, ict ya masungulo na litiresi.

eng: did you know?
tso: vxana a wu switiva?

eng: regardless of whether you left school in the 60s or recently, you have to study the current curriculum.
tso: swingakhathaleki leswaku u tshike xikolo hi va60 kumbe kungari khale, u fanele ku dyondza kharikhu lamu ya sweswi.

eng: a better 2021 for all south africans the first weeks of the year have been difficult for all south africans.
tso: 2021 yo antswa eka maafrikadzonga hinkwavomavhiki lamo sungula ya lembe a ma tika eka maafrikadzonga hinkwavo.

eng: vukuzenzele unnamed the coronavirus pandemic has gotten worse, with new infections increasing far faster and far higher than before.
tso: vukuzenzele unnamed ntungukulu wa khoronavhayirasi wu nyanyile, ku ri na mitluletavuvabyi leyintshwa leyi tlakukaka hi ku hatlisa swinene naswona yi ri ehenhla swinene kutlula leswi a swi ri xiswona eka nkarhi lowu nga hundza.

eng: hospitals have been under great strain as more people have needed medical attention.
tso: swibedhlele swi le hansi ka ntshikelelo lowukulukumba tanihileswi vanhu vo tala va dingaka vutshunguri.

eng: while most economic sectors have been able to operate again for several months, it will take some time for the economy to recover and for lost jobs to be restored.
tso: loko tisekitara tinyingi ti kotile ku tirha nakambe eka tin'hweti to talanyana.

eng: as the new year starts, many families are still feeling the effects of the pandemic on their lives and livelihoods.
tso: tanihiloko lembe ra ha sungula, mindyangu yo tala ya ha twa switandzhaku swa ntungukulu lowu eka vutomi na vutihanyisi bya yona.

eng: the world is now entering the second year of the coronavirus pandemic.
tso: sweswi misava yi le ku ngheneni eka lembe ra vumbirhi ra ntunguku lowu wa khoronavhayirasi.

eng: for south africa, as for most countries around the world, the year 2021 will be extremely challenging.
tso: eka afrikadzonga, tanihi le ka matiko manyingi emisaveni hinkwayo, lembe ra 2021 ri ta tlhontlha kutlula mpimo.

eng: the second wave of covid19 infections may well be followed by further waves, which will threaten both the health of our people and the recovery of our economy.
tso: gandlati lera vumbirhi ra mitluletavuvabyi ya covid19 ri nga ha landzeriwa hi magandlati man'wana, leswi swi nga ta xungeta havumbirhi bya rihanyu ra vanhu va ka hina na nhlakarhelo wa ikhonomi.

eng: difficult as this year will be, i am certain that we will overcome the pandemic and set our country firmly on the path to recovery.
tso: swi ri karhi swi tika tanihileswi lembe ri nga ta va xiswona, ndza tiyisa leswaku hi ta wu hlula ntungukulu lowu kutani hi veka tiko ra ka hina hi ndlela yo tiya eka ndlela ya nhlakarhelo.

eng: my confidence comes from the south african people.
tso: vutitshembi bya mina byi huma eka vanhu va afrikadzonga.

eng: if i look at how south africans responded to this crisis from the moment the virus arrived on our shores, i have no doubt that we have the resilience, discipline and ability to defeat this disease.
tso: loko ndzi languta hilaha maafrikadzonga va anguleke hakona eka nkitsinkitsi lowu kusukela hi xikandyana lexi xitsongwa tsongwana lexi xi fikeke haxona etibuweni ta ka hina, a ndzi na ku kanakana leswaku hi na nkondzelelo, vutikhomi na vuswikoti bya ku hlula vuvabyi lebyi.

eng: certainly there were exceptions, but the vast majority of south africans understood the need for restrictions on their movement and activities, and complied with the regulations that we had to put in place.
tso: hakunene a ku ri na leswi pfumeleriweke, kambe vunyingi lebyikulu bya maafrikadzonga byi twisise xidingo xa swipimelo eka mfambafambo na migingiriko ya vona, naswona byi landzelele swinawana leswi hi bohekeke ku swi veka.

eng: even more important than compliance, most south africans took responsibility for themselves and for others, following advice on issues like social distancing, wearing a mask and hand washing.
tso: hambi ku ri swa nkoka swinene kutlula ku landzelela, maafrikadzonga vanyingi va byarhe vutihlamuleri bya vona vini na bya van'wana, va landzelela switsundzuxo eka timhaka to fana na ku siya mfphuka exikarhi vanhu, va ambala xipfalaxikandza na ku hlamba swandla.

eng: and where we fell short, we have, sadly, seen the consequences.
tso: naswona laha hi kayiveleke kona, hi ndlela yo khomisa tingana, hi vonile switandzhaku.

eng: we now know about the risks of closed spaces and crowded gatherings, of not wearing masks and not keeping our distance from others.
tso: sweswi ha tiva hi mayelana na mixungeto ya tindhawu leti pfalekeke na tinhlengeletano leti nga tala vanhu, hi ku nga ambali swipfalaxikandza na ku nga siyi mpfhuka kusuka eka van'wana.

eng: this bodes well for the year ahead.
tso: leswi swi hlola leswinene elembeni leswa ha taka.

eng: we now know much more about the disease and how to prevent its spread.
tso: sweswi hi tiva swo tala swinene hi mayelana na vuvabyi lebyi na hilaha ku siveriwaka hakona ku hangalaka ka byona.

eng: and despite what one could call ‘pandemic fatigue’, we are no less determined as south africans to do what needs to be done.
tso: naswona hambileswi ku nga na leswi munhu a nga swi vulaka 'nkarhalo wa ntungukulu' a hi tiyimiselangi switsongo tanihi maafrikadzonga ku endla leswi swi dingaka ku endliwa.

eng: as we adhere even more rigorously to the basic prevention measures, we will also be rolling out a mass vaccination campaign.
tso: tanihiloko hi landzelela hambi hi ndlela ya vurhonwana swinene magoza yo sivela ya masungulo, hi ta tlhela hi simeka pfhumba ra nsawutiso wa xintshungu.

eng: as more and more people are vaccinated, we will both save lives and progressively reduce the risk of infection across the population.
tso: tanihiloko vanhu vo tala va ri karhi va sawutisiwa, havumbirhi hi ta ponisa vutomi na ku hunguta hi ndlela leyi yaka emahlweni nxungeto wa mitluletavuvabyi eka vanhu va rixaka hinkwavo.

eng: getting enough vaccines as quickly as possible – and making sure that they reach the people who need them – will be one of the biggest tasks of the year.
tso: ku kuma swisawutisi swo enela hi ku hatlisa hilaha swi kotekaka hakona na ku tiyisisa leswaku swi fikelela vanhu lava va swi dingaka swi ta va xin'wana xa swintirhwana leswikulukumba swa lembe.

eng: this will be particularly challenging as every country in the world is clamouring to secure a limited supply of vaccines.
tso: leswi swi ta va swi tlhontlha swinene tanihileswi tiko rin'wana na rin'wana emisaveni ri lavaka ku kuma mphakelo lowu pimiweke wa swisawutisi.

eng: but we are hard at work with partners in business, labour and civil society to make this happen.
tso: kambe hi le ku tirheni hi matimba na vatirhisani eka mabindzu, vatirhi na vaaki lava nga na ku tsakela kun'we ku endla leswi swi humelela.

eng: we are working on several fronts to get vaccines, including through the global covax facility, the african union initiative and through our own engagements with vaccine manufacturers.
tso: hi le ku tirheni eka matlhelo yo tlala ku kuma swisawutisi, ku katsa na hi ku tirhisa xitirhisiwa xa covax xa misava hinkwayo, pfhumba ra yuniyoni ya afrika na hi ku tirhisa mivulavurisano ya hina vini na vamaki va swisawutisi.

eng: as we act together to overcome the pandemic, we will need to work together to rebuild and transform our economy.
tso: loko hi tirhisana ku hlula ntungukulo lowu, hi ta dinga ku tirhisana ku aka hi vuntshwa na ku hundzuluxa ikhonomi ya hina.

eng: we have both the ability and the will to stimulate economic activity, grow our economy and create jobs.
tso: hi na havumbirhi bya vuswikoti na hiseko ku hlohlotela nghingiriko wa ikhonomi, ku kurisa ikhonomi ya hina na ku tumbuluxa mitirho.

eng: and to do so in the midst of a pandemic.
tso: na ku endla tano exikarhi ka ntungukulu.

eng: public finances are under extreme strain, now even more so because of the cost of our health response to covid19 and the social and economic relief measures we put in place to assist businesses and poor households.
tso: timali ta mfumo ti le hansi ka ntshikelelo lowukulu, sweswi swi nyanyisiwa hikwalaho ka ndhurho wa angulo wa hina wa swa rihanyu eka covid19 na magoza ya mphalalo wa vanhu na ikhonomi lama hi ma vekeke ku pfuneta mabindzu na miti leyi nga swela.

eng: the contraction of the economy also meant that tax revenue has declined significantly.
tso: nkhanyano wa ikhonomi wu tlhela wu vula leswaku mali ya xibalo yi ehlile hi ndlela yo tivikana.

eng: there are some parts of the economy that will take longer to recover due to lower global demand generally and restrictions on international travel.
tso: ku na swiphemu swin'wana swa ikhonomi leswi swi nga ta teka nkarhi wo leha swinene ku hlakarhela hikwalaho ka xikoxo xa misava hinkwavo xa le hansi hi ku angarhela na swipimelo eka tendzo ta matiko ya misava.

eng: that is why we need to be innovative and focused in our plans to rebuild the economy.
tso: leswi hi swona swi endlaka hi dinga ku va na maendlelo mantshwa na ku kongomisa eka makungu ya hina ya ku aka ikhonomi hi vuntshwa.

eng: significantly, the economic reconstruction and recovery plan that we announced in october last year is based on broad consensus among all social part ners on the actions needed to rebuild the economy.
tso: hi ndlela yo tivikana, kungu ro aka hi vuntshwa na nhlakarhelo wa ikhonomi leri hi ri tiviseke hi nhlangula n'wexemu ri simekiwile eka ntwanano wo angarhela exikarhi ka vatirhisani va vaaki eka magoza lama dingiwaka ku aka hi vuntswha ikhonomi leyi.

eng: this lays a firm basis for effective cooperation that draws on the resources, capabilities and energies of all sections of society.
tso: leswi swi vumba masungulo yo tiya ya ntirhisano lowu tirhaka kahle lowu wu tswongaka eka swipfuno, vuswikoti na matimba kusuka eka swiyenge hinkwaswo swa rixaka.

eng: we are seeing this in various practical ways.
tso: hi le ku voneni ka leswi hi tindlela leti endlekaka to hambanahambana.

eng: for example, we have been working closely with private funders and multilateral development institutions to prepare infrastructure projects in areas like transport, human settlements, water and telecommunications.
tso: tanihi xikombiso, hi vile hi ri eku tirhisaneni na vanyikatimali lava nga riki va mfumo na mihlangano ya nhluvukiso ya matikonyingi ku lulamisa tiphurojeke ta swimakiwakulu eka swiyenge swo fana na vutleketli, vutshamiso bya vanhu, mati na vuhlanganisi bya swa tiqingho.

eng: using the infrastructure fund as one of the vehicles, we are developing funding models for these projects that draw on several sources in both the public and private sectors.
tso: hi ku tirhisa nkwama wa swimakiwakulu tanihi yin'wana ya tindlela leti, hi le ku hluvukiseni ka timodlolo to nyika timali ta tiphurojeke leti ti tswongaka eka swihlovo swo hlayanyana eka havumbirhi bya tisekitara ta mfumo na leti nga riki ta mfumo.

eng: this is particularly important at a time when public finances are limited.
tso: leswi i swa nkonka swinene hi nkarhi lowu timali ta mfumo ti nga tsongahala.

eng: the presidential employment stimulus is another example of partnership in action.
tso: xihlohloteri xa mitirho xa le hofisini ya phuresidente i xikombiso xin'wana xa xinakulobye lexi nga eku tirheni.

eng: understanding that it will take time for economic growth to translate into private sector employment, we have launched the employment stimulus to start creat ing work opportunities now.
tso: ku twisisa leswaku swi ta teka nkarhi leswaku ku kula ka ikhonomi ku hundzuka mitirho ya sekitara leyi nga riki ya mfumo, hi simekile xihlohloteri xa mitirho ku sungula ku tumbuluxa swivandlanene swa mitirho sweswi.

eng: this programme is being coordinated from the presiden cy, but is being implemented by a range of government departments and different spheres.
tso: nongoloko lowu wu le ku tirhisanisiweni kusuka eka hofisini ya phuresidente, kambe ku le ku simekiweni hi tindzawulo ta mfumo to hambanahambana na swiyenge swo hambanahambana.

eng: through this programme, tens of thousands of unemployed people are able to both earn and learn as they provide valuable social services.
tso: hi ku tirhisa nongoloko lowu, vakhume va migidi va vanhu lava nga tirhiki va kota havumbirhi bya ku hola na ku dyondza tanihileswi wu nyikaka vukorhokeri bya swa vanhu bya nkoka.

eng: in time, this programme will include a ‘social employment’ part, where we will partner with other social actors to employ people in a variety of activities – from improving food security, to tackling genderbased violence to upgrading informal settlements – that all contribute to the common good.
tso: hi nkarhi, nongoloko lowu wu ta katsa xiphemu xa 'ku thoriwa ka vanhu', laha hi nga ta tirhisana na vatekaxiave xa vanhu ku thola vanhu eka migingiriko yo hambanahambana kusuka eka nsirhelelo wa swakudya, kufika eka ku tirhana na madzolonga yo ya hi rimbewu ku antswisa vutshamiso lebyi nga riki bya ximfumo leyi yi hoxaka xandla eka ku vuyerisa vanhu hinkwavo.

eng: all this work is being reinforced by an aggressive focus on those economic reforms that will have the greatest focus on growth.
tso: ntirho lowu hinkwawo wu le ku tiyisisiweni hi nkongomo wa vurhena eka miantswiso liya ya ikhonomi leyi yi nga va na nkongomo lowukulukumba eka ku kula.

eng: these include the expansion of electricity generation capacity, making our ports more efficient and competitive, improving access to affordable broadband, and improving turnaround times for water, mining and other licenses.
tso: leswi swi katsa ndlandlamukiso wa vuswikoti byo endla gezi, ku endla tinhlaluko ta hina ti tirha hi ku hatlisa na ku va leti phikizanaka, ku antswisa mfikelelo wa netiweke yo chipa, na ku antswisa mikarhi yo heta ku phurosesa tilayisense ta swa mati, ta swa vucelamigodi na tin'wana.

eng: these efforts are being coordinated and monitored jointly by my office and national treasury.
tso: matshalatshala lama ma le ku tirhisanisiweni na ku vekiwa tihlo hi hofisi ya mina na vutamelankwama bya rixaka.

eng: there is much to be done in the year ahead.
tso: ku na swo tala leswi faneleke ku endliwa elembeni leswa ha taka.

eng: and we should be in no doubt that we will have to confront many daunting challenges.
tso: naswona a hi fanelangi ku kanakana leswaku hi ta boheka ku jamelana na mitlhontlho leyo tika yo tala.

eng: but we have shown that, as a nation, we are able to succeed when we work together in pursuit of a common purpose.
tso: kambe hi kombisile leswaku, tanihi rixaka, ha swi kota ku humelela loko hi tirhisana eka ku hlongorisa xikongomelo xo fana.

eng: if we remember that, and if we put our unity into action, we will ensure that 2021 brings better health and better lives to all our people.
tso: loko hi tsundzuka leswaku, na loko hi tirhisa vun'we bya hina, hi ta tiyisisa leswaku 2021 yi tisa rihanyu ro antswa na vutomi byo antswa eka vanhu va ka hina hinkwavo.

eng: parenting a child with epilepsy allison cooper while it may be a shock for a family to learn that a child has epilepsy, you can build an understanding, loving and accepting environment in which your child can grow and believe in their ability to succeed.
tso: ku kurisa n’wana loyi a nga na switshetshela allison cooper hambiloko swi nga ha va xihlamariso eka ndyangu ku thumba leswaku n’w ana u na switshetshela, u nga vumba ntwisiso, rirhandzu na ku amukela mbangu lowu n’wana wa wena a kulaka eka wona na ku tshemba eka vuswikoti bya yena bya ku humelela.

eng: according to epilepsy south africa, parents could be concerned about their child’s future and find epilepsy difficult to accept or talk about.
tso: hi ku ya hi nhlangano wa switshetshela wa afrikadzonga, vatswari va nga vilerisiwa hi mayelana na vumundzuku bya n’wana wa vona na ku kuma switshetshela swi tika ku swi amukela kumbe ku vulavula hi swona.

eng: you may feel angry, depressed, inadequate and guilty, but you can overcome these feelings and your anxiety by educating yourself about the condition.
tso: u nga titwa u hlundzukile, u tshikelelekile, u nga enerisekangi na ku tivona nandzu, kambe u nga kota ku hlula matitwelo lama na nchavo hi ku tidyondzisa hi mayelana na xiyimo lexi.

eng: epilepsy is the tendency to have recurrent seizures, which occur when there is an abnormal electrical discharge in the brain.
tso: switshetshela i mbhulo wa ku va na mitlumbeko leyi vuyelelaka, leyi yi humelelaka loko ku ri na ku humesiwa ka gezi loku nga tolovelekangiki ebyongweni.

eng: why my child?
tso: hikwalahokayini n’wananga?

eng: understanding epilepsy and why seizures occur doesn’t explain why this happened to your child.
tso: ku twisisa switshetshela na leswaku hikwalahokayini mitlumbeko yi humelela a swi hlamuseli leswaku hikwalahokayini leswi swi humelela eka n’wana wa wena.

eng: in approximately 66% of cases, the underlying cause of epilepsy is unknown.
tso: eka kwalomu ka 66% ta timhangu, xivangelo lexi tumbeleke xa switshetshela a xi tiveki.

eng: this is referred to as idiopathic epilepsy.
tso: leswi swi vuriwa switshetshela swa xivangelo lexi nga tivekiki.

eng: in the remaining cases the underlying causes can be identified, which is known as symptomatic epilepsy.
tso: eka timhangu leti nga sala, swivangelo leswi tumbeleke swi nga kumeka, leswi swi tivekaka tanihi switshetshela leswi nga na swikombeto.

eng: there can be a variety of underlying causes such as a head injury, that can occur at any age; a birth injury, such as a lack of oxygen during birth; fever convulsions, encephalitis, meningitis or childhood measles; and metabolic or biochemical disturbances or imbalances.
tso: ku nga va na muxaka wa swivangelo leswi tumbeleke swo tanihi ku vaviseka ka le nhlokweni, loku ku nga humelelaka eka malembe hi vukhale wahi kumbe wahi; ku vaviseka eku velekiweni, ko tanihi ku pfumaleka ka moyatenga hi nkarhi wa ku velekiwa, milombyana ya ku hisa miri, mpfimbabyongo, mpfimbo wa nkuva wa byongo kumbe ximungwamungwana xa vutsongwana; mikavanyeto kumbe mikandzingano ya mpfuvelaseleni kumbe bayokhemikali.

eng: a doctor will prescribe medication based on the age, physical condition and type of seizures your child has.
tso: dokodela u ta lawulela mirhi hi ku ya hi malembe hi vukhale, xiyimo xa le mirini na muxaka wa mitlumbeko leyi n’wana wa wena a nga na yona.

eng: remember, anticonvulsant medication does not cure epilepsy but, in most cases, will reduce the frequency and severity of seizures.
tso: tsundzuka, murhi wo lwisana na milombyana a wu horisi switshetshela, kambe eka swiyimo swinyingi, wu ta hunguta mbuyelelo na ku tika ka mitlumbeko.

eng: some tips on parenting a child with epilepsy: make your child aware of the condition.
tso: switsundzuxo swin’wana hi ku kurisa n’wana loyi a nga na switshetshela: lemukisa n’wana wa wena hi xiyimo lexi.

eng: children as young as three can understand that the brain controls the body.
tso: vana va vutsongwana bya kwalomu ka malembe manharhu va nga kota ku twisisa leswaku byongo bya vona byi lawula miri.

eng: older children should be given a more comprehensive explanation.
tso: vana lavakulunyana va fanele ku nyikiwa nhlamuselo yo angarhela swinene.

eng: inform close relatives and your child’s friends, teachers and other responsible school officials.
tso: tivisa maxaka ya le kusuhi na vanghana va n’wana wa wena, vadyondzisi na tiofixiyali tin’wana ta xikolo leti nga na vutihlamuleri.

eng: ensure your child receives a comprehensive medical assessment by a qualified professional, ideally a neurologist.
tso: tiyisisa leswaku n’wana wa wena u kuma nhlahluvo wa vutshunguri wo angarhela hi phurofexinali leyi nga thwasa, ngopfungopfu nyurolojisi.

eng: emphasise your child’s abilities and any activity that will improve their selfacceptance, selfworth and selfconfidence.
tso: hlamusela hi ku tshikelela vuswikoti bya n’wana wa wena na nghingiriko wihi kumbe wihi lowu wu nga ta antswisa vutiamukeli byakwe, nkoka wakwe na vutitshembi byakwe.

eng: ensure adult supervision for some activities, such as swimming.
tso: tiyisisa leswaku ku na vulanguteri bya munhu lonkulu eka migingiriko yin’wana, yo tanihi vuhlamberi.

eng: ensure medication is administered and taken reg ularly as prescribed.
tso: tiyisisa leswaku mirhi ya kumeka naswona yi nwiwa nkarhi na nkarhi tanihilaha yi lawuleriweke hakona.

eng: an honour to lead the african union vukuzenzele unnamed south africa’s term as chair of the african union has come to an end.
tso: i nxiximo ku rhangela nhlangano wa matiko ya afrika (au) vukuzenzele unnamed theme ya afrikadzonga tanihi mutshamaxitulu wa nhlangano wa matiko ya afrika yi fikile emakumu.

eng: as we reflect on our year in this position, i am reminded of the old saying that ‘in crisis lies opportunity’.
tso: loko hi karhi hi la nguta eka lembe ra hina eka xiyimo lexi, ndzi tsundzu xiwa hi xivulavulelo xa khale lexi nge ‘laha ku nga na ku tika ku na ku humelela’.

eng: ours was a baptism of fire, having assumed the chairship in the same month the first case of coronavirus was reported on the continent.
tso: xa hina a ku ri ku khuvu riwa hi ndzilo, ku va hi su ngurile vutshamaxitulu eka n'hweti leyi fanaka leyi ku nga mangariwa mhangu ya khoronavhayirasi yo su ngula etikwenikulu.

eng: the priorities we outlined for our term, among them furthering peace and security, the economic empowerment of women and deepening economic integration, had to be immediately and dramatically reoriented to deal with the pandemic.
tso: leswi rhangaka hi nga swi longoloxela theme ya hina, exikarhi ka swona ku nga na ku yisa emahlweni kurhula na vusirhelelo, ku nyika vavasati matimba ya ikonomi na ku entisa nghenelelano wa ikhonomi, a swi fanele ku cinca nkongomo hi xihatla na hi laha ku kulu ku tirhana na ntungukulu.

eng: our most pressing task was to steer the focus of the african union to addressing the worst global emergency in over a century.
tso: xintirhwana xa hina xa nkoka a ku ri ku kongomisa ngongomo eka nhlangano wa matiko ya afrika eka ku tirhana na xilamulela mhangu xa misava xo nya nya eka dzana ra malembe lama nga hundza.

eng: covid19 has affected all the countries on the continent.
tso: covid19 yi khumbhile matiko hinkwawo eka tikokulu.

eng: to date there are more than 3.5 million confirmed cases in africa, and more than 88,000 people have died.
tso: ku fika namuntlha ku na kutlula kwalomu ka 3.5 wa timiliyoni wa timhangu leti tiyisisiweke eafrika, naswona kutlula kwalomu ka 88,000 wa vanhu va lovile.

eng: it has been a health, humanitarian, social and economic crisis for african countries, most of whom are inadequately resourced to manage a health emergency of this size.
tso: ku vile nkayakayo wa matiko ya afrika wa rihanyu, tintswalo eka vanhu, vanhu na ikhonomi, mo tala ma wona a ma na swipfuno leswi ringaneleke ku lawula xilamulelamhangu xa rihanyu xa sayizi yo tani.

eng: and yet, as unprecedented as the nature of the pandemic has been, so too has been the manner in which african countries have come together to fight it.
tso: loko swi ri tano, tanihi muxaka lowu wu nga si tsha maka wu va kona wa ntu ngukulu, na hi ndlela leyi matiko ya afrika ma nga si tshamaka ma hlangana ku wu lwisa.

eng: in doing so we have drawn principally on the continent’s own expertise, capabilities and institutions such as the africa centres for disease control and prevention (africa cdc).
tso: hi ku endla tano hi langutisa ngopfu eka vuswikoti bya tikokulu hi byoxe, vu swikoti na mihlangano yo fana na tisenthara ta afrika to lawula no sivela mavabyi (afrika cdc).

eng: africa did not sit by passively as the true extent and danger of the pandemic unfurled.
tso: afrika a yi nga tshamangi ntsena yi nga endli nchumu loko vukulu na nghozi ya ntungukulu swi humelela.

eng: from the earliest days of the pandemic and led by the au, we swiftly developed a continental response strategy, driven by the africa cdc and regional task forces.
tso: kusuka eka masiku yo sungula ya ntungukulu na hi ku rhangeriwa hi au, hi humelerisile kungu ro angula ra tikokulu, leri fambisiweke hi afrika cdc na valawuri va xifundzatsongo va xinti rhwana.

eng: we realised that every country on the continent would be severely affected by the pandemic.
tso: hi lemukile leswaku tiko rin'wana na rin'wana eka tikokulu ritava ri khumbiwile swinene hi ntungukulu.

eng: most would not have the resources needed to meet the public health challenge or to protect their economies.
tso: motala mangava ma nga ri na swipfuno leswi dingekaka ku fikelela xiphiqo xa rihanyu ra vanhu kumbe ku sirhelela tiikhonomi ta vona.

eng: we therefore agreed as african countries to appoint several prominent africans as special envoys, who would engage with international funders and multilateral institutions to make the case for financial support and debt relief on africa’s behalf.
tso: kutani hi pfumelelanini tanihi matiko ya afrika ku thola maafrika ma nkoka tanihi vayimeri vo hlawuleka, lava a va ta burisana na vapfuni hi timali va matiko mambe na mihla ngano ya mpfumelelano wa matiko ku endla mhangu ya nseketelo wa mali na mphalalo wa xikweleti hi ku yimela afrika.

eng: in this way, working as a one continent, we were able to achieve debt relief for many countries and financial assistance towards our covid response and economic recovery.
tso: hi ndlela leyi, ku tirha tanihi tikokulu rin'we, hi kotile ku fikelela mphalalo wa xikweleti wa matiko yo tala na mfuno wa timali eka angu lo wa hina eka covid19 na nhlakarhelo wa ikhonomi.

eng: but much as african countries went to the international community for support, we first helped ourselves – establishing and capitalising a continental covid19 response fund.
tso: kambe swotala tanihi ma tiko ya afrika ya yile eka mu ganga wa matiko mambe ku kuma nseketelo, hi sungurile hi tipfuna – hi humelerisa na ku nyika tikokulu mphalalo wa angulo wa covid19.

eng: for every partnership forged with betterresourced nations and the international donor community, we set up our own innovative and groundbreaking african medical supplies platform to enable all african countries to quickly secure personal protective equipment and other medical supplies in an equitable, affordable manner.
tso: eka xinakulobye xin'wana na xin'wana lexi hi xi endleke na tinxaka na muganga wo nyikela wa matiko mambe, hi ti endlerile pulatifomo ya swiphakeriwa swa rihanyu swa afrika swo sungula swa hina ku pfumelela matiko ya afrika leswaku ma hatla ma kuma switirhisiwa swo ti sirhelela hi wexe hi ku hatlisa na hi ndlela yo ringana na ku xaveka.

eng: and now that the covid19 vaccine is available, we have worked as a collective to ensure that the continent gets its fair share, working with the covax facility and led by our own african vaccine acquisition task team.
tso: naswona sweswi xisawutisi xa covid19 xi nga kona, hi tirhile tanihi nhlanganelo ku tiyisisa leswaku tikokulu ri kuma xiphemu xa rona lexi xi ri faneleke, hi ku tirha na cov ax facility na ku rha ngeriwa hi xipano xa xinti rhwana xo kuma xisawutisi xa afrika xa hina.

eng: vaccine rollout has already commenced on the continent and we aspire to have the majority of the continent’s population vaccinated by the end of 2021 to achieve herd immunity.
tso: mphakelo wa xisawutisi wu sungurile etikwenikulu naswona hi navela ku va vu nyingi bya vanhu va tikokulu va sawutisiwile hi ku hela ka 2021 ku fikelela nsawuto wa xintshungu.

eng: we have acted as one to protect health, people and livelihoods on the continent.
tso: hi tirhile tanihi lava va si rhelelaka rihanyu, vanhu na vutihanyisi eka tikokulu.

eng: in doing so, we have demonstrated our capacity for selfreliance and our ability to be the drivers of our own development.
tso: hi ku endla tano, hi kombisile vuswikoti bya hina bya ku tivuyisela na vuswikoti bya hina byo va vachayeri va nhluvuko wa hina.

eng: despite the dominance of covid19, we have still managed to make advances in several of our key priorities.
tso: handle ka kuva covid19 yi va na matimba, hi tlhele hi swikota ku endla ku antswa eka leswi swi rhangaka emahlweni swa nkoka eka hina swo hlaya.

eng: during our term, the africa continental free trade area (afcfta) was finally launched, heralding a new era of intraafrican trade and economic integration.
tso: hi nkarhi wa theme ya hina, ndhawu ya mabindzu ya nkaswipimelo ya tikokulu ra afrika (afcfta) yi hetelele yi simekiwile, ku komba ku cinca ka nkarhi wuntshwa wa nghenelelano wa ikhonomi na mabindzu exikarhi ka matiko ya afrika.

eng: even under the difficult conditions posed by the pandemic, the continent has pushed ahead with towards the goal of ‘silencing the guns’ on the continent.
tso: (na loko ku ri ehansi ka swiyimo swo tika leswi tisiweke hi ntungukulu, tikokulu ri susumetile ku ya emahlweni na ku kongoma eka xikongomelo xa ‘ku mi yeta swibamu’ eka tikokulu.

eng: the au has been actively involved in negotiations around the grand ethiopian renaissance dam, in achieving a ceasefire in libya and promoting peace in south sudan.
tso: au yi tshame yi nghenelerile eka mikanerisano eka grand ethiopian renai ssance dam, eka ku fikelela ntwanano wo herisa nyimpi elibya na ku hlohlotela ku rhula esouth sudan.

eng: another focus of our term has been on the economic empowerment of women, which we will continue to champion even beyond our term and throughout the decade of african women’s financial and economic inclusion to 2030. as we hand over the baton to the democratic republic of congo (drc) we leave this preeminent continental body in a position of greater strength.
tso: nkongomo wun'wana eka theme ya hina wu vile eka ku nyika matimba ya ikhonomi eka vavasati, leswi hi nga ta ya emahlweni hi swi hlohlotela ku hundza eka theme ya hina na kuya ku yile eka khume ra malembe ya nkatso wa timali na ikhonomi wa vavasati va afrika ku ya eka 2030. tanihi loko hi nyiketa nho nga ya vufambisi eka de mocratic republic of congo (drc) hi siya nhlangano wo antswa swinene wa tikokulu eka xivandla xa matimba swinene.

eng: south africa will continue to play its part to foster integration on the continent, and support the incoming chair and the organisation in its efforts to meet the aspirations of the au’s agenda 2063. when the organisation for african unity was founded in 1963, member states planted the seeds of cooperation and solidarity in pursuit of a better life for all the peoples of africa.
tso: afrikadzonga ri ta ya emahlweni ri tlanga xiphemu xa rona ku tiyisisa nghenelelano eka tikokulu, na nseke telo wa mutshamaxitulu loyi a nghenaka na nhlangano eka matimba ma wona ku fikelela ku navela ku fikelela ka aje nda ya au hi 2063. loko nhlangano wa ntwanano wa afrika wu si mekiwile hi 1963, matiko lama ma nga swirho eka nhlangano wa matiko mambe ma byarile mbewu ya nti rhisano na nseketelano hi ku lava vutomi byo antswa bya vanhu hinkwavo va afrika.

eng: they affirmed that african unity was paramount if the welfare and wellbeing of africa’s people was to be assured.
tso: ma tiyisisile leswaku ntwa nano wa afrika a wu ri na nkoka loko nhlayiseko na ntshamiseko wa vanhu va afrika a wu ta tshembisa.

eng: history bears witness that these seeds have not always fallen on fertile ground, and over the years the continental unity project has experienced many hurdles and false starts.
tso: matimu ya byarhe mbhoni ya leswaku timbewu leti a ti tshamanga ti kha ti wela eka misava yo nona, naswona eka malembe lamo tala phurojeke ya ntwanano wa tiko kulu yi tokotile ku tikeriwa na masungulo yo ka ya nga ri wona.

eng: covid19 vaccine: what you need to know allison cooper with south afri ca’s mass coro navirus disease (covid19) vaccination programme rolling out for healthcare workers in february, vuk’uzenzele sheds some light on what the covid19 vaccine is, how it works and why it’s so important to stop the spread of the virus.
tso: xisawutisi xa covid19: leswi u dingaka ku swi tiva allison cooper hikwalaho ka phurogireme ya nsawutiso wa vuvabyi bya khoronavhayirasi (covid19) wa vanhu va xitshungu wa afrikadzonga lowu wu nga ta va wu nyikiwa vatirhi va swa rihanyu hi nyenyenyana, vuk’uze nzele yi nyika ku vonaka la eka leswi xisawutisi xa covid19 xi nga swona, leswi xi tirhisaka swona naswona hikwalaho ka yini swi ri na nkoka ku kama nyeta ku hangalaka ka xi tsongwatsongwana.

eng: what does a vaccine do?
tso: xana xisawutisi xi endla yini?

eng: a vaccine trains your body’s immune system (which fights infection), to produce antibodies (proteins that fight disease) – exactly like it would if you were exposed to a virus.
tso: xisawutisi xi dyondzisa tirhelo ra nsawutiso wa vuvabyi ra miri wa wena (leri ri lwaka na ntluletavuvabyi), ku endla swidlayaxitsongwatsongwana (tiphurotheni leti lwaka na vuvabyi) – tanihileswi a swi ta va xiswona loko a wu nga hlayisekanga eka vuvabyi.

eng: why is the vaccine so important?
tso: hikokwalaho ka yini xisawutisi xi ri na nkoka swonghasi?

eng: being vaccinated against covid19 is an effective way to protect yourself against the virus because your risk of infection is reduced.
tso: ku va u sawutisiwa eka covid19 i ndlela ya kahle yo tisirhelela eka xitsongwatsongwana hikuva nxungeto wa wena eka ntlulelavuvabyi wa hunguteka.

eng: the aim of vaccination is to reach herd immunity – when enough of the population is immune to the virus it provides indirect protection to those who aren’t immune, bringing the spread of the virus under control.
tso: xikongomelo xa nsawutiso i ku fikelela nsawuto wa xintshungu – loko vanhu vo tala va sawutile eka xitsongwatsongwana swi nyika nsirhelelo wo ka wu nga kongomi eka lava va nga sawutangiki, leswi swi kamanyetaka ku hangalaka ka xitsongwatsongwana.

eng: are vaccines necessary to prevent the spread of covid19?
tso: xana swisawutisi swi fanerile ku sivela ku hangalaka ka covid19?

eng: there is overwhelming scientific evidence that vaccination is the best defence against serious infections.
tso: ku na vumbhoni byo tiya bya xisayense bya leswaku nsawutiso i xisirheleri xo tlula hinkwaswo eka mitluletavuvabyi ya matimba.

eng: will the vaccine stop me from getting covid19?
tso: xana xisawutisi xi ta endla leswaku ndzi nga khomiwi hi covid19?

eng: no vaccine provides 100% protection.
tso: kuhava xisawutisi lexi xi nyikaka nsirhelelo wa 100% .

eng: herd immunity also does not provide full protection to those who are not vaccinated.
tso: nsawuto wa xintshungu na wona a wu nyiki nsirhelelo wo hetiseka eka lava va nga sawutisiwangiki.

eng: however, with herd immunity, these people will have substantial protection.
tso: hambiswiritano, hi nsawuto wa xintshungu, vanhu lava va ta va na nsirhelelo wa nkoka.

eng: is the vaccination safe?
tso: xana nsawutiso wu hlayisekile ke?

eng: covid19 vaccines go through a demanding, multistage testing process, including large trials that involve tens of thousands of people.
tso: swisawutisi swa covid19 swi hundza hi le ka phurosese yo koxa, ya switeji swo tala swa nkambelo, ku katsa mikambelondzinganelo leyikulu leyi katsaka makume ya magidi wa vanhu.

eng: every vaccine used in south africa’s mass vaccination programme has to be approved by the south african health products regulatory authority.
tso: xisawutisi xin'wana ni xin'wana lexi xi tirhisiwaka eka phurogireme ya nsawutiso wa xintshungu ya afrikadzonga xi boheka ku pfumeleriwa hi huvo yo lawula swimakiwa swa rihanyu ya afrikadzonga.
