eng: thanking our nurses allison cooper the country’s nurses, along with other medical staff, have put their lives on the line to help others during the coronavirus disease (cov id19) pandemic.
tso: ku khensiwa ka vaongori va ka hina allison cooper vaongori va tikoswin’we na vatirhi va swa vushu nguri van’wana, va vekile vutomi bya vona ekhombyeni hi ku pfu na van’wana hi nkarhi wa ntungukulu wa khoronavha yirasi covid19.

eng: international nurses day, which is on 12 may, is an opportunity to celebrate nurses for their service to others.
tso: siku ra vaongori ra matiko ya misava, leri ri nga siku ra 12 khotavuxika, i xivandla nene xa ku tlangela vaongori eka vukorhokeri bya vona eka van’wana.

eng: professional nurse luyanda ganuganu (25), from groote schuur hospital in the western cape, says the day is also an opportunity for nurses to continue to shine the bright light of their profession.
tso: muongori wa xiphurofexinali, luyanda ganuganu (25), wa le xibedhlele xa groote schuur xa le kapavupeladyambu, u vula leswaku siku leri ri tlhela ri va xivandlanene xa vaongori leswaku va ya emahlweni va ti nyungubyisa hi ntirho wa vona.

eng: "it’s an opportunity for nurses to be recognised, but we must continue to provide quality care, especially during the pandemic," he says.
tso: "i xivandlanene xa vaongori ku va va tekeriwa enhlokweni, kambe hi boheka ku ya ema hlweni hi nyika nhlayiso wa risima, ngopfungopfu hi nka rhi lowu wa ntungu," a vula.

eng: ganuganu was on the frontline during the pandemic’s first and second wave, working at the hospital’s high care covid19 ward.
tso: ganuganu a ri mutirhi loyi a tirhanaka na vavabyi hi ku kongoma hi nkarhi wa gandla ti ro sungula na ra vumbirhi ra ntungukulu lowu, a ri karhi a tirhela ewadini ya covid19 ya nhlayiso wa le henhla ya.

eng: "the best part was the experience gained while working with patients, but the worst part was all the deaths that took place in the ward.
tso: "xiphemu xa kahle swinene a ku ri ntokoto lowu ndzi wu kumeke loko ndzi ri karhi ndzi tirha na vavabyi, kambe xiphemu xo biha swinene a ku ri mafu hinkwawo lama a ma humelela ewadini leyi.

eng: emotionally, that was not easy.
tso: emo yeni, a swi nga olovi."

eng: "ganuganu, who has been a professional nurse for the past two years, chose the profession because he loves helping people.
tso: ganuganu, loyi a nga muo ngori wa xiphurofexinali kusu kela malembe mambirhi lama hundzeke, u hlawule vuongori hikuva u rhandza ku pfuna vanhu.

eng: "i grew up in a rural area in the eastern cape and could see how people struggled due to a lack of clinics with nursing care.
tso: "ndzi kulele ematikoxikaya ekapavuhumadyambu laha a ndzi kota ku vona vanhu va kayakaya hikwalaho ka ku pfumaleka ka titliliniki leti nga na nhlayiso wa vuongori.

eng: this developed my passion for wanting to make a difference," he says.
tso: le swi swi tumbuluxile ku tsakela ka mina ku va ndzi lava ku endla ku hambana," a vula.

eng: during the pandemic, ganuganu has had to learn to work under pressure.
tso: hi nkarhi wa ntungukulu lowu ganuganu u bohekile ku dyondza ku tirha ehansi ka xiyimo xa ntshikelelo.

eng: "decisions have to be made quickly and you have to think on your feet.
tso: "swiboho a swi boheka ku teki wa hi xihatla naswona u boheka ku ehleketa hi ndlela leyi nga erivaleni ehansi ka ntshikelelo.

eng: i also learnt how to communicate with patients," he adds.
tso: ndzi tlhele ndzi dyondza na hilaha ndzi faneleke ku vula vurisana hakona na vavabyi" a engetela.

eng: ganuganu found it very difficult to go to work during the second wave.
tso: ganuganu a swi n’wi tikela swinene ku ya entirhweni hi nkarhi wa gandlati ra vumbirhi.

eng: while he wanted to help others, he also feared for his own family.
tso: kambe a swi lava ku pfuna van’wana, a chavela na ndya ngu wa yena.

eng: "i got married in december 2020 and my wife is pregnant.
tso: "ndzi tekile hi n’wendza mhala 2020 naswona nsati wa mina a bihile emirhini.

eng: i have seen a lot of pregnant women die in the covid19 ward.
tso: ndzi vonile vavasati vo tala lava bi heke emirhini va lova ewadini ya covid19 .

eng: i had to be even more careful because i did not want to put my wife’s life in danger," he says.
tso: a ndzi fanele ku va na vuxiyaxiya swinene hikuva a ndzi nga swi lavi ku veka vutomi bya nsati wa mina ekhombyeni," a vula.

eng: ganuganu is grateful to his managers and colleagues.
tso: ganuganu u khensa vafambisi na vatirhikulobye va yena.

eng: "i want to thank them for their support and for giving me the opportunity to grow as a nurse.
tso: "ndzi lava ku va khensa ku va va ndzi nyikile nseketelo na xivandlanene xa ku kula tanihi muongori.

eng: it’s an awesome experience to work with colleagues who support younger staff.
tso: i ntokoto wo hlamarisa swinene ku tirha na vatirhikulobye lava va sekete laka vatirhi va vantshwa."

eng: "his message to the community is to help nurses by being responsible.
tso: hungu ra yena eka muganga i ku pfuna vaongori hikuva va va na vutihlamuleri.

eng: "help us to help you.
tso: "hi pfuneni ku kota ku mi pfu na.

eng: everyone knows what is expected of them during covid19.
tso: munhu un’wana na un’wa na wa swi tiva leswi swi langu teriweke eka yena hi nkarhi wa covid19 .

eng: please continue to follow all the guidelines and protocols," says ganuganu.
tso: ndzi kombela leswaku mi ya emahlweni mi landzelela swiletelo na milawu," ku vula ganuganu.

eng: robust media more critical than ever vukuzenzele unnamed we live in a country where not just journalists but any member of the public is able to freely articulate their views, their opinions and indeed their dissatisfaction without fear of retribution.
tso: swihangalasamahungu swo tiya i swa nkoka swinene kutlula leswi swi nga tshama swi va xiswona vukuzenzele unnamed hi tshama eka tiko leri ku nga riki vatekamahu ngu ntsena, kambe muaki un’wana na un’wana a ko taka ku vula hi ku tshunxeka mavonelo ya yena na ku humesela ehandle ku nga eneriseki ka yena ku ri hava nchavo wa ku ri hisetiwa.

eng: we have come a long way from the days where social protest by artists attracted banning orders, and critical reporting by journalists risked imprisonment or the closure of publications.
tso: hi huma ekule eka masiku laha ku kombisa ku vilela ka vaaki hi vatshila ku kokeke rinoko ra swileriso swo yirisa, naswona mavikelo ya vukhensivusoli hi vatekama hungu ya xungeteke ku pfaleriwa ekhotsweni kumbe ku pfariwa ka vukandziyisi.

eng: recently, the organisation reporters without borders published the 2021 world press freedom index, a barometer of the state of media freedom across the globe.
tso: sweswinyana, nhlangano wa reporters without bo rders wu kandziyise xikombo xa ntshunxeko wa mahungu yo tsariwa ya misava xa 2021, xipimo xa xiyimo xa ntshunxeko wa swihanga lasamahungu emisaveni hinkwayo.

eng: overall, it was found that there has been a decline in public access to information and an increase in obstacles to news coverage in a number of countries.
tso: hi ku angarhela, ku kume kile leswaku ku vile ni ku chika eka ku va vaaki va kuma vuxokoxoko naswona ku va na ku engeteleleka eka swirhalanganyi eka ku hangalasa mahungu eka ma tiko mo hlayanyana.

eng: the report said that journalism is "totally blocked or seriously impeded" in 73 countries and "constrained" in 59 others.
tso: xiviko lexi xi vule leswaku vutekamahungu byi "pfaleri wile hi ku hetiseka kumbe ku kanganyisiwa hi ndlela yo tivikana" eka matiko ma 73 naswona byi "tshikeleriwile" eka man’wana ma 59. leswi vilerisaka hileswaku ntshunxeko wa swihangala samahungu wu ehlile ehansi ka ntungukulu wa covid19 , laha ku nga va na swipimelo swo hambanahambana leswi vekiweke leswi tikombeke swi tirhisiwile ku hunguta nghingiriko wa swihangala samahungu eka tindhawu to hlayanyana.

eng: what is worrying is that media freedom has deteriorated under the covid19 pandemic, with the various restrictions put in place having seemingly been used to curtail media activity in several places.
tso: eka xiviko xa sweswi, afrikadzonga yi vekiwe eka xiyimo xa vu32 eka matiko ma 180. xikombo lexi xi hla musela xiyimo xa ntshunxeko wa swihangalasamahungu eafrikadzonga tanihi "lexi tiyisisiweke kambe xi tsa nile".

eng: it notes that while the south african constitution protects freedom and we have an established culture of investigative journalism, a number of impediments still hinder journalists in the performance of their duties.
tso: xi tekela enhlokweni leswaku hambiloko vumbi wa bya afrikadzonga byi sirhelela ntshunxeko, na swona hi ri na ntolovelo lowu hluvukeke wa vutekama hungu byo lavisisa, ka ha ri ni swirhalanganyi swo hlayanyana leswi kavanye taka vatekamahungu eka matirhelo ya mitirho ya vona.

eng: this includes legal injunctions against taking images of national key points or reporting on matters involving state security.
tso: leswi swi katsa swileriso swa xinawu leswi sivelaka ku tekiwa ka swifaniso swa tindhawu ta nkoka ta rixaka kumbe ku vikiwa ka timhaka leti khumbaka nhlayiseko wa tiko.

eng: the report also notes an increase during 2020 of the intimidation of journalists, especially female journalists on social media.
tso: nakambe xiviko xi tekela enhlokweni ku ya ehenhla ka ku chavisiwa ka vatekama hungu hi 2020, ngopfungopfu vatekamahungu va xisati eka swihangalasamahungu swa vanhu.

eng: such intimidation is totally unacceptable, but is particularly harmful when it is directed at female journalists and is occasionally accompanied by threats of sexual violence.
tso: ku chavisiwa loku a ku amukeleki nakan’we, kambe ku ni khombo ngopfungopfu loko ku kongomisiwa eka vatekamahungu va xisati naswona loku hakanyingi ku fambisanaka na ku chavi siwa hi madzolonga ya swa masangu.

eng: this is a matter of great concern and cannot be allowed.
tso: leyi i mhaka leyi vilerisaka swinene naswona a yi nge amukeleki.

eng: at the same time, we take great comfort in the knowledge that we have a free, robust media that is able to report without fear or favour about those in power, about the most pressing social issues of our time, and to provide accurate, impartial information to the public.
tso: hi nkarhi wun’we, ha tsaka ku tiva leswaku hi na swihangalasamahungu leswi tshunxekeke swo tiya leswi swi kotaka ku vika handle ko chava kumbe ku teka tlhelo ra lava va nga ematimbeni, hi mayelana na timhaka ta vaaki leti karhataka swinene eka mikarhi ya hina, na ku nyika vuxokoxoko lebyi nga voyameriki etlhelo ro karhi eka vaaki.

eng: at a time when we are working together to rebuild our economy and our society in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic, a robust media is more critical than ever.
tso: enkarhini lowu hi ttirhisa naka ku aka ikhonomi ya hina na rixaka ra ka hina hi vuntshwa exikarhi ka ntu ngukulu wa khoronavhayi rasi, swihangalasamahungu swo tiya i swa nkoka swinene kutlula leswi swi nga tshama swi va xiswona.

eng: the south african media has played a pivotal role in uncovering much of what we know today about the true extent of capture of the state by selfserving, corrupt individuals and entities.
tso: swihangalasamahungu swa afrikadzonga swi tlangile xiave xa nkoka eku vhumbu nuleni ka leswo tala leswi hi swi tivaka namuntlha hi mayelana na mpimo wa xiviri wa nhlohlotelo wa mfumo hi ku navela ka le handle hi vanhu na mavandla lama tivuyerisaka, lama nga na vukungundzwana.

eng: they sustained their reporting even in the face of intimidation, disinformation and attacks on their person.
tso: swi tiyiserile ku vika ka swona hambiloko swi langu tanile na ku chavisiwa, ku nyikiwa mahungu yo hoxeka na ku onhiwa ka vumunhu bya swona.

eng: corruption is by no means the only challenge we face as a country.
tso: vukungundzwana a hi byona ntsena byi nga ntlho ntlho lowu hi langutaneke na wona tanihi tiko.

eng: the daily lives of many south africans are still affected by poverty, inequality and underdevelopment, poor service delivery and lack of access to opportunities.
tso: vutomi bya siku na siku bya vanhu va afrikadzonga vo tala bya ha hlaseriwa hi vusweti, ku pfumala ndzingano na nhluvuko wo tsotsomba, vukorhokeri bya xiyimo xa le hansi na mpfumaleko wa mfikelelo wa swivandlanene.

eng: if the media is to remain true to its responsibility to support democracy, our journalists must continue to report without fear or favour on the other issues of the day.
tso: loko swihangalasama hungu swi fanele ku tama swa ha ri swa ntiyiso eka vutihlamuleri bya swona ku seketela xidemokirasi, vatekamahungu va ka hina va boheka ku yisa emahlweni ku vika va nga chavi kumbe ku hlawula tlhelo eka tin’wana ta timhaka ta siku.

eng: their sustained coverage must include genderbased violence, crime in our communities and social ills like substance abuse.
tso: ku hangalasa ka vona mahungu loku tiyiselaka ku boheka ku katsa madzo longa ya swa rimbewu, vu gevenga emigangeni ya ka hina na vubihi bya vanhu ku fana na ku tirhisiwa ka swidzidziharisi hi ndlela yo biha.

eng: our media should provide accurate and impartial information, enabling the public to make informed decisions, to access opportunities and to improve their lives.
tso: swihangalasamahungu swa ka hina swi fanele ku nyika vuxokoxoko bya nkhaqato na ku va byo ka byi nga voya meli etlhelo ro karhi, leswi nga ta pfuna vaaki ku teka swiboho va ri na vutivi, ku fikelela swivandlanene na ku antswisa vutomi bya vona.

eng: they should continue to produce journalism that goes beyond the headlines and front pages and that contributes to human development.
tso: swi fanele ku yisa ema hlweni ku humelerisa vute kamahungu lebyi nga heleriki ntsena eka tinhlokomhaka na mahungu lama nga eka tiphe ji to sungula lama ma nga ta hoxa xandla eka nhluvukiso wa vanhu.

eng: they should report both the good news and the bad news, the progress we make and the challenges we face.
tso: swi fanele ku vika havu mbirhi bya mahungu la manene na lamo biha, nhlu vuko lowu hi wu endleke na mitlhontlho leyi hi langu tanaka na yona.

eng: credibility is key to sustaining trust between journalists and the public.
tso: ku tshembeka hi rona khiya ro hlayisa ntshembano exi karhi ka vatekamahungu na vaaki.

eng: when journalists allow themselves or their platforms to be used to fight political battles or settle scores on behalf of vested interests, their credibility suffers.
tso: loko vatekamahungu va pfumelela ku tirhisiwa kumbe ku tirhisiwa ka tipulatifomo ta vona ku lwa tinyimpi ta tipolitiki kumbe ku rihiselana hi ku yimela ku navela ka van’wana, vutshembeki bya vona bya onhaka.

eng: when media disseminate stories that are inaccurate or that they know to be false, the public loses faith in them.
tso: loko swihangalasamahu ngu swi hangalasa switori swa nkankhaqato kumbe leswi va swi tivaka leswaku swi hoxekile, vaaki va lahleeriwa hi ku tshemba eka vona.

eng: it is in the best interests of all who love this country and wish for it to succeed that our media is supported, and not hindered in its work.
tso: swi vuyerisa hinkwavo lava rhandzaka tiko leri na lava va ri navelelaka ku humelela leswaku swihanga lasamahungu swa ka hina swi seketeriwa, naswona swi nga tsandzekisiwi eka ntirho wa swona.

eng: tobacco addiction: your health could go up in smoke kgaogelo letsebe to commemorate world no tobacco day on 31 may, vuk’uzenzelechats to a recovering tobacco addict about overcoming his addiction.
tso: vuhlonga bya fole: rihanyu ra wena ri nga tshwa kgaogelo letsebe ku tlangela hi ku tsundzuka siku ro yirisa fole ra misava hi 31 mudyaxihi, vuk’uzenzele yi burisana na hlonga ra fole leri ri nga eku holeni hi mayelana na ku hlula vuhlonga bya rona.

eng: katlego makhanda, from moiletswane in the north west, knows all too well how hard it is to stop smoking.
tso: katlego makhanda wo huma emoile tswane en’walu nguvupeladyambu u swi tiva hi ku hetiseka ku tika ka swona ku tshika ku dza ha.

eng: until he stopped four years ago, makhanda (28) used to smoke over 30 cigarettes a day.
tso: kufikela loko a tshike mune wa malembe lama hundzeke, makhanda (28) a tolovele ku dzaha kutlula 30 wa tisigarete hi siku.

eng: he started smoking when he was 18 as a result of peer pressure.
tso: u sungule ku dzaha a ri na 18 wa malembe hi vukhale hikwalaho ka ntshikelelo wa tintangha ta yena.

eng: "i was not interested in smoking – it didn’t appeal to me until i was in matric and a group of guys i used to hang out with started picking on me for not being cool enough to smoke."
tso: "a ndzi nga swi tsakeli ku dzaha – a swi nga ndzi naveti kukondza loko ndzi ri eka matiriki naswona ntlawa wa vantshwa lava a ndzi tolovele ku hungasa na vona va su ngule ku ndzi khovolela hi ku ka ndzi nga tsakisiwi hi ku dzaha."

eng: makhanda initially smoked one or two cigarettes a day, but this increased over time.
tso: ekusunguleni makhanda a dzaha sigarete yin’we kumbe timbirhi hi siku, kutani a engetela hi ku famba ka nkarhi.

eng: "after matric, i went to varsity and the freedom that came with not staying with my parents meant i could drink alcohol as frequently as i wanted.
tso: "endzhaku ka matiriki, ndzi ye eyunivhesiti naswona ntshunxeko lowu teke hikwa laho ka ku va ndzi nga tshami na vatswari va mina, a wu vula leswaku ndzi nga kota ku nwa xihoko nkarhi wun’wana na wun’wana hi ku rhandza.

eng: this increased my rate of smoking."
tso: leswi swi tlakuse mpimo wa mina wa madzahelo."

eng: in 2017, makhanda fell ill and was hospitalised.
tso: hi 2017, makhanda u va byile kutani a amukeriwa exibedhlele.

eng: he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and for weeks was too weak to get out of bed.
tso: u kamberiwile a kumeka a ri na muxaka wa 2 wa vuvabyi bya chukela kutani u kumeke a tsanile swinene a tsandzeka no chika emubedweni ku ringana ma vhikinyana.

eng: "the doctor was very specific that managing my illness couldn’t be done if i continued to smoke.
tso: "dokodela u kongomile leswaku a swi nga koteki ku lawula vuvabyi bya mina loko ndzi ya emahlweni ni ku dzaha.

eng: that is when i decided to quit for good.
tso: hiloko ndzi teka xiboho xo tshikela makumu."

eng: "dr midah maluleke from mpumalanga says smoking is harmful to nearly every organ.
tso: dkd midah maluleke ku suka empumalanga u vula leswaku ku dzaha swi vavisa kwalomu ka xirho xin’wana na xin’wana.

eng: "illnesses such as cancer, heart disease, stroke, lung diseases, diabetes and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease can result from smoking.
tso: "vuvabyi byo tanihi bya mfukuzana, vuvabyi bya mbilu, vuvabyi byo oma swirho, vuvabyi bya mahahu, vavabyi bya chukela na vu vabyi byo godzombela byo kavanyeta misiha ya mbilu byi nga sukela eku dzaheni."

eng: "research shows that smokers are 30% to 40% more likely to develop type 2 diabetes than nonsmokers.
tso: "ndzavisiso wu komba leswaku vadzahi va kwalomu ka 30% kufika eka 40% va tala ku khomiwa hi vuvabyi bya chukela bya muxaka wa 2 kutlula lava nga dzahiki.

eng: smoking also creates difficulty in managing the disease," he says.
tso: naswona ku dzaha swi tikisela malawulelo ya vuva byi lebyi," a vula.

eng: tips to stop smokingthe cancer association of south africa (cansa) offers the following tips if you are trying to stop smoking: decide on a date to stop smoking and then do it.
tso: switsundzuxo swo tshi ka ku dzahanhlangano wa mfukuzana wa afrikadzonga (ca nsa) wu nyika switsu ndzuxo leswi landzelaka loko u ri eku ringeteni ku tshika ku dzaha: teka xiboho hi siku ro tshika ku dzaha kutani u swi endla.

eng: throw away everything that reminds you of smoking.
tso: cukumeta hinkwa swo ekule leswi swi ku tsundzuxaka hi ku dzaha.

eng: this includes cigarette packets, ashtrays, lighters.
tso: leswi swi katsa maphakiti ya tisigarete, swidzudzelankuma na swo lumeka hi swona.

eng: drink lots of water – it will help flush the nicotine from your body.
tso: nwana mati mo tala – ma ta pfuna ku hla ntswa nikhothini emirini wa wena.

eng: inform your family and friends that you are trying to stop so that they can support you.
tso: tivisa vandyangu na vanghana leswaku u le ku ringeteni ku tshika ku dzaha leswaku va kota ku seketela.

eng: you may experience some dizziness, headaches or coughing once you have stopped smoking.
tso: u nga khomiwa hi sululwani, ku pandza ka nhloko kumbe ku khohlola xikan’wekan’we loko u tshike ku dzaha.

eng: this is normal and should improve after a day or two and disappear within 14 days.
tso: leswi swi tolovele kile naswona swi nga antswa endzhaku ka siku kumbe mambirhi naswona swi nga nya malala ku nga si hela 14 wa masiku.

eng: makhanda says his journey hasn’t been easy, but he is committed to not smoking.
tso: makhanda u vula leswaku rendzo ra yena a ri nga olovangi, kambe u tinyike tela eka ku ka a nga ha dzahi.

eng: "the local clinic and staff provided me with support and information on the importance of living a tobaccofree life.
tso: "tliliniki ya muganga na vatirhi va ndzi nyike nseketelo na vuxokoxoko hi mayelana na nkoka wo hanya vutomi byo tshunxe ka eka fole.

eng: israel, palestine urged to emulate sa by pursuing peace vukuzenzele unnamed our experience with the democratic transition is a lesson about the power of empathy, negotiation and compromise.
tso: isirayele, palestina ma hlohloteriwa ku encenyeta afrikadzonga hi ku lavana na ku rhula vukuzenzele unnamed ntokoto wa hina wa ku cincela eka xidemokirasi i dyondzo hi mayelana na matimba ya ntwelavusi wana, ku kanerisana na ku fikelela ntwanano.

eng: the escalating situation in israel and palestine affirms once more what we south africans know too well, that intractable conflicts can only be solved through peaceful negotiation.
tso: xiyimo lexi yaka xi tika eisi rayele na le palestina xi ya emahlweni xi tiyisisa leswi hina vanhu va afrikadzonga hi swi tivaka hi ku hetiseka, leswaku madzolonga yo tika ma nga ololoxiwa hi ku kane risana hi ndlela yo rhula.

eng: it also demonstrates that unless the root causes of a conflict are addressed, in this case the illegal occupation by israel of palestinian land and the denial of the palestinian people’s right to selfdetermination, there will never be peace.
tso: swi tlhela swi kombisa le swaku handlekaloko ntlimbo wu lulamisiwa, eka xiyimo lexa ku tekeriwa ka misava loku nga riki enawini hi isi rayele emisaveni ya vanhu va palestina na ku alela mfa nelo ya vanhu va palestina ya ndhawu ya ku tifuma hi ndlela ya vona, a ku nge pfuki ku va na ku rhula.

eng: the latest violence was sparked by an israeli court decision to evict a group of families from their homes in the sheikh jarrah neighbourhood in east jerusalem to make way for israeli settlements.
tso: madzolonga lawa ha ku humelelaka sweswi ya vangi wile hi xiboho xa khoto ya isirayele xo susa ntlawa wa mindyangu emakaya ya yona eka muganga wa sheikh ja rrah eeast jerusalem ku endle la vutshamo bya vanhu va isirayele.

eng: the sight of men, women and children being evicted from the homes their families have lived in for generations brings back painful collective and personal memories for the majority of south africans – of forced removals and land dispossession.
tso: ku vona vavanuna, va vasati na vana va ri karhi va susiwa emakaya lawa mindyangu ya vona yi nga tshama eka wona tinxaka na tinxaka swi tsundzuxa vanhu va afrikadzonga yo tala hi ku vaviseka ka vona hi ku angarhela na ku vaviseka ka munhu a ri swakwe – ka ku rhurhisiwa hi ku sindzisiwa na ku tekeriwa misava.

eng: it was a pain and humiliation faced by my own family, and by many south african families.
tso: a ku ri ku vaviseka na tingana leti nga langutana na ndyangu wa ka hina, na hi mindyangu yo tala ya vanhu va afrikadzonga.

eng: my family was forcibly moved to different parts of the country on two occasions.
tso: ndyangu wa ka hina wu su siwile hi ku sindzisiwa kuya eka tindhawu to hambana hambana ta tiko ku ringana kambirhi.

eng: being forced from one’s home at gunpoint is a trauma not easily forgotten and is carried across generations.
tso: ku susiwa ekaya ra wena hi ku sindzisiwa u kombe teriwile hi xibalesa i mhaka yo vava leyi nga rivalekiki hi ku olova, naswona yi hundzi seriwa eka tinxaka leti la ndzelaka.

eng: as a country, we are still living with the residual effects of the callous acts carried out in the name of apartheid spatial planning.
tso: tanihi tiko, ha ha hanya hi ri na ku khumbeka hi swita ndzhaku swa masalelwa ya swendlo leswo pfumala ntwe lavusiwana leswi endliweke hi vito ra makunguhatelo ya tindhawu to ta mafumelo ya xihlawuhlawu.

eng: for all who believe in equality, justice and human rights, we cannot but be moved and indeed angered, at the pain and humiliation being inflicted on the palestinian people; for it echoes our own.
tso: eka hinkwavo lava va tshembaka eka ku ringana, vululami na timfanelo ta ximunhu, a ku na xin’wana handle ko va hi khumbeka no hlundzuka, hi ku vaviseka na tingana leti twisiwaka vanhu va le palestina, hikuva swi hi vuyisela eka leswi swi nga hi humelela.

eng: israel’s actions are a violation of international law.
tso: swendlo swa isirayele i ku tlula nawu wa matiko ya mi sava.

eng: they show a total disregard for successive united nations security council reso lutions that call for an end to the occupation of palestinian land and for the fulfilment of the rights of the palestinian people.
tso: swi komba ku tsan’wa swiboho swo landzelelana swa huvo ya vusirheleri ya nhlangano wa tinxaka leswi swi lavaka ku herisa ku te kiwa ka misava ya palestina na ku fikeleriwa ka timfanelo ta vanhu va palestina.

eng: since israeli security forces launched assaults on worshippers at alaqsa mosque in jerusalem, the violence has now engulfed the gaza strip, large parts of the west bank and a number of israeli cities.
tso: kusukela loko mavuthu ya vusirheleri ya isirayele ya hlasele vagandzeri eka al aqsa mosque ejerusalem, madzolonga se ya fike na le gaza strip, swiphemu leswikulu swa west bank na madorobakulu yo hlaya nyana ya le isirayele.

eng: it has claimed the lives of dozens of people, including children.
tso: swi koxe vutomi bya madazeni ya vanhu, ku katsa na vana.

eng: it is also deeply troubling that israeli forces destroyed a multistorey building that housed a number of media organisations, sending a chilling message to media reporting on the violence.
tso: swi tlhela swi vava swi nene leswaku mavuthu ya isirayele ya onhe muako wa switheze swo hlaya lowu a wu tirhisiwa hi mihlangano yo hlaya ya swihangalasama hungu, ku ri ku rhumela hungu ro chavisa swihanga lasamahungu leswi vikaka hi madzolonga.

eng: the senseless and continued israeli bombardment of gaza will have devastating consequences for more than two million people who have been suffering under an illegal israeli blockade for 14 years.
tso: ku hlasela loko ka ku nga twisiseki no ya emahlweni ka gaza hi isirayele ku ta va na switandzhaku swo vava eka vanhu vo tlula timiliyoni timbirhi lava a va ri eku xani sekeni ehansi ka ku pfaleriwa etindhawini hi isirayele swi nga ri enawini ku ringana 14 wa malembe.

eng: we call on all parties involved to show restraint, to respect human life and to cease the current hostilities.
tso: hi rhamba vanhu hinkwavo lava khumbekaka ku komba ku yimisa, ku hlonipha vutomi bya vanhu, no herisa ku jamelana loku nga kona.

eng: as south africa, we are committed to being part of international efforts aimed at reviving a political process that will lead to the establishment of a viable palestinian state existing sidebyside in peace with israel and within internationally recognised borders.
tso: tanihi afrikadzonga, ha tinyiketela ku va xiphemu xa matshalatshala ya matiko ya masiva lama kongomisiweke eka ku pfuxelela endlelo ra swa tipolitiki leri nga ta fikelela ku tumbuluxiwa ka mfumo wa palestina lowu tirhekaka lowu hanyisanaka swin’we na isirayele hi ku rhula, na le ndzeni ka mind zilekano leyi amukeriwaka hi matiko ya misava.

eng: the twostate solution remains the most viable option for the peoples of israel and palestine and must continue to be supported.
tso: xitshunxo xa matiko mambi rhi xa ha ri xona xilangwa xo tirheka eka vanhu va isiray ele na palestina, naswona xi fanele ku ya emahlweni xi seketeriwa.

eng: just as israeli security forces were attacking worshippers at the alaqsa mosque, we in south africa were preparing to commemorate the centenary of the bulhoek massacre at a religious site in ntabelanga in the eastern cape.
tso: hi nkarhi lowu mavuthu ya vusirheleri ya isirayele a ya hlasela vagandzeri eka al aqsa mosque, hina eafrikadzonga a hi tilulamisela ku tsundzuka dzana ra malembe ya ku yayarheriwa ka vanhu ka le bulhoek eka ndhawu ya vukhongeri ya le ntabelanga ekapavuhumadyambu.

eng: on 24 may 1921, colonial security forces armed with machine guns and artillery opened fire on worshippers, killing more than 160 people and wounding nearly 130. the massacre laid bare the brutality not only of the police force of the union of south africa, but also the racist system that it was charged to uphold.
tso: hi siku ra 24 mudyaxihi 1921, mavuthu ya vusirheleri ya xikoloni lawa a ya hlomile hi swibalesa na switlhavana ya duvule vagandzeri, ya dlaya vanhu vo tlula 160 no vavisa vanhu vo lava ku fika 130. ku yayarheriwa ka vanhu swi humesele erivaleni tihanyi, ku nga ri ta vuthu ra maphorisa ra yuniyoni ya afrikadzonga ntsena, kambe na sisiteme ya xihla wuhlawu xa rixakanghohe leyi a yi ri na vutihlamuleri bya ku yi sirhelela.

eng: just like the dispute in the sheik jarrah neighbourhood, the atrocity at bulhoek was not just about a local dispute; it was fundamentally about the forced dispossession of land, about colonial occupa tion, about racial discrimi nation and about the violent suppression of dissent.
tso: ku fana na nkwetlembetano wa vaakelana va le sheik ja rrah, ku tshwukiselana ma hlo ka le bulhoek a kungari ntsena hi mayelana nkwe tlembetano wa miganga, a ku ri ngopfungopfu hi mhaka ya ku tekeriwa misa va hi ku tirhisa matimba, ku tekiwa ka misava ka xi koloni, xihlawuhlawu xo ya hi rixakanghohe, na miyeto wa lava kanetaka hi madzo longa.

eng: as we reflect on the crisis in the middle east and particularly on the suffering of the palestinian people, we would do well to recall the words of selby msimang, a founding member of the african national congress.
tso: loko hi ri karhi hi languta eka nkayakayo lowu nga emiddle east na ngopfungo pfu eka ku xaniseka ka vanhu va palestina, swi ta va kahle ku tsundzuka marito ya selby msimang, xirho xa vatumbu luxi va african national congress.

eng: in the aftermath of the bulhoek massacre he wrote: "history has shown that the human soul naturally revolts against injustice".
tso: eka switandzhaku swa ku yayarheriwa ka vanhu ka le bulhoek u tsale leswi: "matimu ya kombile leswaku moya wa munhu hi ntumbu luko wa wona wu pfukela matimba yo lwisana na ku pfumaleka ka vululami".

eng: the protests and the revolt of the oppressed people of south africa against colonialism and apartheid proved the veracity of this prophecy.
tso: ku kombisa ku vilela na ku pfukela matimba yo lwa ka vanhu lava tshikeleriweke va afrikadzonga ehenhla ka mfumo wa xikoloni na wa xihlawuhlawu swi kombe ntiyiso wa leswi a nga swi purofeta.

eng: protect children from cyberbullying kgaogelo letsebe csir experts use technology to try and eliminate cyberbullying the cruelty and devastating effects of cyberbul lying on children have been laid bare in recent months.
tso: sirhelela vana eka nxaniso wa le ka inthanete kgaogelo letsebe vativinkulu va le ka csir va tirhisa thekinoloji ku ringeta ku herisa nxaniso wa le ka inthanete tihanyi na switandzha ku swo onhetela swa nxaniso wa le ka intha nete eka vana swi humeseri wile erivaleni eka tin’hweti leta ha ku hundzaka.

eng: in a recent case of cyberbullying, grade 10 learner lufuno mavhunga, from mbilwi secondary school in limpopo, died by suicide after being beaten by another learner.
tso: eka mhaka leya ha ku endle kaka ya nxaniso wa le ka intha nete, mudyondzi wa le ka gire di ya 10 lufuno mavhunga, kusuka eka xikolo xa sekonda ri xa mbilwi elimpopo, u lovi le hi ku tisunga endzhaku ko biwa hi mudyondzi un’wana.

eng: mavhunga overdosed on prescription pills after the video of the beating was shared on social media.
tso: mavhunga u nwile maphilisi lama nyikiwaka hi vatirhi va swa vutshunguri a hundzisa nhlayo leyi faneleke endzhaku kaloko vhidiyo ya ku biwa ka yena yi hangalasiwile eka swihangalasamahungu swa vaaki.

eng: cyber security experts from the council for scientific and industrial research (csir) say cyberbullying is extremely harmful to children and can lead to depression, sadness, anger, frustration, anxiety and fear.
tso: vativinkulu va vusirheleri bya le ka inthanete kusuka eka khansele ya ndzavisiso wa sayense na vumaki (csir) va vula leswaku nxaniso wa le ka inthanete wa vavisa swinene eka vana naswona swi nga vangela ntshikelelamiehleketo, gome, nhlundzuko, ku hela ntamu, richuho na nchavo.

eng: "it can also lead to low selfesteem, delinquency, school violence, family problems and suicidal thoughts," explains csir senior researcher sipho ngobeni.
tso: "swi nga tlhela swi vangela ku pfumaleka ka ku titshemba, ku tlula nawu eka milandzu ya xikalo xo vevuka, madzolonga ya le swikolweni, swiphiqo swa le mindyangwini na mie hleketo yo tisunga," ku hlamu sela mulavisisinkulu wa le ka csir sipho ngobeni.

eng: cyberbullying occurs when someone uses electronic communication to intentionally harass, threaten, embarrass, intimidate, stalk, humiliate or make fun of another person.
tso: nxaniso wa le ka inthanete wu humelela loko munhu un’wana a tirhisa vuhlanganisi bya xielekitironiki havomu ku va a karhata, a xungeta, a khomisa tingana, a chaviseta, a sala endzhaku, a susa ndzhuti, kumbe a hundzula munhu wun’wana xihlekiso.

eng: ngobeni says research shows that 41% of children develop social anxiety after experiencing cyberbullying, 37% develop depression, 26% have suicidal thoughts and 25% engage in selfharm.
tso: ngobeni u ri ndzavisiso wu komba leswaku 41% ta vana va sungula ku va na richuho ra vanhu endzhaku ko hlangana na nxaniso wa le ka inthanete, 37% ti khomiwa hi ntshikele lamiehleketo, 26% ti na mie hleketo yo tisunga, kasi 25% ti endla swiendlo swo tivavisa.

eng: "these findings show that cyberbullying is a serious issue... getting everyone involved – youth, parents, educators, law enforcement and social media companies – is the key to dealing with this problem," he adds.
tso: "swikumiwa leswi swi komba leswaku nxaniso wa le ka inthanete i mhaka leyi tivikanaka... ku endla leswaku vanhu hinkwavo va khumbeka – vantshwa, vatswari, vadyo ndzisi, vasindzisi va nawu na tikhamphani ta swihanga lasamahungu swa vaaki – i swa nkoka eka ku lwisana na xiphiqo lexi," a engetela.

eng: most cyberbullying, 42%, occurs on instagram, 31% on facebook, 31% on snapchat, 12% on whatsapp, 10% on youtube and 9% on twitter.
tso: nxaniso wa le ka inthanete hi xitalo, 42%, wu humelela eka instagram , 31% eka facebook , 31% eka snapchat, 12% eka whatsapp , 10% eka youtube na 9% eka twitter .

eng: csir expert rofhiwa netshiya says there is a need for public education about all forms of cyberbullying.
tso: mutivinkulu wa le ka csir rofhiwa netshiya u vula leswaku ku na xidingo xo dyo ndzisa vaaki hi mayelana na mixaka hinkwayo ya nxaniso wa le ka inthanete.

eng: "we need to educate children that cyberbullying can lead to serious consequences," she says.
tso: "hi dinga ku dyondzisa vana leswaku nxaniso wa le ka inthanete wu nga va na switandzhaku swo tivikana" a vula.

eng: to tackle cyberbullying, the csir team is working on a platform that detects bullying in chatrooms.
tso: ku tirhana na nxaniso wa le ka inthanete, xipano xa le ka csir xi le ku lulamiseni ka pulatifomo leyi yi kotaka ku thumba nxaniso eka tichati rhumu.

eng: "the platform will automatically detect cyberbullying on chat groups and block users who continue to send hate speech.
tso: "pulatifomo leyi yi ta thumba xikan’wekan’we loko ku ri na nxaniso wa le ka inthanete lowu humelelaka eka mitlawa yo chata kutani yi pfala vati rhisi lava va yaka emahlweni va rhumela mbulavulo wa rivengo.

eng: it will give the user three warning messages and, if they persist, it will block them," says netshiya.
tso: yi ta nyika mutirhisi swihungwana swo tsundzuxa swinharhu, kutani loko a phikelela, yi ta n’wi pfala," ku vula netshiya.

eng: she advises parents to install basic internet monitoring software on their children's devices to monitor their activities.
tso: u tsundzuxa vatswari ku hoxa sofuwere yo veka tihlo ya inthanete ya masungulo eka switirhisiwa swa vana va vona ku kota ku veka tihlo migingiriko ya vona.

eng: "there are lowcost products that can invisibly monitor the activities of your kids and privately email you the results as often as you like.
tso: "ku na swimakiwa swa nxavo wa le hansi leswi nga veka tihlo migingiriko ya vana va wena vona va nga swi voni kutani swi ku imeyilela mivuyelo hi mikarhi leyi u yi lavaka.

eng: these are very important to track internet sites visited, downloads, chatroom conversations and instant messaging.
tso: i swa nkoka swinene ku landzelerisa tiwebusayiti ta inthanete leti va nga nghena eka wona, swo dawunilodiwa, miburisano ya le ka chatirhumu na swihu ngwana swa xikan’wekan’we."

eng: "the csir offers the following tips for parents who suspect their children are victims of cyberbullying: ensure the child feels safe, show unconditional support.
tso: csir yi nyika switsundzuxo leswi landzelaka eka vatswari lava va ehleketelelaka leswaku vana va vona i vaxanisiwa va nxaniso wa le ka inthanete: tiyisisa leswaku n’wana u titwa a hlayisekile, komba ku n’wi seketela handle ka swipimelo.

eng: work with your child to arrive at a course of action that you both agree on.
tso: tirhisana na n’wana wa wena ku fikelela goza leri hinkwenu mi pfumelela naka na rona.

eng: discuss the cyberbullying matter with the relevant school.
tso: kanelani mhaka ya nxaniso wa le ka inthanete na xikolo lexi khumbekaka.

eng: sa strives to realise the vision of the constitution vukuzenzele unnamed sixty years ago, on 31 may 1961, apartheid south africa became a republic, cutting its ties with the british empire.
tso: afrikadzonga ri tikarhatela ku vona leswaku xivono xa vumbiwa xa humelela vukuzenzele unnamed makumetsevu wa malembe lama hundzeke, hi ti 31 mudyaxihi 1961, afrikadzonga ya xihlawuhlawu ri ve rhiphabiliki, kutani ri tsema vuxaka bya rona na mfumo wa britain.

eng: while a ‘republic’ is generally defined as a state in which supreme power is held by the people and their elected representatives, this was not the case in south africa.
tso: kambe loko ra ha ri ‘rhipha biliki’ hi ntolovelo ri vuriwa tanihi tiko leri matimba la makulu ya rona ma nga eka vanhu ni le ka vayimeri lava hlawuriweke, leswi a swi nga ri tano eafrikadzonga.

eng: the constitution of the apartheid republic pledged allegiance to god, "who gathered our forebears together from many lands and gave them this as their own".
tso: vumbiwa ra rhiphabiliki ra xihlawuhlawu a ri tinyikele ku tshembela eka xikwembu, "leri a ri hlengelete vakokwa ni wa hina swin’we ku suka eka tindhawu to hambana hambana kutani ri va nyika tanihi hi ra vona".

eng: it was a constitution written by and for a racial minority, and it used faith to justify tyranny.
tso: i vumbiwa leri a ri tsariwe ni ku tsaleriwa ntlawa wa rixaka leritsongo, kutani va tirhisa ripfumelo ku tiyimele la eka tihanyi.

eng: it outlined the administration of government, providing that only white people were eligible to vote and serve as public representatives.
tso: ri andlale ma fambiselo ya mfumo, ri nyika valungu matimba yo hlawula ku tirha tanihi vayimeri va vaaki.

eng: it contained no bill of rights.
tso: a ri nga ri na nawu wa timfanelo ta vanhu.

eng: the country’s majority was relegated to a footnote towards the end of its 121 provisions, in a section titled ‘administration of bantu affairs, etc.’.
tso: vunyingi bya vanhu va tiko a byi chichiwile xiyimo ku ya ekuheleni ka malembe ya 121 ya nawu lowu, eka xiyenge lexi a xi thyiwile ‘admini stration of bantu affairs, na swin’wana.’eka hungu leri kombisi weke eka makombakule, holobyenkulu hf verwoerd u te: "hi lava nhluvukiso wa mitlawa ya hina hikatsongo tsongo leswaku wu kongoma eka tlhelo ro karhi.

eng: in a televised message, prime minister hf verwoerd said: "we seek the gradual development of each of our groups in a certain direction.
tso: laha xi tshunxo lexi hi xi lavaka xa le rivaleni i ku hlayisa voko ra lavobasa eka vufambisi.

eng: "we are very happy to be a united people," he declared to the world.
tso: ""hi tsakile swinene ku kho mana hi va vanhu van’we," a tiyisisa eka misava hinkwayo.

eng: but the reality was that we were not a united people.
tso: kambe ntiyiso a ku ri le swaku a hi nga ri vanhu lava a hi khomanile.

eng: we were inhabitants of a country where one’s rights, prospects and life expectancy was determined by one’s race.
tso: a hi ri vatshami eka tiko leri timfanelo ta van’wana, leswi languteriweke ni nkarhi wa ku hanya a swi lawuriwa hi rixaka ra yena.

eng: for two decades, the republic of south africa constitution act of 1961 was the legal impetus for the repression of nearly 90% of the south african population.
tso: ku ringana malembekhume mambirhi, nawu wa vumbi wa ra afrikadzonga wa 1961 a ku ri nawu lowu a wu hlohlotela ku tshikeleriwa ka kwalomu ka 90% wa rixaka ra maafrikadzonga.

eng: this unhappy anniversary took place in the same month that we celebrated the 25th anniversary of the adoption by the constitutional assembly of our new democratic constitution, which became the birth certificate of a real united nation.
tso: ku tlangela ko vava ku vile kona hi n’hweti yin’we ni leyi hi tlangeleke 25 wa malelmbe yo tsundzuka ku simekiwa ka huvonkulu ya nawu wa vumbiwa ra hina lerintshwa ra xidemokirasi, leri veke xi tifikheti xo tivisa ku velekiwa ka rixaka leri khomaneke hi ntiyiso.

eng: now we have one law for one nation.
tso: sweswi hi ni nawu wun’we wa rixaka rin’we.

eng: together, we have chosen for ourselves a system of government that gives true meaning to the concept of a republic.
tso: kun’we, hi tihlawulele sisi teme ya mfumo leyi nyikaka nhlamuselo ya ntiyiso eka miehleketo ya rhiphabiliki.

eng: we have said that in our democratic republic, everyone is equal before the law and has the right to equal protection and benefit of the law.
tso: hi boxile eka rhiphabiliki ra hina ra xidemokirasi, le swaku vanhu hinkwavo va ringana emahlweni ka nawu naswona va ni lunghelo ro sirheleriwa ni ku vuyeriwa ka nawu ku fana.

eng: south africa today is a country where the administration of justice is vested in independent courts and a judiciary that is subject only to the constitution.
tso: namuntlha afrikadzonga i tiko laha mafambiselo ya nawu ya simekiweke ehenhla ka tikhoto leti tiyimeleke hi toxe ni vafambisi va nawu lava xiximaka vumbiwa ntsena.

eng: we live in a country where everyone has the right to approach the courts for the fulfilment of their rights.
tso: hi hanya eka tiko leri vanhu hinkwavo va nga ni timfanelo to kongoma tikhoto ku enerisa timfanelo ta vona.

eng: we live in a country where communities can stake a legal claim on land they were forcefully moved from, and where individuals or families are protected against arbitrary eviction from their homes.
tso: hi hanya eka tiko leri vaa katiko va nga koxaka xinawu misava leyi va rhurisiweke eka yona hi nkanu, laha munhu kumbe mindyangu yi sirheleriwaka eka ku rhu risiwa hi nkanu emakaya ya vona swi nga fanelanga.

eng: we live in a country where everyone is permitted to freely practise their culture and traditions.
tso: hi hanya eka tiko leri vanhu hinkwavo va pfumeleriwaka ku endla mfuwo ni mindha vuko ya vona va ntshuxekile.

eng: it is a country where anyone can freely protest in support of social, political and other causes anywhere.
tso: i tiko leri un’wana ni un’wana a nga ni mfanelo yo vilela a nga chavi hi ku seketela vaaki, tipolitiki ni swin’wana ni swin’wana kun’wana ni kun’wana.

eng: our constitutional dispensation is premised on accountable government, where the executive is answerable to the people and where parliament is representative of the people.
tso: vumbiwa ra hina ra sweswi ri simekiwe ehenhla ka vu tihlamuleri bya mfumo, laha vafambisi va nga ni vutihla muleri eka vanhu naswona laha palemente yi nga muyi meri wa vanhu.

eng: it is a country where the law applies equally to any citizen.
tso: i tiko laha nawu wu tirhaka ku ringana eka wihi ni wihi.

eng: we now have a government of the people, for the people and by the people.
tso: sweswi hi ni mfumo wa vanhu, lowu endleriweke vanhu, naswona hi vanhu.

eng: when the apartheid regime triumphantly paraded its racist constitution to the world 60 years ago, it had misplaced confidence that it would endure.
tso: loko mfumo wa xihlawu hlawu wu kombisa vumbiwa ra wona ra xihlawulambala hi vutikukumuxi emisaveni hinkwayo eka malembe ya 60 lama hundzeke, a va ri ni ku tshemba leswaku ku ta va hilaha ku nga heriki.

eng: in an unanswered letter to verwoerd a month before the republic was declared, nelson mandela affirmed the liberation movement’s rejection of the forcibly imposed white republic.
tso: eka papila ra verwoerd leri a ri nga hlamuriwanga, n’hweti ku nga si hlamba nyiwa rhiphabiliki, nelson mandela u tiyisisile leswaku mihlangano ya ntshuxeko yi bakanyerile etlhelo rhiphabi liki ra nsindziso ra lavobasa.

eng: he said that no constitution or form of government decided without the participation of the african people would enjoy moral validity.
tso: u boxile leswaku vumbiwa kumbe mfumo wo karhi lowu tekeriweke xiboho ku nga ri ni ku katsiwa ka vanhu va maafrika a wu nga ta va ni ntikelo eka vumunhu .

eng: indeed no system that entrenches the systematic denial of people’s rights can be sustained.
tso: i ntiyiso leswaku a ku na sisiteme leyi timitsu ta yona ti nga alana ni sisiteme ya timfanelo ta vanhu yi nga tiyiselaka.

eng: though it would be over three decades before the demands of the liberation movement were met, we eventually won our freedom.
tso: hambileswi ku nga ku tlula malembekhume manharhu ku nga si fika ku koxa ka ntshuxeko hi mihlangano ya ntshuxeko, hi kale hi wina ntshuxeko.

eng: in relegating the apartheid constitution to the dustbin of history, we committed ourselves to a new constitution and a new set of values.
tso: ekucukumetiweni ka vumbiwa ra xihlawuhlawu etaleni ra matimu hi tinyikele eka vumbiwa lerintshwa ni le ka nawu wa mahanyelo mantshwa.

eng: when i addressed the constitutional assembly 25 years ago, i said our constitution must become more than words on a page; it must become a reality in the lives of our people.
tso: loko ndzi andlale mbu lavulo eka huvonkulu ya vumbiwa 25 wa malembe lama nga hundza, ndzi boxile leswaku vumbiwa ra hina ri fanele ku tlula leswi tsari weke; ri fanele ku va ntiyiso eka vutomi bya vanhu.

eng: unless we do so, this progressive and revolutionary document will be rendered irrelevant and meaningless.
tso: loko hi nga endli tano, tsalwa leri ra nhluvuko ni ntshuxeko ri ta va ri nga pfuni nchumu kumbe ku vula nchumu.

eng: we have long decided what kind of society we want to be.
tso: i khale hi tekile xiboho xa leswaku hi lava ku va vanhu va njhani.

eng: it is a society rooted in human dignity, equality, freedom and nondiscrimination.
tso: hi vanhu lava simekiweke eka vumunhu, ndzingano, ntshuxeko ni nkalaxihlawuhlawu.

eng: for a quarter of a century we have worked to build such a society.
tso: ku ringana kotara ya ma lembedzana hi tirhile ku aka rixaka ro tani.

eng: we have made undeniable progress, but we still have many challenges and there is much work still to be done.
tso: hi endlile ku humelela loku nga kanete kiki, kambe ha ha ri ni mi tlhontlho leyotala naswona ka ha ri ni ntirho wo tala lowa ha faneleke ku endliwa.

eng: as we mark the anniversary of the adoption of our democratic constitution, let us remember what a decisive break it was with the system underpinned by racism, exploitation, dispossession and oppression that had come before.
tso: loko hi ri karhi hi tsundzu ka ku simekiwa ka vumbiwa ra hina ra xidemokirasi, a hi tsundzukeni xiboho lexi hi xi tekeke ku tshova mafambi selo ya xihlawulambala, ku xanisiwa, ku tekeriwa swilo ni ku tshikeleriwa loku nga va kona ekusunguleni.

eng: let us also remember that it is up to us to make the vision contained in our constitution a reality.
tso: a hi tlheleni hi tsundzuka leswaku swi le mavokweni ya hina ku endla leswaku xivono lexi nga eka vumbiwa ra hina xa hetiseka.

eng: dreams come true for tafelkop community vukuzenzele unnamed a group of black farmers in tafelkop in grob lersdal, limpopo are the proud owners of 189 hectares of land, which they have been farming for the past 25 years.
tso: milorho ya vaaki va le tafelkop yi hetiseka vukuzenzele unnamed ntlawa wa van’wa mapurasi va va ntima etafelkop egroblersdal, elimpo po, i vatinyungubyisi va vun’winyi bya tihekitara ta 189 ta misava, leti va nga rima eka tona ku ri ngana malembe ya 25 lama hundzeke.

eng: the 30 farmers received title deeds for the land from president cyril ramaphosa after the department of public works and infrastructure transferred it for land redistribution purposes.
tso: van’wamapurasi va 30 va amukele mapapila ya vun’winyi bya misava yo huma eka presidente cyril ramaphosa endzhaku ka loko ndzawulo ya mitirho ya mfumo ni switirhisiwa yi hundzisele misava hi swikongomelo swo yi ava hi vuntshwa.

eng: the land is valued at more than r25.5 million, but was handed over to the farmers for free.
tso: misava yi na nkoka wo tlula r25.5 wa mamili yoni kambe yi nyiketiwile van’wamapurasi mahala.

eng: "this is indeed a great day for the community of tafelkop, for the people of limpopo and for the whole of south africa.
tso: "hakunene leri i siku lerikulu eka vaaki va le ta felkop, vanhu va le limpo po, ni le ka afrikadzonga hinkwaro."

eng: "today we are witnessing a community’s dream being fulfilled.
tso: "namuntlha hi le ku mbho niyeleni ka ku hetiseka ka norho wa vaaki.

eng: it is the vision that this community has spent the past 25 years fighting to see realised," said the president at the handover ceremony.
tso: lexi i xi vono lexi vaaki lava va nga heta 25 wa malembe va karhi va lwela leswaku xi hetiseka.

eng: the farmers have been successfully farming various agricultural produce on the land since 1996. they organised themselves in the 1990s to be registered commercial farmers under the banner of the tafelkop farmers association and started to engage government.
tso: van’wamapurasi a va ri karhi va humelela hi ku rima swihumelerisiwa swa vurimi swo hambanaha mbana eka misava ku sukela hi 1996. va tikondleterile eka ma lembe ya va 1990s leswaku va titsarisela tanihi varimi lavakulu ehansi ka nhlanga no wa tafelkop farmers a ssociation kutani va sungula ku vulavurisana na mfumo.

eng: in 2000, the then national department of agriculture entered into lease agreements with the tafelkop farmers association in terms of the land redistribution for agricultural development programme.
tso: hi 2000, khale ka ndzawu lo ya tiko ya swa vurimi yi endlile ntwanano wo lom bisa ni nhlangano wa tafe lkop farmers association hi ku landza phurogireme ya nhluvukiso wa swa vurimi yo avela misava.

eng: in 2009, the former limpopo department of agri culture recommended to the department of public works that the land be transferred to the farmers.
tso: hi 2009, khale ka ndzawulo ya swa vurimi ya limpopo yi bumabumele leswaku ndzawulo ya mitirho ya mfumo yi hundzisela mi sava eka varimi.

eng: the deeds were registered in the names of the farmers earlier this year.
tso: vun’winyi byi tsarisiwile hi mavito ya van’wamapurasi ekusungeleni ka lembe leri.

eng: the land is currently being used to farm tobacco, cotton and fresh produce.
tso: sweswi misava yi tirhisiwa ku rima fole, khotoni ni matsavu.

eng: thirtytwo households are supported by the land and farming activities which provide employment to 128 permanent workers and up to 320 seasonal workers.
tso: makumenharhumbirhi wa mindyangu yi tunderiwa hi misava naswona migingiri ko ya vurimi yi thole vatirhi va 128 va nkarhi hinkwawo ni vatirhi va 320 va tinguva.

eng: justice for the communitythe president said the com munity had endured many hardships over the years and the "title deeds bring justice to a dispossessed community".
tso: vululami eka vaakipresidente u boxile leswaku vaaki va tiyisele mitlhontlho malembe lama hundzeke ku tani "mapapila ya vun’winyi ya tisa vululami eka vaaki lava a va tekeriwe misava".

eng: "we have not forgotten the dispossession, land theft and forced removals that the people of this community and many communities across the country had to endure.
tso: "a hi rivalanga ku teke riwa, ku yiveriwa misava ni ku rhurisiwa hi nkanu loku vanhu va muganga lowu ni yin’wana miganga laha tikweni va nga ku tiyisela.

eng: "we have not forgotten the harsh legacy of farming here in limpopo, where farmdwellers were forced to be labour tenants on their forefathers’ land and not allowed to own land to feed their families or graze their animals."
tso: "a hi rivalanga ndzhaka yo tika ya vurimi laha limpopo, laha vatshami va le mapura sini a va tlimbeletiwa ku va vatirhi ni valuveri eka mi sava ya vakokwa wa vona, naswona va nga pfumele riwi ku va vinyi va misava leswaku va kota ku tundela mindyangu ya vona ni ku va ni madyelo ya swifuwo swa vona.

eng: he added that black farmworkers were exploited and abused in what was previously the northern transvaal.
tso: "u engetele hi ku vula leswa ku varimi va vantima a va nga khomiwi kahle ni ku xanisiwa eka transvaal n’walungu wa khale.

eng: "we also recall how the apartheid government supported white farmers with equipment, technical support and access to credit to build their businesses, but black subsistence farmers struggled to survive.
tso: "hi tsundzuka ni hi ndlela leyi mfumo wa xihlawuhlawu a wu seke tela varimi va valungu hi switirhisiwa, nseketelo wa xithekiniki ni ku fikelela vu lombi bya swikweleti ku aka mabindzu ya vona, kambe varimitsongo va vantima a va tikeriwa ku humelela.

eng: "transforming the agricultural industrythe president said the trans fer of land inspires hope because it shows that with the right support and opportunities, the agricultural industry can be transformed for the benefit of the country.
tso: "ku hluvukisa bindzu ra vurimipresidente u boxile leswaku ku hundziseriwa ka misava swi hlohlotela ntshembo hikuva swi komba leswaku hi ku kuma nseketelo lowu faneleke ni nkateko, bindzu ra swa vurimi ri nga hlu vukisiwa leswaku tiko ri vuyeriwa.

eng: "we celebrate our progress, because day by day our land reform programme is gaining momentum.
tso: "hi tlangela ku humelela, hikuva siku na siku phu rogireme ya mpfuxeto wa misava yi ya yi hatlisa.

eng: "to date, government has redistributed over five million hectares of land, totalling around 5 500 farms, to more than 300 000 beneficiaries."
tso: ""ku fikela sweswi, mfumo se wu tlherisele ku tlula ntlhanu wa mamiliyoni wa tihekitara ta misava, leswi ringanaka ni kwalomu ka 5 500 wa mapurasi, eka ku tlula 300 000 wa vadya ndzhaka.

eng: so far, the land restitution process has benefited over two million land claimants and resulted in the transfer of around 2.7 million hectares.
tso: "ku fikela sweswi, mafa mbiselo yo tlherisela misava ya se ya vuyerise kwalomu ka mamiliyoni mambirhi ya vakoxi va misava leswi fikeleriseke eka ku hundzi sela kwalomu ka 2.7 wa ma miliyoni wa tihekitara.

eng: "land reform isn’t just in the interests of redress, justice and social cohesion.
tso: "mpfuxeto wa misava a hi xikongomelo xo lulamisa ntsena, vululami ni ntwa nano wa vaaki.

eng: it is also about economic development.
tso: swi nga tlhe la swi fanela ku hluvukisa ikhonomi.

eng: agriculture and the agriculture value chain can and must transform rural economies," said president ramaphosa.
tso: vurimi ni ntikelo wa byona swi fanele swi cinca tiikhonomi ta le mati koxikaya," ku vula presi dente ramaphosa.

eng: government plans to establish a land and agrarian reform agency to fasttrack land reform.
tso: mfumo wu kunguhata ku tumbuluxa nhlangano wo hluvukisa swa vurimi ku hatlisisa mpfuxeto wa misava.

eng: "we are looking at how effective our past policies have been.
tso: "hi languta hilaha tipholisi ta nkarhi lowu nga hundza ti tirheke hakona.

eng: we are going to address this issue of land reform urgently.
tso: hi ta tirhana ni ku pfuxeta loku ka misava hi xihatla.

eng: "addressing past mistakesthe president said govern ment was working hard to correct what went wrong during the apartheid years and since the start of de mocracy.
tso: "ku lulamisa swi hoxo swa nkarhi lowu nga hundzapresidente u boxile leswa ku mfumo wu tirhana ni ku lulamisa hi matimba swihoxo leswi humeleleke hi nkarhi wa malembe ya xihlawuhlawu ni hi ku sungula ka malembe ya xidemokirasi.

eng: "land reform is vital to improving the country’s food security, building an inclusive economy and providing a better future for all south africans, added the president.
tso: "mpfuxeto wa misava wu ni nkoka eka ku tlakusa nhlayiseko wa swakudya swa tiko, ku aka ikhonomi hi ku angarhela ni ku endla vumundzuku byo antswa eka maafrikadzonga hinkwavo, ku engetela pre sidente.

eng: he urged the tafelkop farmers to use the land wisely and for the benefit of the community.
tso: u komberile van’wama purasi va le tafelkop ku tirhisa misava hi vukheta ku vuyerisa vaaki.

eng: "for me, today has been the best day in the office; to kick the soil and dust and see your produce.
tso: "eka mina, namuntlha ri vile siku ra nkoka ehofisini; ku raha misava ni ritshuri ni ku vona swihumelerisiwa swa n’wina.

eng: "i have no doubt that with the commitment and energy of all involved, this project will continue to thrive," he said.
tso: ""a ndzi ni ku kanakana hi vutiyimiseri ni matimba ya hinkwavo lava nga ni xiave, projeke leyi yi ta ya ema hlweni yi kula," a vula tano.

eng: chairperson of the tafelkop farmers association jerry sefoloshe thanked government for making it possible for the farmers to become the owners of the land they have worked for decades.
tso: mutshamaxitulu wa ta felkop farmers association jerry sefoloshe u khensile mfumo ku va wu endlile leswaku van’wamapurasi va va vinyi va misava leyi va tirheke eka yona malembe ni malembe.

eng: the youth are our greatest asset vukuzenzele unnamed on june 16th 1976, the youth of soweto and other parts of the country rose up against the iniquity of bantu education.
tso: vantshwa i rifuwo ra hina lerikulukumba vukuzenzele unnamed hi siku ra 16 khotavuxika 1976, vantshwa va le soweto na le ka swiphemu swin’wana swa laha tikweni va yimile hi milenge va lwisa na na vubihi bya dyondzo ya vantima.

eng: on that day and in the days that followed, many lost their lives.
tso: hi siku rolero na le ka masiku lama nga landzela, vanhu vo tala va lahleke riwe hi vutomi bya vona.

eng: they were killed by a callous regime that had little regard for black lives and thought nothing of opening fire on unarmed, uniformed schoolchildren.
tso: va dlayiwile hi mfumo lowo pfumala ntwelavusiwana lowu a wu nga ri na mhaka na vutomi bya vantima na ku nga karhatiwi hi nchumu loko va duvula vana va xikolo lava a va nga hlomangi, lava a va ambale yunifomo.

eng: these events hardened international opinion against the apartheid regime and gave further impetus to the liberation struggle.
tso: swiendleko leswi swi nonohise mavonelo ya matiko ya misava ehenhla ka mfumo wa xihlawuhlawu na ku khutaza ku ya ema hlweni ka nyimpi yo lwela ntshunxeko.

eng: young people have always been at the forefront of social protest, from the antiauthoritarian protests in latin america in the late 1950s, to the protests across africa in the late 1960s.
tso: vantshwa va tshamile va ri emahlweni ka ku kombisa ku vilela ka vanhu hi mika rhi hinkwayo, kusukela eka ku kombisa ku vilela ko alelana na mafumelo yo lerisa elatin amerika ekuheleni ka malembe ya va1950, kuya eka ku kombisa ku vilela eafrika hinkwayo ekuheleni ka malembe ya va1960.

eng: history faithfully records the contribution of the generation of 1976 to the international student movement and its stance against oppression and injustice.
tso: matimu ma rhekhoda hi ndlela yo tshembeka ku hoxa xandla ka rixaka ra 1976 eka nhlangano wa swichudeni wa matiko ya misava na xiyimo xa ka wona ehenhla ka ntshikelelo na nkavululami.

eng: this historic event 45 years ago continues to be commemorated across africa and the world.
tso: xiendleko lexa nkoka eka matimu 45 wa malembe lama nga hundza xi ya emahlweni na ku tsundzu kiwa eafrika hinkwayo na le misaveni hinkwayo.

eng: it is therefore disturbing that knowledge of june 16th is diminishing among young south africans.
tso: hikokwalaho swi twisaka ku vava leswaku vutivi bya siku ra 16 khotavuxika byi le ku nyamalaleni exikarhi ka vantshwa va laha afrikadzonga.

eng: this is particularly so among the socalled generation z, or young people born between 1997 and 2015. the 2019/2020 south african social attitudes survey published by the human sciences research council found that close to 40% of generation z has not heard of the historical events of june 16th.
tso: leswi swi tano ngopfungopfu exikarhi ka lava vuriwaka rixaka ra z, kumbe vantshwa lava nga velekiwa exikarhi ka 1997 na 2015. mbalango wa maehleketelelo ya vanhu va afri kadzonga wa 2019/2020 lowu hangalasiweke hi khansele ya ndzavisiso wa tisayense ta ximunhu wu kume leswaku kwalomu ka 40% ta rixaka ra z a ri si tshama ri twa hi swiendleko leswa nkoka eka matimu swa siku ra 16 khotavuxika.

eng: a similar percentage has heard about it but knows very little or nothing about it.
tso: nhlayo hi tiphesente leyi fanaka yi twile hi mayelana na swona kambe yi tiva switsongo kumbe ku nga tivi nchumu hi mayelana na swona.

eng: nevertheless, the survey also found that young people of this generation are open to learning about key historical events and believe in their continued importance.
tso: hambiswiritano, mbala ngo lowu wu tlhele wu kuma leswaku vantshwa va rixaka leri va swi lava ku dyondza hi swiendleko swa matimu ya nkoka naswona va tshe mba eka ku tshama swi ri swa nkoka ku ya ema hlweni.

eng: we need to do more as a country to ensure that the message of 1976 is transmitted faithfully.
tso: hi dinga ku endla swo tala tanihi tiko ku tiyisisa leswaku hungu ra 1976 ri hundziseriwa emahlweni hi ku tshembeka.

eng: this is a collective responsibility of government, schools, tertiary institutions, parents, families, musicians, artists, and all of society.
tso: lebyi i vutihlamuleri bya nhlanganelo bya mfumo, swikolo, mihlangano ya dyondzo ya le henhla, vatswari, mindyangu, vayi mbeleri, vatshila, na rixaka hinkwaro.

eng: the generation that was born after apartheid ended inherited a country with a democratic constitution and where fundamental freedoms are protected.
tso: rixaka leri nga velekiwa endzhakukaloko mfumo wa xihlawuhlawu wu heri siwile ri kume ndzhaka ya tiko leri nga na vumbiwa ra xidemokirasi naswona laha mitshunxeko ya nkoka yi sirheleriwaka.

eng: the opportunities young black people have today are both vastly different and greatly improved.
tso: swivandlanene leswi va ntshwa va vantima va nga na swona namuntlha havumbirhi swi hambanile swinene na ku va swi antswile swinene.

eng: keeping the story of june 16th alive is a reminder to today’s generation of the great sacrifices made to secure their freedom.
tso: ku kondletela xitori xa 16 khotavuxika xi hanya i xitsundzuxo eka rixaka ra namuntlha xa ku titsona swo tala lokukulu loku endli weke ku kuma ntshunxeko.

eng: youth day is a reminder of the immense power and agency that young people have to create a better future for themselves.
tso: siku ra vantshwa i xitsu ndzuxo xa matimba lama kulu na vuyimeri bya leswaku vantshwa va fanele ku titumbuluxela vumu ndzuku byo antswa.

eng: the struggles of young people in south africa today are many.
tso: ku kayakaya ka vantshwa eafrikadzonga namuntlha ku tele.

eng: young people have remained at the forefront of activism, whether in pursuit of free education or against social ills like genderbased violence.
tso: vantshwa va tshame va ri emahlweni ka vugi ngirikeli, hambi eku laveni ka dyondzo ya mahala kumbe ku lwisana na swilo leswi karhataka vanhu ku fana na madzolonga lama simekiweke eka rimbewu.

eng: today the greatest struggle young people wage is against unemployment, which has worsened under the covid19 pandemic.
tso: namuntlha nyimpi le yikulu leyikulukumba leyi vantshwa va nga hi hloma i ku lwisana na ku pfumaleka ka mitirho, leswi nga nyanya ehansi ka ntungukulu wa covid19.

eng: creating more opportunities for young people, and access to these opportunities, is government’s foremost priority.
tso: ku tumbuluxela vantshwa swivandlanene, na ku fikelela swivandlanene swoleswo, i xirhangana lexikulu xa mfumo.

eng: everything that we do as a government contributes towards improving the lives of young people.
tso: hinkwaswo leswi hi swi endlaka tanihi mfumo swi hoxa xandla eka ku antswisa vutomi bya vantshwa.

eng: tackling youth unemployment requires accelerating economic growth, particularly in labourintensive sectors, and building the capability of the state to fulfil its developmental role.
tso: ku tirhana na ku pfumaleka ka mitirho eka vantshwa swi lava ku hatlisisa ku kula ka ikhonomi, ngopfungo pfu tisekitara leti tirhisaka vatirhi vo tala kutlula mi chini, na ku aka vuswikoti bya mfumo byo hetisisa ntirho wa wona wa nhluvukiso.

eng: we are also driving this agenda through targeted interventions.
tso: hi tlhela hi lawula ajenda leyi hi ku tirhisa miphalalo leyi pakanisiweke.

eng: these include the presidential employment stimulus, which has provided work opportunities and livelihoods support for many young people.
tso: leswi swi katsaxihlohloteri xa miti rho wa phuresidente, lexi xi nyikeke swiva ndlanene swa mitirho na nseketelo wa vutihanyisi eka vantshwa.

eng: we have launched a range of additional measures to create opportunities, enhance skills development, support young entrepreneurs and enable the full participation of young people in the economy.
tso: hi simekile magoza yo hambanahambana yo engetela ku tumbuluxa swivandlanene, ku tiyisa nhluvukiso wa swikili, ku seketela van’wamabi ndzu va vantshwa na ku endla leswaku vantshwa va kota ku teka xiave eka ikhonomi hi ku hetiseka.

eng: this includes the establishment of a national pathway management network, sa youth, to make it easier for young people to view and access opportunities and receive active support to find pathways into the labour market.
tso: leswi swi katsa ku tumbu luxiwa ka netiweke ya malawulelo ya ndlela ya rixaka, vantshwa va afrikadzonga, ku olovi sela vantshwa ku vona na ku fikelela swivandlanene na ku kuma nseketelo lowu tirhaka wo kuma tindlela to nghena eka makete wa vatirhi.

eng: these are among the priorities of the presidential youth employment intervention, which was launched just weeks before we entered a national lockdown last year and which is now entering full implementation.
tso: leswi swi kumeka exi karhi ka swirhangana swa mphalalo wa ku thoriwa ka vantshwa wa phuresidente, loku nga simekiwa mavhiki hi nga se nghena eka ku pfariwa ka tiko hinkwaro lembe leri nga hundza naswona leswi se swi sungulaka ku tirhisiwa hi ku hetiseka.

eng: the presidential youth employment intervention was built on the understanding that addressing the youth unemployment crisis requires innovative thinking and strong partnerships across society.
tso: mphalalo wa ku thoriwa ka vantshwa wa phureside nte wu akiwile ehenhla ka ku twisisa leswaku ku lulamisa nkitsikitsi wa ku pfumaleka ka mitirho eka vantshwa swi lava ku ehleketa hi vutu mbuluxi na ku tirhisana loku tiyeke eka rixaka hinkwaro.

eng: its ultimate objective is to find models that work, whether in skills development or active labour market policies, and to scale these rapidly to reach as many young people as possible.
tso: xikongomelo xa wona xo hetelela i ku kuma timo dlolo leti ti tirhaka, hambi eka nhluvukiso wa swikili kumbe tipholisi ta makete wa vatirhi leti tirhaka, na ku swi pima hi xihatla ku fikelela vantshwa vo tala hilaha swi kotekaka hakona.

eng: most importantly, it recognises that young people must be at the centre of any effort to boost youth employment.
tso: xa nkoka swinene, wu tekela enhlokweni leswaku vantshwa va boheka ku va exivindzini xa matshalatshala wahi kumbe wahi ya ku nyika matimba ku thoriwa ka vantshwa.

eng: young people are our greatest asset, and our greatest weapon in this fight.
tso: vantshwa i rifuwo ra hina lerikuluku mba, na xitlhavana lexiku lukumba eka nyimpi leyi.

eng: we salute the resilience of every young person playing their part to build and develop this country.
tso: hi losa ku tiyisela ka mu ntshwa un’wana na un’wa na lontshwa loyi a endlaka xiphemu xa ntirho wa yena ku aka na ku hluvukisa tiko leri.

eng: they are the young people volunteering in our communities, building our country through the presidential employment stimulus, running their own businesses and studying to better themselves.
tso: hi vona vantshwa lava tinyiketelaka ku tirha eka miganga ya ka hina, ku aka tiko ra ka hina hi ku tirhisa xihlohloteri xa mitirho xa phuresidente, ku fambisa mabindzu ya vona vini na ku dyondza ku va va tiantswisa.

eng: they are the young people who are forging their own path and bringing their families along with them.
tso: hi vona vantshwa lava kumaka tindlela ta vona vini na ku ta swin’we na mindyangu ya vona.

eng: soes must drive economic growth and transformation vukuzenzele unnamed for some years now, south africa’s stateowned enterprises (soes) have mostly been associated in the public eye with state capture, financial mismanagement and inefficiency.
tso: tisoe ti boheka ku hlohlotela ku kula ka ikhonomi na ku cinca vukuzenzele unnamed malembenyana kutafika sweswi, mabindzu lama nga ehansi ka vun’wini bya mfumo (tisoe) ya afrikadzonga ya fambelanisiwile ngopfu na ku tlhakisiwa ka mfumo, matirhiselo yo homboloka ya mali na matirhiselo ya ntlangiso.

eng: in addition to needing regular bailouts from government, some of the country’s biggest and most important stateowned companies have been struggling to meet their mandates.
tso: loko swi ta eka ku lava mali ya nkarhi na nkarhi ya mpfuno kusuka eka mfumo, tin’wana ta tikhamphani leti nga ehansi ka vun’wini bya mfumo letikulu na ku va ta nkoka swinene ta tiko a ti ri eku tikeriweni ku fikelela swilerisoximfumo swa tona.

eng: these soes should be at the forefront of economic and social transformation.
tso: tisoe leti ti fanele ku rhanga emahlweni eka ku cinca ka ikhonomi na ka vanhu.

eng: they are responsible for providing the infrastructure and the services on which the economy depends, whether it be in the generation of electricity, commuter transport, water provision, freight logistics or telecommunications.
tso: ti na vutihlamuleri byo nyika swimakiwakulu na vukorhokeri lebyi ikho nomi yi tiyaka hi byona, ku nga va ku ri ku endliwa ka gezi, swifambo swa vaaki, mphakelo wa mati, mafa mbiselo ya tinhundzu kumbe vutihlanganisi bya tiqingho.

eng: our approach to state ownership is informed by the need for the effective functioning of key network industries, such as energy and ports, and by the need to ensure that the basic needs of all south africans, particularly the poor, can be met.
tso: endlelo ra hina eka vun’wini bya mfumo byi leteriwa hi xidingo xa matirhelo ya kahle eka tiindasitiri ta tinetiweke ta nkoka, to tanihi eneji na mihlaluko, na hi xidingo xa ku tiyisisa leswaku swidingo swa masungulo eka vanhu va afrikadzonga hinkwavo, ngopfungopfu lava nga swela, swa fikeleriwa.

eng: we firmly believe that public ownership is necessary in critical sectors of the economy and that the country needs robust soes that are able to drive economic growth and transformation.
tso: hi tshemba swinene leswaku vun’wini bya vaaki byi na nkoka eka tisekitara ta nkoka swonghasi ta ikho nomi na leswaku tiko ri dinga tisoe to tiya leti ti kotaka ku hlohlotela ku kula ka ikho nomi na ku cinca.

eng: this is particularly the case in the delivery of public goods such as electricity and water, where soes are able to pursue a developmental mandate in the public interest as opposed to a purely commercial one.
tso: leswi swi tano ngopfungo pfu eka mphakelo wa tinhu ndzu ta vaaki to tanihi gezi na mati, laha tisoe ti kotaka ku landzelerisa xilerisoximfumo xa nhluvukiso ku vuyerisa vaaki ematshan’weni ya ku vuyerisa mabindzu.

eng: that is why we have made it a priority of this government to turn these companies around to root out corruption, improve their governance and enable them to play the role they should in driving economic growth and employment creation.
tso: leswi hi swona swi endlaka leswaku mfumo lowu wu rhangisa emahlweni ku antswisa tikhamphani leti leswaku ti kota ku tsuvula vukungundzwana, ku antswisa mafambiselo ya tona na ku endla leswaku ti tlanga xiave xa tona xo hlohlotela ku kula ka ikhonomi na ku tumbuluxiwa ka mitirho.

eng: to this end, we have embarked upon a number of reforms to strengthen these soes so that they can produce the results that the country needs and expects.
tso: ku humelerisa leswi, hi sungurile miantswiso yo hlayanyana ku tiyisa tisoe ku endlela leswaku ti kota ku humesa mivuyelo leyi tiko ri yi dingaka na ku yi langutela.

eng: one of the most important reforms is in the energy sector.
tso: wun’wana wa miantswiso ya nkoka swinene wu le ka sekitara ya eneji.

eng: we have begun the process of restructuring eskom into three different soes, responsible for generation, transmission and distribution, respectively.
tso: hi sungurile phurosese yo aka eskom hi vuntshwa yi va na tisoe ti nharhu to hambana, leti nga na vutihlamuleri byo endla, byo fambisa na byo hangalasa, hi ku hambana.

eng: this is because the previous structure of eskom was illsuited for a changing energy landscape.
tso: leswi swi va kona hikwalaho ka leswi xivumbeko xa nkarhi lowu nga hundza xa eskom a xi nga ringanelangi ku cinca xiyimo xa eneji.

eng: it had become inefficient and costly and was not sufficiently transparent.
tso: a xi hluleka na ku va xo durha naswona a xi nga ri na nkavuciva hi ku ringanela.

eng: the establishment of a transmission entity in particular will mean that eskom will be able to purchase power from a broader range of providers, both private and public.
tso: ku tumbuluxiwa ka vandla ro fambisa ngopfungopfu swi ta vula leswaku eskom yi ta swi kota ku xava gezi kusuka eka vaphakeri vo ha mbanahambana, havumbi rhi bya va mfumo na lava nga riki va mfumo.

eng: this will improve transparency, increase competitiveness and promote the purchase of lowestcost electricity.
tso: leswi swi ta antswisa nkavuciva, swi tlakusa vuphikizani na ku kondletela ku xaviwa ka gezi ra ndhurho wa le hansi.

eng: through the renewable energy independent power producers programme, there has been significant private investment in energy generation.
tso: hi ku tirhisa nongonoko wa vahumesi va gezi lava ti yimelaka va eneji yo vuyele riseka ku vile na vuvekisi lebyi nga riki bya mfumo byo tivikana eka ku endliwa ka gezi.

eng: with the proposal to raise the licencing exemption for embedded generation – where companies produce electricity for themselves and other commercial users – from 1mw to 100mw, we can expect even more private investment.
tso: hi xiringanyeto xa ku tlakusa mpfumelelo wa ku nyika layisense eka ku endliwa ka gezi loku fambaka swin’we – laha tikhamphani ti tiendlelaka gezi ra tona vini na ra vatirhisi va swa mabindzu van’wana – kusuka eka 1mw kufika eka 100mw, hi nga langutela hambi vuvekisi lebyi nga riki bya mfumo byo tala.

eng: this is vital at a time when the country is suffering from severe and sustained electricity shortages and where neither eskom nor the state is able to invest in new generation capacity.
tso: leswi swi na nkoka eka nkarhi lowu tiko ri nga eku tikeriweni hikwalaho ka mikayivelo ya gezi yo tikisa na ku va leyi yaka emahlweni laha eskom kumbe mfumo wu nga swi kotiki ku vekisa eka vuswikoti byo endla gezi byintshwa.

eng: importantly, these reforms will give eskom the space to address its financial and operational challenges.
tso: xa nkoka, miantswiso leyi yi ta nyika eskom xivandla xo tirhana na mitlhontlho ya yona ya swa timali na ya matirhelo.

eng: another critical reform is the establishment of the national ports authority as an independent subsidiary of transnet.
tso: antswiso wa nkoka swo nghasi wun’wana i ku tu mbuluxiwa ka vulawuri bya mihlaluko bya rixaka tanihi rhavi leri tiyimelaka ra transnet.

eng: this a crucial part of transnet’s broader strategy to revitalise our logistics infrastructure.
tso: lexi i xiphemu xa nkoka swonghasi xa qhinga ro angarhela ra transnet ku pfuxa swimakiwakulu swa hina swa mafambiselo.

eng: transnet plans to invest r100 billion over the next five years in upgrading its infrastructure across the ports system.
tso: transnet yi kunguhata ku vekisa r100 ra tibiliyoni eka kutlula male mbe ya ntlhanu lama taka eka ku antswisa swimakiwakulu swa yona eka sisiteme ya mihlaluko hinkwayo.

eng: this will make our ports more efficient and our exports more competitive, and benefit the entire economy.
tso: leswi swi ta endla leswaku mihlaluko ya hina yi tirha kahle naswona tinhundzu ta hina leti rhumeriwaka emati kweni mambe ti ta phikizana swinene, na ku vuyerisa ikho nomi hinkwayo.

eng: for the ordinary consumer, it will mean reduced prices in the long term for many of our goods.
tso: eka mutirhisi ntsenantsena, swi ta vula mixavo leyi hu ngutekeke eka nkarhi wo leha eka to tala ta tinhundzu ta hina.

eng: for our exporters, it will mean greater competitiveness in global markets.
tso: eka varhumeri va ti nhundzu ematikweni mambe, swi ta vula ku tisa vuphikizani lebyikulukumba eka timakete ta misava hinkwayo.

eng: as our exports grow, our economy will expand and create more jobs.
tso: tanihiloko vuxavisi bya ti nhundzu ta hina ematikweni mambe byi kula, ikhonomi ya hina yi ta ndlandlamuka na ku tumbuluxa mitirho yo tala.

eng: more efficient ports will make the entire economy work better – and as port volumes increase, jobs will be created at the ports themselves.
tso: mihlaluko leyi tirhaka kahle yo tala yo antswa yi ta endla leswaku ikhonomi hinkwayo yi tirha ku antswa – naswona tanihiloko tivholomu ta mihlaluko ti tlakuka, mitirho yi ta tu mbuluxiwa emihlalukweni hi yoxe.

eng: establishing the national ports authority as a transnet subsidiary with its own board will, among other things, mean that revenues generated by the ports can be used to replace old equipment and upgrade and expand our ports, work which has been delayed for more than a decade.
tso: ku tumbuluxiwa ka vulawuri bya mihlaluko bya rixaka tanihi rhavi ra transnet lebyi nga na bodo ya byona, exikarhi ka swilo swin’wana, swi vula leswaku malinhle ngeleto leyi nghenisiwaka hi mihlaluko yi nga tirhisiwa ku siva switirhisiwa leswa khale na ku swi antswisa na ku ndlandlamuxa mihlaluko ya ka hina, ntirho lowu wu khomeletiweke kutlula malembexikhume.

eng: among other things, these reforms will encourage greater private investment in the country’s economic infrastructure.
tso: exikarhi ka swilo swi n'wana, miantswiso leyi yi ta hlohlotela vuvekisi lebyi nga riki bya mfumo bya le he nhla eka swimakiwakulu swa ikhonomi swa tiko.

eng: some people have expressed concerns that this will diminish the importance or reduce the value of soes.
tso: van’wana vanhu va kombisile ku khumbeka leswaku leswi swi ta tsanisa nkoka kumbe ku hunguta nkoka wa tisoe.

eng: prevent identity theft kgaogelo letsebe shenki mabitsela (28) is all too aware of identity theft and the crimes relating to it, as he has been a victim of it.
