tso: sivela vukhamba bya vutitivisi kgaogelo letsebe shenki mabitsela (28) wa byi lemuka swinene vukhamba bya vutitivisi na vugeve nga lebyi yelanaka na byo na, tanihiloko a tshame a va mutwisiwakuvava wa byona.

eng: mabitsela, from modimolle in limpopo, applied for a loan at a bank in november 2020, but was told he was overindebted and didn’t qualify.
tso: mabitsela, kusuka modi molle elimpopo, u endli le xikombelo xa xikweleti ebangini hi hukuri 2020, kambe u byeriwile leswaku u na swikweleti kutlula mpimo naswona a nga fikeleli.

eng: "i went to apply for a shortterm loan as i needed to make ends meet after being retrenched in june 2020. to my surprise, i was told i did not qualify.
tso: "ndzi yile ku ya endla xikombelo xa loni ya nkarhinyana tanihileswi a ndzi dinga ku tihanyisa endzhaku ka ku va ndzi hu ngutiwile entirhweni hi khotavuxika 2020. lexi ndzi hlamariseke, ndzi byeriwile leswaku a ndzi fikeleli."

eng: "i initially thought it was because of my unstable income, but it wasn’t.
tso: "emasungulweni a ndzi ehleketa leswaku swi nga va swi vangiwa hi muholo wa mina lowu tsekatsekaka, kambe a ku nga ri swona.

eng: i knew i only had one clothing account and no other debt, so i asked for a printout of my profile," he says.
tso: a ndzi tiva leswaku a ndzo va na akhawunti yin’we ya swiambalo naswona a ndzi ri hava xikweleti xin’wana, hikokwalaho ndzi kombele nkandziyiso wa phurofayili ya mina," a vula.

eng: mabitsela saw that two cellphone contracts, a r65 000 bank loan and numerous re tail shop accounts had been opened in his name.
tso: mabitsela u vonile tikontiraka ta tiselifoni timbirhi, loni ya bangi ya r65 000 na tiakhawunti ta le mavhengeleni ta swiambalo to hlayanyana leti a ti pfuriwile hi vito ra yena.

eng: the debt was close to r100 000.
tso: xikweleti a xi ri kwalomu ka r100 000.

eng: "just before the national level 5 lockdown, i lost my id book.
tso: "masikunyana ku nga si va na mpfalelo wa levhele ya 5 ya rixaka, ndzi lahlekeriwile hi pasi ra mina.

eng: i thought it was somewhere in the house and wasn’t too worried because i had my smart card id," he says.
tso: a ndzi ehleketa leswaku ri kona kun’wana kwala ndlwini naswona a ndzi nga vileli kutlula mpimo hikuva a ndzi ri na pasi ra khadi ro hlayeka hi khomphyutara."

eng: after realising that someone was creating debt in his name, mabitsela opened a case of stolen identity at the south african police service (saps).
tso: endzhaku ka ku lemuka leswaku munhu un’wana a nga va a ri eku endleni ka xikweleti hi vito ra yena, mabitsela u pfurile nandzu wa vutitivisi lebyi yiviweke eka vukorhokeri bya maphorisa bya afrikadzonga (saps).

eng: he had to write an affidavit stating that he lost his identity book and take it to credi tors with his case number to avoid being blacklisted.
tso: u bohekile ku tsala afidavhiti a kombisa leswaku u lahlile pasi kutani a yi yisa eka vakolotisi na nomboro ya yena ya nandzu ku papalata ku nga dzwihatiwi vito.

eng: mabitsela’s experience is not unique.
tso: ntokoto wa mabitsela a wu nga ri lowu fanaka wu ri woxe.

eng: according to the south african fraud prevention service’s (safps) 2020 fraud report, last year fraud increased by 161% in the eastern cape and 120% in gauteng.
tso: hi ku ya hi xiviko xa vumbabva xa vukorhokeri bya nsivelo wa vumbabva bya afrikadzonga (safps) xa 2020, lembe leri nga hundza vumbabva byi tlakuke hi 161% ekapavuxa na 120% egauteng.

eng: manie van schalkwyk, the executive director of the safps, says: "the most worrying is that impersonation fraud – otherwise known as identity fraud – has increased by an alarming 337%."
tso: manie van schalkwyk, mulawurinkulu wa safps, u ri: "lexi vilerisaka swinene hileswaku vumbabva byo tiendla munhu un’wana – lebyi tivekaka tanihi vu mbabva bya vutitivisi – byi tlakukile hi 337% leti chavisaka."

eng: support for businesses and workers vukuzenzele unnamed starting and building a business is a lot like raising a family.
tso: nseketelo wa mabindzu na vatirhi vukuzenzele unnamed ku sungula na ku aka bindzu swi fana swinene na ku kurisa ndyangu.

eng: it takes time, patience, con stant support and consistent nurturing from infancy to maturity.
tso: swi teka nkarhi, ku lehisa mbilu, nseketelo wa nkarhi hinkwayo na vuwundli bya endlelo ro fanana kusukela ekusu nguleni kukondza ri kula.

eng: for many business owners, seeing a business that you grew from scratch struggling to survive, or even being forced to close its doors, is heartbreaking.
tso: eka vini va mabindzu vo tala, ku vona bindzu leri u nga ri kurisa kusukela ehansi ri tikeriwa hi ku ya emahlweni, kumbe ku boheka ku ri pfala, swi tshova mbilu.

eng: since the onset of the covid19 pandemic, this has sadly been the situation facing many businesses both large and small, not just in our country but around the world.
tso: kusukela loko ku vile na ntungu kulu wa covid19, gome ra kona ri ve xiyimo lexi mabindzu yo tala lamakulu na lamatsongo ma nga langutana na xona, kungari laha tikweni ra hina ntsena kambe emisaveni hinkwayo.

eng: the pandemic and the meas ures we have had to take to contain the spread of the virus have had a detrimental impact on businesses.
tso: ntungukulu lowu na magoza lama hi nga boheka ku ma teka ku kamanyeta ku hangalaka ka xitsongwatsongwana ma ve na nkhumbo lowu nga onha eka mabindzu.

eng: in dealing with the pandemic we have sought to adopt an evidencebased approach in both policy and practice, con sidering scientific research, clinical expertise and capabil ities, and impact on all sectors of the population.
tso: eka ku tirhana na ntungukulu lowu hi lavile ku tirhisa endlelo leri simekiweke eka vumbhoni eka havumbirhi bya pholisi na matirhelo, hi ri karhi hi tekela enhlokweni ndzavisiso wa xisayense, vutivikulu bya xitlilinikali na vuswikoti, na nkhumbo eka tisekitara hinkwato ta vanhu.

eng: we have sought to have a balance between saving lives and preserving livelihoods.
tso: hi lavile ku va na ndzingano exikarhi ka ku ponisa vutomi na ku hlayisa tindlela to tihanyisa.

eng: we have sought to mitigate the impact of the successive lockdown restrictions on people’s livelihoods, or risk a second and possibly worse epidemic of poverty and hunger in future.
tso: hi lavile ku hunguta nkhumbo wa swipimelo swa ku pfariwa ka tiko leswi landzelelanaka eka tin dlela ta tihanyisa ta vanhu, kumbe ku langutana na nxungeto wa ntungukulu low u wa vumbirhi na ku va lowu nga tshukaka wu va lowukulu swinene wa vusweti na ndlala eka nkarhi lowu taka.

eng: in the earliest days last year, we introduced measures such as the covid temporary employer/employee relief scheme (ters), the covid19 loan guarantee scheme and various mechanisms to support small businesses to provide immediate and shortterm relief to burdened employees and business owners.
tso: eka masiku ya le kusungu leni lembe leri nga hundza, hi tivise magoza yo fana na xikimi xo phalala vathori/vatirhi xa nkarhinyana (ters) xa covid, xikimi xa ntiyisiso wa xikweleti xa covid19 na magoza man’wana yo seketela mabindzu lamatsongo ku nyika mphalalo wa xihatla na ku va wa nkarhi wo koma eka vatirhi na vini va mabindzu lava a va tikeriwa.

eng: in addition, the special covid19 social relief of distress grant and broadening access to existing social grants provided lifelines to indigent individuals and families.
tso: ku engetela kwalaho, mphalalo wa vanhu wa covid19 wa malimpfuneto ya ntshikelelo na ku ndlandlamuxiwa ka mfike lelo wa timalimpfuneto ta vanhu leti nga kona swi nyike nseketelo eka vanhu na mindyangu leyi nga evuswetini.

eng: through these interventions we were able to mitigate the worst effects of the pandemic, preventing the closure of many businesses and the loss of even further jobs.
tso: hi ku tirhisa miphalalo leyi hi kotile ku hunguta ku onha ko tika ka ntungukulu lowu, ku sivela ku pfariwa ka mabindzu yo tala na ku ya emahlweni ka ku lahle keriwa hi mitirho.

eng: they pro vided a firm foundation for the economic reconstruction and recovery plan that we launched in october last year.
tso: yi nyike masungulo yo tiya ya kungu ra ku akiwa hi vuntshwa ka ikhonomi na nhlakarhelo leri hi nga ri simeka hi nhlangula lembe leri nga hundza.

eng: as part of that plan, we introduced the presidential employment stimulus to provide income and livelihood support to millions of beneficiaries.
tso: tanihi xiphemu xa kungu rolero, hi sungurile xihlohloteri xa mitirho xa phuresidente ku nyika malinghena na nseketelo wa ndlela yo tihanyisa eka timili yoni ta vavuyeriwa.

eng: through the stimulus, over 300 000 young people have been placed as school assistants.
tso: hi ku tirhisa xihlohloteri lexi, kutlula 300 000 wa vantshwa va thoriwile tanihi vapfuneti va le swikolweni.

eng: more than 100 000 subsistence farmers are registered on the firstever database of its kind where they have access to technical support.
tso: kuhundza 100 000 ya varimi vo rimela ku tiha nyisa va tsarisiwile eka databeyisi yo sungula ya muxaka wa yona laha va kumaka nseketelo wa xithekiniki.

eng: more than 30 000 young people have been given opportunities in the cultural, creative and sports sectors.
tso: kuhundza 30 000 wa vantshwa va nyikiwile swivandlanene eka tisekitara ta swa mfuwo, swa vutumbuluxi na swa mitlangu.

eng: young professionals have been given opportunities in infrastructure development, healthcare, environmental conservation and a number of other sectors.
tso: tiphurofexinali ta vantshwa ti nyikiwile swivandlanene eka nhluvukiso wa swimakiwakulu, nhlayiso wa rihanyu, nhlayiso wa mbangu na tisekitara tin’wana to hlayanyana.

eng: there are promising indi cations that our economy is steadily recovering, with growth and job creation in a number of sectors, from manufacturing to mining to agriculture.
tso: ku na swikombo leswi tshe mbisaka swa leswaku ikhonomi ya hina yi le ku vuyeleleni, xikan’we na ku kula na ku tumbuluxiwa ka mitirho eka tise kitara to hlayanyana, kusuka eka vumaki ku ya eka vucelamigodi na vurimi.

eng: at the same time we know that this ‘bigger picture’ is cold comfort to workers and business owners who have suffered immeasurably over the past year and a half, and were hoping to see their situa tions improve as the economy slowly opened up.
tso: hi tlhela hi swi tiva leswaku ‘ku vona ko katsa na leswa ha taka’ loku ku nyika mbuwetelo wutsongo eka vatirhi na vini va mabindzu lava nga twa ku vava swinene eka lembe leri nga hela na hafu ya rona, na swona a hi tshemba leswaku hi ta vona swiyimo swi antswa loko ikhonomi yi ri karhi yi pfuleka hi switsongotsongo.

eng: the rapid rise in infections being fueled by the new delta variant necessitated the imposing of tighter restric tions on the movement of persons, on the operation of certain businesses and on public gatherings, among others.
tso: ku tlakuka hi xihatla ka mitluletavuvabyi leyi hlanganyetiwaka hi muxaka lowuntshwa wa delta ku tise xilaveko xo tirhisa swipimelo swo nonoha eka mfambafambo wa vanhu, eka matirhelo ya mabindzu yo karhi na ku hlengeletana ka vanhu, exikarhi ka swin’wana.

eng: these were not been easy decisions to make, mindful of their impact on people’s livelihoods.
tso: leswi a swi nga ri swiboho swo olova ku swi teka, hi ku tiva nkhumbo wa swona ehenhla ka tindlela to tihanyisa ta vanhu.

eng: just as we did at the beginning of the pandemic, we engaged in deliberations with all social partners, business, labour and civil society to see what financially sustainable measures we could intro duce to support businesses and individuals in distress at this time.
tso: tanihileswi hi nga swi endla ekusunguleni ka ntungukulu lowu, hi endle mivulavurisano na vatirhisani va hina, mabindzu, vatirhi na vaaki ku vona leswaku i magoza wahi lama kotaka ku yiseka emahlweni hi ndlela ya swa timali lama hi nga ma su ngulaka ku seketela mabindzu na vanhu lava nga eku tikeriweni eka nkarhi wa sweswi.

eng: the negotiations at the national economic development and labour council resulted in consen sus that the most practical and financially sustainable measure that can provide urgent relief is extending the covid19 ters scheme to sectors that have been affected by the adjusted level 4 restrictions.
tso: mikanerisano eka khansele ya nhluvukiso wa ikhonomi na vatirhi ya rixaka yi tise ku pfumelelana ka leswaku goza leri kotekaka na ku yiseka emahl weni hi ndlela ya swa timali leri ri nga nyikaka mphalalo wa xihatla i ku yisa emahlweni xikimi xa ters xa covid19 eka tisekitara leti ti nga khumbeka hi swipimelo swa levhele ya vulemukisi leyi fambelanisiweke ya 4. ku seketela mabindzu lama tilayisense ta wona to tirha na tiphemiti swi nga hundzeriwa hi nkarhi exikarhi ka nyenyankulu 2020 na khotavuxika 2021, hi hundzisela ku ya emahlweni ku va enawini ka tona kufikela 31 n’wendzamhala 2022. hi ku engetela, tilayisense kumbe tiphemiti ta mabindzu lama ntshwa leti ti nyikiwaka kusukela 1 mawuwani na tona ti ta va enawini kufikela 31 n’wendzamhala 2022, naswona a ku nga vi na hakelo ya layisense yi nga ta hakeriwa.

eng: to support businesses whose operating licenses and per mits expired between march 2020 and june 2021, we are extending their validity until 31 december 2022. in addition, new business licenses or permits that are issued from the 1 july will also be valid until 31 december 2022, and no license fee will be payable.
tso: eka lembe leri nga hundza, hi tlhele hi tirha hi nga cinci ku sirhelela vatirhi lava nga sirhele lekangiki lava mitirho ya vona a yi ri eka nxungeto, ngopfungopfu eka tisekitara leti a ti tikeriwile ngopfu to fana na indasitiri ya mavhengele, ya swakudya na swakunwa na ya tinsimbhi.

eng: sandf fights covid19 more matshediso the south african national defence force (sandf) is helping fight the coronavirus disease (covid19) pandemic in gauteng, which is currently the epicentre of the third wave.
tso: sandf yi lwisana na covid19 more matshediso vuthu ra vusirheleri ra rixaka ra afrikadzo nga (sandf) ri le ku pfu neteni ku lwisana na ntungukulu wa vuvabyi bya khoronavhayirasi (covid19) egauteng, xifundza lexi nga xona xivindzi xa gandlati ra vunharhu.

eng: the sandf is assisting with mass community test ing, screening and contact tracing, and is also lending a hand at hospitals.
tso: sandf yi le ku pfuneteni hi ku kambela mitshungu ya vaaka ndhawu, ku hlahluva na ku lavana na lava nga hlangana, na ku tlhela yi pfuneta eswibedhlele.

eng: the south african military health service was deployed in the province to ease the burden on healthcare workers.
tso: vukorhokeri bya rihanyu ra masocha bya afrikadzonga byi rhumeriwile eka xifundzakulu lexi ku hunguta ndzhwalo eka vatirhi va nhlayiso wa rihanyu.

eng: a medical task group has been stationed at chris hani baragwanath academic hospital in johannesburg.
tso: ntlawa wa xintirhwana xa vutshunguri wu vekiwile echris hani baragwanath acade mic hospital ejoni.

eng: with gauteng recording the highest number of covid19 cases during the third wave, the hospital was named a pro vincial health facility and is now dedicated to patients with covid19.
tso: leswi gauteng yi rhekodaka nhlayo ya le henhla ya timhangu ta covid19 hi nkarhi wa gandlati ra vunharhu, xibedhlele lexi xi vuri wile ku va ndhawu ya rihanyu ya xifundzakulu naswona sweswi xi nyiketeleriwile eka vavabyi lava nga na covid19.

eng: before assuming their duties, the medical task group had to be vaccinated so that they could be kept safe while handling the increased number of positive cases and hospital admissions.
tso: loko wu nga se sungula mitirho ya wona, ntlawa wa xintirhwana xa vutshunguri wu tlhaveriwile ku endlela leswaku wu ta hlayiseka loko wu ri karhi wu tirhana na nhlayo leyi nga engeteleleka ya timhangu ta ku tluleriwa na ku amukeriwa exibedhlele.

eng: medical task group commander colonel fezeka mabona, who is a professional nurse, says she works on the ground with other members of the group.
tso: khomandara wa ntlawa wa xintirhwana xa vutshunguri kolonele fezeka mabona, loyi a nga muongori wa xiphurofexinali, u ri u ya laha ku tirhiwaka kona ku ya tirha na swirho leswin’wana swa ntlawa.

eng: "the group comprises various healthcare professionals, including nurses, doctors, clinical associates and occu pational health and safety professionals," she says.
tso: "ntlawa lowu wu katsa tiphuro fexinali ta nhlayiso wa rihanyu to hambanahambana, ku katsa na vaongori, madokodela, vatirhisani va swa xitlilinikali, na tiphurofexinali ta swa rihanyu na vuhlayiseki bya le ntirhweni," a vula.

eng: the majority of the nurses have nursing qualifications at the degree level, with different specialities, including primary healthcare.
tso: vunyingi bya vaongori va na mithwaso ya vuongori eka levhele ya digiri, na vutshila byo hlawuleka byo hambanahambana, ku katsa nhlayiso wa rihanyu wa masungulo.

eng: "some nurses are theatre tr ained.
tso: "vaongori van’wana va leteriwile hi swa vuhandzuri.

eng: all of us have worked as general nurses, midwives, nurse educators and managers in both the military and public health system," she adds.
tso: hinkwerhu ka hina hi tirhile tanihi vaongori vo angarhela, vasungukati, vadyondzisi va vaongori na vafambisi evuso cheni na le ka sisiteme ya rihanyu ya mfumo," a engetela.

eng: the group is divided into task teams and work with the hospital staff in shifts, according to the demand at the facility.
tso: ntlawa lowu wu avanyisiwile hi swipano swa swintirhwana naswona swi tirha hi ku cincana hi tixifiti na vatirhi va xibedhlele, hi ku ya hi swilaveko swa ndhawu.

eng: the team is currently providing healthcare services in six wards.
tso: eka nkarhi wa sweswi xipano lexi xi nyika vukorhokeri bya rihanyu eka tiwadi ta tsevu.

eng: "the hospital staff is quite low to handle the number of cases at the moment.
tso: "vatirhi va xibedhlele lexi i vatso ngo swinene ku va va nga kota ku tirhana na nhlayo ya timhangu eka nkarhi wa sweswi.

eng: it is very important for us to try as much as we can to assist them in order for all of us to avoid further strain on the health care system," says mabona.
tso: i swa nkoka swinene eka hina ku va hi ringeta hilaha hi nga kotaka hakona ku va pfuneta leswaku hinkwerhu ka hina hi papalata ntshikelelo wo yisa emahlweni eka sisiteme ya nhlayiso wa rihanyu," ku vula mabona.

eng: inclusive communities critical to sa’s success vukuzenzele unnamed while the violence and destruction that engulfed parts of kwazulunatal and gauteng recently caused much damage to property and livelihoods, it also had a huge impact on the cohesion of our communities.
tso: miganga leyi katsaka mani na mani yi na nkoka eku humeleleni ka afrikadzonga vukuzenzele unnamed loko madzolonga naku onheteriwa leswi hlaseleke ti ndhawu tin’wana ta k w a z u l u n a t a l n a gauteng swi vangile ku onhaka lokukulu ka tinhundzu na tindlela to tihanyisa, ya tlhele ya khumba swinene ntwanano wa miganga ya hina.

eng: this was most evident in the tragic events that took place in and around phoenix in ethekwini.
tso: leswi swi vonakile eka swendlo swa mikitsikitsi leyi nga endleka ephoenix na tindhawu ta le kusuhi na kona ta le ethekwini.

eng: during some of the worst unrest in our democracy, and in a climate already thick with suspicion and paranoia, people that had lived sidebyside in relative peace turned on each other.
tso: hi mikarhi yin’wana ya nkatshamiseko wo tika eka xidemokirasi xa hina, hambi kuri xiyimo lexi ehleketelerisaka no pfumala ntsembho, vanhu lava tshameke swin’we hi vuxaka byo rhula va tshwu kiselana mahlo.

eng: there is still much we have to unearth about the events that took place.
tso: ku na swo tala leswi hi faneleke ku swi kumisisa mayelana na swendlo leswi humeleke.

eng: the proliferation of fake news, doctored images and incorrect information has made it difficult to separate fact from fiction.
tso: ku tlakuka ka xihatla ka mahungu yo pfu mala ntiyiso, swifaniso swa mavunwa, na mahungu yo hoxeka swi endlile leswaku swi tika ku hambanyisa swilo swa ntiyiso eka swa mava rivari.

eng: but we do know from official reports and personal accounts that people were racially profiled at illegal roadblocks, some people were pulled out of cars and beaten, and some were humiliated and degraded.
tso: kambe ha swi tiva ku suka eka swiviko swa ximfumo na ku hlamusela ka vanhu lava swi nga va humelela leswaku vanhu a va aviwa ku ya hi nhlonghe eku siveni ka magondzo ko ka ku nga ri enawini, van’wana vanhu va humesiwile emimovheni va biwa, loko van’wana va susiwile ndzhuti no yisiwa ehansi.

eng: several people were killed.
tso: vanhu vo hlayanyana va dlayiwile.

eng: much of what has happened is the inevitable outcome when people take the law into their own hands.
tso: swo tala swa leswi nga humelela i mbuyelo wa swiyimo leswi nga papalatekiki loko vanhu va teka nawu va wu veka emavokweni ya vona.

eng: vigilantism will not be tolerated in this country.
tso: ku teka nawu vanhu va wu veka emavokweni a swi pfumeleriwi laha tikweni.

eng: it is criminal and it is dangerous.
tso: i vugevenga naswona swi na nghozi.

eng: now that calm has been restored to the affected areas, our law enforcement agencies are investigating all acts of criminality.
tso: sweswi ntshamiseko wu nga tlhelela vutshan’wini etindhwani leti khumbekeke, swiyenge swa hina swo hlayisa nawu swi le ku lavisiseni ka migingiriko hinkwayo ya vugevenga.

eng: a team of detectives has been assigned to deal with the murders and are working closely with local communities.
tso: ntlawa wa mafokisi wu hlawuriwile leswaku wu tirhana na ku dlwa ka vanhu naswona wu tirhisana na miganga yale kusuhi.

eng: there have been arrests and those responsible will face the full might of the law.
tso: ku na lava nga khomiwa naswona lava va nga ni vutihlamuleri va ta langutana na nawu hi ku hetiseka.

eng: much of the narrative around the events in phoenix has been dominated by attempts to turn one race against another.
tso: switoritori swo tala mayelana na swendlo swa le phoenix swi taleriwile ngopfu hi ku ringeta ku lwisa rixaka ro karhi na rin’wana.

eng: it has been stoked by anonymous people on social media and in messaging groups making outrageous claims and calling for revenge.
tso: leswi swi hlohloteriwile hi vanhu lava nga tivekiki eka swi hangalasa mahungu swa le ka inthanete nale ka mitlawa ya marungula laha a ku andlariwa swikoxo swa nyimpi no lava ku tlheriseta.

eng: there is an attempt to present this as a sign of imploding race relations between african and indian communities.
tso: ku na ku ringeta ku endla swilo leswi swi languteka tanihi xikombeto xa ku onhaka ka vuxaka ku ya hi nghohe exikarhi ka miganga ya maafrika na maindiya.

eng: just as there were people who tried to exploit people’s vulnerability and cause mayhem, there are those who want to present criminal acts in racial terms to serve their own purposes.
tso: tanihileswi a ku ri na vanhu lava a va ringeta ku tirhisa ku va vanhu va nga sirhelelekanga ku vanga mpfilumpfilu, ku na lava ava lava ku endla migingiriko ya vugevega yi languteka yi ri yo ya hi nghohe ku fikelela swikongomelo swa vona vini.

eng: they will not succeed.
tso: va nge humeleli.

eng: south africa has a proud history of principled nonracialism and working class solidarity.
tso: afrikadzonga yi na matimu yo tiya lama ya nga pfumeriki xihlawulambala na ntwanano wa ntlawa wa vatirhi.

eng: african and indian communities were united in the struggle against apartheid and, together with other communities, remain committed to a united and democratic society.
tso: miganga ya maafrika na maindiya a yi twanana na loko ku ri karhi ku hlu phekiwa ku lwisaniwa na xihlawuhlawu, naswona miganga yin’wana, yi ya mahlweni yi tiyimisela eka rixaka leri nga na ku twanana no va na xidemokirasi.

eng: in response to the fear and mistrust, the people of phoenix and the neighbouring areas of bhambayi, zwelitsha and amaoti are working to repair the damage.
tso: ku hlamula eka ku chava na ku pfumala ntshembo, vanhu va le phoenix na tindhawu ta le kusuhi ta bhambayi, zwelitsha na amaoti vale ku lunghiseni ka leswi onhakeke.

eng: aided by a peace forum established by the south african police service in partnership with community leaders, the communities have come together to support those affected by the unrest and to open channels of dialogue.
tso: hi ku pfuniwa hi foramu yo tisa kurhula leyi tumbuxiweke hi maphorisa ya afrikadzonga hi ku tirhisana na varhangeri va miganga, miganga yi hlanganile ku ta seketela lava khumbiweke hi nkatshamiseko no kuma tindlela to burisana.

eng: this is not the only part of the country that is confronted with such challenges.
tso: lexi a hi xiphemu xi ri xoxe xa tiko lexi hlanganeke na mitlhontlho yo tano.

eng: our efforts to build integrated communities are frustrated by the legacy of apartheid planning and persistent inequality.
tso: matshalatshala ya hina yo aka miganga leyi hlanga neke yi pfilunganyiwile hi ndzhaka ya makunguhatelo ya xihlawuhlawu no pfuma leka ka ndzingano leswi yaka emahlweni.

eng: our cities, towns and rural areas are still all divided by both race and class.
tso: madorobakulu ya hina, swidorobani na tindhawu tale makaya ta ha aviwile ku ya hi tixaka na mitlawa.

eng: this discourages cooperation and understanding, and hampers the work we have undertaken to build a nonracial society.
tso: leswi swi nyamisa ntirhisano na ku twisisa, na ku hlulekisa ntirho lowu hi wu sunguleke wo aka miganga leyi nga avanangiki ku ya hi tinxaka.

eng: correcting these spatial distortions must be part of our work of building an inclusive economy and improving the living conditions of all south africans.
tso: ku lulamisa ku avana ka matshamelo loko ku nga kona swi fanele ku va xiave xa ntirho wa hina wo aka ikhonomi leyi katsaka vanhu hinkwavo na ku antswisa xiyimo xa mahanyelo ya maafrikadzonga hinkwavo.

eng: it is why we are working to build flourishing township and rural economies, and focusing on the growth of small businesses.
tso: hikokwalaho hi tirhanaka na ku aka malokixi yo koka rinoko na ikhonomi ya le matiko xikaya, no kongo misa ngopfu eka ku kurisa mabindzu lamatsongo.

eng: it is why we are investing in infrastructure in these areas and working to improve the provision of services.
tso: hiko kwalaho hi endlaka vuvekisi eka switirhisiwa etindha wini leti na ku tirhela ku antswisa ku nyikiwa ka vukorhokeri.

eng: at the same time, we need to confront racism in our society.
tso: hi nkarhi wu ri wun’we, hi fanele ku lwisana na xihlawulambala emigangeni ya hina.

eng: we need to have honest conversations not only about our attitudes to one another, but also about the material conditions that divide us.
tso: hi fanele ku va na mbhurisano wa ntiyiso ku nga ri hi matikhomelo lawa hi kombanaka wona ntsena, kambe na swiyimo leswi nga erivaleni leswi swi hi avanyisaka.

eng: for as long as the division of wealth and opportunity in south africa is largely still determined by race and gender, we will not be able to build a truly united nation.
tso: ntsena loko ku aviwa ka rifumo na swivandlanene eafrikadzonga swa ha ya hi rixaka na rimbewu, hi nge swi koti ku aka rixaka leri nga na ntwanano wa ntiyiso.

eng: the events in phoenix are a painful reminder of how much work we still need to do to build inclusive communities that have successfully broken down the boundaries of the past.
tso: swendlo swa le phoenix i switsundzuxo swo vava leswi kombisaka leswaku ka ha ri na ntirho lowu faneleke ku endliwa ku aka miganga leyi katsaka vanhu hinkwavo leyi nga kota ku herisa mindzelekako ya karhi lowu nga hundza hi ku hetiseka.

eng: these events also demonstrate how determined some people are to divide us, and how we need to do everything we can to resist them.
tso: swendlo leswi swi tlhela swi komba hilaha vanhu van’wana va nga tiyimisela hakona ku hi ava, na hilaha hi faneleke ku endla hinkwaswo leswi kotekaka ku va sivela.

eng: it is our collective responsibility to support these communities in ethekwini and elsewhere in their journey towards reconciliation and healing.
tso: i vutihlamuleri bya hina hinkwerhu ku seketela miganga leyi ya le ethekwini na kun’wana laha va nga eka rendzo ra ndzivalelano na ku hola.

eng: help learners cope with covid19 vukuzenzele unnamed parents and teachers can help learners cope with the anxiety and depression they are experiencing because of the coronavirus disease pandemic.
tso: pfuna vadyondzi ku lawula covid19 more matshediso vatswari na vadyondzisi va nga pfuna vadyondzi ku lawula nchavo na ntshikelelo leswi va hlanganaka na swona hikwalaho ka ntungu wa vuvabyi bya xitsongwatsongwana xa khorona.

eng: more matshediso learners have been faced with many challenges as a result of the coronavirus disease (covid19) and the lockdown restrictions.
tso: vadyondzi va la ngutanile na mi tlhontlho yotala hikwalaho ka xivange lo xa vuvabyi bya xi tsongwatsongwana xa khorona ( covid19) na swipimelo swo pfala mi gingiriko.

eng: there has been constant change in the learning environment at south africa’s schools, which can leave learners feeling anxious and fearful.
tso: ku vile na ku cinca loku yaka emahlweni eka madyondzelo eswikolweni swa afrikadzonga, leswi nga siyaka vadyondzi va twa va nga tshamisekanga no chava.

eng: learners have had to navigate a new world of online or delayed learning, social isolation, loss, grief and trauma, all of which can cause increased anxiety and depression.
tso: vadyondzi a va fanele ku lawula maendlelo yantshwa yo dyondza hi ku tirhisa inthanete kumbe ku hlwerisiwa ku dyondza, ku tshama voxe, ku lahlekeriwa, ku vava na ku chuwha, leswi hinkwa swo swi nga vangaka ku tlakuka ka nchavo na ntshi kelelo.

eng: counselling psychologist boitumelo tlhapane, who works for the inclusive education unit at the free state department of education, says feeling anxious or depressed during these trying times is understandable.
tso: mutivi wa swa miehleketo, boitumelo tlhapane, loyi a tirhaka eka yuniti ya dyondzo yo angarhela eka ndzawulo ya dyondzo ya le free state uri ku titwa u nga tshamiseka nga kumbe u ri na ntshikelelo hi nkarhi lowu wo tika swa twisiseka.

eng: "for about ayearandahalf now, learners have had to adjust to a new way of learning, with less contact and teaching time.
tso: "kwalomu ka lembe na hafu sweswi, vadyondzi a va fanele ku cinca vaya eka madyondzelo yantshwa, laha ku nga na ku hlangana ku ntsongo na nkarhi wuntsongo wo dyondzisa.

eng: "many have had to study independently, while living with uncertainty about their future and the impact of covid19 on their hopes and dreams, family and social life," says tlhapane.
tso: "votala a va fanele ku tidyondzisa hi voxe, va ri karhi va hanya va nga tivi vumundzuku bya vona na ku khumbiwa ka ntshembo na milorho, mindyangu na vutomi byo hanyisana na vanhu van’wana hi covid19."

eng: how to cope she explains that anxiety is the fear of or worrying about something that has an uncertain outcome.
tso: u nga lawula njhaniu hlamuserile leswaku nchavo i ku chava xilo kumbe ku vilela hi xilo lexi mbuyelo wa xona wu nga tivekiki.

eng: to help learners to cope, she offers the following advice: understand that it is normal to be anxious or fearful.
tso: ku pfuna vadyondzi ku lawula, u nyikile switsundzuxo leswi landzelaka: twisisa leswaku swi tolovekile ku titwa u nga tshamisekanga kumbe ku va na nchavo.

eng: this does not mean that you are weak.
tso: leswi a swi vuli leswaku a wu tiyangi.

eng: it is okay to not be okay.
tso: swi kahle ku va u nga vi kahle.

eng: what you do with your fear is what is important.
tso: leswi u swi endlaka hi ku chava ka wena hi swona swa nkoka.

eng: are you obeying all the covid19 rules that have put in place to protect you and others?
tso: xana u le ku landzeleleni ka milawu hinkwayo ya covid19 leyi vekiweke ku sirhelela wena na van’wana?

eng: what else can you do to ensure your and others’ safety?
tso: hi xihi xin’wana u nga xi endlaka ku tiyisisa vuhlayiseki bya wena na van’wana?

eng: do you have reliable information about covid19 in case you or a loved one gets infected?
tso: xana u na mahungu yo tshembeka mayelana na covid19 l o k o w e n a kumbe munhu loyi u n’wi rhandzaka a tluleriwa hi vuvabyi?

eng: do you have the support of teachers, family and friends to help you when you feel uncertain or stressed or anxious?
tso: xana u na nseketelo wa vadyondzisi, ndyangu na vanghana wo ku pfuna loko u twa u nga titshembi kumbe ku tikeriwa kumbe ku ka u nga tshamiseka nga?

eng: this is very important.
tso: leswi swi na nkoka swinene.

eng: teachers can also provide noncontact support and learning through online material and study groups; by setting up reminders to motivate learners to study at home; and by encouraging them to communicate their fears about schooling.
tso: vadyondzisi va nga nyika nseketelo va ri ekule no dyondza hi ku tirhisa matheriyali wa le ka inthan ete na mitlawa yo dyondza; hi ku endla switsundzuxo swo khutaza vadyondzi ku dyondza va ri ekaya; na ku va hlohlotela ku vulavula hi ku chava ka vona mayelana na ku dyondza.

eng: "this is important, especially for subjects that learners find challenging," she adds.
tso: "leswi swi na nkoka, ngop fungopfu eka tidyondzo leti vadyondzi va kumaka ti tika," a engetela.

eng: family and friends can provide learners with emotional support, in the form of encouragement and constant reassurance, says tlhapane.
tso: ndyangu na vanghana va nga nyika vadyondzi nseke telo wo va tiyisa emoyeni, hi ndlela ya nhlonhlotelo no va tshembisa hi mikarhi hinkwayo, ku vula tlhapane.

eng: "learners need to be constantly reminded that their efforts and dedication are recognised and appreciated, thus increasing their confidence.
tso: "vadyondzi va lava ku tshama va ri karhi va tsu ndzuxiwa leswaku ku tikarhata no tiyimisela ka vona swa vonaka no amukeriwa, leswi swi engetela ku ti tshemba ka vona.

eng: "how to reduce anxietytlhapane says there are various ways that parents and learners can reduce anxiety.
tso: "u nga hunguta njhani nchavotlhapane uri ku na tindlela to hambana leti vatswari na vadyondzi va nga hungutaka nchavo hatona.

eng: these include: ensure that there is a strict routine for studying, sleeping and socialising.
tso: leti katsaka: ku tiyisisa leswaku ku na endlelo ra ntolovelo leri landzeleriwaka ro dyondza, ku etlela no hungasa na vanhu van’wana.

eng: this will help learners meet their goals and deadlines, while helping them to feel in control of their studies.
tso: leswi swi ta pfuna vadyondzi ku fikelela swikongomelo na swipimelo swa nkarhi, swi ri karhi swi va pfuna ku titwa va kota ku lawula tidyondzo ta vona.

eng: learners must use all of the available resources provided at school and on educational programmes, in line with the curriculum, that are broadcast on television and radio.
tso: vadyondzi va fanele ku tirhisa swipfuno hi nkwaswo leswi nyikiwaka exikolweni na le ka mino ngonoko ya tidyondzo, leyi fambelanaka na kharikhu lamu, leyi haxiwaka eka mavonakule na xiyani moya.

eng: parents can assist by ensuring that learners are not overexposed to covid19 news, especially around death and conspiracy theories, as this may fuel their fears and lead to more psychological conditions.
tso: vatswari va nga pfuna hi ku tiyisisa leswaku vadyondzi a va voni ngopfu mahungu ya covid19, ngopfungopfu lama fambelanaka na rifu na tithiyori ta mavunwa, hikuva leswi swi nga engetela ku chava no endla leswaku miehleketo yi hlanganana.

eng: learners should limit social media consumption, as it wastes study time and is a major distraction.
tso: vadyondzi va fanele ku hunguta ku tirhisa swi hangalasa mahungu swa le ka inthanete, hikuva swi heta nkarhi wo dyondza naswona hi swin’wana swa swionhi leswikulu.

eng: the family can adapt their lifestyle by adding selfcare tasks, such as physical exercise and play.
tso: ndyangu wu nga cinca mahanyelo ya wona hi ku engetela swintirhwana swo tihlayisa, swo fana na vutiolori no tlanga.

eng: "if a learner loses a loved one, they may experience grief symptoms that resemble depression or anxiety.
tso: "loko mudyondzi a lahleke riwa hi munhu loyi a n’wi rhandzaka, a nga titwa a ri na swikombeto swo twa ku vava emoyeni leswi yelanaka na ntshikelelo kumbe nchavo.

eng: "it is important that the school and the parents refer these learners for psychosocial support, which is provided by the department of basic education, or consult free resources or local clinics for a referral," says tlhapane.
tso: "swi na nkoka leswaku xikolo na vatswari va rhumela vadyondzi lava eka vativi va miehleketo, lava tisiwaka hi ndzawulo ya dyondzo ya le hansi, kumbe va tihlanga nisa na swipfuno swa mahala kumbe tliliniki ya le kusuhi ku hundziseriwa emahlweni," ku vula tlhapane.

eng: signs of distress parents should be alert and watch for various signs that may indicate that their child is in distress.
tso: swikombeto swo tikeriwavatswari va fanele ku va na vuxiyaxiya no la nguta swikombeto swo hambanahambana leswi nga kombisaka leswaku n’wana wa vona u le ku tikeriweni.

eng: these include: the child being withdrawn and isolating from others.
tso: leswi katsaka: n’wana a nga lavi ku vulavula a tlhela a tihlawula eka van’wana.

eng: irregular eating and sleep patterns.
tso: madyelo yo ka ya nga tolovelekanga na phetheni ya maetlelelo.

eng: being overly emotional, such as constantly crying, irritable moods or losing their temper quickly.
tso: ku tlhaveka swinene, ku fana no tshamela ku rila, ku kwatakwata kumbe ku hela mbilu hi xihatla.

eng: not completing tasks and homework.
tso: ku hluleka ku heta mitirho ya le tlilasini na miti rhokaya.

eng: behavioural problems, such as aggressiveness.
tso: swiphiqo swa matikhomelo, swo fana na ntshiva.

eng: building a society free of state capture vukuzenzele unnamed the scheduled hearings of the judicial commission of inquiry into allegations of state capture, corruption and fraud in the public sector, including organs of state, recently ended, more than 1 000 days after the first witness testimony was heard.
tso: ku aka rixaka leri nga hava ku tekiwa ka vulawuri bya mfumondzati vukuzenzele unnamed tinhlengeletano to twa miehleketo leti xeduriweke ta khomixini ya vuavanyisi ya vulavisisi eka ku tekiwa ka vulawuri bya mfumo ta ha ku fika emakumu, kutlula 1000 wa masiku endzhakukaloko mbhoni yo sungula yi nyikile vumboni.

eng: while the commission’s chairperson, deputy chief justice raymond zondo has said it may be necessary for a few more witnesses to testify, the work of the commission is now one step closer to completion.
tso: hambileswi mutshamaxi tulu wa khomixini leyi, xandla xa muavanyisinkulu raymond zondo a vuleke leswaku swi nga ha va na nkoka leswaku ti mbhoni tingaritingani ti nyika vumbhoni, ntirho wa khomixini leyi sweswi wu tshinerile swinene emakumu.

eng: this is a significant milestone that brings us ever closer to a reckoning with one of the most ruinous episodes in the history of our democracy.
tso: leri i goza ra nkoka lowukulu leri hi tshinetaka ekusuhi ni ku ahlula xin’wana xa swiphemu leswo biha eka matimu ya xidemokirasi xa hina.

eng: even before judge zondo submits his findings and recommendations to the president, we can all agree that the commission’s work has been invaluable.
tso: hambiloko muavanyisi zondo a nga si rhumela swi kumiwa na swibumabumelo eka phuresidente, hi nga pfumela hinkwerhu leswaku ntirho wa khomixini leyi a wu ri wa nkoka.

eng: over the course of three years, we have heard testimony detailing alleged acts of corruption on a massive scale.
tso: eka malembe manharhu lama nga hundza, hi twile vumbhoni lebyi koxometaka swiendlo leswi hehliwaka swa vukungundzwana hi xikalo xa le henhla.

eng: we have heard about actions that resulted in the theft of billions of rands of public money.
tso: hi twile hi mayelana na swiendlo leswi nga endla leswaku ku yiviwa ka tibiliyoni ta tirhandi eka mali ya mfumo.

eng: we have heard how many public institutions and stateowned companies were deliberately weakened.
tso: hi twile hilaha mihlangano ya mfumo yo tala na tikhamphani leti nga ehansi ka vun’wini bya mfumo swi nga tsanisiwa hi vomu hakona.

eng: this exposure of the nature, extent and depth of state capture did not take place behind closed doors, but was broadcast to the entire country.
tso: ku humelerisa erivaleni ka muhlovo, vukulu na vuenti bya ku tekiwa ka vulawuri bya mfumo a swi endle kanga exihundleni, kambe swi haxiwile eka tiko hi nkwaro.

eng: by allowing all south africans to follow the commission’s proceedings, it has helped to instil public confidence in our democracy in the way it promotes openness and transparency.
tso: hi ku pfumelela vanhu va afrikadzonga hinkwawo ku landzelela mafambiselo ya khomixini leyi, swi pfunile leswaku vaaki va va ni ntshembo eka xidemokirasi xa hina hi ndlela leyi hlohlotelaka mpfuleko na nkavuciva.

eng: the country owes a debt of gratitude to all who were involved in the work of the commission; from those who investigated, researched and compiled a huge amount of information; to the many witnesses who testified and provided evidence; to the journalists who diligently reported on the proceedings; to the lawyers who helped present evidence.
tso: tiko ri kolota ku khensa hinkwavo lava nga hoxa xandla eka ntirho wa kho mixini leyi; kusuka eka lava va lavisiseke na ku hlengeleta voxokoxoko byo tala; kufika eka timbhoni to tala leti nga nyika vumbhoni; kufika eka vatekamahungu lava va nga vika hi vurhonwana hi mafambiselo wa khomixini leyi; kufika eka magqweta lama ma nga pfuna ku nyika vumbhoni.

eng: we also owe a debt of gratitude to the many individuals, some of whom remain unknown, whose actions led to the establishment of the commission in the first place.
tso: hi tlhela hi kolota ku khensa lokukulu eka vanhu vo tala, lava van’wana va vona hi tshamaka hi nga va tivi, lava swiendlo swa vona swi nga pfuna ku tumbuluxiwa ka khomixini leyi.

eng: these are the people who unearthed these alleged criminal acts, who resisted, who spoke out and who took up campaigns – both public and behind the scenes – to end state capture.
tso: lava i vanhu lava va nga humesela erivaleni swiendlo leswa vugevenga leswi hehliwaka, lava va nga ala, lava va nga vulavula na ku sungula mapfhumba – havumbirhi bya le rivaleni na le xihundleni – ku herisa ku tekiwa ka vulawuri bya mfumo.

eng: it is thanks to them that we now speak of state capture in the past tense.
tso: hikwalaho ka vona sweswi hi vulavula hi ku tekiwa ka vulawuri bya mfumo eka nkarhi lowu nga hundza.

eng: state capture did not end of its own accord.
tso: ku tekiwa ka vulawuri bya mfumo a swi tihelelangi hi swona n’wini.

eng: it was brought to an end by the concerted actions of south africans from all walks of life, working in various areas to restore the values of our constitutional democracy.
tso: swi herisiwile hi swiendlo swa ntirhisano swa vanhu va afrikadzonga kusuka eka swiyimo hinkwaswo swa vutomi, lava tirhaka eka tindhawu to hambana hambana ku tlherisela mikhuvanene ya xidemokirasi xa hina xa vumbiwa.

eng: and it is up to all of us to ensure that these practices are never allowed to happen again.
tso: naswona swi le ka hina hink werhu ku tiyisisa leswaku mikhuva leyi a yi pfumele riwi ku endleka nakambe.

eng: over the past three years, we have taken several important steps to tackle corruption and state capture.
tso: eka malembe manharhu lawa nga hundza, hi tekile magoza yo hlayanyana ku lwisana na vukungundzwana na ku tekiwa ka vulawuri bya mfumo.

eng: we have been painstakingly rebuilding bodies like the national prosecuting authority (npa), the south african police service, the south african revenue service and others.
tso: hi vile hi ri eku akeni hi vuntshwa hi ku tikarhata tihuvo to fana na vulawuri bya vuchuchisi bya rixaka (npa), vukorhokeri bya maphorisa bya afrikadzonga (saps), vukorhokeri bya swibalo bya afrikadzonga (sars) na tin’wana.

eng: we have set up new structures, like the investigating directorate in the npa to prosecute highlevel corruption and the special investigating unit (siu) special tribunal to recover stolen public funds.
tso: hi tumbuluxile swivumbeko swintshwa, ku fana na xiyengetsongo xo lavisisa eka npa ku tengisa vukungundzwana bya xiyimo xa le henhla na huvo yo hlawuleka ya siu ku vuyisa mali ya mfumo leyi nga yiviwa.

eng: we have improved our crimefighting capacity through the establishment of the fusion centre, which brings together various lawenforcement agencies to share information and coordinate the investigation and prosecution of crime.
tso: hi antswi sile vuswikoti byo lwisana na vugevenga hi ku tumbu luxa senthara ya nkatsaniso, leyi hlengeletaka tiejensi ta nsindziso wa nawu ku avelana vuxokoxoko na ku tirhisana ku lavisisa na ku tengisa vugevenga.

eng: we have changed the leadership at several strategic stateowned enterprises (soes), and begun the process of restoring them to financial and operational health.
tso: hi cincile vurhangeri eka mabindzu lama nga ehansi ka vun’wini bya mfumo ya xiqhinga yo talanyana, naswona hi sungurile phu rosese ya ku ma tlherisela eka xiyimo xo antswa xa swa timali na matirhelo.

eng: we are working towards a new soe model that promotes greater transparency, accountability and sustainability.
tso: hi le ku tirheleni ku tumbu luxa modlolo wa soe wuntshwa lowu wu nga ta kondletela nkavuciva, vutihlamuleri na vuyiseka mahlweni.

eng: much of this work is ongoing.
tso: vunyingi bya ntirho lowu byi ya mahlweni.

eng: there are areas where progress has been far slower than we would have hoped, and these are now receiving closer attention.
tso: ku na tindhawu laha nhluvuko wu nga nonoka swinene kutlula leswi a hi swi languterile, naswona leswi sweswi swi vekiwile mahlo.

eng: the findings and recommendations of the commission will undoubtedly strengthen these efforts.
tso: swikumiwa na swibu mabumelo swa khomixini leyi swi ta pfuna ku tiyisa hi ndlela leyi nga kanakani siki matshalatshala lama.

eng: we expect that the commission will identify some of the systemic weaknesses that allowed state capture to take place.
tso: hi langutela leswaku khomixini leyi yi ta kuma yin’wana ya mitsano leyi eka sisiteme leyi yi nga pfumelela ku tekiwa ka vulawuri bya mfumo ku va kona.

eng: this will empower us to take further corrective measures.
tso: leswi swi ta hi havexerisa matimba ku teka magoza man’wana mo lulamisa.

eng: while we can say that the era of state capture is over, we have not defeated corruption.
tso: hambiloko hi nga vula leswaku nkarhi wa ku tekiwa ka vulawuri bya mfumo wu hundzile, a hi byi hlulangi vukungundzwana.

eng: fraud and corruption remain pervasive and deeply entrenched in both the public and private sectors.
tso: vumbabva na vukungu ndzwana swa ha tele naswona swi simekiwile swi tiya eka havumbirhi bya tisekitara ta mfumo na leti nga riki ta mfumo.

eng: although it may not be on the scale of state capture, such criminal activities cost our country greatly, weaken our institutions and deprive south africans of many basic needs.
tso: hambileswi swi nga ha vaka swi nga ri xikalo xa ku tekiwa ka vulawuri bya mfumo, migingiriko ya vuge venga yo tano yi koxa tiko ra ka hina swinene, yi tsanisa mihlangano ya ka hina naswona yi tsonisa vanhu va afrikadzonga swidingo swa masungulo swo tala.

eng: corruption is deeply immoral at the best of times, but takes on a greater depravity in the midst of a humanitarian crisis.
tso: vukungundzwana byi bihile swinene mikarhi hinkwayo, kambe byi bihe ngopfu hikuva byi xungeta ntshamiseko wa vanhu.

eng: one speaks here of the despicable acts of corruption last year in the procurement of goods and services needed for our fight against the covid19 pandemic.
tso: un’wana a nga vulavula hi swiendlo swa manyala swa vukungundzwana lebyi nga humelela lembe leri nga hundza eka ku xaviwa ka tin hundzu na vukorhokeri leswi a swi laveka eka ku lwisana ka hina na ntungukulu wa covid19.

eng: we acted swiftly to stop such corruption, to identify those responsible and to take action against them.
tso: hi teke magoza hi xihatla ku sivela vukungundzwana byolebyo, ku kuma lava nga na vutihlamuleri na ku teka magoza ehenhla ka vona.

eng: this is proof of our commitment to root out corruption.
tso: leswi i xitiyisiso xa vutiboheleri bya hina ku herisa vukungundzwana.

eng: we tightened up treasury regulations, established the fusion centre and gave the siu a wideranging mandate to investigate all covid19related corruption allegations.
tso: hi tiyise swinawana swa vutamelankwama, hi tumbuluxe senthara ya nkatsaniso naswona hi nyike yuniti yo lavisisa yo hlawuleka xilerisoximfumo xo hambanahambana ku lavisisa swihehlo swa vukungundzwana byo yelana na covid19.

eng: in a first for the country, we also published online the details of all covid19 procurement contracts across all public entities.
tso: i rosungula eka tiko leri, hi nga hangalasa eka inthanete vuxokoxoko bya tikontiraka ta ku xaviwa ka tinhundzu na vukorhokeri ta covid19 hinkwato eka mavandla wa mfumo hi nkwawo.

eng: the damage done to our country by state capture is deep.
tso: ku onheka loku nga end liwa eka tiko ra ka hina hi ku tekiwa ka vulawuri bya mfumo ku entile.

eng: its effects will be felt for many years to come.
tso: switandzhaku swa kona swi ta twiwa eka malembe lamo tala lama taka.

eng: but, working together, we have started to put things right.
tso: kambe, hi ku tirhi sana, hi sungurile ku lulamisa swilo.

eng: we have started to rebuild and restore.
tso: hi sungu rile ku aka hi vuntshwa na ku tlherisela eka xiyimo xa khale.

eng: help prevent suicide allison cooper more people die as a result of suicide than hiv, malaria, breast cancer, war and homicide.
tso: pfuna ku sivela ku tisunga allison cooper va tele vanhu lava lovaka hikwalaho ko tisunga ematshan’wini ya hiv, dari, khensa ya mavele, nyimpi na ku dlayiwa.

eng: this is according to the world health organisation’s (who) latest statistics, which show that over 700 000 people die by suicide each year – that is one in every 100 deaths and approximately one person every 40 seconds.
tso: leswi swi boxiwile hi tinhlayonhlayo leta ha ku humaka ta nhlangano wa rihanyo wa misava, leti ti kombaka leswaku kuhundza 700 000 wa vanhu va lova hi ku tisunga lembe na lembe – leswi swi vula les waku i munhu un’we eka 100 ra mafu man’wana na man’wana na kwalomu ka munhu un’we eka 40 wa tise kondi tin’wana na tin’wana.

eng: "we cannot – and must not – ignore suicide," says dr tedros adhanom ghebreyesus, directorgeneral of the who.
tso: "a hi nge swi koti – naswona a hi fanelangi – ku nga swi tekeli enhlokweni ku tisunga," ku vula dkd tedros adhanom ghebrey esus, mulawurijenerali wa who.

eng: our attention to suicide prevention is even more important now, after many months of living with the coronavirus disease pandemic, with many of the risk factors for suicide – job loss, financial stress and social isolation – still very much present," he adds.
tso: ku tekela enhlokweni ku sivela ku tisunga ku ni nkoka lowu kulu sweswi, endzhaku ka tin’hweti to tala hi hanya ni ntungukulu wa vuvabyi bya khoronavhayirasi, na swivangelo swo tala swo tisunga – ku heleriwa hi ntirho, mabibi ya swa timali na ku hambanisiwa na vanhu van’wana swa ha ri kona swinene," a engetela.

eng: world suicide prevention dayworld suicide prevention day was launched on 10 september 2003, by the international association for suicide prevention.
tso: siku ra nsivelo wa ku tisunga ra misava siku ra nsivelo wa ku tisunga ra misava ri sime kiwile hi 10 ndzati 2003 hi nhlangano wa matiko ya misava wa nsivelo wa ku tisunga (iasp).

eng: it aims to prevent suicide and suicidal beha viour, alleviate its effects and provides a forum for academics, mental health professionals, crisis workers, volunteers and suicide survivors.
tso: ri kongomisiwile eka ku sivela ku tisunga na mahanyelo ya ku tisunga, ku hunguta switandzhaku swa kona na ku nyika foramu eka swidyondzeki, tiphurofexinali ta rihanyo ra le miehleketweni, vatirhi va swa mikitsikitsi, vatinyikeri ni lava nga pona eku tisungeni.

eng: according to the south african depression and anxiety group (sadag), there are 23 suicides and 230 serious suicide attempts recorded in south africa daily.
tso: hi ku ya hi ntlawa wa ntshikelelamiehleketo na nchavo wa afrikadzonga (sadag), ku na vanhu va 23 lava tisungaka na 230 lava ringeteke ku tisunga hi ku ya hi tirhekodo ta siku ni siku eafrikadzonga.

eng: "suicide is still a very taboo topic in our society – no one wants to talk about it; no one knows how to talk about it and parents don’t want to talk to their children about it in case it ‘plants ideas’.
tso: "ku tisunga ka ha ri nhlokomhaka yo yila erixakeni ra ka hina – ku hava loyi a lavaka ku vulavula hi ma yelana na swona; ku hava loyi a tivaka hilaha ku vulavuriwaka hakona hi mayelana na swona naswona vatswari a va lavi ku vulavula na vana va vona hi mayelana na swona hikwalaho ko chava leswaku swi nga ha "byala miana kanyo".

eng: however, it is a very real issue, and can be seen by the increasing daily calls we receive," says cassey chambers, sadag’s operations director.
tso: ha mbiswiritano, i mhaka leyi nga kona, leswi hi swi vona hi tiqingho leti engetelaka leti hi ti kumaka masiku hinkwawo, ku vula cassey chambers, mulawuri wa mitirho wa sadag.

eng: "if more people are aware of suicide and know how to get someone help before it’s too late, we can help reduce the suicide rate," she says.
tso: "loko vanhu vo tala va tiva hi mayelana na ku tisunga na ku tiva hilaha u nga kumelaka hakona munhu un’wana ku pfuniwa ku nga se hela nkarhi, hi nga pfuna ku hunguta nhlayo ya lava tisungaka", a vula.

eng: possible suicide warning signs include: talking about ending one's life, dying or suicide.
tso: swikombeto swo tsundzuxa swi katsa:l ku vulavula hi mayelana na ku teka vutomi bya vona, ku fa kumbe ku tisunga.

eng: strong wish to die or a preoccupation with death and dying.
tso: l ku navela ka matimba ka ku fa kumbe ku ehleketa ntsena hi rifu na ku fa.

eng: giving away prized possessions.
tso: l ku nyika vanhu nchumu wa nkoka swinene.

eng: signs of depression, such as moodiness, hopelessness, withdrawal, difficul ty with appetite and sleep, and loss of interest in usual activities.
tso: l swikombo swa ntshikelelamiehleketo, ku fana swa swipfukela, ku kala ntshembo, ku tihambanisa, ku tikeriwa hi navelo wa swakudya na vurhongo, ku nga naveli migingiriko ya ntolovelo.

eng: increased alcohol or drug use.
tso: l ku tirhisa xihoko na swidzidziharisi loku engeteleke.

eng: hinting about not being around in the future or saying goodbye.
tso: l ku gegagega les waku u nge vi kona enkarhini lowu taka kumbe ku lela.

eng: drastic behaviour changes.
tso: l ku cinca lokukulu ka mahanyelo.

eng: making arrangements to take care of unfinished business.
tso: l ku lulamisela ku yisa emahlweni ntirho lowu a wu nga hetisekangi.

eng: sa salutes whistleblowers vukuzenzele unnamed over the course of the three years, since the commission of inquiry into state capture started its work, we have heard of the lengths to which the perpetrators of corrupt acts have gone to conceal their misdeeds.
tso: afrikadzonga ri xixima valumandleve vukuzenzele unnamed eka nkarhi wa malembe manha rhu ku sukela loko khomixini yo lavisisa swihehlo swo lawuriwa ka mfumu hi swiyenge swa le tlhelo yi sungurile ntirho wa yona, hi twile ku leha loku vaendli va migi ngiriko ya vukungundwa na va ringeteke hakona ku fihla vubihi bya vona.

eng: it has been an extremely complex undertaking to unravel the networks of influence that enabled corruption.
tso: swi vile swo tika swinene ku ntlhatlha tinetiweke ta nkucetelo lowu pfuleleke vukungundwana.

eng: among other things, vast webs of front companies were established to move funds around and disguise payments made to politicallyconnected individuals.
tso: swin’wana swa kona, nhlayo yotala ya tikhaphani leti rhangisiwaka emahlweni ti vile ti tumbuluxiwa ti ngungumerisa mali no fihla tihakelo leti endleriweke vanhu lava nga ni vuxaka bya tipolitiki.

eng: the same patterns have been seen in a number of investigations into corruption being undertaken by the special investigating unit (siu) the directorate for priority crime investigation, the national prosecuting authority's (npa) investigating directorate and others.
tso: maendlelo yo fana ya vonakile eka milavisiso yo hlaya ya vukungundwana leyi endliweke hi yuniti ya vulavisisi byo hlawuleka (siu), xipano xo lavisisa vugevenga lebyi rhangeke emahlweni (dpci), xipano xa ndzavisiso xa npa na swin’wana.

eng: as these investigations progressed and the net began to close on implicated individuals, we have seen witnesses being threatened, their families intimidated, being forced into hiding, and even killed.
tso: loko vulavisisi lebyi bya ha ya emahlweni naswona xirimbana xi sungula ku pfalela vanhu lava kumbekaka, hi vonile timbhoni ti chavisetiwa, mindyangu ya vona yi chuhwisiwa, yi si ndzisiwa ku tumbela hambi ku dlayiwa.

eng: the murder of babita deokaran, a senior finance official in the gauteng health department, is a stark reminder of the high stakes involved in our collective quest to remove this cancer from our society.
tso: ku dlayiwa ka babita deo karan, muofisarankulu wa swa timali eka ndzawulo ya rihanyo ya le gauteng, i xitsundzuxo xo vonaka xa nxungeto lowukulu lowu khumbekaka eka ku tinyike tela ka nhlengelo ko lwisana na ku susa mfukuzani leyi eka vaaki va hina.

eng: while we do not yet know the motive for her murder, she was a key witness in a siu investigation into the procurement of personal protective equipment in the department.
tso: hambiloko hi nga si tiva xivangelo xa rifu ra yena, a a ri mbhoni yo tiya eka vulavisisi bya siu eka maendlelo yo nyikana tippe eka ndzawulo.

eng: the saps and the private security teams who apprehended seven suspects recently are to be commended for their work.
tso: saps na mitlawa ya vusirheleri yo ka yi ga ri ya mfumo lava khomeke vaehleketeleriwa va nkombo sweswinyana yi ta ndhu ndhuzeriwa eka ntirho lowu wa yona.

eng: the docket has been transferred to the hawks, and the investigation will yield further information on why ms deokaran was murdered.
tso: tidokete ti hundziseriwile eka tihawks, naswona vulavisisi byi ta ya emahlweni byi humesa mahungu ya leswaku hikokwalaho ka yini ms deokaran a dlayiwile.

eng: regardless of the circumstances behind this tragedy, ms deokaran was a hero and a patriot.
tso: swi nga ri na mhaka le swaku hi swihi swiyimo leswi nga va nga khombo leri, ms deokaran a a ri nhe nha na mulwelatiko.

eng: as are the legions of whistleblowers who, at great risk to themselves, help to unearth instances of misdeeds, maladministration, cronyism and theft.
tso: tanihi valumandleve vo tala, lava tivekaka ekhombyeni ku pfuna ku pfupfula swiendlo swo biha, mafambiselo yo biha, xin’wanamanana na vukhamba.

eng: without their brave and principled interventions, we would be unable to unmask those committing corruption.
tso: handle ka tiyanhlana wa vona na manghenelelo lamanene, a hi nge swikoti ku vona lava endlaka vukungundwana.

eng: though much focus in recent times has been on whistleblowers in the public sector, we also owe a debt of gratitude to those in the private sector whose actions receive less attention, but are equally important.
tso: hambileswi eka nkarhi wa sweswi ku kongomisiweke ngopfu eka valumandleve va leka sekitara ya mfumo, hi na xikweleti xo nkhesa lava nga eka sekitara yo ka yi nga ri ya mfumo lava mitirho ya vona yi nga voniwiki ngopfu, kambe yi na nkoka wo ringana.

eng: whistleblowers are important guardians of our democracy.
tso: valumandleve i vahlayisi va nkoka va demokirasi ya hina.

eng: they raise the alarm against unethical acts and practices in government and organisations.
tso: va vika matikhomelo yo biha na maendlelo eka mfumo na mihlangano yin’wana.

eng: they speak out in good faith and with a reasonable expectation not only that action will be taken on their disclosures, but that they will be protected and not suffer victimisation or prejudice.
tso: va vulavula hi ndlela ya kahle yo tshembeka no va na ku langutela ko khomeka ku nga ri ntsena leswaku ku ta tekiwa magoza ku landza ku humesela ka vona ehandle, kambe leswaku va ta si rheleriwa naswona va nge twisiwi ku vava kumbe ku nyadziwa.

eng: in south africa there is extensive legislative protection for whistleblowers, including through the protected disclosures act, labour relations act, companies act, protection against harassment act, and the constitution itself.
tso: eafrikadzonga ku na milawu yo hlaya leyi sirhele laka valumandleve ku katsa nawu wo humesela erivaleni u sirhelelekile, nawu wa vuxaka bya vatirhi, nawu wa tikhaphani, nawu wo sirhelela eka ku xanisiwa na vumbiwa hi roxe.

eng: in addition, the department of justice and correctional services, working with other lawenforcement agencies, administers the office of witness protection to provide support to vulnerable and intimidated witnesses in any judicial proceedings.
tso: hi ku engetela, ndzawulo ya vululami na vukorhokeri bya makhotso, hi ku tirhi sana na swiyenge swin’wana swa nawu, yi lawula hofisi ya nsirhelelo wa timbhoni ku nyika nseketelo eka lava nga sirhelelekangiki na timbhoni leti chavisiwaka eka mafambiselo man’wana na man’wana ya nawu.

eng: entering witness protection is voluntary, and neither the saps nor the npa can compel a witness to do so.
tso: ku tinghenelerisa eka vuhlayiseki bya mbhoni a swi bohi, naswona hambi saps kumbe npa yi nge sindzisi mbhoni ku endla tano.

eng: should a witness receive threats to their life or feel unsafe, they have to inform investigators and apply for admission to the programme.
tso: loko mbhoni yi kuma nxungeto wa vutomi bya yona kumbe ku twa yi nga hlayisekangi, yi fanele ku tivisa valavisisi no endla xikombelo xo nghenisiwa eka nongonoko.

eng: this successful programme has played a key role in securing successful prosecutions since its inception, particularly with regards to organised crime.
tso: nongonoko lowu, lowu nga tisa ku humelela wu tlangile xiave xa nkoka eka ku tiyisisa ku tengisiwa loku nga humelela ku sukela loko wu sungule ku tirhisiwa, ngopfungopfu eka vugevenga lebyi va ka byi kunguhatiwile.

eng: it is clear that as the fight against corruption gathers momentum, we need to urgently review our current approach not only to witness protection, but also to the broader protection of whistleblowers.
tso: swi le rivaleni leswaku loko ku lwisana na vukungu ndwana swi va ni matimba, hi fanele ku tlhela hi langutisisa maendlelo ya hina ya sweswi hi xihatla ku nga ri ku languta ntsena vusirheleri bya mbhoni, kambe na ku ndlandlamuxa vuhlayi seki bya valumandleve.

eng: while numerous systems are in place to enable whistleblowers to report anonymously, we need to tighten up existing systems and provide greater support to those who publicly come forward with information.
tso: loko tisisitime to hlaya ti ri ku endliweni ku endla leswaku valumandleve va vika va nga tiveki, hi fanele hi tiyisa tisisitime leti nga kona no nyika nseketelo wa lehenhla eka lava humelaka rivaleni ni mahungu.

eng: as society, we need to identify where existing laws and policies are inadequate in protecting the livelihoods, reputations and safety of whistleblowers – and work together to address these.
tso: tanihi vaaki, hi fanele hi vona laha milawu leyi nga kona na tipholisi ti kayivelaka kona eka ku sirhelela tindlela to tihanyisa, ndzhuti na vuhlayiseki bya valu mandleve no tirha swin’we ku fikelela leswi.

eng: the intent of the criminals who target whistleblowers is not only to silence particular individuals – it is also to send a message to other potential whistleblowers.
tso: xikongomelo xa swi gevenga leswi hlaselaka valumandleve a hi ku miyeta vanhu vo karhi ntsena– swi tlhela swi rhumela hungu eka valumandleve van’wana.

eng: day by day, brave south africans like babita deokaran are standing firm that they will not be party to corruption and they are prepared to bear witness against it.
tso: siku na siku, maafrikadzonga ya tiyanhlana ku fana na babita deokaran va vula leswaku va nge vi xirho xa vukungundwana naswona va tiyimiserile ku va timbho ni ku lwisana na byona.

eng: as the south african people, we salute her and all the whistleblowers in the public and private sectors who are exposing corruption to the harshest of glares.
tso: tanihi vanhu va afrikadzonga ha n’wi xixima na valumandleve lavan’wana eka tisekitara ta mfumo na toka ti nga ri ta mfumo lava nga ekuhumeseleni vuku ngudwana ehandle eka nka rhi lowo tika.

eng: they are doing so without expectation of acknowledgement or reward.
tso: va endla leswi va nga langutelanga nchumu xo nkhensiwa kumbe ku nyikeriwa hi xona.

eng: theirs is the highest form of public service.
tso: xa vona i vukorhokeri bya mfumo bya xiyimo xa le henhla.

eng: we cannot let them down.
tso: a hi nge va nyumisi.

eng: spot childhood cancer warning signs allison cooper childhood cancer is on the rise globally, with an esti mated one in 408 children worldwide diagnosed with cancer before the age of 15. according to taryn seegers, the communications coordinator at the childhood cancer foundation of south africa (choc), it is believed that two thirds of children with cancer do not receive treatment and often those who do are already in the late stages of the disease.
tso: tiva swikoweto swa ndzemukiso wa mfukuzani ya le ka vana allison cooper n'hweti yo lemukisa hi mfukuzani ya le ka vana, leyi va ka kona n’hweti yin’wana na yin’wana ya ndzati, yi endla xilemukiso mayelana na timfukuzani to tala ta le ka vana.

eng: since 2011, choc has been working with the department of health and traditional healers to provide health professionals, healthcare workers, traditional healers and communities with knowledge of childhood cancer.
tso: mfukuzani ya le ka vana yi le ku tlakukeni emisa veni hinkwayo, hi ringa nyeto wa n’wana wun’we eka 408 wa vana emisaveni hinkwayo a kumekaka a ri na mfukuzani a nga si fikisa malembe ya 15. ku ya hi taryn seegers, mukhondleteri wa vuhlanga nisi eka nhlangano wa mfu kuzani ya le ka vana wa afrikadzonga (choc), ku tshembiwa leswaku tinhlayo ta mbirhixanharhu ta vana lava nga na mfukuzani a va kumi vutshunguri na swona hakanyingi lava va byi kumaka va va se vari eka switeji swo hetelela swa vuvabyi.

eng: "these individuals are taught the siluan early warning signs and learn how to demystify myths and stigma in communities," says seegers.
tso: ku sukela hi 2011, choc yi le ku tirhisaneni na ndzawulo ya rihanyu na tin'anga ta xintu ku nyika vatirhi va rihanyu; vatirhi va nhlayiso wa rihanyu, tin’anga ta xintu na miganga vutivi bya mfukuzani ya le ka vana.

eng: the siluan early warning signs are: seek: medical help for early, persistent symptoms.
tso: "vanhu lava va dyondza swikoweto swa ndzemuki so swo sungula swa siluan no dyondza ku olovisa swi kholwana swa mavunwa na ku tsan’wa emigangeni," ku vula seegers.

eng: eye: white spot in the eye, new squint, new blindness, bulging eyeball.
tso: swikoweto swa ndzemukiso swo sungula swa siluan hi leswi: lava: ku pfuniwa ka vutshunguri eka swikombeto swo sungula swo sihalala.

eng: lump: abdomen and pelvis, head and neck, limbs, testes and glands.
tso: tihlo: papa ro basa eti hlweni, ku sungula ku va na mangayi, ku sungula ku ka u nga voni, ku pfimba tindzololo.

eng: unexplained: prolonged fever over two weeks, weight loss, pallor, fatigue, easy bruising or bleeding.
tso: thumba: ehansi ka nkava na le xisutini, nhloko na nhamu, mavoko na milenge, marhanga ya swirho swa xihundla eka vaxinuna na tinhlaribya.

eng: aching: bones, joints, back and easy fractures.
tso: swo ka swi nga hlamu seleki: dari ra nkarhi wo leha ku tlula mavhiki mambirhi, ku ondza, ku basuluka, ku karhala, mafidzula no huma ngati hi ku olova.

eng: neurological signs: change or deterioration in walk, balance or speech, regression of milestones, headache for more than a week with or without vomiting and an enlarged head.
tso: ku pandza: marhambu, mahlangano, nhlana na ku tshoveka marhambu hi ku olova.

eng: childhood cancerschildhood cancers are different from cancers affecting adults.
tso: timfukuzani ta le ka vanatimfukuzani ta le ka vana ti hambanile na timfukizani leti karhataka lavakulu.

eng: they tend to occur in the organs of the body, look different under the microscope and respond more favourably to treatment, says seegers.
tso: ti tala ku endleka eka swirho swa miri, ti languteka ku hambana eka xo pompola ti tlhela ti tshu nguleka hi ku olova, ku vula seegers.

eng: "cure rates for most childhood cancers are much higher than those for most adult cancers.
tso: "tinhlayo ta ku tshunguleka ka timfukuzani ta le ka vana ti le henhla ku tlula timfukuzani ta lavakulu.

eng: today, in developing countries, the majority of childhood cancers can be treated very effectively, and between 50% to 60% can be cured.
tso: namuntlha, eka matiko lama ha hluvu kaka, timfukuzani to tala ta le ka vana ti nga tshunguriwa hi ku hetiseka, naswona exi karhi ka 50% ku ya ka 60% ti nga tshunguleka.

eng: in highincome countries, the survival rate can be between 85% to 90%.
tso: eka matiko lama nga fuma, tinhlayo ta ku pona ti le xikarhi ka 80% ku ya ka 90%.

eng: brics key to sa's growth vukuzenzele unnamed a year before the first democratic elections, president nelson mandela wrote an article in foreign policy magazine on the new south africa’s future foreign policy.
tso: brics i xiphemu xa nkoka eka ku kula ka afrikadzonga vukuzenzele unnamed lembe ku nga si va na nhlawulo wo sungu la wa xidemokirasi, phuresidente nelson ma ndela u tsale atikili eka ma gazini wa foreign policy hi mayelana na pholisi ya ma tiko mambe ya vumundzu ku ya afrikadzonga leyi ntshwa.

eng: reflecting on the shifts in global alliances brought about by the end of the cold war, he wrote that countries would have to "recast their nets" if they were to reap any benefit from international affairs.
tso: hi ku langutisisa ku cinca eka swinakulobye swa misava hinkwayo leswi swi tisiweke hi ku hela ka nyimpi yo tshwukiselana mahlo, u tsarile leswaku matiko ya boheka ku "ku languta leswi nga kotekaka" loko ya lava ku tshovela mbuyelo wihi kumbe wihi kusuka eka timhaka ta matiko ya misava.

eng: since the tectonic shift of 1994 when we made a decisive break with not just apartheid but the international relations outlook of its architects, south africa’s foreign policy continues to be characterised by this "recasting the net".
tso: kusukela eka ku cinca ka nkoka ka 1994 loko hi ha mbane ramakumu kungari na xihlawuhlawu ntsena kambe na xivumbeko xa le handle xa vuxaka bya matiko ya misava na vapulani va xona, pholisi ya matiko mambe ya afrikadzonga yi ya ema hlweni yi hlawulekisiwa hi "ku langutiwa loku ka leswi nga kotekaka".

eng: our foreign policy priorities are regional political and economic integration, pursing african development, multilateral engagement and the promotion of democracy, peace and human rights.
tso: swirhangana swa hina swa pholisi ya matiko mambe i mpfanganiso wa tipolitiki na ikhonomi swa xifundza, na ku landzelela nhluvukiso wa afrika, ku vulavurisana ka matikonyingi na nkondletelo wa xidemokirasi, ku rhula na timfanelo ta vanhu.

eng: to this end, we have forged strategic alliances with both the countries of the global south and mutually beneficial cooperation with the countries of the north.
tso: ku humelerisa leswi hi vumbile swinakulobye swa xiqhinga na havumbirhi bya matiko ya misava ya le dzonga wa malinghena ya le hansi na ntirhisano wo vu yerisa matlhelo hinkwawo ya le n’walungu.

eng: joining the brics group of countries in 2010 was a milestone in our quest to advance our own national development priorities by forging stronger ties with the important emerging economies of brazil, russia, india and china.
tso: ku tikatsa eka ntlawa wa brics wa matiko hi 2010 ku vi le ndzima ya nkoka eka ku lava ka hina ku kondletela swirhangana swa hina swa nhluvukiso wa rixaka hi ku vumba vuxaka byo tiya na tiikhonomi leta ha tumbulu kaka ta nkoka ta brazil, russia, india na china.

eng: put into context, brics countries comprise roughly 41% of the world’s population and account for around 24% of global gdp and some 16% of global trade.
tso: hi ku tekela nhlokweni swiyimo hinkwaswo, matiko ya brics ya vumbiwa hi kwa lomu ka 41% ta nhlayo ya vanhu va misava na ku endla kwalomu ka 24% ta gdp ya misava hinkwayo na kwa lomu ka 16% ta mabindzu ya misava.

eng: we have reaped the benefits of membership of this important bloc, most notably in the area of economic cooperation.
tso: hi tshoverile mivu yelo ya vuxirho bya vuxaka lebya nkoka, ngopfungopfu eka xiyenge xa ntirhisano wa ikhonomi.

eng: bilateral trade has grown, particularly with china and india, with commodity exports and manufactured goods imports featuring strongly.
tso: mabindzu ya matiko ma mbirhi ya kurile, ngopfu ngopfu ya china na india, hi ku rhumeriwa ematikweni mambe switirhisiwambisi na ku xaviwa kusuka ematikweni mambe tinhundzu leti endli weke swi ri leswi nghenaka hi ndlela ya matimba.

eng: the brics countries continue to be important sources of foreign direct investment in key such as mining, automotive, transportation, clean energy, financial services and it.
tso: matiko ya brics ya ya emahlweni ya va swihlovo swa nkoka swa vuvekisi byo kongoma bya matiko mambe eka mabindzu ya nkoka yo tanihi vucelami godi, mimovha, vutleketli, eneji yo basa, vukorhokeri bya timali na it.

eng: a 2018 review of our brics membership by professional services firm deloitte noted that brics partners "invested three times more capital in the country compared to the seven years prior to 2011".
tso: nkambisiso wa 2018 wa vuxirho bya hina bya brics hi feme ya vukorhokeri bya xiphurofexinali, deloitte wu lemuke leswaku vatirhi sani va brics "va vekise hi kanharhu xumakulu xo tala etikweni loko ku fananisiwa na malembe ya nkombo ku nga si fika 2011".

eng: these investments and projects have in turn led to significant job creation.
tso: vuvekisi lebyi na tiphurojeke leti endzhakukaswona swi tisile ku tumbuluxiwa ka mitirho yo tivikana.

eng: since the formation of the new development bank, whose regional office is located in johannesburg, south africa has been a beneficiary of financing and technical support for projects in transportation, clean energy, environmental protection, water infrastructure and greenhouse gas emissions reduction.
tso: kusukelaloko ku tumbu luxiwile bangi ya nhluvukiso leyintshwa, leyi tihofisi ta yona ta xifundza ti nga ejoni, afrikadzonga yi vile muvu yeriwa wa nseketelo wa timali na wa xithekiniki wa tiphu rojeke leti nga eka vutleketli, eneji yo basa, nsirhelelo wa mbangu, swimakiwakulu swa mati na ku hungutiwa ka ku tswongiwa ka rihiso exiba kabakeni.

eng: since the outbreak of the covid19 pandemic, south africa has received $2 billion in funding from the new development bank under the covid19 emergency loan programme to fight the pandemic and to support our economic recovery.
tso: himpfhuka loko ku sungu rile ntungukulu wa covid19 , afrikadzonga yi amu kerile $2 ta tibiliyoni ta mpfuneto kusuka eka bangi ya nhluvukiso leyintshwa ehansi ka nongonoko wa tiloni ta xilamulelamhangu ta covid19 ku lwisana na ntungukulu lowu na ku seke tela nhlakarhelo wa hina wa ikhonomi.

eng: there has also been substantial cooperation with our brics partners in securing personal protective equipment and cooperation around vaccine access and distribution.
tso: ku tlhele ku va na ntirhisano wo tivikana na vatirhisani va hina va brics eka ku kuma switirhisiwa swo tisirhelela na ntirhisano hi mayelana na mfikelelo wa swisawutisi na hangalaso.

eng: we recently participated in the 13th brics summit, where brics countries agreed to deepen cooperation to fight covid19 and mobilise the political support and financial resources needed to respond to future pandemic preparedness.
tso: sweswinyana hi teke xiave eka samiti ya brics ya vu13, laha matiko ya brics ya nga twanana ku tiyisisa ntirhisano ku lwisana na covid19 na ku hlengeleta nseketelo wa xipolitiki na swipfuno swa timali leswi dingiwaka ku angula eka vulunghekeli bya mitungukulu ya nkarhi lowu taka.

eng: this includes the establishment of a virtual brics vaccine research and development centre and a brics integrated early warning system to forecast future outbreaks of infectious diseases.
tso: leswi swi katsa ku tumbu luxiwa ka senthara ya ndza visiso na nhluvukiso wa swisawutisi ya brics ya le moyeni na sisiteme yo tsu ndzuxa ka ha ri na nkarhi leyi pfanganisiweke ya brics ku kota ku vhumba ku tu mbuluka ka mitungukulu ya nkarhi lowu taka ya mavabyi yo tluletana.

eng: another important area of agreement was on mutual recognition of national documents of vaccination and systems of covid19 testing – something that will be vital to crossborder travel in the future.
tso: xiyenge xa nkoka xin’wana xa ntwanano ku vi le ku lemu kiwa ka matlhelo hinkwawo ka tidokhumente ta rixaka ta nsawutiso na tisisiteme ta ku kamberiwa ka covid19 – leswi swi nga ta va swa nkoka eka ku teka rendzo ro tsemaka nya mindzilekano eka nkarhi lowu taka.

eng: the concept of mutually beneficial cooperation will be particularly important in the global economic recovery, where unequal development means that some countries will bounce back quickly, while others will lag behind.
tso: nongoti wa nti rhisano wo vuyerisa matlhelo hinkwawo wu ta va wa nkoka ngopfungopfu eka nhlaka rhelo wa ikhonomi ya misava hinkwayo, laha nhluvukiso wa nkandzingano wu vulaka leswaku matiko man’wana ya ta vuyela evutshan’wini hi ku hatlisa, loko man’wana ya ta salela endzhaku.

eng: in support of economic recovery, brics partners agreed to strengthen collaboration in catalytic sectors such as energy, it, science, technology and innovation, agriculture and the green economy.
tso: hi ku seketela nhlakarhelo wa ikhonomi, vatirhisani va brics va twanane ku tiyisa ntirhisano eka tisekitara to nyika matimba to tanihi eneji, it, sayense, thekinoloji na vutumbuluxi, vurimi na ikho nomi ya rihlaza.

eng: these are all important sectors identified in our economic reconstruction and recovery plan announced last year.
tso: leti hikwato i tisekitara ta nkoka leti kumi weke eka nkungu ra ku aka hi vuntshwa na nhlakarhelo ra ikhonomi leri tivisiweke lembe leri hundzeke.

eng: cooperation with other brics countries, particularly in the field of innovation research, will help to accelerate our country’s industrialisation and help us meet our fourth industrial revolution aspirations.
tso: ntirhisano na matiko ma n’wana ya brics, ngopfu ngopfu eka ndzima ya ndza visiso ya vutumbuluxi, wu ta pfuna ku hatlisisa ku endliwa ka tiindasitiri eka tiko ra ka hina na ku hi pfuna ku fikelela ku navela ka hina ka ncinco wa tiindasitiri wa vumune.

eng: in this regard, discussions were held around the creation of formal brics platforms to share best practice, knowledge and expertise, including the use of open source technology platforms.
tso: hi mayelana na mhaka leyi, mijekajekisano yi vile kona hi mayelana na ku tumbuluxiwa ka tipulatifomo ta brics ta ximfumo leswaku hi avelana maendlelonene, vutivi na vu swikoti, ku katsa ku tirhisiwa ka tipulatifomo ta thekinoloji ya swihlovo swo pfuleka.

eng: the brics partners agreed that developing countries need assistance to achieve the un sustainable development goals, and that donor countries should honour their commitments in this regard.
tso: vatirhisani va brics va twa nane leswaku matiko lama ha hluvukaka ya dinga mpfuno ku fikelela swikongomelokulu swa nhluvukiso lowu yise kaka emahlweni swa un, na leswaku matiko lama nyike laka ya fanele ku humelerisa ku tiyimisela ka wona hi ma yelana na mhaka leyi.

eng: this is particularly important within the context of climate action.
tso: leswi swi na nkoka ngopfungopfu loko ku tekeriwa enhlokweni hinkwaswo eka goza ra tlila yimete.
