eng: nearly 3 000 south african female entrepreneurs are already registered on the shetradesza hub and receive free elearning and capacity building.
tso: kwalomu ka 3 000 wa van’wamabindzu va xisati va afrikadzonga se va titsariserile eka xivindzi xa migingirko xa shetradesza naswona va kuma dyondzo ya mahala ya le ka inthanete na ku antswi sa matirhelo.

eng: we can and will do more to end load shedding vukuzenzele unnamed over the past few weeks, severe load shedding has disrupted our economy and caused extreme hardship for all south africans.
tso: hi nga swi kota naswona hi ta endla swo tala ku herisa ku timiwa ka gezi vukuzenzele unnamed eka mavhiki ma nga ri mangani lama nga hundza, ku timiwa ka gezi ko hlaya ku kavanyetile ikhonomi ya hina no vanga ku tike riwa lokukulu eka ma afrikadzonga hinkwa wo.

eng: stage 6 load shedding was triggered by the loss of more than 18 000 megawatts (mw) of generation capacity due to unit breakdowns and an unprotected strike by eskom workers.
tso: xiteji xa 6 xo timiwa ka gezi xi vangiwile hi ku lahlekeriwa ko tlula kwalomu ka 18 000 wa megawati (mv) ta vuswikoti byo endla gezi hikwalaho ka ku onhaka ka yuniti na xitereke xo ka xi nga hlayisekangi hi vatirhi va eskom.

eng: after more than a decade of electricity shortages, south africans are right to feel frustrated and angry.
tso: endzhaku ka ku tlula malembe ya khume ya nkayivelo wa gezi, maafrikadzonga va fanerile ku vilela no kwata.

eng: at times like this, it can feel like there is no end in sight.
tso: hi mikarhi yo fana na leyi, swi twala wonge a ku na ku tikomba ku swi ta fika emakumu.

eng: yet, while load shedding appears to worsen, the reality is that we have already taken several important actions to address the shortfall in electricity supply.
tso: kambe loko ku timiwa ka gezi ku languteka ku ya ku tika, ntiyiso hileswaku se hi tekile magoza ya nkoka yo hlaya ku lwisana na nkayivelo wa mphakelo wa gezi.

eng: our immediate priority is to stabilise the electricity system.
tso: leswi hi swi rhangisaka emahlweni hi xihatla i ku lawula sisiteme ya gezi.

eng: as the system recovers and generation capacity is restored, eskom will be able to reduce load shedding to lower stages.
tso: loko sisiteme yi tshamiseka na vuswikoti byo endla gezi byi vuyela evutshan’wini, eskom yi ta kota ku hunguta ku timiwa ka gezi ku ya eka switeji swa le hansi.

eng: the agreement reached between eskom and labour unions will enable critical repairs and return additional units to operation.
tso: ntwanano lowu nga fikeleriwa exikarhi ka eskom na mihlangano yo yimela va vatirhi wu ta pfumelela ku lunghisa ka nkoka no vuyelerisa ku tirha ka tiyuniti to engetela.

eng: the transmission line from cahora bassa in mozambique has been restored, adding 600 mw to the grid, and medupi unit 6 returned to service recently adding another 720 mw.
tso: layini yo fambisa gezi ku suka ecahora bassa emozambique yi vuyele ematshan’wini, yi engetela 600 mw eka giridi, na yuniti ya 6 ya le medupi yi vuyelerile eku tirheni hi mugqivela, leswi nga engetela timegawati tin’wana ta 720. tiyuniti to engetela ti languteriwa ku vuyelela eku tirheni, leswi nga ta ya emahlweni swi hunguta nkayivelo wa nkarhi wa sweswi.

eng: additional units are expected to come back online, further easing the current shortfall.
tso: hi nkarhi wu ri wun’we, swiyenge swa vahlayisi va nawu swi le ku tirheni hi matimba ku lwisa nkavanyeto, vukhamba na vuxisi eka eskom ku lulamisa nxungeto lowu migingiriko ya vugevenga wu nga na yona eka sisiteme ya gezi.

eng: this will create space for eskom to undertake critical maintenance and increase the reliability of its fleet.
tso: leswi swi ta nyika eskom nkarhi wo endla ku lunghisa ka nkoka no tlakusa ku tshembela eka switirho swa yona.

eng: it will also create a buffer so that even if several units experience breakdowns at once, other sources can be used.
tso: swi ta tlhela swi va xisirhelelo leswaku na loko tiyuniti to tala ti onhaka hi nkarhi wun’we, ku nga tirhisiwa tindhawu letin’wana.

eng: one of the first steps i took in 2018 was to revive the renewable energy procurement programme.
tso: rin’wana ra magoza yo sungula lawa ndzi nga ya teka hi 2018 a ku ri ku pfuxeta nongonoko wa makumelo ya eneji leyi pfuxetekaka.

eng: in addition to the procurement of new generation capacity through this programme, the increase of the licensing threshold for new generation projects to 100 mw means that private investors do not require a license to build generation facilities up to this size.
tso: ku engetela eka makumelo ya xivandla lexintshwa xa vuswikoti byo endla gezi hi ku tirhisa nongonoko lowu, ntlakuso wa xikalo xa layisense xa tiphurojeke letintshwa to endla gezi ku ya 100 mw swi vula leswaku vavekisi va le xihundleni a va lavi layisense ku aka switirhisiwa swo endla gezi ku fika eka sayizi leyi.

eng: this simple reform has unlocked a massive potential pipeline of investment.
tso: ku cinca loku ko olova ku pfurile tindlela to tala ta ku koteka ka vuvekisi.

eng: eskom has made land available next to existing power stations for private investment in renewable energy projects.
tso: eskom yi endlile leswaku ku va na misava ekusuhi na switichi swa gezi leswi nga kona leyi nga ta tirhisiwa hi vuvekisi bya le xihundleni eka tiphurojeke ta eneji leyi pfuxetekaka.

eng: design modifications have been completed to improve the performance of medupi units 1, 2 and 3 and are underway in units 5 and 6. while these actions are significant and will bear fruit over the coming months, they are clearly not enough to address the crisis that we face.
tso: ku cinciwa ka swivumbeko swi herile ku endlela ku antswisa matirhelo ya tiyuniti ta 1, 2 na 3 ta le medupi naswona swi ya mahlweni eka tiyuniti ta 5 na 6. loko migingiriko leyi yi ri na nkoka naswona yi ta tswala mihandzu eka tin’hweti leti taka, swi le rivaleni leswaku a yi ringanelanga ku ololoxa xiphiqo lexi hi nga langutana na xona.

eng: what the past few weeks have demonstrated is that we need to do more and do so with the utmost urgency.
tso: leswi mavhiki ma nga ri mangani lama nga hundza ya swi kombiseke hileswaku hi fanele ku endla swo tala no swi endla hi xihatla lexikulu.

eng: there is no reason why a country like ours – with the skills, capabilities and resources we have at our disposal – should have to endure a shortage of electricity.
tso: a ku na xivangelo xa leswaku hikokwalahokayini tiko ro fana na ra hina– ra vuswikoti, matimba na switirhisiwa leswi hi nga na swona – ri fanele ku tiyisela ku vava ka nkayivelo wa gezi.

eng: over the past few weeks, we have been working with the relevant ministers and senior officials on a range of additional measures to accelerate all efforts to increase our electricity supply.
tso: eka mavhiki ma nga ri mangani, a hi ri ku tirheni na vaholobye lava faneleke na vaofisarankulu eka magoza yo hambana yo engetela ku hatlisisa matshalatshala hinkwawo ku tlakusa mphakelo wa hina wa gezi.

eng: the message is clear: this is no time for business as usual.
tso: hungu ri le rivaleni: lowu a hi nkarhi wo tirha tanihi ntolovelo.

eng: we need to act boldly to make load shedding a thing of the past.
tso: hi fanele ku teka goza hi ku titshemba ku endla ku timiwa ka gezi ku va ka nkarhi lowu nga hundza.

eng: while the measures we have already taken will secure the supply of reliable and affordable electricity into the future, we have been looking at what additional measures we can take now to bring that goal closer.
tso: loko magoza lama se hi nga ma teka ya ta tiyisa mphakelo wa gezi wo tshembeka no ka ri nga durhi ku ya eka nkarhi lowu taka, a hi ri eku languteni ka magoza yo engetela lama hi nga ma tekaka sweswi ku tshineta xikongomelo xexo ekusuhi.

eng: we will soon be completing the detailed work and consultations needed to finalise these further measures.
tso: ku nga ri khale hi ta heta ntirho hi vuenti na ku tihlanganisa lo ku lavekaka ku hetisisa magoza lama ku ya emahlweni.

eng: we will then, soon, be able to announce a comprehensive set of actions to achieve much faster progress in tackling load shedding.
tso: hikwalaho, ku nga ri khale, hi ta kota ku tivisa migingiriko yo twisiseka ku fikelela ku humelela hi xihatla eka ku lwisana na ku timiwa ka gezi.

eng: new approach to fight corruption gets results vukuzenzele unnamed the fight against corruption requires both firm political will and independent, capable crimefighting institutions.
tso: endlelo rintshwa ro lwisana na vukungundzwana ri kuma mivuyelo vukuzenzele unnamed ku lwisana na vuku ngundzwana swi lava haswimbirhi ku tiyimisela ka swa tipolitiki loku tiyeke na mihlangano yo lwisana na vugevenga leyi nga na vuswikoti, leyi tiyimeleke.

eng: in my first state of the nation address, in 2018, i made a commitment to turn the tide against corruption in our public institutions and fight fraud and collusion in the private sector with the same intensity and purpose.
tso: eka mbulavulo wa mina wa xiyimo xa rixaka wo sungula hi 2018, ndzi tibohe ku vuyerisa swilo ematshan’weni ehenhla ka vukungundzwana eka mihlangano ya hina ya mfumo na ku lwisana na vumbabva na ku tirhisana ka le xihundleni loku nga riki enawini eka xiyenge lexi nga riki xa mfumo hi ntamu wo fana na xikongomelo xo fana.

eng: since then, we have been working hard to strengthen and support our law enforcement and related agencies.
tso: kusukela nkarhi wolowo, hi le ku tirheni hi matimba ku tiyisisa na ku seketela tiejensi ta hina to hlayisa nawu na tiejensi leti fambela naka na tona.

eng: we set up the investigating directorate in the national prosecuting authority to deal with serious corruption and the special tribunal to enable the special investigating unit (siu) to more easily recover stolen funds.
tso: hi simekile xiyengetsongo eka vulawuri bya vuchuchisi bya rixaka ku tirhana na vukungu ndzwana byo tika na khoto yo hlawuleka ku endlela leswaku yuniti ya vulavisisi byo hlawuleka (siu) yi kota ku vuyisela timali leti yiviweke hi ku olova.

eng: we have also provided support and resources to other critical crimefighting bodies like the asset forfeiture unit, specialised commercial crimes unit and directorate for priority crime investigation, known as the hawks.
tso: hi tlhele hi nyika nseketelo na swipfuno eka tihuvo to lwi sana na vugevenga ta nkoka tin’wana to fana na yuniti yo tekela tinhundzu, yuniti ya vugevenga bya mabindzu yo hlawuleka na xiyengetsongo xa vulavisisi bya vugevenga lebyi rhangisiwaka ema hlweni, lexi vuriwaka hawks .

eng: these efforts are producing results.
tso: matshalatshala lawa ya le ku tswaleni ka mihandzu.

eng: through collaboration with key entities in the criminal justice system, the investigating directorate has enrolled over 20 corruption cases in the last financial year and 65 accused have been charged.
tso: hi ku tirhisana na mava ndlakulu eka sisiteme ya vululami bya vugevenga, xiyengetsongo xo lavisisa xi tsarisile milandzu yo hundza 20 ya vukungundzwana eka lembeximali leri nga hundza naswona vahehliwa va 65 va hehliwile.

eng: these include several ‘state capture’ and other serious corruption cases.
tso: milandzu leyi yi katsa yo hlaya ya ‘ku tekiwa ka vulawuri bya mfumo’ na milandzu ya vukungu ndzwana byo tivikana yin’wana.

eng: in the past financial year, the asset forfeiture unit obtained freezing orders to the value of r5.4 billion relating to corruption offences, with r70 million paid into the criminal assets recovery fund.
tso: eka lembeximali leri nga hundza, yuniti yo tekela tinhundzu yi kume swileriso swo yimisa ku tirhisa swa nkoka wo ringana r5.4 wa tibiliyoni swa mayelana na milandzu ya vukungu ndzwana, laha r70 wa timiliyoni ti nga hakeriwa eka nkwama wo tekela tinhundzu ta vugevenga.

eng: over the past eight years, the siu has recovered funds and assets to the value of r2.6 billion and set aside contracts to the value of r18 billion.
tso: eka malembe ya nhungu lama nga hundza, siu yi vuyiserile timali na tinhundzu ta nkoka wo ringana r2.6 wa tibiliyoni na ku yimisa tikontiraka ta nkoka wo ringana r18 wa tibiliyoni.

eng: a total of 119 cases worth more than r13 billion have been enrolled by the siu at the special tribunal.
tso: ntsengo wa 119 wa milandzu leyi durhaka kutlula r13 wa tibiliyoni yi tsarisiwile hi siu eka khoto yo hlawuleka.

eng: corruption is an extremely complex crime to prosecute.
tso: vukungundzwana i vuge venga byo pfilungana kutlula mpimo ku byi tengisa.

eng: perpetrators go to extraordinary lengths to cover their tracks.
tso: vaendlamilandzu va tirha hi matimba lamakulu ku tumbeta mikondzo ya vona.

eng: they set up shelf companies to hide dodgy transactions, rapidly moving monies between multiple accounts, misrepresenting income to the tax authorities, and, in the case of government employees, using friends and relatives to apply for tenders to mask their involvement.
tso: va sungula tikhamphanivito ku tumbeta mixaviselano yo ka yi nga tshembekangi, va fambisa timali exikarhi ka tiakhawunti to hamba nahambana hi xihatla, va nga boxi hi ntiyiso mali leyi ngheneke eka vulawuri bya swibalo, naswona, laha ku nga vatirhelamfumo, va tirhisa vanghana na maxaka ku endla swikombelo swa tithendara ku tumbeta ku khumbeka ka vona.

eng: this means that the response of the authorities has to be just as sophisticated.
tso: leswi swi vula leswaku ku hlamula ka vulawuri ku fanele ku va ka matirhelo ya xiyimo xa le henhla lama fambelanaka na maendlelo ya vona.

eng: in 2020, we established a multidisciplinary fusion centre as an operational hub to address priority financial crimes, including corruption.
tso: hi 2020, hi tumbuluxile senthara yo hlanganisa ya marhavinyingi tanihi xivindzi xa matirhelo ku ti rhana na vugevenga bya swa timali, ku katsa na vukungu ndzwana.

eng: the centre brings together the investigative capabilities of government’s crime prevention and security structures and those of the financial intelligence centre, which develops intelligence for law enforcement agencies to use in their investigations.
tso: senthara leyi yi hlanganisa vuswikoti bya vulavisisi bya swivumbeko swo sivela vugevenga na swa vusirheleri swa mfumo na leswiya swa senthara ya vunhlori bya timali, leyi tumbuluxaka vunhlori bya tiejensi to hlayisa nawu ku va ti byi tirhisa eka vulavisisi bya tona.

eng: two years since the fusion centre was established, its multidisciplinary approach to ‘follow the money’ has yielded significant results.
tso: malembe mambirhi kusu kela loko ku tumbuluxiwile senthara yo hlanganisa, endlelo ra yona ra marhavi nyingi ra ku ‘landzelela mali’ ri tswarile mihandzu yo tivikana.

eng: in the last financial year, the work of the fusion centre supported 276 fraud and corruption investigations.
tso: eka lembeximali leri nga hundza, ntirho wa senthara yo hlanganisa wu seketerile vulavisisi bya 276 bya vu mbabva na vukungundzwa na.

eng: approximately r659 million was restored to the state through preservation and recovery of the proceeds of crime.
tso: kwalomu ka r659 wa timiliyoni ti vuyiseriwile eka mfumo hi ku tirhisa ku hla yisa na ku vuyisela rifuwo leri nga kumiwa hi vuge venga.

eng: approximately r613 million in suspected criminal proceeds were frozen.
tso: kwalomu ka r613 wa timiliyoni ta rifuwo leri ku ehleketeriwaka leswaku ri kumiwile hi vugevenga ti yimisiwile ku tirhisiwa.

eng: the fusion centre was initially set up to investigate corruption around covidrelated procurement.
tso: ekusunguleni, senthara yo hlanganisa a yi tumbu luxiwile hi xikongomelo xo lavisisa vukungundzwana hi mayelana na maxavelo ya leswi fambelanaka na covid19 .

eng: its mandate is now being expanded to include moneylaundering, fraud, maladministration, terrorist financing and other serious financial crimes.
tso: sweswi xileri soximfumo xa yona xi le ku ndlandlamuxiweni ku katsa ku tumbetiwa ka swihlovo swa mali, vumbabva, mafambiselo yo biha, ku hakelela vutherorisi na milandzu ya timali yin’wana yo tivikana.

eng: the hawks recently outlined some of the progress that has been made by the anticorruption task team, of which the fusion centre forms part.
tso: hawks ya ha ku andlala kun’wana ka ku humelela loku nga endliwa hi xipano xa xintirhwana xo lwisana na vukungundzwana, lexi senthara yo hlanganisa yi nga xiphemu xa xona.

eng: between the 2019 and 2022 financial years, 554 suspects were arrested for corruption, of which 142 were convicted.
tso: exikarhi ka malembeximali ya 2019 na 2022, vaehlekete leriwa va 554 va khomiwile hikwalaho ka vukungu ndzwana, laha 142 va nga voniwa nandzu.

eng: another vital financial intelligence tool is the lifestyle audits conducted by the south african revenue service (sars).
tso: xitirho xa vunhlori bya timali xa nkoka xin’wana i tioditi ta hanyelo leti endli waka hi vukorhokeri bya xibalo bya afrikadzonga (sars).

eng: last year, sars completed 25 lifestyle audits to the value of over r450 million to resolve discrepancies between declared income and an individual’s lifestyle.
tso: lembe leri nga hundza, sars yi hetile 25 wa tioditi ta hanyelo ta kufika eka nkoka wo tlula r450 wa timiliyoni ku ololoxa ku hambana exikarhi ka mali nghena leyi paluxiweke na hanyelo ra munhu.

eng: it is clear that the measures we have taken as this administration to restore the capacity, capability and credibility of the institutions involved in the fight against corruption are having a demonstrable impact.
tso: swi le rivaleni leswaku magoza lama hi nga ma teka tanihi vulawuri lebyi ku vuyelerisa vuswikoti, ku koteka na ku tshembeka ka mihlangano leyi khumbe kaka eka ku lwisana na vukungundzwana ma na nkhumbo wo vonaka.

eng: the synchronised work of all the law enforcement agencies is hitting criminals where it hurts most: in their pockets.
tso: ku tirha hi nkarhi wun’we ka tiejensi hinkwato to hlayi sa nawu swi ba swigevenga laha ku vavaka ngopfu: eswikhwameni swa swona.

eng: public funds that were looted and diverted are being recovered and those responsible for these acts are being prosecuted by our courts.
tso: timali ta mfumo leti phangi weke na ku tumbetiwa ti le ku vuyisiweni naswona lava nga na vutihlamuleri bya swendlo leswi va le ku tengi siweni hi tikhoto ta hina.

eng: look out for early signs of childhood cancer more matshediso a lack of awareness of childhood cancer and its symptoms means that many south african children are diagnosed when the disease is at an advanced stage.
tso: xiyaxiya swikoweto swo sungula swa mfukuzana ya vutsongwana more matshediso ku pfumaleka ka vulemukisi bya mfukuzana ya vutsongwana na swikombeto swa yona swi vula leswaku vana va laha afrikadzonga vo tala fembiwa loko vuvabyi se byi ri eka xiyimo xo tika.

eng: the earlier cancer is diagnosed and treated, the higher the chance of a full recovery.
tso: loko mfukuzana yi fe mbiwa na ku tshunguriwa ka ha ri ekusunguleni, ku va na nkoteko wa le henhla wo hola hi ku hetiseka.

eng: childhood cancer foundation south africa (choc) communication coordinator taryn seegers says by knowing the common signs of cancer in young people, you could help save a life.
tso: taryn seegers, mukondle teri wa vuhlanganisi eka childhood cancer foundation south africa (choc) u vula leswaku hi ku tiva swikoweto swa ntolovelo swa mfuku zana eka vantshwa, u nga pfuna ku ponisa vutomi.

eng: "the signs and symptoms can be difficult to spot amid the normal bumps, bruises, growth spurts and mood swings.
tso: "swikoweto na swikombeto swi nga nonoha ku swi vona exikarhi ka matshumba ya ntolovelo, mafelangati, ku kula hi xihatla na ku cinca ka swipfukela.

eng: however, early detection is key," she says.
tso: hambiswiri tano, ku yi thumba ka ha ri ekusunguleni i swa nkoka," a vula.

eng: according to the cancer association of south africa (cansa), between 800 to 1 000 south african children are diagnosed with cancer each year.
tso: ku ya hi cancer association of south africa (cansa), exi karhi ka 800 na 1 000 wa vana va laha afrikadzonga va kumiwa va ri na mfukuzana lembe rin’wana na rin’wana.

eng: however, the association estimates that half of the children with cancer in south africa are never diagnosed.
tso: hambiswiritano, nhlangano lowu wu kumbetela leswa ku hafu ya vana lava nga na mfukuzana laha afrikadzonga a va fembiwi naswitsanana.

eng: to help ensure cancer is spotted as soon as possible, choc runs awareness programmes in communities, telling parents and children about the early warning signs they must look out for.
tso: ku pfuna ku tiyisisa leswa ku mfukuzana yi voniwa hi xihatla lexi kotekaka, choc yi fambisa minongoloko yo lemukisa emigangeni, yi byela vatswari na vana hi mayelana na swikoweto swo lemukisa swa le kusunguleni leswi va faneleke ku swi xiyaxiya.

eng: the foundation supports children and teenagers with cancer or lifethreatening blood disorders and their families.
tso: fawundexini leyi yi seketela vana na vakondloandzidyi lava nga na mfukuzana kumbe mipfilungano ya ngati leyi xungetaka vutomi xikan’we na mindyangu ya vona.

eng: "we aim to improve early detection and facilitate effective treatment.
tso: "hi na xikongomelo xo antswisa ku yi thumba ka ha ri ekusunguleni na ku humelerisa vutshunguri lebyi tirhaka hi ku hetiseka.

eng: at any one time, choc can have over 1 500 children and teenagers in its care, while offering psychosocial support to over 1 500 families," says seegers.
tso: eka nkarhi wun’wana wihi kumbe wihi, choc yi nga va na ku hundza 1 500 wa vana na vakondloandzidyi lava nga ehansi ka nhlayiso wa yona, loko yi ri karhi yi nyika nseketelo wa swa miehleketo na wa vanhu eka kuhundza 1 500 wa mindyangu," ku vula seegers.

eng: in the past financial year, seegers says choc was able to serve 1 724 children, 553 teenagers and 2 232 adults through its core programmes.
tso: eka lembeximali leri nga hundza, seegers u vula leswaku choc yi kote ku nyika vukorhokeri eka vana va 1 724, vakondloandzidyi va 553 na 2 232 wa vanhu lavakulu hi ku tirhisa mino ngolokokulu ya yona.

eng: "our services include emotional support through their cancer journey, comfort, endoflife care and bereavement support," says seegers.
tso: "vukorhokeri bya hina byi katsa nseketelo wa mati twelo eka rendzo ra vona ra mfukuzana, ku chaveleleka, nhlayiso wa makumu ya vutomi, na nseketelo wa loko va loveriwile," ku vula seegers.

eng: st siluan’s signs of childhood cancer s – seek medical help early for ongoing symptoms.
tso: swikoweto swa st siluan swa mfukuzana ya vu tsongwana s – lava ku pfuniwa ka vutshunguri ka ha ri eku sunguleni ka swikombeto leswi yaka emahlweni.

eng: i – white spot in the eye, new squint, sudden blindness or bulging eyeball.
tso: i – papa ro basa etihlwe ni, ku sungula ku va na mangayi, vubofu bya xitshuketa, ku pfimba tindzololo.

eng: the n3 upgrade is empowering south africans owen mngadi mduduzi jijana is the owner of the disability empowerment movement, which is one of the companies that is currently benefiting from the r26 billion upgrade of the n3 highway between pietermaritzburg and durban in kwazulunatal.
tso: ku ndlandlamuxiwa ka n3 swi nyika maafrikadzonga matimba owen mngadi mduduzi jijana i n’wini wa disability empowerment movement, leyi ku nga yin’wana ya tikhamphani leti sweswi ti nga eku vuyeriweni ku suka eka r26 wa mabiliyoni ya ku ndlandlamuxiwa ka gondzo lerikulu ra n3 exikarhi ka pietermaritzburg na durban ekwazulunatal.

eng: the project, which is being spearheaded by the south african national roads agency soc limited (sanral), is ensuring that entrepreneurs such as jijana not only benefit but in turn create employment for others.
tso: phurojeke, leyi rhangeriweke hi ejensi ya le magondzweni ya afrikadzonga ya rixaka (sanral), yi tiyisisa leswaku van’wamabindzu vo fana na jijani a va vuyeriwi ntsena kambe hi tlhelo va tumbuluxa mitirho eka van’wana.

eng: jijana, who lives with a disability, says his company installs road signs between hilton and pietermaritzburg.
tso: jijani, loyi a hanyaka na vutsoniwa, u vula leswaku khamphani ya yena yi nghenisa swikoweto swa le gondzweni exikarhi ka hilton ku ya pietermaritzburg.

eng: he employs 13 people and says the project has changed their lives.
tso: u thorile 13 wa vanhu naswo na u vula leswaku phurojeke yi cincile vutomi bya vona.

eng: "as people living with a disability, we have shown that we are capable.
tso: "tanihi vanhu lava hi hanyaka na vutsoniwa, hi kombisa leswaku hi na vuswikoti.

eng: we no longer rely on grants.
tso: a ha ha tshe mbeli eka mali ya mpfuneto.

eng: we do the actual work," says jijana.
tso: hi endla mitirho ya xiviri," ku vula jijanamurhangeri wa nongonoko wa sanral wa le n3, tsepo matekane u vula leswaku khamphani ya yena yi tiyi sisile leswaku 30% ta ntirho ti nyikiwile tikhamphani ta le mugangeni leti nga na vuswi koti byo nyika vukorhokeri byo hambanahambana.

eng: this created many opportunities for small businesses owned by youth, previously disadvantaged people and women.
tso: leswi swi tumbuluxile swivandlanene eka mabindzu lamatsongo ya vantshwa, vanhu na vavasati lava a va nyadziwa eka nkarhi lowu nga hundza.

eng: "there are 108 small, medium and micro enterprises currently working on the various projects," he says.
tso: "ku na 108 wa mabindzu lamatsongo lama sweswi ya ti rhaka eka tiphurojeke to hamba nahambana."

eng: nokuthula zondi of ingqalabutho yamalinda multipurpose trading was awarded a contract to supply soil and install water drainage pipes.
tso: nokuthula zondi wa ingqalabutho yamalinda multipurpose trading u nyikiwile kontiraka yo phakela misava no nghenisa tiphayiphi ta mati ya nkululo.

eng: she says her company employed eight skilled workers, including drivers.
tso: u ri khamphani ya yena yi thorile nhungu wa vatirhi va vuswikoti, ku katsa na vachaye ri.

eng: zondi adds that women are as capable as men and her company has a good service track record.
tso: zondi u engeterile leswaku vavasati va na vuswikoti ku fana na vavanuna naswona khamphani ya yena yi na matimu ya vukorhokeri bya kahle.

eng: "we understand the importance of time and meet all our targets to ensure the project runs accordingly.
tso: "hi twisisa nkoka wa nkarhi no fikelela mikongomelo ya hina hinkwayo ku tiyisisa le swaku phurojeke yi famba kahle.

eng: we appreciate the opportunity and we hope more will come so that our company can grow according to construction levels," she adds.
tso: hi amukela xivandlanene naswona hi tshemba leswaku swotala swi tata leswaku khamphani ya hina yi kula ku ya hi xiyimo xa tikontirhaka," a ngetela.

eng: national government’s key projects matekane says the durbanfree stategauteng logistics and industrial corridor development has an estimated budget of r26 billion and is one of national government’s key strategic integrated projects.
tso: tiphurojeke ta nkoka ta mfumo wa rixaka matekane u vula leswaku nhluvukiso wa durbanfree stategauteng logistics and industrial corridor wu na mpimanyeto lowu ringanyetiweke wa r26 wa mabiliyoni naswona hi yin’wana ya tiphurojeke ta nkoka leti hlanganisiweke ta mfumo wa rixaka.

eng: it is known as sip2.
tso: yi tiveka tanihi sip2.

eng: the project will widen the n3 with more lanes in each direction.
tso: phurojeke yi ta anamisa n3 yi va na mitila yo hlaya eka tlhelo rin’wana na rin’wana.

eng: it also includes changing some of the major interchanges to improve traffic flow.
tso: swi tlhela swi katsa ku cinciwa ka yan’wana ya magondzonkulu yo hlanganisa ku antswisa nkhuluko wa mimovha.

eng: the affected section of the n3 has over the years experienced traffic congestion, particularly during peak hours because the majority of cargo trucks from the durban harbour use the highway to gauteng and other inland provinces.
tso: xiyenge lexi khumbekaka xa n3 xi na malembe yo tala xi ri na ntlimbano wa nkhuluko wa mimovha, ngopfungopfu hi tiawara ta bizi hikuva titiraka to tala to rhwala nhundzu ku suka eka nhlaluko wa durban ti tirhisa gondzo lerikulu ku ya egauteng na swifundza nkulu swin’wana swa le ndzeni ka tiko.

eng: some of the cargo truck drivers have caused accidents by not taking care on sharp curves.
tso: van’wana va vachayeri va titiraka to rhwala nhundzu va vangile tinghozi hikuva va nga ri na vukheta eka tikhevhe to totswa.

eng: "apart from resolving chronic traffic by creating greater mobility through the construction of additional traffic lanes, the upgrading of the n3 will result in increased safety.
tso: "handle ko lunghisa ntlimbano wa nkarhi wo leha hi ku tumbuluxa mafambelo ya kahle hi ku aka mitila yo engetelela ya mafambelo, ku ndlandlamuxiwa ka n3 swi ta tisa ntlakuso wa vuhlayi seki.

eng: dangerous curves will be ironed out.
tso: tikheve ta khombo ti ta susiwa.

eng: unsafe intersections will be redesigned," maketane says.
tso: tindhawu to hlangana to ka ti nga hlayisekangi ti ta akiwa hi vutshwa," ku vula matekane.

eng: sanral awarded three contracts in the last quarter of 2021, and construction work began between january and april.
tso: sanral yi nyikile tikontiraka tinharhu eka kotara yo hetelela ya 2021, naswona ntirho wo aka wu sungurile exikarhi ka sunguti na dzivamusoko.

eng: the sections currently being upgraded are the 19 kilometre (km) stretch from cato ridge to dardanelles, commonly known as umlaas road; the 26.6 km section from the dardanelles interchange to lynnfield park; and the 30 km stretch from lynnfield park to the ashburton interchange.
tso: swiyenge leswi nga eku ndlandlamuxiweni sweswi i 19 wa tikhilomitara (km) ku suka ecato ridge ku ya edardanelles, laha ku tivekaka ngopfu tanihi umlaas road; xiyenge xa 26.6 km ku suka dardanelles interchange ku ya lynnfield park; na 30 km ku suka lynnfield park ku ya ashburton interchange.

eng: matekane explains that sip2 will strengthen the logistics and transport corridor between south africa’s main industrial hubs, improve access to durban’s export and import facilities and raise efficiency along the corridor.
tso: matekane u hlamusela leswaku sip2 yi ta tiyisa logisitiki na phaseji ya vutleketli exikarhi ka mihlaluko ya le swivindzini swa mabindzu ya vumaki swa afrikadzonga, yi ta atswisa ku fikeleriwa ka switirhisiwa swo humesa no nghenisa swixavisiwa edurban no kurisa matirhelo ya kahle ya leka phasejini ya vutleketli.

eng: he adds that the project is part of the national development plan 2030 and national transport master plan 2050 and supports government’s economic reconstruction and recovery plan.
tso: u engetela leswaku phurojeke i xiphemu xa kungu ra nhluvukiso ra rixaka ra 2030 na kungu ra vutleketli bya xiyimo xa le henhla ra rixaka ra 2050 no seketela kungu ra mfumo ra ku aka ikhonomi hi vuntshwa na ku yi vuyelerisa eka xiyimo xa kahle.

eng: to this end, government intends to develop a transport system that is consistent with the real needs of the people living in south africa and caters for people with less money to spend on travel.
tso: ku ta fika sweswi, mfumo wu kunguhata ku hluvukisa sisiteme ya vutleketi lebyi nga kotaka ku yiseka emahlweni ku ya hi swilaveko swa xiviri swa vanhu lava tshamaka eafrikadzonga no korhokela vanhu lava nga na mali yintsongo leyi va nga yi tirhisaka ku fambafamba.

eng: maketane says the upgrades will take between eight and 10 years to complete and road closures will be kept to the minimum.
tso: matekane u vula leswaku ku ndlandlamuxa swi ta teka exikarhi ka nhungu na 10 ra malembe ku hela naswona ku pfariwa ka gondzo ku ta endliwa hi switsongo.

eng: alcohol may damage your unborn baby’s health vukuzenzele unnamed pregnant women have the responsibility to not drink because alcohol can cause a condition that affects a baby’s development.
tso: xihoko xi nga onha rihanyo ra n’wana wa wena loyi a nga se velekiwaka vukuzenzele unnamed vavasati lava nga biha emirini va na vutihlamuleri byo ka va nga nwi hikuva xihoko xi nga vanga xiyimo lexi nga khumbaka makulelo ya n’wana.

eng: this is according to the deputy minister of social development, hendrietta bogopanezulu, who recently launched the 999 foetal alcohol spectrum disorder (fasd) advocacy programme.
tso: leswi i ku ya hi xandla xa holobye wa ndzawulo ya nhluvukiso wa vaaki, hendrietta bogopanezulu, loyi sweswinyana a simekeke nongonoko wa vuyimeri bya 999 foetal alcohol spectrum disorder (fasd).

eng: the aim of the initiative is to encourage communities to help protect unborn babies by educating people, especially women of childbearing age, about the dangers of drinking alcohol while pregnant or breastfeeding.
tso: xikongomelo xa pfhumba i ku hlohlotela vaaki ku pfuna ku sirhelela vana lava nga se velekiwaka hi ku dyondzisa vanhu, ngopfungopfu vavasati lava nga eka malembe yo bebula, mayelana na nghozi yo nwa xihoko loko va bihe emirini kumbe ku mamisa.

eng: "it is important for all women who are pregnant and those who wish to give birth to healthy babies to avoid alcohol.
tso: "swi na nkoka leswaku vavasati hinkwavo lava nga biha emirini na lava navelaka ku kuma vana lava nga na rihanyo ra kahle va papalata xihoko.

eng: the damage caused by fasd is permanent and irreversible, and children born with this condition have physical and intellectual problems," said deputy minister bogopanezulu at the launch.
tso: ku onha loku vangiwaka hi fasd i ka nkarhi hinkwawo naswona a ku lunghiseki, naswona vana lava velekiwaka va ri na xiyimo lexi va va na swiphiqo swa le mirini na swa miehleketo," ku vula xandla xa holobye, bogopanezulu eka ntirho wo simeka.

eng: she added that south africa is known to have a drinking problem, with the country ranking among the worst in the world for its levels of alcohol consumption.
tso: u engeterile leswaku afrikadzonga yi tiveka hi ku va na xiphiqo xa manwelo, na tiko leri xaxametiwaka eka lamo biha emisaveni hi levhele ya rona ya manwelo ya xihoko.

eng: deputy minister bogopanezulu recently visited different parts of the country, educating women about the dangers of drinking alcohol while pregnant as part of the 999 fasd campaign.
tso: xandla xa holobye, bogopanezulu sweswinyana u endzerile tindhawu to hambanahambana ta tiko, a dyondzisa vavasati hi nghozi ya ku nwa xihoko loko munhu a bihe emirini tanihi xiphemu xa pfhumba ra 999 fasd.

eng: when she was in boitekong in rustenburg in the north west, she told residents that the levels of alcohol abuse in the township are alarming.
tso: loko a ri eboitekong, erustenburg enorth west, u byerile vatshami va kona leswaku xiyimo xa manwelo yo biha ya xihoko emalokixini xa chavisa.

eng: a fourmonth pregnant woman and resident of boitekong, basetsana tlalang (28), who attended one of the campaigns, said she stopped drinking alcohol entirely after learning she was pregnant and said she is attending antenatal and information sessions at the clinic.
tso: wansati loyi a nga na tin’hweti ta mune a bihe emirini tlhelo mutshami wa le boitekong, basetsana tlalang (28), loyi a nga ya eka rin’wana ra mapfhumba, u vule leswaku u yimile kunwa xihoko hi ku hetiseka endzhaku ko tiva leswaku u bihe emirini naswona u vule leswaku u le ku yeni eka nkambelo wa loko munhu a bihe emirini na tisexini ta mahungu etliliniki.

eng: she urged other pregnant women to immediately stop drinking alcohol and doing drugs.
tso: u komberile vavasati van’wana lava nga biha emirini ku tshika ku nwa xihoko no tirhisa swidzidziharisi hi xihatla.

eng: the struggle to give south africa a more human face vukuzenzele unnamed on 12 september 1977, stephen bantu biko died in police custody in pretoria central prison.
tso: nkayakayo wo nyika afrikadzonga ku twi sisa vumunhu hi vuenti vukuzenzele unnamed hi ti 12 ndzati 1977, stephen bantu biko u lovele emahlwe ni ka maphorisa epretoria central prison.

eng: human dignity, the principle at the heart of his black consciousness activism, was denied to him.
tso: ndzhuti wa vumunhu, misinya leyi nga nchumu wa nkoka eka vugi ngiriki bya yena bya lemukiso wa vantima, u aleriwile yona.

eng: in the words of the family lawyer sir sydney kentridge, his was "a miserable and lonely death on a mat on a stone floor in a prison cell".
tso: hi marito ya qgweta ra ndyangu, sir sydney kentri dge, ra yena a ku ri "rifu ro vava no lova a ri yexe eme tseni ehenhla ka fuloro ya ribye endzeni ka sele ya khotso".

eng: it remains a source of great sorrow all these years later to recall that steve biko was just 30 years old when he died.
tso: ri tshama ri ri karhi ri vanga gome lerikulu endzhaku ka malembe lama hinkwawo ku tsundzuka leswaku steve biko a ri na 30 wa malembe ntsena loko a lova.

eng: he was cut down in his prime by those who feared the power and resonance of his ideas of selfliberation and his efforts to infuse black men and women with pride and dignity.
tso: u dlayi wile swa xitshuketani a ha ri ntsongo hi lava a va chava matimba na ntikelo wa mavonelo ya yena ya ku tintshuxa na matshalatshala ya yena yo tata vavanuna na vavasati va vantima hi vutinyungubyisi na ndzhuti wa vumunhu.

eng: he never got to see in his lifetime what he called ‘the glittering prize’, the realisation of a true humanity.
tso: eka nkarhi wa vutomi bya yena, a nga kalanga a kota ku vona leswi a swi vula ‘xivandla lexi vanhu vo tala va xilavaka’, ku lemuka vumunhu bya ntiyiso.

eng: writing about this ideal, he famously said: "in time we shall be in a position to bestow upon south africa the greatest gift possible – a more human face.
tso: ku tsala hi mavonelo lama, u vurile leswi a tivekaka hi swona a ku: hi ku famba ka nkarhi hi ta kota ku nyika afrikadzonga nyiko leyikulu leyi kotekaka ku twisisa vumunhu hi vuenti.

eng: "when we won our freedom in 1994, we understood that the right to vote was just one part of our struggle for human dignity.
tso: "loko hi kuma ntshuxeko wa hina hi 1994, hi swi twisisile leswaka mfanelo yo vhota a ku ri xin’wana xa swiphemu swa hina swo kayakayela ndzhuti wa vumunhu.

eng: twentyeight years into our democracy, we are confronted with many challenges, such as poverty, unemployment and inequality.
tso: makumembirhinhungu wa malembe hi ri eka xidemokirasi, hi hlanganile na mitlhontlho yo tala, yo fana na vusweti, ku pfumaleka ka mitirho na ku pfumaleka ka ndzingano.

eng: as a result, we often lose sight of how far we have come in giving effect to the principles on which our constitution is founded and that anchored steve biko’s thought and teachings.
tso: hikwalaho ka sweswo, hi tala ku hluleka ku vona leswaku hi fike kwihi eka ku tirhisa misinya leyi vumbiwa ra hina ri simekiweke ehenhla ka yona naswona leswi a swi tshama swi ri eka miehleko na tidyondzo ta steve biko.

eng: in 1977 a heartless regime killed one of our country’s most promising leaders by depriving him of the food, water and medical treatment he urgently needed as a result of brutal beatings by the apartheid police.
tso: hi 1977, mfumo wo pfumala ntwela vusiwana wu dlayile un’wana wa varhangeri va tiko ra hina lava a va tshembisa hi ku n’wi tsona swakudya, mati na vutshu nguri lebyi a byi lava hi xihatla hi xivangelo xo mbeyeteriwa hi tihanyi hi maphorisa ya mfumo wa xihlawuhlawu.

eng: twenty years later, in a 1997 judgment, the constitutional court said that fulfilling the fundamental rights of every citizen and striving to achieve their socioeconomic rights is the hallmark of a democratic society aiming to salvage lost dignity.
tso: endzhaku ka makume mbirhi wa malembe, eka vuahluri bya 1997, khoto ya vumbiwa yi vule leswaku ku fikelela timfanelo ta nkoka ta muakatiko un’wana na un’wana no lwela ku fikelela timfanelo ta yena ta ikhonomi i mfungho wa vaaki va xidemokirasi lowu ringetaka ku vuyisa ndzhuti wa vumunhu lowu lahlekeke.

eng: in south africa today, we continue to work to fulfil the basic rights of every south african so that they may lead quality lives free of disease, hunger and deprivation.
tso: eafrikadzonga, eka nkarhi wa sweswi, hi ya emahlweni hi tirha ku fikelela timfanelo ta masungulo ta muafrikadzonga un’wana na un’wana ku endlela leswaku va ta hanya vutomi bya xiyimo xa le henhla byo pfumala vuvabyi, ndlala na ku kayivela swilo leswi va faneleke ku swi kuma.

eng: successive democratic administrations have implemented policies to salvage the lost dignity of this country’s majority by providing education, health care, housing and basic services.
tso: vulawuri bya xidimokirasi byo landzelelana byi tirhisile tipholisi ku vuyisa ndzhuti wa vumunhu lowu lahlekeke wa vanhu vo tala va tiko leri hi ku nyika dyondzo, nhlayiso wa rihanyo, tindlu na vukorho keri bya nkoka.

eng: in south africa today, a decent education is a fundamental right.
tso: eafrikadzonga, eka nkarhi wa sweswi, dyondzo ya kahle i mfanelo ya nkoka.

eng: the state invests in early childhood development, in supporting learning outcomes for our youngest citizens, and provides social relief through school feeding programmes to ensure young learners achieve the best outcomes possible.
tso: mfumo wu vekisa eka nhluvukiso wa vana lavantsongo, hi ku seketela mivuyelo ya dyondzo ya vaakatiko lavantsongo, no nyika xintshuxo hi minongonoko yo phaka swakudya eswikolweni ku tiyisisa leswaku vandyondzi lavantsongo va fikelela mivuyelo leyi kotekaka.

eng: through the national student financial aid scheme and various other forms of state support, thousands of young south africans from poor backgrounds have been able to become doctors, lawyers, teachers, scientists, artisans and entrepreneurs.
tso: hi xikimi xa mpfuneto wa swa timali xa swichudeni xa rixaka na swipfuno swin’wana swo hambanahambana swa mfumo, magidigidi ya vantshwa va afrikadzonga ku suka eka mindyangu leyi nga na vusiwana va swi kotile ku va madokodela, maqgwetai, va dyondzisi, vativi va sayense, vatshuri na van’wamabindzu.

eng: government supports poor and vulnerable citizens through an extensive social safety net and provides work opportunities through mass public employment programmes.
tso: mfumo wu seketela vaaka tiko va swisiwana na lava nga sirhelelekangiki hi mpfuneto wo hlayisa no antswisa vutomi bya vaaki lowu engeteleriweke no nyika swivandlanene swa mitirho hi ku tirhisa minongonoko yotala ya ku thoriwa ka vanhu.

eng: in the repressive south africa in which steve biko died, freedom of speech was curtailed and political activism attracted detention or worse.
tso: eka afrikadzonga leyi a yi tshikeleriwile leyi steve biko a nga lova eka yona, ntshu nxeko wo vulavula a wu hungutiwile naswona vugi ngiriki bya swa tipoliti a byi vangela ku pfaleriwa kumbe swo tlula swona.

eng: in south africa today, young people of the same age as steve biko was and even younger are at the forefront of activism for causes closest to them, and they are able to organise free of harassment or banishment.
tso: eafrikadzonga, eka nkarhi wa sweswi, vantshwa va malembe yo tani hi ya steve biko hambi lavantsongo nyana va le mahlweni ka vugi ngiriki byo lwela swilo leswi va khumbaka, naswona va swi kota ku kondletela handle ko xanisiwa kumbe ku hlongoriwa tikweni.

eng: freedom of speech and association, the right to protest and the right to equality before the law is upheld for all.
tso: ntshunxeko wo vula vula no hlangana, mfanelo yo kombisa ku vilela na mfanelo ya ndzingano emahlweni ka nawu swa pfumeleriwa eka vanhu hinkwevo.

eng: as a country, we have come a long way towards the fulfilment of human dignity, the principle that steve biko so cherished.
tso: tanihi tiko, hi huma ekule mayelana no fikelela ndzhuti wa vumunhu, misinya leyi steve biko a yi vona yi ri ya nkoka.

eng: yet, we still have so much further to go.
tso: kambe ka ha ri na swo tala swo swi fikelela.

eng: without a job, without a house, electricity or running water, without land, without skills or opportunities, millions of south africans are still deprived of the lives they seek and deserve.
tso: loko va pfumala ntirho, va pfumala yindlu, gezikumbe mati ya letindlwini, va pfumala misava, va pfumala swikili kumbe swivandlanene, mamiliyoni ya maafrikadzonga va ha kayivela vutomi lebyi va byi lavaka no fanela ku va na byona.

eng: that is why government is working with social partners to build an inclusive economy, create employment, enable businesses to thrive and tackle poverty and hunger.
tso: hiswona swi endlaka leswaku mfumo wu ri eku tirheni na vatirhisani va wona wa timhaka ta vaaki ku aka ikhonomi leyi katsaka hi nwavo, ku tumbuluxa mitirho, ku pfumelela mabindzu ku hanya no lwisana na vusweti na ndlala.

eng: victim empowerment programme restores hope owen mngadi the thohoyandou victim empowerment programme (tvep) strives to restore hope and confidence in the justice system through its intensive initiatives aimed at assisting survivors of genderbased violence (gbv) and rape by providing them with psychosocial services.
tso: nongonoko wo nyika vaxanisiwa matimba wu vuyisela ntshembo owen mngadi thohoyandou victim empowerment programme (tvep) yi lwela ku vuyisela ntshembo na ku titshemba eka sisiteme ya vululami hi ku tirhisa migingiriko ya wona yo tika leyi kongomisiweke eka ku pfuna vaponi va madzolonga lama simekiweke eka rimbe wu (gbv) na ku pfinyiwa hi ku va nyika vukorhokeri bya swa miehleketo.

eng: founded in limpopo over 20 years ago, the tvep operates in tshilidzini and donald fraser hospitals under the thulamela local municipality.
tso: tvep yi simekiwile elimpopo ku tlula 20 wa malembe lama nga hundza, yi tirha eswibedlhele swa tshilidzini na donald fraser ehansi ka masipala wa muganga wa thulamela.

eng: its acting director fhatuwani manthada says the programme aims to instil a zerotolerance attitude towards sexual assault, gbv and child abuse among thohoyandou residents, given the fact that these cases are prevalent in the area.
tso: mufambisi wa yona wo khomela, fhatuwani manthada, u vula leswaku nongonoko lowu wu kongomisa eka ku nghenisa vonelo ra ku nga tiyiseli ku xanisiwa hi swa masangu, gbv na ku xanisiwa ka vana eka vaaki va thoho yandou, loko hi languta mhaka ya leswaku milandzu leyi yi tele eka ndhawu liya.

eng: he says in the past, crime statistics indicated that there were many rape cases in thohoyandou, but the tvep has made great strides in raising awareness and providing trauma counselling services to curb the scourge.
tso: u vula leswaku eka nkarhi lowu nga hundza, tinhlayo ta vugevenga a ti tala ku kombisa leswaku a ku ri na milandzu yo tala ya ku pfinya ethoho yandou, kambe tvep yi teke magoza lamakulu yo tlakusa vutivi na ku nyika vukorhokeri bya vutsundzuxi bya ku vaviseka ku sivela ntungu lowu.

eng: as the world will be observing the 16 days of activism for no violence against women and children from 25 november to 10 december, manthada says the programme is satisfied with the progress made with encouraging residents to understand their rights and report crimes.
tso: tanihi leswi misava yi nga ta va yi ri karhi yi languta pfhumba ra 16 wa masiku ya vutirheli bya ku nga vi na madzolonga eka vavasati na vana ku sukela hi ti25 hukuri ku fika hi ti10 n’wendzamhala, manthada u vula leswaku nongonoko wu enerisekile hi ku humelela loku endliweke hi ku hlohlotela vaaki ku twisisa timfanelo ta vona na ku vika vugevenga.

eng: "the tvep receives between 80 and 100 victims of domestic violence every month, while 45 to 50 rape cases are reported monthly," says manthada.
tso: "tvep yi amukela vaxanisiwa va madzolonga ya le mindyangwini va le xikarhi ka 80 na 100 n’hweti ni n’hweti, kasi ku vikiwa milandzu ya ku pfinyiwa ya 45 ku ya eka 50 n’hweti ni n’hweti," ku vula manthada.

eng: the programme’s onestop centres offer a wide range of services to victims, including access to legal assistance, protection of victims against perpetrators, court case monitoring, counselling and empowerment through skills development, thus giving the victims a fresh start.
tso: tisenthara ta nongonoko leti nyikaka vukorhokeri byo hambanahambana eka vaxanisiwa, ku katsa na mfikelelo wa mpfuneto wa swa nawu, nsirhelelo wa vaxanisiwa eka vaendli va swiendlo, ku veka tihlo eka milandzu ya khoto, vutsundzuxi na ku nyikiwa matimba hi ku tirhisa nhluvukiso wa vuswikoti, hi ndlela yoleyo swi nyika vaxanisiwa masungulo lamantshwa.

eng: manthada states that the tvep works closely with the south african police service, department of health and department of social development to prevent secondary traumatisation of victims in the process of opening a case.
tso: manthada u vula leswaku tvep yi tirhisana swinene na vukorhokeri bya maphorisa ya afrikadzonga, ndzawulo ya rihanyo na ndzawulo ya nhluvukiso wa vanhu ku sivela ku vaviseka ka vumbirhi ka vaxanisiwa eka endlelo ro pfula nandzu.

eng: "in rape cases, healthcare workers and the police come to the tvep centres to assist victims to open criminal cases against the perpetrators and also provide counselling services," he says.
tso: "eka milandzu yo pfinya, vatirhi va nhlayiso wa rihanyo na maphorisa va ta eka tisenthara ta tvep ku pfuna vaxanisiwa ku pfula milandzu ya vugevenga eka vaendli va swiendlo leswi na ku tlhela va nyika vukorhokeri bya vutsundzuxi," a vula tano.

eng: the tvep accommodates victims for up to 14 days, however, the arrangement could be extended in cases that involve the whole family or children.
tso: tvep yi amukela vaxanisiwa ku fikela eka masiku ya 14, hambiswiritano, ku nga engeteleriwa malulamiselo eka milandzu leyi katsaka ndya ngu hinkwawo kumbe vana.

eng: "we have empowerment unity that conducts public dialogues and educates people about their rights.
tso: "hi na vun’we bya ku nyika matimba lebyi fambisaka mivulavurisano ya mani na mani na ku dyondzisa vanhu hi timfanelo ta vona.

eng: we serve more than one million residents from thohoyandou and surrounding areas.
tso: hi ti rhela vaaki vo tlula miliyoni lava humaka ethohoya ndou ni le tindhawini ta le kusuhi.

eng: we have managed to restore hope and people now have trust in the criminal justice [system] through our relationship with the police," he says.
tso: hi kotile ku vuyisela ntshembo naswona vanhu sweswi va na ku tshemba eka sisiteme ya vululami bya vugevenga hi ku tirhisa vuxaka bya hina na maphorisa," a vula tano.

eng: the tvep has also created employment for 44 people who serve in various departments such as finance, human resources and evaluation.
tso: tvep yi tlhele yi tumbuluxa mitirho eka vanhu va 44 lava tirhaka eka tindzawulo to ha mbanahambana ku fana na swa timali, swipfuno swa vatirhi na ku kambela.

eng: despite receiving continuous funding of r90 000 quarterly from the limpopo department of social development, the tvep was affected by covid19 as many funders pulled out, thus negatively affecting the organisation’s operational processes.
tso: hambileswi va kumaka mali leyi yaka emahlweni ya r90 000 hi kotara ku suka eka ndzawulo ya nhluvukiso wa vanhu elimpopo, tvep yi khumbekile hi covid19 tanihileswi vanyikeri va mali votala va nga huma, leswi nga khumba maendlelo ya matirhelo ya nhlangano hi ndlela yobiha.

eng: however, the genderbased violence and femicide (gbvf) response fund, which was launched by president cyril ramaphosa, together with the international women’s forum of south africa and social partners have assisted the programme.
tso: hambiswiritano, nkwama wo hlamula eka madzolonga ya rimbewu na ku dlayiwa ka vavasati (gbvf), lowu nga simekiwa hi presidente cyril ramaphosa, kun’we na foramu ya vavasati ya matiko ya misava ya afrikadzonga na vatirhisani va swa timhaka ta vanhu wu pfunile nongonoko.

eng: the tvep was among the first batch of the organisations, that fight against gbvf, to receive funding.
tso: tvep a yi ri exikarhi ka ntlawa wo sungula wa mihlangano leyi lwisanaka na gbvf, ku kuma mali.

eng: with the sum of r128 million that was raised through contributions by the private sector, multisectoral fund, the gbvf fund will assist and support the implementation of the national strategic plan on gbvf.
tso: hi mali ya ntsengo wa r128 wa timiliyoni leyi nga hlengeletiwa hi ku tirhisa tihakelo hi xiyenge lexi nga riki xa mfumo, nkwama wa swiyenge swo hambanaha mbana, nkwama wa gbvf wu ta pfuneta no seketela ku tirhisiwa ka kungu ra qhinga ra rixaka eka gbvf.

eng: the tvep has been allocated r250 000 for the current year and will receive more funding for 2023. manthada says the funds have enabled the tvep to reach out to more victims and keep the organisation running.
tso: tvep yi nyikiwile r250 000 ya lembe ra sweswi naswona yi ta kuma mali yin’wana ya 2023. manthada u vula leswaku mali leyi yi endle leswaku tvep yi kota ku fikelela vaxanisiwa vo tala no tlhela yi endla leswaku nhlangano wu tshama wu ri karhi wu tirha.

eng: murendeni vhengani (26) is a survivor who was rescued by the tvep from her abusive exboyfriend.
tso: murendeni vhengani (26) i muponi loyi a ponisiweke hi tvep eka khale ka jaha ra yena leri a ri n'wi xanisa.

eng: she spent 46 months months at the centre, with her fouryearold daughter.
tso: u hete tin'hweti ta 46 esentha reni ni n'wana wa yena wa nhwanyana wa malembe ya mune hi vukhale.

eng: the centre assisted her to open charges against him and to file a protection order.
tso: senthara leyi yi n’wi pfunile ku pfula swihehlo ehenhla ka khale ka jaha ra yena ni ku nghenisa xileriso xo n’wi sirhelela.

eng: he is still on trial.
tso: wa ha ri ekutengeni.

eng: "they welcomed me with warm hands after many years of suffering.
tso: "va ndzi amukerile hi mavoko lama kufumelaka endzhaku ka malembe yotala ndzi ri karhi ndzi xaniseka.

eng: i felt safe.
tso: ndzi titwe ndzi hlayisekile.

eng: i have regained my confidence," she says.
tso: ndzi tlhele ndzi va na ku titshemba," a vula.

eng: the gbvf fund chairperson, dr judy dlamini, says funding for 108 organisations whose applications have been successful are being processed.
tso: mutshamaxitulu wa nkwama wa gbvf, dkd judy dlamini, u vule leswa ku ku nyikiwa ka mali eka 108 wa mihlangano leyi swikombelo swa yona swi humeleleke swi le ku endliweni.

eng: information regarding the next round of applications will soon be available on the gbvf fund website: https://gbvf.
tso: mahungu mayelana na nkarhi lowu landzelaka wo endla swikombelo ma ta kumeka ku nga ri khale eka webusayiti ya nkwama wa gbvf eka: https: //gbvf.

eng: nsfas 2023 applications open vukuzenzele unnamed the national stu dent financial aid scheme (nsfas) 2023 application cycle has opened.
tso: swikombelo swa nsfas swa 2023 swi pfurile vukuzenzele unnamed nkarhi wo endla swi kombelo swa xikimi xa mpfuneto wa timali xa rixaka (nsfas) wa 2023 wu pfurile.

eng: higher education, science and innovation minister dr blade nzimande made the announcement recently during a media briefing.
tso: holobye wa dyondzo ya le henhla, sayense na vutumbuluxi, dkd blade nzimande, u endlile xitiviso lexi sweswinyana hi nkarhi wa mbulavurisano wa vuhangalasi bya mahungu.

eng: minister nzimande says the scheme resolved to open the application cycle early, as opposed to the previous year, in order to give prospective applicants enough time to submit their applications and supporting documents.
tso: holobye nzimande u vula leswaku xikimi lexi xi teke xiboho xo pfula nkarhi wo endla swikombelo ka ha ri na nkarhi, ku hambana na lembe leri nga hundza, leswaku ku ta nyikiwa lava nga ta endla swikombelo nkarhi lowu ringaneke wo yisa swikombelo swa vona na matsalwa yo seketela.

eng: giving an update report on nsfas funding for the 2022 academic year, minister nzimande says a budget of r43 billion was allocated to the scheme towards the beneficiaries’ tuition fees, including food and travelling allowance, and study material.
tso: loko a nyika xiviko xa mpfuxeto xa nkwama wa nsfas eka lembe ra dyondzo ra 2022, holobye nzimande u vula leswaku mpimanyeto wa r43 wa tibiliyoni wu nyikiwile eka xikimi lexi ku ya eka tihakelo ta tidyondzo ta vavu yeriwa, ku katsa na swakudya na mali yo famba, na switirhisiwa swo dyondza.

eng: he says 985 672 applications were received with 140 636 application unsuccessful.
tso: u vula leswaku 985 672 wa swikombelo swi amukeriwile laha 140 636 wa swikombelo swi nga humelelangiki.

eng: of the applications received, 739 526 applications were provisionally approved for funding pending registration from respective institutions.
tso: eka swikombelo leswi amukeriweke, 739 526 wa swikombelo swi pasisiwile swa xinkarhana ku kuma mali loko ka ha yimeriwe ku tsarisiwa eka swivandla swa dyondzo leswi faneleke.

eng: "[the] majority of unsuccessful applicants failed to provide sufficient evidence to support their applications for funding; exceeded the financial eligibility threshold; already achieved the highest level of qualification that nsfas funds and being noncompliant to the academic pathways of the tvet college sector," minister nzimande explains.
tso: "[vunyingi bya] vaendli va swikombelo lava nga humelelangiki va tsandzekile ku nyika vumbhoni lebyi eneleke byo seketela swikombelo swa vona swa mali; ku tlula mpimo lowu vekiweke wa lava faneleke ku seketeriwa hi timali; se va fikelerile xiyimo xa le henhla xa vuthwaseri lebyi nsfas yi byi seketelaka hi timali na ku va va nga landzeleli tindlela ta dyondzo ta sekithara ya kholichi ya tvet," ku hlamusela holobye nzimande.

eng: according to information on the nsfas website, as of the 2021 academic year, nsfas no longer provides funding for postgraduate courses.
tso: hi ku ya hi mahungu lama nga eka webusayiti ya nsfas, ku sukela eka lembe ra dyondzo ra 2021, nsfas a ya ha nyiki mali ya tikhoso ta le ndzhaku ka tidyondzo ta le henhla.

eng: this includes postgraduate certificates, postgraduate diplomas, honours degrees, masters and phd degrees.
tso: leswi swi katsa switifikheti swa le ndzhaku ka tidyondzo ta le henhla, tidiploma ta le ndzhaku ka tidyondzo ta le henhla, tidigiri ta tionasi, tidigiri ta timasitasi na ta phd.

eng: this means the highest qualification that the scheme funds is a bachelor’s degree.
tso: leswi swi vula leswaku xiyimo xa le henhla xa vuthwaseri lexi xikimi xi xi seketelaka hi timali i digiri ya bachula.

eng: improving the application systemin a bid to improve its appli cation system and process to simplify it for prospective applicants, minister nzimande says this year, nsfas has implemented a number of enhancements to the system to ensure a seamless application experience.
tso: ku antswisa sisiteme ya swikombelohi ku ringeta ku antswisa sisi teme ya yona ya swikombelo na maendlelo ku olovisela lava nga ta endla swikombelo, holobye nzimande u vula leswaku lembe leri, nsfas yi tirhisile ku antswisiwa ko hlaya eka sisiteme ku tiyisisa maendlelo ya swikombelo lama nga riki na swiphiqo.

eng: he says the nsfas online application portal was redesigned to be more user friendly and closer to other platforms that prospective applicants are accustomed to such as whatsapp, twitter, facebook and instagram.
tso: u vula leswaku phothali ya nsfa ya swikombelo swa le ka inthanete yi endliwile hi vuntshwa leswaku yi va leyi tirhisiwaka hi ku olova no va ekusuhi na tipulatifomo tin’wana leti lava nga ta endla swikombelo va ti toloveleke ku fana na whatsapp, twitter, facebook na instagram.

eng: "the application process itself has been simplified and the questions asked are easier to understand by the public.
tso: "endlelo ra xikombelo haroxe ri olovisiwile naswona swivutiso leswi vutisiweke swa olova ku twisisiwa hi vaaki.

eng: additionally, applicants can pause the process and continue at a later stage without restarting from scratch, something that was not possible in previous cycles, he says.
tso: ku engetela kwalaho, vaendli va swikombelo va nga yimisa endlelo ivi va ya emahlweni endzhaku ka nkarhi handle ko sungula ehansi, ku nga nchumu lowu a wu nga koteki eka swiyenge leswi hundzeke, a vula tano.

eng: "over and above the enhancements, nsfas developed additional channels of application to cater for applicants from diverse backgrounds, also keeping in mind that most of the prospective applicants are young people who embrace the digital way of doing things," minister nzimande adds.
tso: "ehenhla ka ku antswisiwa, nsfas yi tumbuluxile tindlela to engetela to endla swiko mbelo ku khathalela vaendli va swikombelo kusuka eka swiyimo swo hambanahambana, yi tlhela yi tekela enhlokweni leswaku vunyingi bya lava nga ta endla swikombelo i va ntshwa lava amukelaka ndlela ya dijitali yo endla swilo," ku engetela holobye nzimande.

eng: the new channels include a mobile app, ussd and whatsapp where one can apply for nsfas funding, track application status and cancel applications, amongst other things.
tso: tichanele letintshwa ti katsa app ya le ka selulafoni, ussd na whatsapp laha munhu a nga endlaka xikombelo xa mali ya nsfas, ku landzelela xiyimo xa xikombelo na ku khansela swikombelo exikarhi ka swin'wana.

eng: this was previously done via the web portal.
tso: leswi khale a swi endliwa hi ku tirhisa photali ya webu.

eng: furthermore, to ensure that no applicant is left behind, minister nzimande says nsfas will embark on an outreach campaign to ensure that individuals who do not have access to technological devices that enable them to apply online are given the necessary resources and support to apply.
tso: ku ya emahlweni, ku tiyisisa leswaku ku hava mukomberi loyi a nga sala endzhaku, holobye nzimande u vula leswaku nsfas yi ta sungula pfhumba ro fikelela ku tiyisisa leswaku vanhu lava nga kotiki ku fikelela switirhisiwa swa thekinoloji leswi endlaka leswaku va kota ku endla swikombelo eka inthanete va nyikiwa switirhisiwa leswi lavekaka na nseketelo ku va va endla swikombelo.

eng: how to access nsfas bursaryyou qualify for a nsfas bursary if you are a south african citizen who plans to study in 2023 or you are already studying at a public university or tvet college and you meet the following requirements: you are a sassa grant recipient.
tso: ndlela yo fikelela basari ya nsfas wa fikelela ku kuma basari ya nsfas loko u ri muakatiko wa afrikadzonga loyi a kunguhataka ku dyondza hi 2023 kumbe se u dyondza eyunivhesiti ya mfumo kumbe kholichi ya tvet naswona u fikelela swilaveko leswi landzelaka: u muamukeri wa mali ya mpfuneto wa sassa kumbe muholo wa ndyangu wa wena lowu hlanganeke a wu hundzi r350 000 hi lembe.

eng: your combined household income is not more than r350 000 per year.
tso: loko u ri munhu loyi a nga mutsoniwa, muholo wa ndyangu wa wena lowu hlanganeke a wu fanelanga ku tlula r600 000 hi lembe.

eng: a million work and livelihood opportunities, and counting vukuzenzele unnamed less than two years ago, we launched the presidential employment stimulus to create jobs and support livelihoods as part of supporting the economic recovery from the covid19 pandemic.
tso: miliyoni ya mikateko ya mitirho na tindlela to tihanyisa, na ku hlayela vukuzenzele unnamed ehansi ka malembe mambirhi lama nga hundza, hi simeke nhlohlotelo wa mitirho wa presidente ku tumbuluxa mitirho ni ku seketela tindlela to tihanyisa tanihi xiphemu xo seketela mpfuxelelo wa ikhonomi hi vuntshwa kusuka eka ntungu wa covid19.

eng: the presidential employment stimulus has just reached the milestone of one million participants since its inception.
tso: nhlohlotelo wa mitirho wa presidente wa ha ku fikelela xiyimo xa nkoka xa miliyoni yin’we ya vatekaxiave kusukela loko wu sunguriwile.

eng: this achievement is the result of a collaborative effort across government and the wider society, including the private sector, communitybased organisations and many others.
tso: ku humelela loku i mbuyelo wa matshalatshala ya ntirhisano eka mfumo hinkwawo na vaaki hi ku angarhela, ku katsa na swiyenge swo ka ri nga ri swa mfumo, mihlangano leyi simekiweke eka vaaki na swin’wana swotala.

eng: the programme is contributing to employment creation while the economy takes time to recover and create jobs at the scale we need.
tso: nongonoko wu hoxa xandla eka ku tumbuluxiwa ka mitirho loko ikhonomi yi teka nkarhi ku vuyelela no tumbuluxa mitirho hi mpimo lowu hi wu lavaka.

eng: as we pursue economic growth to deliver decent and sustainable employment at a much larger scale, we will continue to build on the success of the presidential employment stimulus and expand its reach.
tso: loko hi ri karhi hi landzelela ku kula ka ikhonomi ku tisa mitirho leyi xiximekaka no va kona nkarhi wo leha hi mpimo lowukulu swinene, hi ta ya emahlweni hi aka eka ku humelela ka nhlohlotelo wa mitirho wa presidente na ku ndlandlamuxa ku fikelela ka wona.

eng: it is still very much needed to complement recovery of the job market.
tso: wa ha laveka swinene ku tatisela ku pfuxetiwa ka makete wa mitirho.

eng: it also supports economic recovery in important ways.
tso: wu tlhela wu seketela ku pfuxetiwa ka ikhonomi hi tindlela ta nkoka.

eng: in a context where a lack of work experience is a major barrier to finding work, these programmes are providing highquality work experiences.
tso: eka xiyimo lexi ku pfumaleka ka ntokoto wa ntirho ku nga xirhalanganyi lexikulu xo kuma ntirho, minongonoko leyi yi nyika ntokoto wa ntirho wa xiyimo xa le henhla.

eng: in the largest programme supported by the stimulus, for example, nearly 600 000 young people have been placed as school assistants in over 22 000 schools in every corner of the country.
tso: eka nongonoko lowukulu swinene lowu seketeriwaka hi xihlohloteri, xikombiso, kwalomu ka 600 000 wa vantshwa va vekiwile tanihi vapfuni va le swikolweni eka swikolo swo tlula 22 000 ekhonweni yin’wana ni yin’wana ya tiko.

eng: school management, teachers and other stakeholders all agree that the contribution of the school assistants has improved the learning environment in schools.
tso: vufambisi bya swikolo, vadyondzisi na vatekaxiave van’wana hinkwavo va pfumela leswaku ku hoxa xandla ka vapfuni va le swikolweni ku antswisile ndhawu yo dyondza eswikolweni.

eng: many selfemployed people found their livelihoods disrupted by the pandemic.
tso: vanhu votala lava titirhelaka va kume tindlela ta vona to tihanyisa ti kavanyetiwile hi ntungu.

eng: the creative sector was particularly badly affected.
tso: xiyenge xa vutumbuluxi xi khumbekile ngopfu.

eng: in this sector, support was provided to people to create jobs for themselves and others.
tso: eka xiyenge lexi, nseketelo wu nyikiwile vanhu ku tumbuluxa mitirho ya vona na ya vanhu van’wana.

eng: the movies, music and plays produced are now able to generate further income from the sale of rights, tickets and royalties.
tso: tifilimi, vuyimbeleri na mitlangu leyi humesiweke sweswi ya swi kota ku endla mali yin’wana kusuka eka ku xavisiwa ka timfanelo, mathikithi na mali ya tihakelo ta vutshila.

eng: all of this has been contributing to the growth of the sector.
tso: hi nkwaswo leswi swi vile leswi hoxaka xandla eka ku kula ka sekithara.

eng: the presidential employment stimulus has also supported sustainable livelihoods.
tso: nhlohlotelo wa mitirho wa presidente wu tlhele wu seketela tindlela to tihanyisa leti tiyiselaka nkarhi wo leha.

eng: over 140 000 subsistence farmers have received production input vouchers to assist them to resume and expand production after the disruptions of covid19.
tso: ku tlula 140 000 van’wamapurasi lavatsongo va amukele tivhochara ta switirhisiwa swa vuhumelerisi ku va pfuna ku tlhela va sungula ni ku ndla ndlamuxa swikumiwa endzhaku ka nkavenyeto wa covid19.

eng: one such beneficiary is 36yearold phindile ngcoya from richmond in kwazulunatal.
tso: un’wana wa vavuyeriwa votano i phindile ngcoya wa malembe ya 36 wa le richmond ekwazulunatal.

eng: she is one of ten members of a family farming cooperative and says the voucher she received helped the new cooperative survive and become profitable.
tso: hi un’wana wa swirho swa khume swa ndyangu wa bindzu ra vurimi naswona u vula leswaku vhochara leyi a yi amukeleke yi pfune bindzu lerintshwa ku pona ni ku vuyeriwa.

eng: the presidential employment stimulus is also supporting graduates, with opportunities provided to nurses, science graduates, artisans and others.
tso: nhlohlotelo wa mitirho wa presidente wu tlhela wu seketela mathwasana, hi ku nyika mikateko eka vuongori, ma thwasana ya sayense, vatirhi va mavoko na yin’wana.

eng: twenty six universities are helping to place unemployed graduates in work relevant to their qualifications.
tso: makumembirhitse vu wa tiyunivhesiti ti le ku pfuneni ku thola mathwasana lama nga riki na mitirho eka mitirho leyi fambelanaka na vuthwaseri bya vona.

eng: the department of science and innovation has introduced a range of innovative citizen science programmes, such as the duzi umngeni conservation trust, which employs local youth as envirochamps to empower communities to rehabilitate local water sources.
tso: ndzawulo ya sayense na vutumbuluxi yi tivise minongonoko yo hambana ya sayense ya vaaki leyi nga na vutumbuluxi, tanihi duzi umngeni conservation trust, leyi tholaka vantshwa va le mugangeni tanihi envirochamps ku nyika vaakindhawu matimba yo pfuxeta swihlovo swa mati swa le mugangeni.

eng: another programme by the department helps entrepreneurs to develop business proposals in the green economy.
tso: nongonoko wun’wana wa ndzawulo wu pfuna van’wamabindzu ku tumbuluxa swiringanyeto swa mabindzu eka ikhonomi ya rihlaza.

eng: public employment programmes also have a direct positive impact on communities because they create work for the common good.
tso: minongonoko ya mitirho ya mfumo yi tlhela yi va na nkucetelo lowunene wo kongoma eka vaakindhawu hikuva yi tumbuluxa ntirho wo pfuna hinkwavo.

eng: in the case of the presidential employment stimulus, this includes improving learning in schools, upgrading informal settlements, supporting survivors of genderbased violence, environmental conservation and innovating in wasterecycling.
tso: eka mhaka ya nhlohlotelo wa mitirho wa presidente, leswi swi katsa ku antswisa dyondzo eswiko lweni, ku antswisa vutshamo lebyi nga riki enawini, ku seketela lava poneke madzo longa lama simekiweke eka rimbewu, nhlayiso wa mbango na vutumbuluxi byo vuyelerisa malakatsa.

eng: the presidential employment stimulus was launched in response to the unemployment crisis that was deepened by the covid19 pandemic.
tso: nhlohlotelo wa mitirho wa presidente wu sunguriwile ku hlamula eka xiphiqo xa ku pfumaleka ka mitirho lexi nga nyanyisiwa hi ntungu wa covid19.

eng: although the pandemic may have abated, unemployment has not.
tso: hambileswi ntungu wu nga vaka wu hungutekile, ku pfumaleka ka mitirho a ku hungutekanga.

eng: the incomes earned in presidential employment stimulus programmes have been an economic boost to small enterprises and informal businesses in local economies across the country.
tso: miholo leyi kumiweke eka minongonoko ya nhlohlotelo wa mitirho wa presidente yi vile ku tlakusa ikhonomi eka mabindzu lamatsongo na mabindzu lama nga riki ya ximfumo eka tiikhonomi ta le migangeni etikweni hinkwaro.

eng: school assistants employed in umgungundlovu are spending their wages in umgungundlovu.
tso: vapfuni va le swikolweni lava thoriweke eumgungundlovu va tirhisa miholo ya vona eumgungundlovu.

eng: the same in putsonderwater.
tso: swi tano ni le putsonderwater.

eng: instead of the ‘trickle down’ effect, money is being put directly into the hands of communities that need it most.
tso: ematshan’wini ya mbuyelo wo ‘khulukela ehansi’, mali yi vekiwa hi ku kongoma emavokweni ya vaakindhawu lava yi lavaka ngopfu.

eng: that money then circulates locally and ‘trickles up’ into the wider economy.
tso: mali yoleyo yi tlhela yi fambafamba laha mugangeni naswona yi ‘khulukela ehenhla’ eka ikhonomi hi ku angarhela.

eng: that is why we call it a stimulus, because the entire economy benefits along with society.
tso: hikwalaho hi yi vitanaka xihlohloteri, hikuva ikhonomi hinkwayo ya vuyeriwa kun’we na vaaki.

eng: through the presidential employment stimulus, we have unlocked energy, commitment, creativity, innovation and opportunities.
tso: hi ku tirhisa nhlohlotelo wa mitirho wa presidente, hi pfule matimba, ku tinyiketela, vutumbuluxi, vusunguri na mikateko.

eng: in the process, we are building a society that works.
tso: eka endlelo leri, hi le ku akeni ka rixaka leri tirhaka.

eng: over one million people have benefited directly.
tso: vanhu vo tlula miliyoni va vuyeriwile hi ku kongoma.

eng: many more people, in the families and communities of participants, have felt the impact of the stimulus.
tso: vanhu vo tala swinene, emi ndyangwini na miganga ya vatekaxiave, va twe nkucetelo wa xihlohloteri.

eng: our task now is to expand and deepen the impact of this work.
tso: ntirho wa hina sweswi i ku ndlandlamuxa no dzikisa mbuyelo wa ntirho lowu.

eng: as a result of the presidential employment stimulus, we now have hundreds of thousands of people with valuable work experience.
tso: hikwalaho ka nhlohlotelo wa mitirho wa presidente, sweswi hi na madzana ya magidi ya vanhu lava nga na ntokoto wa ntirho wa nkoka.

eng: most of these people are easy to find through the sayouth.
tso: vunyingi bya vanhu lava swa olova ku va kuma hi ku tirhisa pulatifomo ya sayouth.

eng: early childhood development holds the key to our future vukuzenzele unnamed there are few pre sidential activities more fulfilling than spending a morning in the company of small children.
tso: nhluvukiso wa tindzumulo eka masungulo swi khome xikhiya xa vumundzuku bya hina vukuzenzele unnamed leyi i yin’wana ya migingiriko ya phuresidente yo enerisa ku tlula ku heta mixo wun’we u ri ni vana lavatsongo.

eng: i recently attended the opening of the little flower early childhood development (ecd) centre in bizana in the eastern cape, where i got to spend time with some of the future leaders of our country, reading to them and listening to them.
tso: sweswinyana ndzi yile eka ku pfuriwa ka senthara ya nhluvukiso wa tindzumulo eka masungu lo (ecd) ya little flower ebizana ekapavuxa, laha ndzi nga kota ku tirhisa nkarhi na van’wana va va rhangeri va mundzuku va tiko ra hina, ndzi karhi ndzi va hlayela no va yingisela.

eng: the centre was recently built by the development organisation impande south africa through the support of the nelson mandela foundation.
tso: senthara yi akiwile swe swinyana hi nhlangano wa nhluvukiso wa impande south africa hi ku seketeriwa hi nelson mandela foundation.

eng: i was deeply touched by the dedication of the centre’s staff to supporting the community and its children.
tso: a ndzi khumbekile swinene hi ku tinyiketela ka vatirhi va senthara ku seketela miganga na vana va wona.

eng: they told me how in the centre’s earliest days, staff struggled to get paid and yet still came to work.
tso: va ndzi byerile leswi a swi ri xiswona eka senthara masiku yo sungu la, vatirhi a va tikeriwa ku kuma ku hakeriwa kambe va ala va ta entirhweni.

eng: they also told me that even if families are not able to pay the r20 fee for their child, the children are not turned away.
tso: va tlhela va ndzi byela leswaku hambi mindyangu yi tsandzeka ku hakela r20 ya xikolofisi xa vana va vona, vana a va tlheriseriwi endzhaku.

eng: the commitment of the ecd centre staff is so important because early childhood development centres play a pivotal role in our nation’s development.
tso: ku tinyiketela ka vatirhi va senthara ya ecd swi na nkoka hikuva tisenthara ta nhluvukiso wa tindzumulo eka masungulo ti tlanga xiave xikulu eka nhluvukiso wa hina wa tiko.

eng: these centres can be found in every village, town and city in the country.
tso: tisenthara leti ta kumeka emugangeni wun’wana na wun’wana, xidorobana na doroba etikweni.

eng: most were started by women in the community to support parents who need their children to be cared for when they are at work.
tso: to tala ti sunguriwile hi vavasati emigangeni ku seketela vatswari lava lavaka vana va vona va hlayiseka loko va ri emitirhiweni.

eng: many of these centres began as creches and daycare facilities.
tso: to tala ta tisenthara leti ti sungu rile ku ri tikhirexe na tind hawu ta vuhlayiselo.

eng: many have subsequently grown and expanded to incorporate a basic learning curriculum into their services.
tso: to tala ti kurile swinene no ndlandlamuka ku tirhisa kharikhulamu yo dyondzi sa eka vukorhokeri bya tona.

eng: as government, we have taken up the task to improve the standards of care and make resources available for ecd centres to run suitable activities for young children to prepare them for formal education.
tso: tanihi mfumo, hi endli le ntirho wo antswisa swiyimo swo vuhlayisi no endla leswaku switi rhisiwa swi kumeka eka tisenthara ta ecd ku endla migingiriko yo ringanela ya vana lavatsongo ku va lulamisela dyondzo ya ximfumo.

eng: in april 2022, we completed the move of the ecd function from the department of social development to the department of basic education.
tso: hi dzivamusoko, 2022, hi hetisisile ku susa mafambiselo ya ecd ku suka eka ndzawulo ya nhluvukiso wa vaaki ku ya eka ndzawulo ya dyondzo ya le hansi.

eng: this is to link early childhood development to the formal school curriculum and to provide training, education and development to staff in ecd centres around the country.
tso: leswi swi hlanganisa nhluvukiso wa tindzumulo eka masungu lo na kharikhulamu ya ximfumo ya dyondzo no nyika vuleteri, dyondzo na nhluvukiso wa vatirhi eka tisenthara ta ecd tiko hinkwaro.

eng: because this foundational learning is key to a child’s success in later years, the basic education laws amendment bill that is currently before parliament proposes that it be compulsory for all children to receive two years of ecd before they enter grade 1. it is at this stage that children should be taught, learn through play and receive at least one meal a day.
tso: hikuva dyondzo leyi ya masungulo i xilotlelo xa ku humelela ka n’wana emalembeni ya le ndzhaku, nawubisi wa ndzulamiso wa milawu ya dyondzo ya masungulo lowu nga emavokweni ya palamende wu ringanyeta leswaku swi va swi boha leswaku n’wana un’wana na un’wana a kuma malembe yambirhi ya ecd a nga se ya eka giredi 1. swi le ka xiyimo lexi leswaku vana va fanele ku dyondza, ku dyondzisiwa hi ku tlanga no kuma swakudya kan’we hi siku.

eng: early childhood development centres don’t just prepare our country’s youngest citizens to succeed in school; they are also an important source of entrepreneurship and job creation.
tso: tisenthara ta nhluvukiso wa tindzumulo eka masu ngulo a ti lulamiseli vana va tiko ra hina ntsena leswaku va humelela exikolweni; ti tlhela tiva switirhisiwa swa nkoka eka swa vubindzu no endla mitirho.

eng: these centres are an important part of the care economy.
tso: tisenthara leti ti na xiave xa nkoka xo hla yisa ikhonomi.

eng: they sustain livelihoods, especially for women, which contributes to job creation in many communities.
tso: ti hlayisa mahanyelo, ngopfungopfu ya vavasati, leyi engetelaka ku tumbuluxa mitirho emigangeni yotala.

eng: when the covid19 pandemic struck, ecd centres were hard hit.
tso: loko ntungu wa covid19 wu hlasela, tisenthara ta ecd a tihlaseriwile swinene.

eng: facilities that rely on school fees to keep running were unable to pay their staff and many parents who lost their jobs were unable to keep their children enrolled.
tso: tindhawu leti tshembelaka eka xikolofisi ku ti tirha a ti nga swikoti ku hakela vatirhi va tona naswona vatswari votala lava lahlekeriweke hi mitirho a va nga swikoti ku endla leswaku vana va vona va dyondza.

eng: in response, government established the ecd employment stimulus relief fund to help ecd centres that had lost income as a result of the pandemic and to enable them to recover.
tso: hi ku hlamula, mfumo wu tumbuluxile nkwama wa mpfuneto wa nhlohlotelo wa ntirho wa ecd ku pfuna tisenthara ta ecd lava nga lahlekeriwa hi ku nghenisa mali hikwa laho ka ntungu no endla leswaku tivuyela evu tshan’wini.

eng: preparing our youngest citizens with the tools they need to succeed in life is a responsibility we must collectively shoulder.
tso: ku lulamisela vaakatiko va hina lavatsongo hi switirhisiwa leswi va swi lavaka ku humelela evuton’wini i vutihlamuleri lebyi hi faneleke ku khomisana hinkwerhu.

eng: we must continue to do all we can, as government, the private sector and development organisations, to support early childhood development.
